text: TLOU is in the top five of my favourite video games of all time, and has a special place in my heart. It's no wonder then that the narrative is particularly important to my experience when expecting the same plot twists and dramatic tones. There's something wrong about the way the story is told, to be more precise its experimental structure that failed miserably. I also didn't appreciate the melodramatic way of conveying a simple message ad nauseum just so that the ending feels redundant and sprinkled with hipocrisy. Also weighing it down is a level design that has moments where it seems bloated, and puzzles that border on mediocrity at times. The only reason I can give it this grade is because the gameplay still manages to be brutally entertaining, and there have certainly been some improvements compared to the first instalment.

text:
I think in terms of the game itself, this is a 10/10. The graphics, gameplay mechanics and general feel is unbelievably good. For me personally, where this game falls short is the story, pushing real world political agenda's into games has always been one of my pet peeves, swapping out a hero because of their gender or sexual orientation, then pushing agenda's throughout the story, I got a bit sick of it after a while. By the end of the game, I felt like I just sat through a feminist seminar that I involuntarily attended. I don't have a problem with anyone's race, gender or sexual orientation, but I am a strong believer, in using that where it suits the story, such as Cyberpunk 2077, which done it perfectly, this game however, did not, it felt like bringing in a bunch of feminist views into a zombie world, something I cared little for. I will however note, the game itself is fantastic, and I am a huge Naughty Dog fan of everything they do, this game however, is just not for me.

TLDR:

Game itself: 10/10
Political agenda's hidden within: 1/10

text:
I give it 2 instead of 1 (or 0) because I liked the game mechanics,  the graphics, most parts of the world created and I appreciate the effort the developers clearly put into the game.
I loved the first game, it's probably my favorite game of all times, inversely the second game is the biggest disappointment a game ever caused me. I could write a lot of specific things about the story and about general concepts they have, but it doesn't worth my time. 
The story is terrible, it's loaded with far left liberal bs. There are lesbians (fine by me, but in this kind of world definitely not advantageous for a family), a trans (how exactly?! much more disadvantageous), woman with the physics of Dwayne The Rock Johnson (again how tf?!, not like you have a lot of steroids to spare in a zombie apocalypse), mindless **** old guy (because that's what those are, who does not support lesbians in an apocalypse right? :) ), stupid religious cult, that does not support trans people (like those religious people irl right? :) ).
The game disrespects the player several times, but I don't want to get into spoilers. There is an interesting theme all along about revenge, grief and forgiveness, but the game conveys these themes with a confusing, sometimes chaotic story that jumps all around space and time with strongly varying quality and detail.
If you loved the first game I strongly suggest you give this game a pass.
All that said, because of my love of the first game and the interesting world they created I would give a shot to a third Last of Us game.

keywords: story, last, also, character, gameplay, feel, instead, present, hype, find
text:
The gameplay, setting, progression and soundtrack are the most impressive you'll find in a game, but it's not worth the absurd script failure.

There is nothing anyone can say that makes sense of Joel's decision to tell his real name to a stranger -- after more than 20 years of experience in a cruel world, full of terrible people, having killed so many whose acquaintances would love to see him dead.

Just as there is no sense in Ellie's decision to have killed so many, abandon her family to obtain the revenge that absolutely everyone wanted and, in the end, save the person she was supposed to kill and who caused so much disgrace to everyone she loved.

All of these flaws are only justified if you, as a writer, wanted the story to be about an empowered woman replacing the cis straight white man, but anyone who has played both games knows that in no alternate universe would that woman beat Joel.

This game was a mistake. An error that showed how a bad script can ruin a game whose other aspects are exceptional.

text: Title: A Disastrous Sequel That Ruins the Legacy - The Last of Us Part IIRating: ★☆☆☆☆Where do I even begin with The Last of Us Part II? It's a colossal disappointment that fails to live up to the high standards set by its predecessor. This sequel is a perfect example of how not to continue a beloved franchise.First and foremost, the story is an absolute trainwreck. It's convoluted, poorly paced, and filled with unnecessary twists and turns that only serve to confuse and frustrate players. The narrative decisions made by the developers seem like they were chosen purely for shock value rather than for the sake of meaningful storytelling. The characters we grew to love in the first game are mishandled and their arcs are completely undermined, leaving players feeling detached and uninvested.Speaking of characters, the new additions to the cast are equally disappointing. Ellie, the strong and relatable protagonist from the original game, is reduced to a one-dimensional revenge-driven character with questionable decision-making skills. The game tries to force players into empathizing with her, but it's hard to sympathize when her actions become increasingly irrational and out of **** gameplay, while solid in the first game, feels clunky and uninspired here. The stealth mechanics are frustratingly inconsistent, often leading to cheap deaths and repetitive encounters. The level design lacks creativity and fails to offer any real sense of exploration. It's a far cry from the immersive and engaging gameplay experience we had in the first **** aspect that cannot be ignored is the game's heavy-handed political agenda. The Last of Us Part II seems more interested in pushing a specific message than in delivering an enjoyable gaming experience. The themes of revenge, violence, and LGBTQ+ representation are forced upon the players, overshadowing any potential for genuine emotional **** top of all these flaws, the technical issues are abundant. The game suffers from frequent frame rate drops, long loading times, and numerous glitches that break immersion and hinder gameplay. It's astonishing that a game of this magnitude could be released with such glaring technical **** conclusion, The Last of Us Part II is a soulless cash grab that tarnishes the legacy of its predecessor. It fails to capture the essence of what made the original game so special and instead delivers a mess of a story, uninspired gameplay, and technical problems. Fans of the first game will be left feeling betrayed, and newcomers will be left wondering what all the hype was about. Save your time and money—this sequel is a disgrace.

text: My issues with the Last of Us Part 2 is how the narrative is not good whatsoever. The gameplay is fine, and somewhat better than the first game (which is what is saving it from a grade lower than a 4), but the issues stem with the characterization and story, the strongest points of the previous game. When a game/series with an excellent story has a weak outing in a sequel, it will stand out. Abby's motivations are understandable, but the way it was tied to the first game just feels so hamfisted, and requires too many mental gymnastics to make it work.  It doesn't help that Abby is very impulsive of a character, reckless, and has no issues endangering her friends to get what she wants. Ellie, who's spent her whole life in this apocalypse, makes tons of illogical decisions that don't make sense with someone who has lived through it. She also has some of the same issues as Abby in this game. Joel's death wasn't what it should have been. He should have went out in a blaze of glory, or protecting Ellie, but instead he went out like a punk.  Now, while the characterizations were terrible, the actual protrayals are well performed, and I don't condone those who sent threatening messages to the actors. Sometimes, you need to learn to separate the art from the artist. I don't hate the actors who played these characters, I'm just not a fan of the character they portrayed. I can't recommend this game even at a discount, simply for how hard the narrative drops the ball compared to the first game.

text:
The Last of Us Part II: A Melancholic Muddle - 0/10

The realm of narrative-driven video games is replete with tales of grandeur, and "The Last of Us" stood as a shining example of such magnificence. Thus, it's with a heavy heart that one must navigate the murky waters of its sequel, "The Last of Us Part II."

From the outset, the game's tone feels disjointed. Where the original painted a poignant picture of humanity's struggle and the lengths one might go to protect loved ones, Part II meanders, oscillating between half-realized themes and tonal inconsistencies. The gravity of Ellie's journey, so deeply personal in its intent, is often lost amidst the cacophony of secondary narratives that add little to the overarching tale.

Visually, while the world of "The Last of Us Part II" boasts intricate details, there's a palpable absence of soul. Environments, though technically marvelous, lack the atmospheric tension that once made every corner turned a potential threat. This sterility permeates even the character models, rendering emotional sequences somewhat hollow.

The game's narrative decisions remain its most contentious aspect. Characters, once beloved, are offered up on the altar of shock value, their arcs concluding in ways that feel unearned and, at times, gratuitous. This penchant for subversion, rather than adding layers, often detracts from the emotional heft of the storyline.

Gameplay, a potential saving grace, also falters. Combat scenarios, though more varied, often descend into repetition, lacking the strategic depth of the original. Stealth, a staple of the series, feels more forced than ever, with AI patterns that seem predictable rather than intuitive.

In sum, "The Last of Us Part II" stands as a shadow of its predecessor. Despite its technical prowess and moments of genuine emotional depth, the game feels like a disjointed tapestry of missed opportunities. One can't help but yearn for the nuanced storytelling and immersive world-building of the original.

text:
The gameplay and environment are good, but overall tainted by the terrible narrative and overall theme of the game. Naughty Dog tries to warn and discourage players about the consequences of pursuing revenge, yet they force us to play as a character right after said character kills one of our beloved protagonist from the series! How exactly does this discourage us from seeking revenge when it only makes us sympathetic to their horrible actions.

Both Abby and Ellie do not mature or get character development and they essentially remain the same towards end of the game. Player's spend hours seeing their character get revenge by killing key characters and innocent NPC's only to spare the main target at the very last second? It felt like we wasted our time and we were left with dread and disappointment. It doesn't make sense for the main character to just walk away from their objective at the last second despite the fact said character gave up the pursuit sometime earlier in the story.

There are some characters in the game that do not supplement character development or show qualities that make us feel sympathetic towards them. Take for instance Jesse and Manny who are only there to provide some drama to the narrative without providing memorable personal traits.

The flashbacks were also poorly executed. Those flashbacks should have been the first playable parts of the game and then switch over to the main plot. It would have made the game's ending even more impressionable instead of making us feel like all our efforts were basically for nothing. I honestly think Naughty Dog should have created two campaign modes for the game, one focused completely from Ellie's perspective and another on Abby's story. Upon completion of Ellie's story we will have the option to complete Abby's campaign instead of having us switch between these characters.

Overall, I don't think this game is worth $59+ and I am disappointed with it. I think Naughty Dog should remake this game or at least learn their mistakes by the time they release Last of Us III.

text:
The graphics are great, but not the gameplay. There are some issues with the gameplay mechanics and AI. And part of it has to do with the story telling and how the developers are trying to sway your opinion. To avoid spoilers, I’ll have to be cryptic here. You play as more than one character, and there is a significant difference between how easy they are to control (which seems to be another lame attempt to make you like that character more). Trying to play with Ellie makes it seem like she is physically ****. It’s like they turn the difficulty down a couple notches with the other character. They move faster, aim better, have better weapons that do more damage, get more supplies, are not noticed as easily, and craft more supplies with less materials. It’s a whole different game where you don’t care who you’re fighting or how much ammo you have, you’re going to win.
Playing the guitar was a clever way of using the PS4 controller, but after doing it again and again, it’s becomes a distraction. Can we get back to the **** yea, that’s not the strong-point on this one, is it?
Concerning the **** seemed the developers could not figure out whether they wanted a stealth or combat game. The AI follows predetermined patrol paths in every scene, until you do something. Then they obviously gravitate towards you no matter where you are hiding. Say you set a trap and sneak away to a quiet corner. Once the trap is triggered, all remaining enemies start moving towards you. Humans and infected both do this. It became most obvious when a human discovered me while I was hiding behind cover, and they were on top of the building I was in. Then he starting shooting and doing damage...through the roof. Hmm, ok.
If humans and infected are in the same scene, they will only engage in a brief confrontation before they act like the other side is invisible. That part made me curse out loud. You try to lure infected towards human opponents, they engage and then...just stop and wander around each other looking for you.

Story: Disappointing, over and over. The drama about ‘who kissed who?!’ makes it seem like you’re watching Pretty Little Liars. I wouldn’t actually know because I’ve never watched that show. Because I don’t care about who is kissing who.
Overall, this starts as a revenge story and it’s obvious they want to say that revenge is futile. But lord they make you pay for it, and that message got beat to a pulp with the ancient Greeks. You find yourself saying, ‘wait we’re going off to do what? What does that have to do with this story? Is this even the same story, and who heck is that guy?’ After a while, it’s not the same story at all

Concerning the events that happen, the developers try too hard for shock value and to mess with your head in obvious and tacky ways. You’re forced to do things that should have been a choice, and were probably bad ideas to begin with.
Also on that part, the decisions that are made by the characters seem unbelievably immature considering the world where the game takes place, and they’re own statements. The characters make it obvious how they little they care about other characters but then drop everything to go do the impossible for them.
Essentially, the first and second game have almost nothing to do with each other plot-wise. Watching it was painful and I wish I had not seen it.

Skip it. For me, the story of Last of Us ended with Joel and Ellie walking into Jackson after they left the hospital. He lies, she cries, and the guitar plays on. Best happy ending I’ve seen in a long time

It's a great game on some aspects, but when the story does not make sense, when there's so many easy to read manipulative narrative techniques to enforce you to feel things, non-sens events happening to help the plot continuing to live, it's just non-immersive, non interesting. All the story is understood after 2h in the game and when you dive a little into characters perspective, history and minds, you'll figure out they are no longer who they used to be, making senseless choices that are way off from what they used to be from the first game. They even modificate things in TLOU 1 remake for the plot to have more sense in this useless sequel. Even using the word "sequel" is not right, it's more like a bad spin-off, they even used fake commercials to trick the player into buying this game. I regret spending my money, and my time on this ego-trip from the writter, who believe he's the only one creator of TLOU franchise. And we are lucky he's not, because TLOU 1 is a great piece of art. This is just a constant disapointment, easy and lazy storytelling, bad characters development, bad pacing, bad sequences, I mean, how can a flashback into a flashback can be consider a great "storytelling" ?

Great respect to the devs though, that made great graphics, that might be the best on PS4 that I've played. Gameplay got no real new interesting features, just melee combat feels better.
I feel a little diaspointed with the OST as I expected more from Gustavo Santaolalla, who made a better OST in the first one. Thanks to him, the first opus had a real identity, here it feels just okay. Nothing to be rememered.
At the end, everything in this game feels so enforced that it becomes funny.

keywords: release, really, review, go, say, year, see, know, come, make
text:
I loved Last of Us 1, but Last of Us 2 was very interesting to play and not in a positive way. I was seriously enjoying the story about Joel's death and Ellie trying to avenge his death, and Ellie's romance on the side. It could have been one of the best games ever.
Unfortunately, towards the end, I was forced to play as Abby. I really liked Joel as a character, and when Abby killed him, I, of course, developed a serious dislike for Abby. Furthermore, Abby is just a pissed-off, unlikable character in general. Thus, I really didn't want to play as Abby and found myself just letting zombies kill me because I wanted to return to playing as Ellie, and it was more enjoyable to watch her die than to try to help her survive.
I tried to play it out as Abby, hoping it would return to Ellie at any moment, but hours went by, and it still made me play as Abby until eventually I just said, "Screw it. I'm not enjoying this game at all, and I stopped playing altogether. I've played almost every rpg there is, and there is only one other game I have stopped playing halfway through. Thus, Last of Us 2 is one of the only games I rate as a 0 out of 10 since it was so unenjoyable that I didn't even finish it. The lesson here is NEVER FORCE THE PLAYER TO PLAY AS AN UNLIKABLE ANTAGONSIST, PLEASE.
After, being so disappointed with Part 2, I don't recommend either of these games.

text:
I heard it was bad, I saw the ratings, but I never imagined it would be such a disaster.

Without spoiling anything, here are things you should consider before trying this game.

Pros: The graphics are fantastic. That's all.

Now for the rest:
(1) This is not a horror game. If it was a movie, it would be tagged as "drama", then "action" maybe. You are not escaping some evil or hoping to find survive to reach some destination. In this game you are the hunter. If there is any horror, it's you. The whole game is about a quest for revenge. In doing so, you will butcher countless humans. There are still some infected (zombies) here and there, but they are more like random critters, not at all the main focus.

(2) This is the main problem. You play as various characters, but they are all detestable, including Ellie. I've never hated main characters that much before. If it was a movie it would be alright perhaps. But sticking such long hours commanding a character that you hate on a quest that you reject makes enjoying the game impossible. I still watched the story to the end, and believe me, it only gets worse. In the last hour of the game, I was like, are you for real !!!

(3) As others commented, the game has a lot of political messages here and there. As a mature individual I don't care, but the problem is with influenceable kids playing the game. And no matter what the rating is, kids will always play all kind of games. Then it becomes a problem what they are being told.

I believe this game killed the franchise. The only way they could release another game in this series is by moving completely away from this horrible cast.

text:
Review

Rating: ★☆☆☆☆

The Last of Us Part 2 is a prime example **** that prioritizes pushing a supposed "LGBT agenda" over delivering a compelling and enjoyable experience. This sequel is marred by heavy-handed and forced attempts at inclusivity, overshadowing any potential for a well-crafted story and engaging gameplay.

Rather than focusing on the characters and their development, the game seems more interested in hammering its progressive messaging into the player's consciousness. The inclusion of LGBTQ+ characters feels contrived and unnecessary, as their sexual orientation becomes their defining trait rather than an aspect of their identity. The narrative sacrifices depth and coherence to virtue signal, resulting in a disjointed and unsatisfying storyline.

Unfortunately, this obsession with inclusivity negatively impacts the gameplay as well. The forced diversity feels more like tokenism, with the game's agenda taking precedence over meaningful gameplay mechanics. It's clear that the developers prioritized their message over creating a polished and enjoyable gaming experience.

In addition to the narrative shortcomings, the gameplay itself is riddled with flaws. The combat encounters lack innovation and fail to offer any real challenge, while the stealth mechanics feel clunky and unrefined. The pacing is uneven, with stretches of repetitive gameplay that make the experience monotonous and tedious.

Furthermore, technical issues plague the game, with frequent frame rate drops and glitches that disrupt immersion and undermine the overall experience. It's disheartening to see a game of this magnitude released with such significant technical shortcomings.

Ultimately, The Last of Us Part 2's preoccupation with pushing an "LGBT agenda" at the expense of a well-crafted narrative and enjoyable gameplay is a disservice to the potential of the franchise. Instead of embracing diversity in a meaningful way, the game comes across as pandering and lacks the substance that made its predecessor so memorable. It's a missed opportunity and a disappointing addition to the series .

Before I even review the game, just don't get this version, if you have a Playstation just play it on there

The bugs and glitches and problems that this PC port STILL HAS over a year after launch are ridiculous 

For me I'd have textures, mostly grass and water just turn into a black square of nothing, the characters' hair would constantly glitch out into low res polygons, trying to use DLSS for more FPS is basically unusable due to ugly ghosting that is caused by the game not having it properly implemented

The performance of this game sucks too, the fact that Valve really marked it as Steam Deck Verified is a joke, any game that runs out of the box with FSR on should NOT be verfied, it'll cook your steam deck and the shader complication you need to do every time you change the proton is ridiculous, I really only played the game for maybe 17 hours but it says I have 21 because of shader complying time after time after time 

It's really just a bad port, I thought they had fixed it, and its PLAYABLE but it is not $60 good

When it comes to the game itself, it's good, the story and writing and acting are all great, but I felt like ultimately it wasn't for me, the ending made me angry and has me questioning why anyone would play this game and want an addtion to the story, and I don't want to spoil anything so I won't, but just be weary

The gameplay loop I was alright with, it kind of felt like a cheaper version of Resident Evil, the stealth is great with the Clickers but after a while it starts to feel like the game is shoving it down your throat so I started just running head on into enemy situations until I eventually just didn't die because of how sick I was of it 

I have Part II on my PS5, so I'll be playing that next (after the Left Behind DLC on here) and I really hope I enjoy it more, but I just came out of this one feeling like a 7/10 at best, and that's all the bad PC port problems aside

keywords: story, last, also, character, gameplay, feel, instead, present, hype, find
text:
Honestly I have never played a Zombie game that tries its damn hardest to not be a Zombie game.

The writing is fantastic, characters are believable in its settings only enhanced by the voice actors, and the story itself is great.

Visuals are spectacular, and the attention to detail is top notch in the industry. 

The zombie designs and lore are some of the most unique out of all the zombie games I have played.

Really loved the runners, the stalkers and the clickers. 

The bloaters were ok.

But the game play is personally its biggest issue.

Puzzles are there just to pat out the run time.

The gun play is a bit lacking in my opinion, I would have to think hard of a game that doesn't do it better.

Combat at its best is found when the player is sneaking around and killing the enemies one by one. Whether its the humans or the zombies.

Attracting them and killing them off with nail bombs, motolovs or just straight up shanking them is actually fun.

I do wish it had more gore in it.

The most memorable moments are during escaping the city, from first encountering the Humvee all the way to rescuing Ellie from the fire.

The game slows down prior and after that for me. To the point of nearly losing me both times. 

The drama took center stage over the game play, and personally, that is the worst disservice that you can do to a game.

Overall, I would say is a C- for me.

A - Must Play.
B - Fun to play.
C - Decent experience. 
D - Forgettable experience.
F - Skip it.

keywords: story, last, also, character, gameplay, feel, instead, present, hype, find
text:
[h1]TL;DR: The game is functionally fine and the story is good but I'm very picky about HOW exactly video games should tell stories.[/h1]

The Last of Us is well-executed for what it is. Effectively the first of its kind in a generation of gaming rewarding cinematic narratives delivered in prestigious AAA realism, the harsh post-apocalypse puts on the pressure with a linear but immersive and distinctly survivalist experience. But perhaps as a consequence of the hype and awards it received over the last decade, it turns out I am not the audience for the exact way it tries to blend gameplay and story–it feels like oil and water to me.

I love video games as a storytelling canvas, for the unique language they are able to take advantage of. I love Psychonauts, Half-Life, and Undertale for trusting the player to engage with the depth of their worldbuilding when it is baked deeply into the game design itself. You don't really get enough in The Last of Us that utilizes the gameplay language meaningfully for narrative effectiveness like those games do. The game’s story IS good, that much is fact. Rarely, however, can TLoU deliver any piece of it in a way only a video game can.

Outcomes are all predetermined by TLoU’s set path, dampening its themes about the cycle of violence (a topic Undertale’s player freedom engages with more intimately since you can affect the narrative by choosing murder or mercy for yourself.) Extraneous worldbuilding is typically found only in written notes, a far cry from Psychonauts demonstrating who its side characters are with the intramental level designs that represent them, right down to even the collectibles therein. Ellie is typically invincible, taking away from the stakes of protecting her as you bring her across America. Compare that to Ashley from Resident Evil 4, who isn’t even close to being as much of a character, yet you feel more need to actively defend her since she has a health bar and a failstate for it dropping to 0.

All these simpler decisions TLoU makes lend to it having broad appeal, but in trying to please the many, it fails my expectations about what video games are truly capable of. I enjoyed subversion of numerous established functions in the late-game, where you're made to think you'll be going through the motions, but enlightened by character-informed twists instead. But it feels like too little too late. I dunno. Frontloading the game with status quo and saving subversion for the eleventh hour could be genius, actually, but it doesn’t come across that way after the gameplay basics got repetitive and eventually felt like a slog.

I hear the HBO show is a good adaptation! Looking forward to watching that with my mom. Having a version of this story that doesn’t bog itself down for me by falling short of expectations of its artistic medium ought to be nice.

text:
Update: The game is now unplayable if you have an Nvidia GPU. It's been almost a week and  there has been no patch. If it can't or won't be fixed refunds should be given.

Steam needs an option between do you recommend this game yes or no. Cause my feelings about TLOU Part 1 are very mixed. 

The game it's self is fantastic. 

The port even after a year just really sucks. It might be the worst modern port I've played. 
Strike 1: keyboard and mouse controls are wonky so you need a controller to really play it. 
Strike 2: The game refuses to save my display settings so I have to reset them EVERY singe time I play. It saves all the other settings 
Strike 3: Sometimes when I open the game it needs to rebuild shaders and it takes a very long time. No other game makes me rebuild shaders so often or more than once. 
Strike 4: issues that have existed since launch still exist. 

But when the game works it is so much fun. The setting, the characters, the game play are all top notch. Hopefully, TLOU Part 2 will receive the PC port it deserves. But given the issues I don't feel like I can recommend this port of TLOU Part 1 but I really want to.

Combination of 3rd person shooter, stealth, puzzles, crafting and walking simulator. Unfortunately all of those gameplay elements are missing something.

[b]Good:[/b]  
+ Level loading times are quite reasonable  
+ There some minor skill upgrades and weapon upgrades available that you can use to customize your gameplay style a bit  
+ Hearing mechanic is better than in some other similar games  

[b]Bad:[/b]
- Shooting isn't fun (and it also lacks precision element)  
- Melee combat would need some additional controls (it is just hitting the enemy with single button)  
- Puzzles are too easy  
- Crafting is very limited (only couple of items)  
- System requirements (CPU/GPU) are way too high for the game that doesn't have better graphics quality  
- Audio volume level issue with stereo speakers  
- The plot would be better with some more down to earth design (e.g. zombies completely freezing in winter, zombies not living forever, zombie killzones, smaller looter posses)  

[b]Ugly:[/b]  
* Very long shader compiler wait times  
* Crashes and micro stutters still happen in game after multiple patches

text:
The game has great visuals, story is so-so, combat and shooting isn't bad, but there are three big issues with the game for me:

1. Key bindings are simply put atrocious -- you can remap them but you can't rid of the controller and console mentality. For example, manual reload and fire are both bound to the left mouse button, but melee hit is not. Melee has its own key for some retarded reason which is used both for taking it out and hitting. Worse yet, you can't take out melee weapon without swinging it which makes you yell and pop out of cover... in a survival game where sneaking is the key since you are always low on resources. Weapon selection is similarly stupid and done through long press of a key and scroll of the wheel instead of just using more keys, one for each weapon.

2. Joel decides at the worst possible times he had enough of holding a gun or a melee weapon and stoves it away automatically after 10-15 seconds of nothing happening just to get jumped by a Clicker a second later and get his neck ripped out. It is horrible design and mighty annoying. Hold the f*cking weapon in your hand man, you can't let your guard down in the f*cking zombie apocalypse!

3. Manual saves work except when they don't -- they often return you to checkpoints and sometimes it happens that a checkpoint is really in a bad spot so good luck getting out of the bind if it happens.

I don't really know what I was expecting when I know that the game was originally released on the console? I guess I was hoping it will have proper PC controls, but that was apparently too much to hope for.

text:
After the FSR 3 implementation was fixed, which made me waste two hours of time and didn't let me play until the April update. I was able to enjoy much of the game and finalized it, and it really is amazing in many ways; But my review will be negative again due to the many problems that this port entails. I think it's a real insult to be writing all the problems that happen when playing this game because despite the fact that I liked it, it's disrespectful to go through so many problems and still have to report them because they become serious and because it seems that the developers are never going to solve them. 
Not so serious common problems:
The game always had performance issues and always consumed a lot of resources, it still lacks optimization. 
Errors in the graphics as bad colors or black dots; Also often you see corners or walls that do not load the textures well. On one occasion the display camera was moving on its own until the computer restarts. 
On another occasion the game stopped and stopped working when it had been around for two hours. 
Lots of auto save data was stored that I cannot delete. 
Issues that affect a lot in the experience:
I had to do the file integrity check 2 times. The first time because the game was stuck at the point that Ellie must be transported on a platform or "palette" (as she was called in the translation) before entering the Pittsburgh hotel; The second time, after a few weeks I finished the game, I had to do the verification because I couldn't activate two optional dialogues in the area before the Pittsburgh hotel. 
Several optional conversations that you had already activated were not logged until I activated them a second time after the second file integrity check. By the way, until I did the second review of the integrity of saved data, I began to get the confirmation messages to load games, in addition to the fact that before that second review the system did not record Ellie's jokes.

text:
[h1]A Mixed Bag of Survival, Stealth, and Story – A 2024 Perspective on The Last of Us Part 1[/h1]

These are my thoughts but I did use ChatGPT to format and enhance them.

In reflecting on its esteemed launch, "The Last of Us Part 1" initially presents itself as a seminal entry into the survival-horror genre. However, revisiting the game in March 2024, I find myself grappling with a mixture of admiration and disappointment.

[h2]The Highlights: Story and Environment[/h2]

At its core, "The Last of Us" shines through its narrative and the beautifully desolate world it paints. The game masterfully crafts a post-apocalyptic environment teeming with detail and atmosphere, serving as the backdrop to a story that remains compelling despite its age. The concept of survival is not only a theme but a mechanic, though it's here my enthusiasm wanes.

[h2]Diving Deeper:[/h2]

[h3]Gameplay Dynamics:[/h3]

The crux of my critique lies in the gameplay. Spanning approximately 13 hours, the journey felt more like a chore than an adventure. As a player, you're thrust into a world ravaged by the infected and hostile humans, with the options to approach situations with stealth or aggression ("Rambo style"). The stealth mechanic, ostensibly a key gameplay element, proves tedious, often feeling like it sets you up for failure unless an inordinate amount of effort is invested in perfecting it. This repetitiveness quickly wears thin.

The game's upgrade system paradoxically muddles its intended gameplay dynamics. While weapon enhancements are readily accessible, encouraging a more confrontational, action-packed approach, the stark contrast arises with the [b]stealth and character-based upgrades[/b]. These crucial enhancements, pivotal for those preferring a stealthy playstyle, require a hefty resource investment, rendering them nearly out of reach until the game's later stages.

This imbalance not only hampers the feasibility of consistent stealth gameplay but also introduces a dissonance with the game's thematic essence. While cutscenes might glorify the player's prowess, suggesting a narrative of dominance, the gameplay mechanics, particularly the prohibitive cost of [b]stealth and character upgrades[/b], significantly lean towards vulnerability and survival.

Such a discrepancy between the narrative’s portrayal of the character and the actual gameplay experience, accentuated by an upgrade system that disproportionately favors aggression over stealth, [b]dilutes the game's overarching survival theme[/b], presenting a jarring inconsistency that detracts from the cohesion of the experience.

[h3]Narrative Engagement:[/h3]

The story, while good, falls short of greatness. Its linear progression feels outdated in 2024, a time when player choice and narrative branching have become standard in story-driven games. This lack of player agency diminishes the personal connection to the narrative, a stark contrast to games like "The Witcher 3," where choices significantly impact the storyline. Incorporating choice in the PC remake could have refreshed the game for contemporary audiences without detracting from its core narrative.

[h3]Environmental Design:[/h3]

The game's environment remains a high point, meticulously crafted and immersive. It sets a compelling stage for the story, though further commentary risks nitpicking at what is generally an impressive aspect of the game.

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]

In sum, "The Last of Us Part 1" stands as a testament to the potential of storytelling and environmental design in video games. However, its gameplay mechanics and lack of player agency, especially when viewed through the lens of 2024, highlight missed opportunities for innovation and refinement in its PC iteration. While it retains its place in the annals of video game history, one can't help but feel that this relic of the past could have been so much more with just a few modern enhancements.

[hr][/hr]

text:
before delving into this review, let me preface this by clarifying that I played and finished this game when I was 13 yo. most of my playtime on the ps3 I spent playing factions ( multiplayer aspect of tlou ) and I didn't purchase the remastered version. also I haven't owned anything sony for more than a decade now. 

with that said, I don't think this is a good game. the gameplay is not good. it's intentionally clunky for, what I guess the developers decided, realism's sake. 
on it's own merits the gameplay could be considered a modern stealth masterpiece were it not for the lack of custom saves ( a stealth game with checkpoints is terrible ) and the fact that joel and ellie both have serious onset of parkinson's disease. no one shakes this much and sways their weapon like a madman while aiming unless they have severe physical issues or are drunk on the verge of passing out. 

it's clear why they added this nonsense to the gameplay, so you can grind for medicine and upgrade/reduce your weapon sway. 
that is peak modern gaming. they intentionally gimped the gameplay, so they can add an unnecessary upgrade system that is as bland and banal as ubisoft "RPG-mechanics". 

but on a positive note, the AI is a serious threat on grounded difficulty and can in unexpected ways, ruin your ghosting which is genuinely great but again the lack of a custom save system in a stealth game, ensures that it becomes an excercise in frustration. 

moving on to the plot that so many call a "masterpiece", I've got to say that it's sloppy and that's putting it mildly. 

it desperately wants to be realistic to a fault until it doesn't and it starts at the very beginning of the game with a marry sue character named tess. nobody finds joel the big, brawny dude scarry but tess? jesus, mary and joseph call the local fedra command because it's tess!

or the time they get caught by a patrol for no reason. they are hardened vets in regards to smuggling, yet they get caught by two random soldiers. why? because naughty dog couldn't come up with an organic solution to introduce the fact that ellie is infected and immune. 

it doesn't stop there. ellie was born after the central government collapsed and the fedra commanders enslaved everyone. so it makes sense that she has no grasp of pre-apocalyptic concepts. like why people emaciated themselves down to 12% body-fat, just to become a model and look good. that's good. it's reasonable.

however what isn't reasonable, is some of the forced situations in which the devs desperately try to make ellie more likeable with absolutely immersion-breaking moments. like her knowning in full detail how 5-star hotel staff received their guests. why is it in here? nd lacks the capacity to create organic situations. 

then there is their sloppy environmental story-telling. from soldiers in full functional tactical gear being strung up and left to rot in that gear ( in the apocalypse mind you ) to stacks of fully pristine clothes lying around. why? I guess some of their concept artists thought it was cool and that's why you don't allow artists to make stories, they let go of their pens and all of a sudden you have hodgepodge of concepts that don't gel. 

furthermore dead enemies with guns, won't net you ammunition but some random lubber with a rusty pipe? here you go lad with a full mag for your sniper rifle. 

if not any of this turned anyone with a functional prefrontal cortex off, then add a smidgen of idiotic american societal issues to the mix by adding something that is only polarising in the states and nowhere else. like their gun control stance. 
it's the apocalypse mate. nobody cares anymore. denying a 14yo a gun is a sure way to get both of you killed but like everything I listed above, nd doesn't have the capacity to tell a realistic story. 

but nothing really breaks the suspense of disbelief when joel out of the blue decided to see ellie to their destination. 
yes he had a daughter, nearly the same age as ellie but that was 20 year ago. he is now a grizzled, bitter old man that had to adapt in order to survive. him taking care of a 14yo because his partner begged him, is rich. 

but who cares I guess. the sony sycophants deemed tlou a masterpiece. my god the word has completely lost it's importance. 

2 / 5 graphical fidelity is exceptional, provided you have the necessary hardware. gameplay and story are grossly overstated by fans. if you still desire to experience this "masterpiece", then wait until a steep sale because once you finish it, it will be gathering digital dust in your library.

I have been wanting to play this game for many years. One of main reasons being the melee combat.

My pc is decent. It can reach 60fps at 1080p without issues. But I figured let's lower the resolution. Still stuttering. Picked low preset along with fsr, still stuttering. So regardless of settings, I have stuttering. I figured let's cap my fps to 30 but there is still stuttering.
Now imagine running a game and you can play the game from high settings to low settings but still have stuttering in gameplay, still have problems in cutscene, is it even possible to give this a positive feedback?

Maybe future me can somehow keep playing this game even with the stutter. But as of now, I would never ever think of recommending this game to anyone.

The game is really good and beautiful.
I am generally really bad with shooters, and this game is giving me a hard time with its realistic aiming, but that is a me problem and not a game problem.

I do not have the most beast rig in the world, but my PC is capable of running the game on Ultra settings 60FPS capped, without FPS drops or stutters, and still, crashes are guaranteed every time I play. 
It is really sad seeing such a good game tarnished by a very bad port, but this is the world we live in.

For anyone wondering, I have a 12 GB RX 6750 XT AMD GPU, 32 GB of DDR4 3200 RAM and a Ryzen 7 3800X CPU, which should be more than enough to handle the game, so I cant really recommend the game to anyone that is on the fence about buying it.

EDIT:
So, after a bit of digging, I found that the crashes I had were connected to the game using iCue. Once I turned off the app Integration of iCue from the games system settings, the crashes went away. Mostly leaving this edit here for people that have iCue on their PC and have experienced crashes like me.

text:
I wish steam gave us the option for neutral reviews, however I can't recommend this game in its current state unless you have a brand new PC with the latest RTX GPU.

How did you screw this up Naughty Dog? The Last of Us is in many peoples opinions is one of the best games ever made, for this reason you would think as one of the best game developers out there, they would have put maximum effort into this huge PC remake. 

The worst part is, I've literally just finished playing Uncharted - A Thieves Legacy which is frankly one of the best PC ports I've ever played and ran flawlessly from start to finish. This to me proves they are more than capable but chose not to put in the same level of time, resources and effort. Uncharted ran at 100+ FPS on Max settings while The Last of Us Part 1 struggles to maintain 60fps on medium settings. Uncharted also looks a hell of a lot better yet uses far less of my GPU's processing power. This just confuses me, as presumably its the same game engine they are running on?

For anyone who has yet to play The Last of Us, it's a brilliant game and well worth your time, however you might do better to either play the remastered version on PS4 or wait another year or two for more patches on this one. They certainly have not been quick the patch the current problems out. I chose to wait until now to allow for some patching to take place, however as soon as I loaded the game Joel's hair was glitching out and totally ruining the experience. In addition to this, my already questionable frame rate was dropping significantly during rainy scenes and remained somewhat inconsistent throughout my last couple hours.

What bewilders me the most is that the developers and producers knew full well that this was going to be a huge AAA release and chose to still release the game in its alpha-like, bug ridden state. It's as though they didn't care at all about the possibility of the initial negative reviews. We expected better from you Naughty Dog, and whoever else helped with your port. We know you are capable of greatness, but in this instance, you let your fans down.

I will change this review to positive if you fix the terrible frame rate issues and the graphics glitches.

keywords: run, setting, pc, fps, performance, port, even, low, still, well
text:
There is no option to recommend *conditionally* so let me try to unpack this the best I can.
I've avoided purchasing this game for months because of the same negative reviews that YOU have been seeing. I read and researched into many complaints over those months and gained enough confidence on the situation to make the purchase, so good news. If you have had many questions about these bad reviews, I have some answers. 

  Is this a poor job of a port? Yes absolutely. Has this game crashed multiple times for many people? Yes. Are there more strict hardware requirements? Yes. Does this mean that its a random roulette of weather or not this game is going to work for you? No... So lets get into it. 

  This is a demanding, inefficiently ported title. The hardware requirements have a bar that must be reached, in which if you are below, you will likely encounter problems. Reportedly, that bar begins at: 

GPU 6600xt/3060ti range (will cover VRAM shortly)
CPU ryzen 5/equivalent

  If you have this hardware, you *CAN* get this game to work just fine for you (will discuss steps at the end). If you have hardware beneath this bar, some have reported they can run it at 720p.
VRAM. VRAM requirements begin at 8GB, as the game will reserve all of that. It will still play, but more than 8GB of VRAM is *highly recommended. 

Lets talk about the crashes. It appears that the most common cause of the game crashes that many have experienced comes from starting game play before allowing the shaders to load. There is strong evidence for this in addition to reported resolved issues by allowing the shaders to load. Minimum requirement hardware users report this step can take over an hour to complete. Higher end hardware users report 5-15 minutes. You only need to let the shaders load once after install.

Now a more serious quirk that isnt addressed enough is the danger to ICUE software users. This port will try to highjack your ICUE settings upon first launch to link your LED's to the game play. Why is this dangerous? Well if your CPU cooler is running with ICUE, your coolant pump can turn off (like mine did), your fans can all turn off, etc... You can disable this quickly in the game main menu by turning off software integrations in settings. Crashes are linked to this issue. 

  So lets go over the steps to make the game work. 
1. Meet the minimum hardware requirements (Nvidia gpu's might need an extra step for shaders)
2. Let the shaders load completely before beginning game play. 
3. If you have ICUE, disable software/RGB integrations in the main menu settings. (You can do this while the shaders are loading).

  -My experience with this title so far and some thoughts-
Upon following the 3 mentioned steps, I have encountered no problems with the game at all. Im using a 6700xt GPU(oc/uv) and a r7 7700x CPU.  I am averaging 90fps at 1080p ultra settings. The game hasnt crashed. The game hasnt lagged. The game is working fine. I will update this post if it ever does. I am not expecting it to. 
The port job is lazy and probably went to the lowest bidder. Your hardware wont give you as much as it normally does for this game. The game is from 2013 and expensive at $60 for some strange reason,
but its still a great play and if you follow the mentioned first-start steps, you very likely arent going to encounter problems. 

So with this, I recommend this game, as it will work fine under *conditions,* and used the thumbs down because buying and playing a game shouldnt require this much research and work. 
I hope this cleared things up for you.

text:
One of the worse port jobs I have seen since Arkham Knight when it was first released. At least the game runs where AK would barely would run without crashing or at least I thought. For many there will come a point where the game will constantly crashing every few minutes for me this was the dam area. People will tell you it is resizable bar or something or another, but it doesn't always fix the problem. The only advice I can give is to keep pushing through the area into the next and the crashes will happen less and less frequently until they just completely stop. Extremely frustrating when most of the game runs fine minus the various non game breaking bugs. Dynamic lights pixelating on enemies, enemies reset to spawn points, falling through the world, camera going through walls showing out of bounds areas (this happens at ton), etc. The amount of bugs, which I would have thought would have been fixed at this point is staggering. 

Some of the pros are the lighting and the texture work in this game is some of the very best you will see in a game. I don't think there is a another game out there with textures as detailed as this game if you can run it that high. On Samsung's 57" dual 4k the detail is mind-boggling. Also if you haven't play this game it is one of the very best stories told in games. 

But I would seriously skip it until it is either fixed or seriously discounted. They do not deserve your money if they are not going to fix the game. 
It is really sad that companies want you to buy their games on PC (consoles and PC are more alike than ever before) yet PC ports are just bad these days. No reason to spend any more money than they need to get the game out the door and on PC and still want full price.

text:
I can't in good faith recommend this game due to the fact that in 2024, there are still random issues that plague this port.

In my experience, sometimes the game would launch, run, and play wonderfully. Other times I'd spend upwards of a half hour trying to stop it from crashing or trying to get it to actually work. I remember the first time I tried to launch this game, it told me I didn't have enough memory, when I had nothing else open.

Uhhh, Frankie, bubbie....I've got 32 whole gigs of RAM for you to use....

All in all, when the damn game works it's a masterpiece. Elements from The Last of Us Part II like game play modifiers and a revamped HUD and more have made it into a now remade 2013 game we all know and love.

If you do decide to buy it, just expect issues.

--- E D I T ---

Okay. 

Some (game play) hours later, when I last left off, I said that when the game works it's a masterpiece. And I still stand by that statement. But I've also run into another absolutely ridiculous issue that is completely unacceptable when you take time to consider just how BIG Naughty Dog is.

The achievements are bugged. I am not joking. A company this big remade a game with a bunch of nice improvements and what not and somehow managed to mess up achievement triggers.

There's an achievement that makes you have to listen to all of a certain characters jokes, 3 to be exact, to unlock it. My first time through the game, I did that. Guess what? I check back, turns out according to steam that I got NONE of the triggers, so I had to do it all over again.

The saddening thing about this is that it's not even exclusive to the PC port, players on PS5 have also been having this same issue, meaning they have to replay sections of the game and recollect shit they've already gotten before if they want all the achievements. 

Everything I had expressed before this edit still holds true to me, but if you do consider buying this game, just be prepared for it to irk your nerves.

Not because it's too hard, but because it's a genuinely buggy mess.

Game played perfect until I got to "Go Big Horns". Now it just constantly crashes at the beginning of the chapter, even in "safe mode". New PC with Ryzen 9 7950X3D, RTX 4090, 64gb ram with a aspect ration of 32:9 on a iNNOCN 1440p 49" ultrawide monitor. 

Update to the crashing. Apparently the culprit of the constant crashing in the Go Big Horns chapter was the ultrawide. It doesn't make any sense that the aspect ratio is what was causing that particular chapter to crash. The game has the 32:9 ration in the display options. But, playing it on my Dell 27" 1440p monitor at 16:9 ratio, the game hasn't crashed. This is one reason why I hate PC gaming. The dumbest things can make a game crash.

text:
The game breaking Issues present at launch are solved, at least for me. But the optimization is still a shame. I run the game on low settings, and I still have a lot of clipping, framerate drops, micro-freezes, textures not loading... all this with a rtx 3050 ti (it runs Baldur's Gate III or RDR2 in Ultra)

Apart from that, this is one of the best 3rd person survival-horror shooter game along with "the evil within 1&2" and "Resident Evil 4". I played the game in hard difficulty and had a blast, it took me 14 hours to complete. 

The gameplay is brutal and diversified. Each encounter is unique. The level design is clever, the interiors are amazingly detailed, the exteriors are beautiful. Exploration is rewarding, and ressources are scarce. Joel is an amazing killing machine and Ellie is one of the most memorable character in a video game. Your relation with the other protagonists as well as the scenario are well written. The acting, voice acting, sounds and musics are astonishing. 

Still, I don't like being taken for a fool, so not recommanded for the current price, should be 15$ max considering it is a poorly optimized 10yo game.

text:
Look, this may change at a later date, but as of now:
An unacceptable lack of optimisation. It took 10 minutes to load shaders, then THIRTY-FIVE minutes to load when New Game was selected.
Now, in the gameplay itself, it is generally really good, however, there are textures on some objects that have delayed render.
The cutscenes... oh, the cutscenes, well, sometimes they flow just fine, but it is not uncommon for freezes, glitches, and character models shifting positions in a manner that looks like damn teleportation. When a cutscene flows into gameplay, the glitches can carry over, so you can pull the trigger for your gun, then the world freezes for 2 seconds, and then the gun finishes firing.
There is a reason this game is held in such high regard, so it's a pity we don't get that.

Oh, also, the price tag is obscene. I don't care how "remastered" a game is, if it was released originally a decade ago, then the price it had then, should not still be the price now. (I did buy it during this sale for 30% off, but I think indignation is still valid.

keywords: run, setting, pc, fps, performance, port, even, low, still, well
text:
I try my hardest to enjoy this game, but I literally can't. I was expecting that the game would've been somewhat optimized with the recent updates that it got, and while the current state is much better than what was on release, there's still a lot of polishing left to do.

As I've stated on my review, "I literally spent 7 hours troubleshooting the graphical settings here and there, while going through the game just to be met up with a lot of stutters that ruin the gameplay". I had to build the shaders 3 times, and took a good 3 hours in total for them to all be compiled. 5 hours of gameplay that was constantly met with changing graphical settings, messing with unofficial FSR3+FG mods that also hit a good amount of lows (due to again, the horrible optimization), making the game unplayable.

Interestingly, I'm using hardware that meets the recommended specs on a performance scale (RTX 3060 TI + Ryzen 5 3600). Despite the GPU surpassing the recommended specs, I'm surprised that the game, which supposedly matches my system requirements, struggles to run. I felt like I fell into the void of false advertising from the developers.
I genuinely regret buying this game and spending 8 hours of my life on such an unpolished, unoptimized port, that I'd rather spend it on another quality game that is much better optimized. I can't deny that it's much better than what we got when it came out though, but there's still a lot of polishing left to do.
For what its worth right now, its best to spend it on some other game instead.

keywords: run, setting, pc, fps, performance, port, even, low, still, well
text:
Look. I love this series and I personally see The Last Of Us as one of the most compelling video games of all time, I simply cannot recommend this specific port of the game in it's current state. I feel that merely the fact that my very expensive hardware capable of out performing a current gen console ten times over should not be barely hitting sixty frames per second only with the most performance heavy DLSS enabled. I can name many games I've played this year that arguably should be more taxing to run that I simply ran into no performance issues with. All of this is not accounting for the average PC gamer who's experience is likely to be a lot worse. Only purchase this if you are sure you can run it properly and if not, idk maybe just play it on a friends PS5.

Edit after finishing game: To anyone thinking of disregarding this review or giving it a clown reaction emoji, I'd like to clarify that it's likely not to be a terrible experience for those with mid range newer hardware in your computers, but there are too many people running on gtx 1650s and even gtx 1080s for a game to HEAVILY require dlss in most cases and be seen as a success. performance saving options like dlss are a good evolution of technology, but should never be required to reach stable frame rates or even hit that sixty fps mark. This port is an incredible game that's bogged down by performance issues and poor optimization.

text:
Despite the patches that have been released in the last year, this is still an unoptimised mess. With a 4070 and the settings at the default the game suggested, I hit a point in an early transition area where a side character was helping Joel up over a barrier and my framerate dropped to sub-1 FPS. I had to alt+F4 out and go back to reduce all of my graphics settings to get it functioning again.

Despite this, the game is still hit with stuttering at frequent intervals and constant "texture pop" during cut scenes. 

The game itself is ehh, okay. The main story is around 12 hours long, and that was with plenty of exploring and backtracking, so nothing world-shattering. 

The story suffers from the usual post-apocalyptic story issues, where side characters only exist to create moral quandaries for the main character either by dying, betraying you or betraying you and dying. And something about the second half of the game, where there's frequent large time skips and jumps between locations just left me feeling like something was missing. It's not bad, just... eh. That's the best I can say for it.

To be honest, if you've got access to a playstation capable of playing this I'd probably recommend just getting it on there rather than fecking around with the optimisation mess that this game offers.

keywords: release, really, review, go, say, year, see, know, come, make
text:
Now don't let my hours fool you, I bought it because it was on sale, I played it because it really is one of the greatest games of all time, With that being said, if you have the power to run this game on your current Rig, i'd say it is worth the sale price $40 or less is good (Not counting taxes) My other issues are with other aspects of this PC Version and the game itself in general, if you want to know them Read Below, if not, then just go by what i said here.

What the hell is with this game needing so much? Owning a RTX 3070, 32gb of VRAM, and UHD 770 I can pretty much handle almost every single modern game out there, To get this to run at Ultra Settings all the way through, you need a computer made by goddamn NASA, I have seen plenty of games that look so much better than this "Remake" and yet I can run those games at the highest settings without my rig breaking so much as a sweat, But since this game is pretty poorly optimized (At least in my opinion) I had to follow a specific video on YouTube, which really did help me run this game at 60fps and Above. And if you really want to be one of those people that classifies this as a from the ground up "Remake" then you really have no clue what a Remake is, Play RE4 Remake, play Destroy All Humans 1 & 2, those are from the ground up full blown remakes, Yes the visuals in TLOU "Remake" are beautiful, you'd have to be a moron to not acknowledge that at least, But you cannot just port slight animation changes (which you ripped from TLOU 2) and consider that being a "Remake" which for some reason you charge full price for (thank steam for the sales) but at least you didn't charge $70 for it. Another thing I was kinda sick of in this "Remake" was the fact that now (for some reason) you added animations for the Workbench and added the Manual Safe Entry minigame in this, now what the hell was the reason for that? It's not bad the first few times, some of the animations are cool at first, but do I really need to waste 5-10 seconds watching Joel poke his Shotgun with a pair of pliers? It made me miss the hold the button down for a few seconds then move onto the next thing, And I honestly don't like the manual safe input, again cool at first, but gets old after the first time you do it, for those who don't know, you had to find a note or something that had a safe code on it and you just pressed a button and watched a quick animation play out, now it just takes longer. Overall the experience of the game is really great though, It's the same Last of Us we knew and loved back in 2013, packed in with its respective DLC Left Behind, which you can get through in about an hour or an hour fifteen. You got different ways you can handle situations in the game, no real bad outcome to whatever choice you make it's not a Telltale Game, just which option will save you more ammo or not. But I really do think i would've been happier if they just ported the PS4 Remaster to the PC due to all the bugs and issues this game had with graphics, occasionally you would see some Black Squares as well. It isn't an awful option though, it's fair if you have never played TLOU before and want to experience it since you never touched a PS3 or PS4, then this is a good buy... if you got the right rig for it. But overall... I really would ONLY recommend it on sale any time it is $40 or less, i'd leap on it. But i wanted to at least try it so I wouldn't here some dumb shit say "But you never had your hands on the controller, so clearly you have no clue what your talking about" Don't worry homeboy, I've known it since the beginning, which is why I waited for a sale first.

text: The graphics are great, I have a beefy system and it play smoothly with Ultra settings and very few but some bugs. In spite of that good bit, I can't recommend the game. This game constantly drags you where it wants you to go and I don't mean its linear map. I've played linear map games I enjoyed, however the best analogy I came up is imagine your supposed to fly a plane but instead of being the pilot your the co-pilot with the pilot telling you to raise flaps, radio the tower, lower the gear, etc. That's exactly what this game felt like, I was along for the ride and being told what to do instead of taking my own actions. My choices didn't matter, my actions were scripted to fit into a narrow band of options, and I was like the audience watching rather than an the actor doing. There was too many things that went this way to mention, but I noticed even ammo drops were manipulated. For example I saw two drops of a certain ammo during a fight near me, after I picked up one and headed for the second I saw it disappear in front me before I got close enough to pick it up. I noticed in other cases too when I went back to get an ammo drop I passed while fighting they were gone when I came back. This game constantly made me follow the a tight script including actions and fights, that ruined the game play for me. I finished it and wouldn't play it again, or a sequel like it.

text:
bought the game on sale to complain about it, lmao. tldr: only get if you've never played before, and even then, wait for sale. if you have played before wait for better sale.

lets get the good out of the way: The Last of Us (2013) has always been a shining example of the best of the Sony catalog and often considered one of the best games of all time. This is still pretty much true--the story of Joel and Ellie is written brilliantly, paced wonderfully, and acted/soundtracked beautifully. The story has actual consistent themes and ideas that reflect in each character, rarely if ever feels contrived or otherwise unrealistic, and the end will stick with you for some time.

Gameplay is a standard mix of third person shooting, exploration and some puzzle solving, and brutal melee combat. Genre-wise, its going for the survival/panic horror idea, so expect some good monster design, limited ammo, and slower deliberate movement. Stealth is always advised and achieved in most cases by crouching out of sight and taking enemies down from behind. 

This port looks better in every way. Graphics look lush and animations, especially facial ones are top-notch; the original game was probably the best looking game of the seventh generation of consoles, and its PS4 remaster remained solid looking throughout the eighth. Some face models were redesigned, Tess in particular looks much more like her actor, Annie Wersching (RIP). The updated engine allows for better lighting and shadow work all around. The quality of the reflection mapping made me think it was ray tracing (its not, its just really dang good). Performance is fine on my Ryzen 5 2600x/RX 6700XT combo (high settings), but certainly still leaves a lot to be desired.

Enemy AI from Part 2 makes its appearance here, without the near-constant callouts of people's names in a cheap but realistic attempt to guilt you. Human enemies will stick with friends when alerted, react to the sound of you being out of ammo, but are relentless. Infected behave slightly differently than originally, being more active and moving more when alerted, clickers in particular, leading to stealth encounters often feeling similar but slightly harder.

Safecracking from Part 2 also gets to appear in this remake. Originally, you had to find the note with the code on it. While those notes still exist, you have to manually enter the code, and if you haven't found the note, you can crack the safe by hear, which is rather satisfying to do.

now for the complaints and why I don't recommend this game to anyone who still has a PS4 or has played the game before.
-This should not qualify as a remake, despite claims otherwise. This is a remaster with some remade models and textures and an updated engine. As such, logical gameplay benefits from Part 2 (dodging, prone crawling) make no appearance hear, despite the minimal impact they would present on balancing.

- new upgrade animations are weird. at best, they add aesthetics to the gun or you can see the realistic approach. however, sometimes they are baffling, such as the fact that the level 2 revolver fire rate animation is just oiling the gun (shoulda been level 1), other times, they are obscured entirely by Joel's shoulder, making it impossible for you to even tell what he's doing.

-Performance hog, this just eats resources, i wouldn't recommend running it with any less than 12 GBs of VRAM.

-this is not worth full price nor is it worth the $40 or so they've put it on sale for so far, AT ALL. Nor is the digital deluxe content worth paying for. First, the game lacks Factions mode, the original's and remaster's multiplayer--this is frankly egregious, especially after plans for a separate free to play version were canned. The MP in this game is really good, playing on a cat and mouse-esque dynamic as players stalked each other through maps; at any point gunfire could break out between the sides or you could have a sharp thing jammed into your neck from behind. it was tense, it was brutal, and it deserves to be played by everyone. 2, they've done the absolute bare minimum here (and maybe thats unfair, but it certainly feels that way). C, if you've still got a PS4, dust it off. The remaster is like 10 bucks on the PS Store or at your local games shop, it has the Left Behind DLC and some of the digital deluxe stuff already baked in, and you CAN STILL PLAY FACTIONS with a fairly active community. Its just not worth anything when a more feature complete version is a sixth of the price. It speaks to what I'm frankly assuming is the start of the downfall of the once brilliant Naughty Dog, and some really shitty behind the scenes decisions at Sony.

text:
If you enjoy escorting NPC who possess the stealth of a herd of elephants and a story so linear it makes a straight line jealous, then this is the right game for you. Get ready to question why enemies suffer from chronic blindness, conveniently ignoring your character's flashlight shining in their eyes like a beacon. Crafting in this game is revolutionary, turning a post-apocalyptic world into your personal Home Depot. Story so unsurprising, it could rival a children's book for predictability. And don't forget the plot twists that are as shocking as watching paint dry. 

Game is overrated asf, with more blind followers than the zombies within and If you're into following the herd or praising mediocrity as a masterpiece, then this is the right game for you. 

To sum, the game is trapped in a maze of its own hype, desperately trying to catch up to the masterpiece it can only dream of being. Last of Us offers about as much excitement as watching grass grow.

text:
Although I wrote the review of this game as the positive recommendation, but it has changed my mind since the PSN restriction policy of other Sony's games such as Ghost of Tsuchima, God of war Ragnarok and Until dawn, and sooner or later, Sony will soon apply this policy to the other games.

I. Graphic review
The game brings a new level of visual fidelity to the beloved classic.he game features stunningly detailed environments, character models, and textures, all enhanced by the capabilities of modern PC hardware. The post-apocalyptic world is rendered with incredible realism, with meticulously crafted landscapes and atmospheric effects that immerse players in the desolate beauty of the setting. Lighting and shadow effects are particularly noteworthy, adding depth and intensity to the game's various locales. The improved frame rates and resolution options available on PC ensure a smooth and visually impressive experience, making the most of the platform's graphical potential.

II. Gameplay review
The gameplay remains as engaging and intense as ever. The blend of survival, stealth, and action elements creates a gripping and challenging experience. Players must carefully manage resources, navigate dangerous environments, and engage in tactical combat. The AI of both enemies and allies is intelligent, providing a realistic and dynamic challenge. The crafting system adds a layer of strategy, requiring players to make critical decisions about resource allocation. The game's controls are responsive and can be customized to suit different play styles, with options for both keyboard and mouse or gamepad. The PC version also benefits from fast load times, enhancing the overall gameplay experience.
The Last of Us Part 1 is renowned for its compelling and emotionally charged narrative. The story follows Joel and Ellie as they journey through a post-apocalyptic world, forming a deep and complex bond. The writing is exceptional, with well-developed characters and a plot that explores themes of survival, loss, and humanity. The voice acting and motion capture performances are top-notch, bringing the characters to life in a way that resonates deeply with players. The story's pacing is masterfully handled, balancing moments of intense action with quieter, more introspective scenes that allow for character development and emotional depth. It is a narrative experience that stays with players long after the game is finished.

III. Performance review
One of the most significant improvement for the PC version is the crashing issues, sometimes plays smoothly and crashes continuously due to the hardware temperature and performance although my hardware has reach beyond the recommended game's specification. Some players have reported encountering technical issues, including performance hiccups, crashes, and optimization issues on certain hardware configurations. While these issues may be addressed through future patches and updates, they can detract from the overall experience for some players.

IV. Reliability
Sony's decision to restrict from selling the games that released this year in 180 countries is deeply concerning. This move appears to be a significant oversight in a world that increasingly values global connectivity. By limiting access to PSN, Sony is not only disenfranchising a substantial number of players but also missing out on the potential growth and innovation that could arise from these diverse markets. This restriction impedes players in these countries from participating in the broader PlayStation ecosystem, including access to digital contents, and even the latest updates for the specific game. For a brand that is celebrated for its cutting-edge technology and commitment to enhancing user experiences, such a restrictive policy seems counterproductive. It sends a message that these regions are not valued, which could harm Sony's reputation and hinder its global expansion efforts. Globalization should be at the forefront of any modern gaming strategy and Sony's current approach falls short of this ideal.
Removing these restrictions would not only expand Sony's reach but also align with the growing demand for accessible gaming experiences worldwide. It would allow plasers from these restricted countries to fully participate in Sony's games, contributing to a richer community and potentially unlocking new market opportunities for Sony.
Although I really love this game, but it has changed my mind since the PSN restriction policy of other Sony's games such as Ghost of Tsuchima, God of war Ragnarok and Until dawn, and sooner or later, Sony will soon apply this policy to the other games. And even though I buy the PS5 or later PlayStation version console, it is hard by 2 reason:
1. My region is not support PSN, and even though I created the account from another regions that supported the PSN, the account will be banned sooner or later.
2. Lack data synchronization across multiple devices

V. Conclusion
The Last of Us Part 1 on PC is a visually stunning and deeply engaging game that brings a classic narrative to a new audience. The enhanced graphics and smooth performance make it a standout title on the platform. The gameplay is intense and satisfying, with a blend of survival, stealth, and action elements that challenge and engage players. The story is emotionally compelling, with well-developed characters and a plot that explores profound themes.
Reconsidering and removing these restrictions on selling games in 180 countries that don't have PSN would be a positive step towards enhancing global gaming and ensuring that all players have equal opportunities to enjoy all Sony's games.

Although the game is fun to play in part of its dynamic style, graphics and animation, the game is still inadequately optimised. I waited about 7 months to see whether they'd fix a lot of the problems most players were experiencing; alas, the problems still persist. The game crashes constantly without warning; there are still a few character/animation glitches (random T-poses and getting stuck by objects).
