keywords: story, last, also, character, gameplay, feel, instead, present, hype, find
text:
SPOILERS 

Until the last 5 minutes of the game, I loved the father / daughter relationship and it looked like I'd be replaying this game a ton. The combat is great - the weapons, finding ammo, needing to use melee / bricks / bottles / stealth kills / bow to avoid activating all enemies at once, the way Ellie would do her own thing here and there instead of just staying 2 feet from you at all times like most games - how you didn't have to worry about the other characters exposing us while we're hiding and so much more. The (so you thought) development of caring between Joel and Ellie was working out really well (meaning the writers doing this).

Then suddenly in the last 5 minutes of the game, they totally destroy all of it, making the man a psycho who will tell a MASSIVE set of lies to the girl so she will now go live with him as a family, and also trash her trust for him making him "swear that what you said is 100% true". So now it's clear she really doesn't trust him. And the writers have him say 'yes' without flinching, which only a psycho could pull off after telling such a MASSIVE set of lies.

The potential father / daughter love between them was a very strong point of this game, which would easily make me want to replay it given all the other aspects mentioned above.

Games with strong points like this make people want to REPLAY it.  That's what game developers WANT: people to play it and REPLAY it. That should drive all your decisions.

"Not us! In spite of 99% of the game's character and relationship development, let's trash all of that at the end and instead turn one of the two main characters into a lying psychotic just to manipulate her to going back to live with him, and let's show the other main character doesn't trust the other either! We were just fooling you the entire game that their relationship, trust and caring was growing stronger - who cares if it ruins what would have been a great story that people would love replaying - let's just trash it all - I'm sure everyone will love us trashing it just as much!"

It would be like Resident Evil 2 remake with Claire, where Claire just kills Sherry's mom, then lies to Sherry and says a zombie got her, and telling Sherry that before her mom died that her mom told Claire that she's not even Sherry's mom and that she never did like Sherry, then Claire having Sherry leave with her to go see where she lives and move in with her. Then Sherry asking "Swear to me that all of this is 100% true" - "Yes" (without flinching). That would completely destroy that game as well.

Don't know if this will change, but in the span of that 5 minutes at the end, now I have no desire to replay the game since you know the writers are just out to pretend the man and girl are growing together, their relationship and caring growing, and instead at the end trash all of it and just instead have him be a psycho that will tell her MASSIVE lies to have his fake family with her and she doesn't trust him anyway.

Epic fail by the writers. Epic failure by the company for approving that stupidity as if that would be "better" and "more fun" for those who play it.

Given the ton of woke content in the game that is very blatant, I should have seen it coming. I was overlooking all of the blatant woke trash because the relationship between the two and how it was growing was so well done and it made me want to replay the game. Until the last 5 minutes of the game, it was looking to be one I'd replay a ton. 

Now I despise it.

I thought I would find the weird hair rendering issue fixed, aswell as my rifle scope finally working instead of being black/unusable (as in I literally cant see through it).
This is already annoying, but many people seem to still experience crashes and performance issues. I had 1-2 crashes the first week after release but nothing that bad. I tend to be quite lucky with not having any performance issues in games even when people say they are riddled with them, so maybe it was just my luck again.

But any of these issues persisting this late after release is not cool. And my 2 issues still happen frequently so that its annoying and ruins the immersion. The cutscenes may look semi-funny at first with the weird hair rendering but it gets old quick.

Fix your game. I am also patiently waiting for the TLOU2 port which I would play the shit out of, but please do better with that one because it would be disheartening to see TLOU2 also tarnished by a bad port.

Flat out doesn't work for me, I turn the game on and the framerate is fine, but as soon as I hit an encounter or certain parts of the world the framerate takes a nose dive. Doesn't matter what graphics settings I have it on, it will always dive down into the 50s and 40s. I'm a on a pretty solid machine too, 7900 XTX, 32 gb ram, 5800X, SN750 NVME drive.  The game looks good but there are better looking games these days that run better. Not sure what happened here but the performance issues aren't resolved. I'm on AMD's latest drivers as of this month (10/23). I had to ask for a refund unfortunately, this is in my top 5 games of all time. I played it on PS3 when it first launched, and I was really looking forward to a second play through. I'm a little bummed out by it but it's not the end of the world. Hopefully it gets fixed and not just abandoned. I'll try buying it again in a year or so when I swap to AM 5. It seems worse when there are encounters, but there's really nothing happening AI wise in this game that's special or difficult for modern CPUs to handle. The whole thing is very odd. 

For reference I just played through Halo Infinite who's game world is significantly bigger and requires a larger rendering budget, the AI is more sophisticated as well. I also just played Resident Evil 4 and decided to return this and play the DLC of that instead. Both games in my opinion require more of the GPU and CPU yet run significantly better.

text:
I'm so torn on this game. The truth is, this is one of my favorite stories of all time and I absolutely love the last of us. I had it on PS3, but when I switched to PC, I couldn't play the game since I had to sell all my consoles to afford the PC. Now that it's been almost a decade since then and the sequel is out, I don't know how to feel anymore. 

Firstly, The game was a complete mess when it came out. I wont spend much time on that, but from my end, they've totally fixed the performance issues. That doesn't really effect my opinion too much because those issues never should have been there in the first place, but at least they fixed them. MAKE SURE YOU LOAD YOUR SHADERS BEFORE PLAYING THE GAME! IT DOESNT TAKE LONG! JUST WAIT!

Next, the game is great. Its The Last of Us of course, and its fantastic. The remaster is awesome, and I'm glad it's on PC, because every game should be, obviously. 

The thing that I hate the most is that the sequel is actually terrible. You may be wondering, "You don't have a playstation, how have you played it?" Well, my friends are dumb enough to give sony money for subpar hardware to play video games so I watched their playthrough, and its actually a godawful sequel. Probably the worst sequel of all time.

Maybe I'm just an idiot (that is probably the case ngl) but the sequel ruins the story of The Last of Us. I dont wanna get into it too much but it just makes the entire story feel worthless, and It's hard to give Naughty Dog money for ruining one of my favorite games. I should seek help, I know. 

Im not going to refund the game because it's awesome not just because I can play this game again, but I can play it properly on PC after something like 7 years of not playing it. However, I am going to leave a negative review because of what I've already mentioned, and also the fact that they are charging $60 for a game that was released a decade ago. I know its got a cool new coat of paint on it and all, but for fucks sake, get over yourselves.

SPECS: i7 13700k, 64GB DDR5 memory, 3080. 

Loved this game since launch, played through twice on PS3, twice on PS4, and was not going to get the PC port because of the criticisms of the coding. Eventually I'll get a PS5 so I was holding off for that. But my sister, a devoted fan, is coming to visit and I want her to experience the remaster in 4k on my OLED TV so against my better judgement I bought it here.

Started a playthrough to unlock every chapter for sis, that way she can dip into whichever part of the story she wants. Everything was great for the first half of the game; every now and then I saw a slight hitch when transitioning between gameplay and cinematics but that was it. Then I got to the sewers.

When they first opened the door and triggered the sound trap at the beginning of the abandoned living area in the sewers, the stutters hit hard and did not stop. The game gets so choppy it becomes unplayable. This is intermittent and can be mitigated somewhat by reloading the checkpoint, but results are spotty. I'm continuing the playthrough because sis arrives tomorrow night but it has become a chore. I've made it into the suburbs and am now sneaking up on the sniper and the chop is still intruding on my game.

This is obviously not a hardware issue because my specs are more than enough to run the game smoothly and my rig has done so for the first 14 hours of play. Even when the chop hits my FPS counter still reads between 50-70 so it is not a graphical issue at all; it has to be this shitty poorly coded port. 

It pains me to downvote this game but 7 months after its PC release it is downright unethical to sell it in this condition. I'm going to play it with my sister this weekend to see what we can get out of the experience then see if I can talk Steam into a refund because this is broken-ass bullshit. Very disheartened.

text:
Honestly one of the best stories in gaming. I bought it when the remaster for PS4 released and I played the hell out of it, loved it, and constantly recommended the game to everyone. The story was amazing, the characters didn't feel like creepy dolls, and the environments were absolutely gorgeous.

Specs
Ryzen 7 5800X
16GB DDR4
Gigabyte 3080
NVME drive

I'm playing this port several months after release and the amount of graphical bugs in the first ten minutes has me regretting the key I bought. I have my settings on low-med and am only managing 50fps in an enclosed room. There's something very wrong with AA as well, edges look absolutely atrocious and the sharpening for DLSS is completely broken.
I spent the first hour and a half of my playtime troubleshooting the graphical bugs, only to find out that it's just the game being absolute trash. Not what I want to waste my time on. Whoever green lit this game, slapped that $60 price tag on there and said "Yup, she's done!" needs an intervention, because, Dear God, they must be completely blind.

I purchased this game thinking that they would have fixed the launch issues, but no. To say I'm disappointed would be an understatement. If you have great memories of this game with beautiful environments, amazing story, and memorable characters- go play the original remaster. This port will tarnish those memories, and does not deserve to share its name with the original.

Edit: I love this game even more now that I have a high end gaming rig. I did expect the graphics to be a complete improvement from the original, but this is a "remaster" of sorts so theyve improved easy things like the post processing, lighting, animations ,etc. that wont supersede their budget. What I dislike about this game is the few issues that I have come across. Some involve my camera going haywire to the point where I am in the void, and Im currently running part 2 and I cannot win the watergun fight because I cannot spray Riley, it does not detect me hitting her even though she reacts to it and comes out drenched at the end (assuming it isnt something youre guaranteed to see even without hitting her once). The camera clipping I got to fix by restarting the game and the watergun fight is something permanent since I restarted twice and still have that issue (it might be a save issue but that rarely happens to me with any game so i doubt it). So 100% ing this is impossible (at least for me), but the game itself is still an astonishment from whatever crap larger brands have come out with recently.

I can only speak on behalf of watching because i am waiting until I can afford a high end computer in order to play at the highest graphic settings. This game is very story driven, this means no side quests from what Ive seen, no exploration like in dying light, etc. The story is very unique, well thought, well made and played parallel with exceptional acting. The environment is so detailed, well animated and textured. The sound design is accurate, the Ai's reaction is accurate, and just the idea in general is unique and follows a very different type of story compared to what we come across now a days. Even though this game came out on ps4 in 2013, it is still one of the best games I have ever seen, even if people are complaining that its still priced at 70 bucks when the newest call of duty is of that price yet full of hackers, bugs, cosmetics which people attacked techland for adding in dying light 2 and so on. These people find a game like modern warfare 2 on release well priced but not a game of its time such as last of us. They need to grow up

text:
[h1]The Last of Us Part I PC Port: A Beautiful Game Hindered by Technical Issues[/h1]

Naughty Dog, known for their exceptional storytelling and character development, captivated audiences with "The Last of Us Part I." The game's original release on PlayStation was a masterclass in immersive storytelling, delivering an emotionally charged experience that left players in tears, filled with rage, and warmed their hearts. The port of this game to the PC, however, was handled by Iron Galaxy, and it regrettably fell short of expectations, leaving players with a less-than-optimal experience. This article critically examines the PC port, the technical issues it faces, and the choices made by Sony in entrusting Iron Galaxy with the task, all while considering the hardware requirements.



Before diving into the specifics of the PC port, it's essential to acknowledge the remarkable storytelling prowess of Naughty Dog. "The Last of Us Part I" was an emotional rollercoaster, featuring deeply relatable characters and a post-apocalyptic world that felt both bleak and beautiful. The relationship between Joel and Ellie was the heart of the narrative, and players were drawn into their struggles and triumphs, shedding tears over the heart-wrenching decisions and sharing their moments of happiness.

The narrative was beautifully layered with complex characters, ethical dilemmas, and a vividly crafted world, all contributing to the emotional impact of the game. Naughty Dog's ability to engage players on such a deep emotional level is a testament to their storytelling expertise.



While the PC gaming community was thrilled to see "The Last of Us Part I" making its way to the platform, the excitement turned to disappointment upon experiencing the PC port. Iron Galaxy, a company not known for their exemplary porting abilities, took on the task of bringing this beloved title to the PC. Unfortunately, it became evident that the port had several technical issues that significantly hindered the overall experience.



One of the most glaring issues with the PC port is its performance problems. Many players reported frame rate drops, stutters, and other performance-related issues. Even high-end hardware configurations, like the RTX 4080 and i9-1300k, struggled to maintain smooth gameplay, which was a disappointment given the game's age and the capabilities of modern PC hardware.



Sony, who owns Nixxes, a company with a history of successful game porting, left many scratching their heads when they chose to entrust Iron Galaxy with this crucial task. It was a missed opportunity to deliver a high-quality PC port that could have introduced a new audience to the masterpiece that is "The Last of Us Part I." Nixxes' expertise and track record with PC ports could have been a game-changer for the experience.



Another issue with the PC port lies in its demanding hardware requirements. To run the game without encountering performance problems, players are practically required to have an RTX 4090, an extremely powerful and expensive GPU. Such high hardware demands alienate a significant portion of the PC gaming community, leaving them unable to enjoy the game in its full glory.


For many players, the stutters in the PC port of "The Last of Us Part I" were a significant source of frustration. Stutters not only disrupt the immersion but can also make gameplay less enjoyable. It's disappointing that a game of this caliber suffered from such technical issues on the PC platform, especially when the original PlayStation version was so highly regarded for its optimization.



In conclusion, "The Last of Us Part I" by Naughty Dog remains a masterpiece of storytelling, character development, and world-building. The emotional journey it offers is unparalleled. However, the PC port, handled by Iron Galaxy, leaves much to be desired. The technical issues, high hardware requirements, and the choice of developer for the port are all sources of disappointment for PC gamers.

It is unfortunate that a game that had the potential to be a remarkable addition to the PC gaming library fell short due to these issues. For those with the necessary hardware and patience to work through the technical hiccups, the emotional depth of "The Last of Us Part I" can still be experienced. However, it serves as a reminder that even the most exceptional games can falter when not given the proper care and attention in their transition to a new platform. The gaming community can only hope that future PC ports receive the attention they deserve, allowing more players to enjoy the beauty of games like "The Last of Us Part I."

But I guess only Nintendo, Larian Studios, and Fromsoft can release a game that isn't broken anymore.

text:
EDIT: If you have the black scope bug you should verify game files so the shaders need to recompile, THEN DON'T WAIT FOR THEM TO RECOMPILE BEFORE PLAYING. I don't know if I just got lucky or not, but letting the shaders recompile during gameplay meant the black scope and everything else was actually fixed by recompiling and didn't keep reoccurring. Sure, it happened a few more times, but I could get rid of it and was able to finish my playthrough. This is an amazing game with a 10/10 story and pretty dated gameplay. Everyone should play it, but I still recommend not playing it like this.

I'm left saddened by my experience with this version of The Last of Us. Everything was going well for the first few chapters, until I got a scope for my rifle and it was bugged and blacked out. Looking online this is a common occurrence, and has to do with shader compilation. Verifying the game files so the shaders recompile fixed this for a bit, and for a while I would do this whenever I wanted to play. Eventually though this stopped working.

The blacked out scope is only the most egregious symptom of this bug though. It also causes black outlines around transparencies like the arrows in your backpack, and also for Joel's eyebrows to have a black outline that makes them look very bushy.

I love The Last of Us. I originally played the remastered version on PS4 and it's the best story I've ever played in a game, and my emotional connection to Joel and Ellie goes far beyond any other characters in media as a whole. Films and games never make me cry, but several scenes in this game and the sequel get me every time. I cannot overstate how unique this is for me, and so I really hold these games in a special place.

The bugs in this version ruin this experience. I want to get immersed and lost in the moment, to for a time get lost with my favourite characters, but instead I'm repeatedly ripped out of the experience and the message "YOU'RE PLAYING A BROKEN PORT" is inescapable. I'm not playing this version any more, I don't want my love for the series to be further tainted by it.

32GB Ram DDR5 6000mhz Expo

I received the game for free as part of AMD's GPU bundle. I waited a long time for this game to come to PC, and was very excited to play In fact I played through it twice! I played the game with the recommend 1440p  specs for high settings 60fps. I couldn't stream and play at same time at 60fps without a massive CPU bottleneck which was unfortunate. So I decided to run at 4k ultra preset 30fps for the rest of the playthrough, and was able to stream it just fine. It played fine when not trying to stream, besides the 90% CPU utilization which in all fairness they sorta fixed. But almost every preset kept the CPU utilization very high anyway which sucks.
Prior to my 2nd playthrough (which I did not stream) I upgraded to Ryzen 7600x ddr5 6000mhz 32GB  CPU from Intel i7 9700k ddr4 3600mhz 32Gb. I ran the game at FSR 2 upscaled 4k at around 80fps on Custom Ultra/high settings. The Game looks phenomenal at higher settings... If you can run it. But that's not the real problem with game. The lack of optimization is the real nail coffin of this port. Every update of the game brought new bugs and random crashes. Last time I played was from a July patch which caused button input combos to crash the game, and analysis stated a GPU crash? really?! Or Random cutscene crashes causing me to replay areas over and over again. Crashing in cutscene viewer from the main menu while director commentary is playing. I have footage of the game crashing while just veering off a random path, it makes no sense. Naughty Dog isn't some no name studio, and it's unfortunate that they put so much time into the remake/remaster to have it run badly on PC. Hopefully they can fix it, because If i had payed for this game instead of getting it for free, I would have refunded it. 
Despite the amazing visuals and storytelling, I cannot recommend this game for PC in it's current state.

text:
[h1] Good Game, Bad Devs [/h1]

Those are the two faces of The Last Of Us: the good and the bad. Unfortunately, we cannot discuss the good without addressing the bad. This title is undeniably haunted by its IP owner, "Naughty Dog," who seems determined, and successful, in undermining this franchise.

Full disclosure: I did not purchase the game on Steam, and I certainly did not pay $60 for it. I would recommend exploring alternatives, as this 10-year-old game does not justify the price of a new triple-A title, especially given the subpar quality of this port (keep reading for more details).

[h1] Good Game [/h1]

The Last of Us 1 marked a pivotal moment in gaming history. It emerged at the zenith of the "zombie genre" trend, alongside titles like Telltale's The Walking Dead, State of Decay, and 7 Days to Die. Naughty Dog had a significant challenge ahead of them. Rather than following the same style as other zombie games, TLOU distinguished itself by presenting "zombies" differently and focusing on story, gameplay, providing a linear character-driven experience.

For the most part, TLOU is an exceptional game; a trendsetter that redefined the way we perceive games. With its spectacular graphics, compelling characters, and the profound "not-father & not-daughter bond" (which I believe drew inspiration from Lee and Clementine, as some of the more somber scenes bear striking resemblance), it introduced us to deeper gaming worlds, more nuanced characters, and intricate mechanics. The scavenging, crafting, gunplay, and melee combat are all executed flawlessly and offer a highly enjoyable experience.

So, what went wrong?

[h1] Bad Devs [/h1]

The major issue with playing TLOU lies with its owner, Naughty Dog. This California-based subsidiary of Sony Interactive Entertainment is overtly left-leaning. While the game ticks all the right boxes and addresses relevant topics, it tends to lean heavily into what's often referred to as "woke" (a term that, while overused, applies here). These topics include atheism, LGBTQ representation, and diversity. For instance, early on in the game, we encounter a character named Bill. The last thing I needed to know about Bill was his sexual orientation, but the game places significant emphasis on it, becoming one of the only times Joel expresses condolences in the game. Religion is also discussed by minors - an 11-year-old boy and a 14-year-old girl - as they openly express their disbelief in Heaven and make jokes about it. That same 14-year-old girl later becomes a prominent character in an lesbian relationship. What's concerning is Naughty Dog's apparent fixation on assigning LGBTQ identities to child and minor characters, doing so not once, not twice, not three times, but around four more instances. It's genuinely discomforting to contemplate. You might be wondering, how did this affect TLOU? Well, my friend, these were just the seeds of what was to come. This pattern of promoting a particular ideology would ultimately lead to Chapter 2 of the game, revealing that Naughty Dog cared more about their agenda than the integrity of the IP, even at the cost of one of their most beloved protagonists.

Now, let's talk about the PC Port. Greedy Neil Druckmann, after upsetting TLOU fans with Chapter 2, decided to hand off the PC port to a random company. Unfortunately, this port was subpar and continues to be so. Achieving over 50 fps is a challenge, particularly if you attempt to run it at anything higher than medium settings. The game frequently crashes, experiences world unloading issues, and suffers from lighting problems. It's safe to say that this port was a disaster. Many attempted to defend it by playing the "Naughty Dog didn't handle the port" card. Fine, but whose IP is it? Who failed to oversee the port? Who submitted it to Steam? Who has yet to acknowledge or apologize for it?

In conclusion, if TLOU 1 had been left as TLOU 1, it would have stood as a genre-defining, perhaps even industry-redefining game, worthy of praise for its stunningly detailed graphics, character-driven linear plot, and exceptional world-building. However, as time has passed, it's devolved into what every Netflix show seems to do now. It's become a political and moral sermon delivered by millionaires, imposing their opinions and worldviews on players to the point where it's no longer an addition to the game, but a lesson within the game. I find myself fatigued by this trend of pushing intrusive political beliefs, particularly those involving minors, in games where they have no place.

If you can overlook what Chapter 2 does, if you can tolerate the uncomfortable and repetitive themes of sexuality, if you can accept the 30~50 fps performance, and if you can stomach the $60 price tag for a 10-year-old game... perhaps you might find some enjoyment in it.

text:
A Disappointing and Overrated Experience

The Last of Us Part 1, often hailed as a masterpiece by critics and fans alike, left me profoundly disappointed and questioning the overwhelming praise it has received. While it undoubtedly has its strengths, I found several aspects of the game that left me frustrated and underwhelmed.

First and foremost, the gameplay in The Last of Us Part 1 falls short of its potential. The combat mechanics are clunky, making it a chore to engage in gunfights or melee encounters. The scarcity of ammunition and resources often leads to unnecessary frustration, as the game forces players into situations where they must resort to trial-and-error tactics rather than strategic gameplay.

The AI of both enemy and companion characters is often erratic and inconsistent. Enemies display unrealistic levels of awareness at times, making stealth an unreliable option. Conversely, your AI companions can frequently be a hindrance rather than an asset, failing to react intelligently to the danger around them and compromising your efforts to progress.

While the story of The Last of Us Part 1 is praised for its emotional depth and character development, I found it to be predictable and clichéd. The post-apocalyptic setting, overrun by a zombie-like infection, feels tired and unoriginal, lacking the fresh perspective that could have set it apart from similar narratives in the genre. Furthermore, the character of Joel, often touted as a complex anti-hero, comes across as one-dimensional and unsympathetic for much of the game.

The pacing is another significant issue. The game's narrative is often disrupted by extended sections of mundane and repetitive gameplay, such as moving ladders or planks to progress. These segments only serve to pad out the game's length without adding meaningful content or excitement.


In summary, The Last of Us Part 1 is a game that I found to be overhyped and ultimately underwhelming. Its gameplay frustrations, inconsistent AI, unoriginal storytelling. While it may have resonated with many players, I couldn't help but feel let down by the immense acclaim surrounding this title.

If you feel like playing a video game : play a video game. 
This just doesn't work, and collapses on itself in 2023. Hot. Overrated. Garbage. A 60 bucks B movie that drags on and on and never really delivers...a TOUGH investment.

text:
The Last of Us PC - Honest Review and Performance Test

-----------------

Back in the day, when it first came out, I absolutely loved The Last of Us. The storytelling and the atmosphere was and still is one of the best out there. When I heard it was also coming out on PC, I was of course over the moon.

Well... as many of you know, the launch was terrible and the game was clearly still not complete. I feel like this MUST be taken into consideration whenever anyone is commenting on this PC port. The bad performance and the glitches were not an "accidental mistake", it was an intentional decision by the publishers and the higher-ups to release the game at that state and hope people will still buy it and forget about it after a while.

Let me tell you guys, for a title this big and with a price even above some brand new titles, how they launched this game was totally unacceptable and that should not ever be "forgotten" by the fans and community.

-----------------

So, now to my experience. I haven't preordered this game or bought it any time close to launch. The version I bought it at and am currently running is v1.1.2. I do not recommend getting this game without it going on sale. The specs I have tested it on are:

- windows 11 22h2
- ryzen 5 5600x
- rtx 3060 (driver 537.13)
- 32gb ram (ddr4)

The Steam download is around 75gb. As soon as you launch the game, it will automatically start building the shaders. This means it will instantly max out your cpu until the shaders for the main game and the dlc are built. With these specs, it took around 20 minutes to finish and the cpu maxed out at around 70°c. There are people who have experienced system shutdowns because of high cpu temperatures. If you have such concerns, you can always edit your power plan or disable turbo boost on amd systems. I highly recommend waiting for the shaders to fully build before doing anything.

For the display and graphics settings, a quick google search for "the last of us pc optimal settings" will give you many websites with detailed explanations on what each setting does. For this test I have used the guide from a website called exputer and made some small tweaks. Some settings have little impact on the visuals but a big impact on the performance. With these settings the visuals look great and the performance is optimal as well.

In the first two hours of gameplay the game ran on average at around 80 fps with dlss balanced and vsync off. I haven't experienced major stutters or graphical glitches. The average total hardware utilisations were around:

- cpu 60%
- vram 8gb
- ram 16gb

However, not all scenes are the same. Some are lighter to run and some are heavier to run. I would consider the overall experience to be smooth and playable.

-----------------

If you happen to have the exact specs and drivers as I have, then I do recommend getting this game only on a sale. Although not guaranteed, you likely should not experience major problems.

Even though I had a great experience with the game performance, that does not make any other recent complaints invalid. Some systems are still clearly having problems, regardless of whether they have the recommended specs or not. This is certainly not their fault, but rather the game's fault. I absolutely do not recommend buying the game without checking whether you have any known issues with your hardware. With all things taken into consideration, I would not recommend this game to most people due to performance issues.

-----------------

Edit: After finishing the main game, here is some additional information about the performance.   

- Overall it was a smooth experience, however towards the end of the game there were sections where the frame rate dropped to low 40s and one section where the frame rate was in the low 30s. Other sections were smooth as mentioned before.
- There was one time in the early game where the game froze up and resulted in me having to restart the game.

Other than that I haven't experienced any new major issues.

text:
Update August 2023: a lot of the initial graphics glitches have been fixed... until you get to the Capitol when "post it notes" instead of hair and other graphical glitches reappear. Rather remarkable that the post-PC release fixes have only got that far into the game, after how many months of fixes and patches? But, hey, it is getting better. Slowly. 

Also, be aware that every time you update your graphics driver (usually once a month if you have an Nvidia graphics card) you will have to rebuild the game shaders. This will also happen if you verify your install files. So keep that in mind before you do the (entirely reasonable) thing and click "verify" after a crash and/or heavy graphical glitching. Set aside an hour or more for that process to complete. 

At this rate, the PC port should be a recommended purchase (5 out of 5 for gameplay and non-glitching graphics) sometime in late 2024. Maybe early 2025. Pretty sure. 

Alright, that's all for now, I need to go rebuild the shaders. Again.

I would like to have given this a horizontal thumb, neither up nor down.  It depends what people want.  This is not so much a game, more an interactive movie.  It is very linear and all the decisions you are able to take only impact your ability to survive and have no effect on the progress or end of the story.  There is one way through the story and once one stage is complete there is no going back. Like I said, it depends what you want.

The scenery  and atmosphere is very well done, as is the porting to a PC (someone should tell the Days Gone guys about using a mouse to steer a vehicle - in this case a horse).

It is quite short, making it rather an expensive purchase, but on balance I enjoyed it, though I have no desire to do it again.  I much prefer large open worlds, but that is just me.  Others, I am sure, will see it differently.

text:
I still can't recommend this game since there's still a lot of problems for me BUT they have fixed it partly and have made it playable (at least on my PC)

I've loved this game for years and it's incredible to be able to play it on Steam too now, the story is still amazing even replaying it all these years later it still holds up incredibly well. The best parts about this game are the environments and attention to detail plus the way they know how to build tension and make you nervous without just constantly throwing creepy shit in your face. The world building and lore around the virus is also incredibly interesting, especially if you love zombie/virus/apocalypse stories. I just wish that the developers had been more careful and didn't break so many things when it came out.

If you'd really love to try this game and enjoy the storyline but don't have a Playstation, you might consider getting it on Steam. If you have a Playstation, just get it on there. It runs much smoother, at least it did for me.

text:
Update 8-17-2023: I'm 3/4 through the game and it has hard crashed ten times in my total play through. The most recent being during a boss fight I was half way through. Do not buy this game right now. 

As of 8-13-2023, the game is still suffering from crashes and technical issues. I am seven hours into the game and it has hard crashed on me six times so far; three of which have been in the games financial district. It is basically unplayable at this point.

 The games implementation of DLSS has a weird blurring issue whenever you are moving your character; the blur is not present if you are standing still. It can look like the game its running at 720p (even on Quality DLSS at 3440-1440p) when you are walking, which is quite distracting. There are also certain rooms and environments where the lighting is glitchy, resulting in your character being lit up in a dark room.

I am sure they will keep updating, but it is not worth full price after this release. Wait until its $30 or lower, as it is a technically deficient port. Shame as the game itself is a genuine classic and the developers/artists who made it deserve better shepherding of their exceptional work.

keywords: run, setting, pc, fps, performance, port, even, low, still, well
text:
a real mixed bag.

pro:
1) looks great, even on lowest settings.
2) PC requirements on steam about storage are wrong: the game is only 78GB, which is nice.
3) I could not care less, but most other people really like the story.

con:
1) runs like ass. on a ryzen 3600x cpu with 16GB ram, radeon 6800xt with 16GB vram, on an ssd, vsync off, on lowest settings at 2000x1000 px resolution (downscaled from 1440p, no FSR): 60-80fps. (on high settings, full res 1440p, 40-70fps). does not sound too bad, but in either scenarios the game stutters like absolute hell. multiple times per second, always (AFTER shaders have been precompiled in the main menu, which btw took about 5-10 mintues on this PC). capping the framerate at 30 or 60 does not help, neither does enabling vsync.
2) has a weird bug in linux where the vram is wrongly detected as 4GB, even though my gpu has 16. can be fixed though by launching the game with WINEDLLOVERRIDES="amd_ags_x64.dll=b" %command% . (this has no influence on performance, incl. stutters)

conclusion: not recommended. this is a cinematic game, even 30fps would be fine (for me), but it needs to be stable. the stuttering means you cannot enjoy the visuals or cinematics because the image jerks around, which also would make combat suck if you stick around that long, which arguably is the whole point of this game. absolute tragedy.

text:
I figured I'd give this a shot since reportedly the pc port seems to have been fixed after a few months. For me there were still plenty of issues, hence the review. As a side note, the game is great performance aside, but this is pretty much common knowledge it seems.

I won't go into specs and stuff, but as a reference point, my pc is pretty good and I can generally run pretty high-fidelity games (Destiny, Doom, and other sony pc ports as some examples) on high settings without issue. The biggest issue I experienced was intense frame dropping, typically during cutscenes, but often when loading into new areas as well. The game crashed twice on the default settings, and while switching stuff around to the low-mid settings area helped, these issues were still present. I also experienced a bug seemingly caused by the low frame drops where the camera would glitch outside of the map. It wasn't unplayable, but if you don't have a super high-end pc, maybe wait on this one, or perhaps the issue was specific to my pc.

Remember the jokes we used to say when Crysis was first released? Looks like we have a serious modern day competitor: "But can it run... Crys... (clears throat)... TLOU?" You know your port has serious problems when even the lowest setting performs worse on modern hardware 100+ times more powerful than PS3.

BTW, it says I spent 2.4 hours playing, while in fact it was compiling shaders for 2.2 hours. The heck?..

P.S. I could swear I had seen Ellie wearing a greyish beard at some point, That alone gives me nightmares... Thanks to all the gfx issues they decided not to address up until this very day.

text:
I'll start by saying I own probably 3 copies of this game by now and I'm a big fan of this game. This is the penultimate TLOU experience, with many of the quality-of-life improvements brought with the 2nd game. It looks better than the PS4 remastered versions, and in many ways it's the first game with the engine/graphics/UI of the second one. I also held off on playing until the most recent patches came out this month.

Having said that, after 8 hours, I've been unable to progress beyond the second chapter, as this game crashes every hour or so. I'm playing on an RX 6750xt (12GB of VRAM), core i7-4790 (still a great CPU), 16GB RAM, and getting about 51 FPS avg. I've updated drivers repeatedly, but still at random intervals, the game just crashes. It's very frustrating to experience and really kills my desire to keep playing. Especially since it's a 10+ year old game that I've played many many times before. It just doesn't seem worth it to deal with the bugs, to see a better version of everything I've already experienced. I might try changing the install to be on an SSD, before I completely give up. I hope this helps you make your decision to purchase or not.

text:
Last of Us Part 1 falls short of expectations, especially when it comes to its performance on PC. Despite several patches, the game fails to run smoothly on even decent PC rigs. Players have reported numerous technical issues, including frequent frame rate drops, stuttering, and input lag, which significantly hinder the overall gameplay experience. It is disheartening to see a game with such potential suffer from performance issues that detract from the immersive storytelling and emotional impact it aims to deliver.

Furthermore, Last of Us Part 1 has a major flaw when it comes to compatibility with AMD graphics cards. Users have encountered consistent crashes when using these cards, particularly when attempting to modify the clock settings. This issue not only disrupts the gameplay but also frustrates players who have invested in high-performance hardware. It is disappointing that the developers have not adequately addressed these problems, leaving players with a subpar experience that undermines the game's reputation and diminishes its potential as a PC port.

text:
The Last of Us is one of the closest things gamers will get to a perfect game... but it deserved way better treatment than this.

My review here is mostly gonna focus on performance, which I rarely do considering the fact that I like to focus on the game itself most of the time when I review something. But this port definitely warrants it, because this game deserved better. All I will say is that this is The Last of Us and its companion story DLC Left Behind in their entirety on PC. The combat, story and level design are amazing and in my opinion live up to the hype.

Getting into why I'm actually writing this review, I do want to say that my playthrough with TLOU on PC was not nearly as bad as I saw near launch. I didn't encounter any major visual glitches and only had 1 crash during my playthrough. 60-65% of the time, the game ran in 60 FPS. 

However, this game still runs like dookie. My CPU and RAM were idling most of the time at 80% usage and my CPU was at 100% for massive amounts of time. My GPU was handling the game fine, especially with DLSS, but was still at 81% usage even with DLSS on. While I mentioned earlier that 60-65% the game would run in 60 FPS, that's still nearly half of my time playing this game with major FPS dips and stuttering. 

In addition to these performance issues, the shader cache building and rebuilding is still a problem. Granted, these shaders are not taking nearly as long they were at launch. But I'd hardly call a game optimized for PC if the game needs a shader rebuild every time I update my GPU drivers.

The whole point of why I'm writing this review is that we are getting progressively worse ports from Naughty Dog and by extension Sony. Uncharted 4, while not being the most optimized and having the same issue of building/rebuilding shaders, ran way better than TLOU when I played it at launch. 

I see a lot of positive reviews beginning to pop up on here and while I'm happy that people are finally able to play the game, I don't want to communicate to Iron Galaxy and Naughty Dog that they can slap Steam Deck verified on this port and call it a day. This was a rushed out port to try and capitalize on the HBO series' success, and it still shows even after the multiple updates this game has received. Further work needs to be done to optimize this game, and until that is done the PS5 version or the original/remastered version on PS4 are still the superior ways to play this game. 

TL;DR

While the game is certainly playable, it's still not fully fixed. I'm going to revisit the game around Halloween after (hopefully) a few more updates and change my review if I see significant improvement. Overall, if you're looking for a smooth action adventure/ survival horror experience on PC, go play the Dead space remake or RE 4 remake. Otherwise, I would wait a bit longer or play the game on PS5. 

Game itself: 5/5

Performance: 2.5/5

text:
[h1][b] What is TLOU:P1 [/b][/h1]
The Last of Us™ Part I is an AMAZING game with a story that is unrivalled even to this date no game has EVER been as good as The Last of Us. I played the game day 1 and it blew my mind. I played the game in 2023 Remastered and it blew my mind. I watched HBO's Last of Us show and it BLEW MY MIND... the The Last of Us will NEVER be forgotten... that is how good this game is. Watching Joel and Ellie's bond getting stronger as the game goes on. Watching Joel teach Ellie how to shoot and play the guitar is father of the year material. Watching Joel put his own life on the line for Ellie.... its truly beautiful. The stealth is a 10/10. Story a 10/10. Music 10/10. Characters 10/10. Combat 10/10. EVERYTHING Last of Us 10/10. 

[h1][b] PC PORT ISSUES [/b][/h1]
Now, I would 100% recommend this game to ANYONE and EVERYONE but... the PC port is an absolute mess. I have played for 10 hours and let me list the issues for you:
⚫I have crashed 15 times so far and I am about half way through the game.
⚫I have CONSTANT FPS drops and stuttering. FPS cannot stay above 40 at times and the stuttering is constant the entire time.
(PC SPECS ARE LISTED ON MY STEAM ACCOUNT)
⚫My game occasionally freeze's here and there which results, sometimes, in a crash which makes me loose about 10 minutes of progress (playing on the hardest difficulty).
⚫Shader loading times are longer than CoD shader loading times.... wow....

[h1][b] My Verdict [/b][/h1]
I am truly heartbroken that the PC port is broken. If it did not have this many issues I would recommend the PC port version of it but if you have a PS4/PS5... just go play it there.

[h1][b] The Last of Us Part 1 PC PORT - Terrible. Not worth £50 for an unfinished broken mess of a port [/b][/h1]

text:
I purchased this game at launch and waited patiently for it to reach a playable state, which it is now in. I had about 14.5 hours of playtime registered just from the amount of time it took to rebuild shaders after patches and graphics driver updates and initial performance testing. Now I've actually completed the game because it is in what I would call a "playable" state. That being said, I wouldn't recommend it quite yet. There is still very frequent stuttering during gameplay and cutscenes throughout the entire game. There are a handful of areas that seem to have bugged performance overall, not tied to the capability of the hardware. There were occasional occurrences of the screen flicking to white, both entirely and parts of the image. Areas with lots of water are the most problematic in the game. There are some bugs with the companion AI, sometimes they just stop following you for a while. There are occasional moments of the camera going through a wall and the world disappearing, some moments where animations don't line up correctly, and some moments of music errors. 

It's playable, it generally runs well when not encountering stutter or water issues, and it's a very good looking game. It's come a long way from launch, but there's still a ways to go.

text:
Well, well, well

Somehow this game got worse over time for me. I am not speaking of the gameplay or the story but of the "optimization" Updates.
I preordered TLOU 1 and when I first started it at the release date everything went fine. I had a near bugfree experience and it was just a bet nervewrecking to wait for the Shaders to build after every update.
But then, after another update the game dind't run smoothly anymore. I lowered the graphics setting to the minimum but it still didn't get more than 5-8 fps.
This was around one and a half months ago.
3 Days ago I thought i could jump back in again and look, wether or not it got fixed. So I tried to update the game, but Steam said i dont have enough space left on my disk (I have around 200 GB left). This issue didn't stop to accure so I reinstalled the Game entirely (I have shitty internet so it took a night to download).
Today i started the game and the Shaders started to build. There was just one difference to the older shader building proccess. This time it overloaded my CPU which led to my PC restarting itself. I tried it a second time afterwards but my PC crashed again.
I find it funny that I had no issues with the game at its release but after all the updates it got unplayable.
Probably won't touch it again, sadly.

text:
Review date: 17/07/2023

Its not recommended because its 4.5/10

The game is not bad but i wouldn't say the best game as some people hype. My friends gonna hate me for this but here we go.

[b]Important note: [/b]i have never played or watched anything related to last of us previously, it may sound impossible given the game was quite popular, i stayed away to any content hoping one day i would play the game myself. And i played the game on pc. Finished it couple minutes ago. Havent played the extra scenario, not planning to.

================
[b]Visuals:[/b] graphics are amazing if you have a beast. I have 3080 rtx with i7-12700H (Laptop) thinking it would be enough, but in the lowest settings i got -60 fps most of the time(from 30-140). And yes, fans are maxed, laptop is in performance mode.

[b]Gameplay: [/b]sometimes annoying, as i played with the controller, with the weapon sway it is nearly impossible to shoot enemies.

[b]World: [/b] Because the storyline is linear, we have to follow a specific path literally. Idk how to explain it properly but I'm just running in an empty street then get to the next checkpoint, killing some guys following another path, and do it again. The models and props are good, with lots of variety but as we can't interact with anything there wasn't any reason for me to check out the surroundings.

[b]Plot: [/b]Oh boy. Let me be honest, It's not the best story, good one yes, but not the best. There are lots of time skipping and it's just random, with no information on what happened in the meantime. It's like, now we are at a dangerous place we just fought against a horde of enemies, boom, next scene *sometime later*  now we are at completely irrelevant place. don't know what happened, how we survived like its just LAZY WRITING. I understand nothing important happened but still its weird. And i didn't get surprised by any scene, most of the story felt like a cliche.

[b]Characters: [/b]They come, they say something, then they die after some scenes. All of them! Only the 2 protagonist Joel and Ellie survives. And every single character is so bloodthirsty like come on, there is only 10% population left and people kill everyone they see, even if they are not threats.

My opinion on the ending: [spoiler] Ok, even if fireflies were unethical, if the surgery was gonna cure the world, not sure if the plan was real or not, Joel acted like a total dumbass, selfish person[/spoiler]

text:
Two Part Review: Game Performance & Game Play

GAME PERFORMANCE: 
I had read the reviews and I was aware that the game was bugged pretty badly when it was first released for PC, but I was hoping that all bugs would be fixed by now; they are not! The game had graphics issues where in the cinematic scenes the characters hair would look like melted plastic strips, and Joel's facial hair would look like splashed on road tar. During the game itself, there was some shading and shadow flickering going on. Also, the scopes for the weapons where blacked out inside so that you could not view anything through them, thus rendering them unusable; I even had a game crash to deal with. I am using top of the line gaming hardware that has played every other modern day title without issue. 

GAME PLAY:
As far as the game itself, I expected far better considering all the hype associated with this game and the fact that this is one of Sony's franchise games. The game was extremely linear with a very small world. I was really shocked by the lack of content in this game for the price; even the added DLC felt like nothing more than a short collection of cut scenes. I completed the main story in about 21 hours which is far less than I have gotten out of the other big title games. Although I enjoyed the ending and found myself bonding with the character Ellie as the game progressed, the story itself is just not that inspirational or deep; just a simple case of we have to get there from here. I guess my mistake was playing Days Gone right before I played this, which is a far superior post-apocalyptic zombie type game when compared to The Last of Us.

The one thing I will give the developers props for is their attention to detail. The abandoned homes and buildings looked like real living and working environments instead of just some half empty shells with a few pieces of basic furniture thrown in like some developers take shortcuts with.

And technically speaking, the game is badly optimized... takes about 5 - 10 minutes each launch just to compile shaders over and over again, game crashes from time to time, cpu/gpu hog, even with settings at minimum... It's too bad, because when it runs, it looks great, even at minimum settings and even on a laptop with 3070 rtx.

In conclusion, if you can live with the technical problems this game has and you like basic zombie apocalypse story, The Last of Us is for you...

text:
Edit: 29th May, after the most recent patch.

This game, to put it mildly, is a complete disappointment in terms of its performance on my setup – even when forced to operate under the lowest possible settings. Despite employing a 9700k & 4070Ti configuration – a setup that just flawlessly ran Miles Morales at max settings, hitting a solid 120fps with DLS Quality – this game still sputters, stumbles, and strains, pushing my CPU to its absolute limit. Texture loading is erratic, audio sporadically crackles, and those pervasive, pesky stutters? They're still there, regardless of how long I allow everything to compile prior to play. In no uncertain terms, I can't recommend this. Do not buy this.

Original Review

I'm absolutely gutted to write this, but wow, the PC version of The Last of Us is a letdown of epic proportions. It's so sub-par in its optimisation that it's bordering on absurd. I braved the storm of negative reviews at launch and decided to give it a whirl. But man, what an unplayable mess it turned out to be.

We're talking about textures that refuse to load, stuttering visuals, and audio that crackles like a bonfire. I was really looking forward to experiencing this game; all I'd heard were glowing reviews. But I sure didn't want my first impression to be tarnished by a shoddy PC port like this.

My advice? Hold off on buying this for at least half a year, or even better, a full year. It's a sad joke, and I genuinely hope PlayStation rethinks its decision to work with Iron Galaxy. Seriously, give Nixxes a call next time, will ya? Thanks.

text:
Spoilers Below, so be warned, if you somehow haven't either played this 10 year old game yet, seen the show, or heard about it, or watched a video about it somewhere on social media.

Gameplay: overall pretty good, if illogical. If an enemy drops a loaded firearm, could Joel or Ellie pick it up and use it? This game's answer, maybe 10% of the time, the rest of the time, literally random ammo will drop, or nothing will drop, and the enemy's weapon turns into part of the scenery. This is a personal pet peeve of mine for games, and to be fair, there is usually adequate ammo if you do mostly stealth kills(free version, no shiv version).  Aiming with mouse and keyboard is easy, I assume console controller people had a much harder time with this game, all you have to do is hit headshots on even the toughest enemy, of which there are few.   Scavenging, crafting, are all pretty good for 2013, other games have surpassed this by now, but you have to realize the timeframe difference.

Story, overall, really good, right up until the end. At that point, the makers decided they want to be directors, not game makers (good job on the show by the way, up until the same scene at the end).  In a better GAME (not show, or movie) there would have been a choice at the end. Does Joel A) Believe the Fireflies and try to save humanitry? or B) Seflishly and illogically and emotionally childishly prevent the possibly LAST DOCTORS ON EARTH from taking what they need from one person to save literally the entire human race?

Of course, the player can only allow Joel to do what the directors wanted. You cannot choose option B, literally you have no choice. You cannot walk away, you cannot make Joel kill himself, you are railroaded into the foolish emotional choice that I hope leads to the death of the human race in The Last of Us Part 2, that or Part 2 ends with Ellie finally getting her fucking skull sawed open.

If you can tolerate a railroaded, illogical, fake binary choice ending, then this game may be for you.

The game has been patched up admirably as of this writing, and runs well, and looks great. I beat the main story in apparently 28 hours, but there was definitely some random walking around and searching for resources and story notes in there, this game can probably be completed in 10-12 hours if you truly hustle.

I realize it's just a video game(and now a show, of course) but this kind of selfish, illogical thinking being continually praised is literally bad for the human race, in real life.  Of course it's a Trolley Problem in game format, but most people don't realize the point of the Trolley Problem is to point out how ludicrous reducing a situation to one of two outcomes really is.  If you must be railroaded at the end, then AT LEAST do the video game option of letting the player ACTUALLY CHOOSE THE OUTCOME.   Shout out to the "Should have let Ellie Die" crew, all dozen of us. :)

Now I need to go make a mod that allows Joel to just walk away at the end, and let Ellie die.

text:
I find it fascinating how poor the port for this is currently. They literally had the perfect example of good port with God Of War and yet they still messed it up? How is this possible?
Anyway, a friend of mine owned this game so I had the opportunity to try out barely enough to see that it legitimately does not work.
I might be on the most entry-level gaming laptop out there (GTX 1650Ti 4GB, Ryzen 7 4800H), but I can play games like Dead Space Remake, Battlefield V, Control, Mafia: Definitive Edition, Modern Warfare 2 (the new one), all RE Engine Resident Evil games, Far Cry 6 and so on without too much of a hitch. This pile of garbage can barely run on 720p FSR Performance Lowest Settings. 

I would've rather had them release this game on PC back in 2014 with the Remaster instead of having us wait for this... *thing*. Atleast even if that port was garbage, PCs/gaming laptops will get so good that they would be running it perfectly fine, now (look at GTA IV).

And if they haven't had enough fuel to the fire, remember how I said I managed to play because my friend owned the game? Yeah, they had the *nerve* to disable Family Sharing, so I can't play anymore.
Why? It's not a multiplayer game (they removed Factions), it's all singleplayer and there's no other reason to disable family sharing other than to piss more people off, or to expect people to buy into it and get scammed by the poor performance of the port. Dead Space Remake doesn't do this, so why? There's so many examples of good choices in this industry, literally just look left and right, fellas. Look. Left. And. Right.

What a disgrace.

text:
I am an age-old gamer with my gaming history going back to my Atari 2600 bought by my parents as a gift for having done well in my 4th-grade exams back in 1985. I hardly write reviews probably because am growing old and lack time nowadays even to finish games. My Steam account is as old as Steam itself downloaded as DRM that came with Half-Life 2 CD back in 2004. I had to post my thoughts on The Last Of Us Part 1 cause am having a blast playing this on my PC with the latest patch. Granted I consider myself lucky as I have a high-end PC and this may not be the case with other configs. 

Having played around 60% of the game back in 2013 on my PS3, I was eager to go back to it and finish it sometime. When the news was out that it was coming out on PC, I was eagerly waiting for its release but was disappointed when I saw all the negative reviews on performance, bugs and crashes.  I waited for a few patches, took the risk and bought it after the release of the 1.0.5 patch. On my high-end PC running an RTX 4090, Intel i9 13900K, 128GB of DDR5 memory, I haven’t had a single crash after 11.6 hrs of gameplay with the 1.05 patch. Frame rate varies between 80-105 on the highest settings in 4K. Shaders took exactly 7 min in initial loading. The only 1 bug I encountered was when a brief cut scene started looping and restarting the last checkpoint fixed it. 

 As for the game itself, despite somewhat outdated gameplay (aged like fine wine) it still is one of the best video games that exists.

Update July 28th '23: Multiple crashes to desktop with patches 1.0 and 1.1. Am changing my review to negative. I finished the game enduring multiple crashes which spoilt the experience for me.

Figured I'd try this game out on PC, even after reading the reviews, talking to people who have it, and looking up the game running on specs similar to mine.

I can say that the reviews were true and the game is a blatant spit in the face to consumers. This game ran like crap and constantly crashed when it first came out. As of May 11, the game has received a few performance patches and it still crashes but runs a tad better. I got my first crash after I was nearly done sneaking past clickers and that was when I decided to request a refund. 85% of my hours in this game are logged waiting for shader optimizations as well, maybe they make it slow on purpose to reduce the likelihood of refunds?

Games releasing in this state shouldn't be acceptable and we as gamers have come to normalize this bs behavior from so many developers and I won't deal with it any longer. I miss the days where games HAD to be stable on release due to lack of internet and patches easily being pushed, but now it's normalized to release a pile of vomit title then fix it later which is a shame. I hope more people hold these trash developers with their low effort ethics and QA accountable.

text:
I don't know how many marketing persons they hired to chant the "greatest narrative" of this game, but it is a lie. The prerequisite of "the greatest narrative" is that there is a narrative at first place. But there is no valid narrative in this game. At the end of the day, you won't know anything about the cataclysm: why, how, when; you won't know anything about Ellie: where, what, who; you won't know anything more about Jole except what you learn at the opening scene; you won't get to know Firefly either. Hey, where are the " narratives"? What does it narrate on earth?

 The "narrative" (whatever it is, let's call it this way, for now)has a lot of loose ends; everyone with wits will doubt the validation of such a bizarre story that isn't intuitive at all. In a word, the premise is so unconvincing that players have enough reason to question the possibility of its existence. The poor story also fails to build up characters as well because of the information scarcity; for example, you still barely know Ellie at the end of the game. Thus, the only thing left in this game is unnecessary violence --- senseless violence, how violent is it? Only two significant roles, besides JO and Ellie, are spared in this game. 

 The game causes severe motion sickness. The gameplay is also quite dull and repetitive: wiping out all enemies in a stage and then moving to the next one that resembles others. This game has no combat freedom; everything is highly deliberated, including routes, weapons, ammunition, and status(forced injurious and captures). So, you can "choose" only from one of the solutions/approaches prepared by devs to play through. 

It's frustrating that I was misguided by the hype; after all, Sony is a company that can afford it. But it indeed deteriorates its original reputation.

text:
Do not play this game.

I'm sure that The Last of Us was great on Playstation. I wish I could have experienced it like that, but I'm not about to buy a PS3 just to play it. The story is great and I wish I could enjoy it. The experience on PC, however, is abysmal.

I could write a whole essay on the graphical bugs alone. Textures clipping, turning black, the scope being blocked so you can't use it, character's hair turning into weird squares, the list goes on and on. And these aren't one-off issues, they are constant. I was experiencing two or three visual bugs at a time throughout every play session.

Then there are the gameplay bugs. Characters will get stuck on objects, stuck on nothing, decide to not move objects that they are supposed to move, and more! Enemies will take cover behind absolutely nothing at all. Sometimes they track you through walls like Superman, and other times they roleplay as Hellen Keller, ignoring you as you take down their friends right in front of their faces.

Sometimes the game will crash during a shootout. Sometimes it crashes during exploration. Sometimes it crashes on startup. Very rarely, the game doesn't crash at all.

You can shoot your gun by clicking on menu options, which is an interesting design choice. As is the fact that Joel seems intent on pulling out the molotov at every opportunity. Craft an item? Molotov! Throw a brick? Molotov! Out of ammo? Molotov! He sure does love arson.

Also, the game runs like I'm trying to run Crysis on a PSP, but I'm trying to run a remake of a ten year old game on a modern mid-end system, ON LOW SETTINGS.

This is unacceptable. Do not play this game, do not let anyone you care about play this game. Shame on you, Naughty Dog.

text:
At launch the overall experience was garbo; low fps, stuttering, crashes etc etc. Easily the worst PC port I have ever played, Iron Galaxy should be ashamed and so on. Despite this, my overall experience with TLOU Part 1 has been positive. The game itself is one of the best I have ever played, alongside The Witcher 3 and Uncharted 4, and it's one of the few single player games that I feel inclined to replay. Despite this, I can't reccomend you support ND by purchasing the game full price from the Steam store.

PROS:
- Extremely immersive world
- Graphics are *chefs kiss*
- The story is genuinely well written and well paced for the most part, despite being a little short imo
- Voice acting and facial animations are top tier, probably the best I've come across

CONS:
- Performance is still not great, despite the numerous patches since launch
- Overall gameplay is pretty linear, emphasis on stealth/picking your battles, traversing terrain using your partner etc
- NDs overall attitude to PC market. No matter how much I enjoyed the actual overall experience, I can't accept the blatant disregard ND have had for their PC fanbase, and for that reason I can't give the game a positive review.

text:
While I haven't experienced some of the problems others have mentioned, there is something to be said about the games optimisation.

For reference I'm playing this on an I5 12600K and an RTX 4080. I get an average of about 80-90fps with DLSS off at 1440p, which isn't bad compared to some of the other reviews I've seen on here.

But think about that in the context of other demanding or recent games - I can get nearly 200FPS in returnal with Raytracing on using DLSS and Frame Generation, and 130-140 with Frame Generation off. I can get 150FPS in Cyberpunk (fuggin' Cyberpunk!) with all Raytracing besides path-tracing and with DLSS and FG on.

In Last of Us Part 1, DLSS actually [i]makes the framerate worse[/i], dragging it down to 70-80fps.

On the bright side if you're on team red and have a 7900XTX your experience will be exactly the same, getting about 80-90fps with FSR on - but when you consider there's no raytracing in this game, on paper the XTX should be outpacing the 4080 with rasterization and it really doesn't, at least not in my experience testing between the two GPU's.

It's a shame because the games reputation for being a modern great is well deserved, but they fumbled this port hard. You might shudder when you see Iron Galaxy (notorious for the crappy Arkham Knight PC port) helped port the game to PC but various sources around the internet are saying their involvement was minimal, and the vast majority of the port work was handled by Naughty Dog themselves.

For me personally, I don't care who's to blame, I just want them to fix the damn thing. If you're reading this wondering whether to pick the game up: wishlist it and keep an eye on patches and updates. If you've got a 4080 or a 7900XT/XTX and are happy to lock the framerate to 60 you'll be happy. If you're running something older or with less power, or are wanting to push your rig to try and throw out 120fps+, cross your fingers they are going to do something about it and come back later.

text:
As mixed isn't an option, I'm going with negative because yes, it's better than it was at launch. But unless you have a high end Nvidia GPU (or a very high end AMD one that won't have to rely on the subpar FSR2 implementation), the PS5 will provide a better experience. If you are at all interested, wait, wait for a sale at the earliest. The only reason why this is in my library is because I got it for literally free with my PC, it was cheaper than picking up an old PS4 to play the original remaster.

From my first hour, I had no VRAM issues, but you should expect that from having a 16gb card. I did have CPU performance issues that meant that I couldn't have a smooth experience above 60fps, and I wouldn't be surprised if I could get drops under that in more data streaming intensive areas. What was even more shocking was the lengthy loading times, like I decided to restart the game after several minutes of no progress on a fucking PCIe SSD. Even had a few graphical glitches, nothing a settings tweak or two didn't revert, but I literally just started the game and had them.

So seriously, I have had good luck with this version, and still had issues. Please exercise some goddamn patience and wait before burning your parents money on this. We shouldn't be supporting companies for rushing and crunching their devs to a pulp, then continuing to do so post launch under the stress of the public eye. I can understand that alot of the issues come from just it being a PS5 title, itl naturally be hard to run and hungry on memory and resources. But many signs show it just being rushed onto PC, like the file formats being designed for PS5 and harder to decompress on PC. So more importantly of all, give the fucking devs some time to fix this instead of complaining they didn't radically fix all the issues in one patch. Because of upper management bullocks, they now have to work under the ire of the public. I hope that one day I can delete this review and replace it with a positive one.

text: POST MAY 9TH UPDATE: I'M FINALLY ABLE TO PLAY. FOR SOME REASON THAT IS AN ACHIEVEMENT. I UNDERCLOCKED my i9-13900K (stock it should be able to boost to 5.8 on P-core with sufficient cooling but LOL GOOD LUCK) I had it overclocked from 5.5 static (just what it would reach with my cooling solution; liquid AIO) to 5.8 static on cores 0-3 (boosting to 5.8 in heavier loads), and 5.7 on cores 4-7, boosting to 5.8 in heavier loads. E-cores I left at 4.3Ghz since they are mostly meant fore background tasks on the desktop and don't affect games that don't utilize more than 8 cores. Also to keep the processor a little cooler :P But I had to revert back to complete stock/safe core values of 5.5 on cores 0-7 and no voltage offset and the game finally works. I also had my RTX 4070TI overclocked slightly but had to axe that aswell, AND my intel XMP memory overclock in the bios had to go as well. The game looks beautiful, apart from TAA you can't turn off (when you move it slightly blurs stuff) There's a few shadow and effects settings you can tune with almost no noticeable difference in picture quality to help improve stability and performance. That being said, there is a constant fps dip every few second of around 7-10 fps for some reason, and when it dips to around 60 fps, it is NOTICEABLY choppy. Granted, I'm playing it with almost everything maxed out and raytracing pretty much maxed as well and I get and average of around 75 fps. It goes up to and maintains 100+ fps indoors but outside it's kinda all over the place; anywhere from 65-95 fps. It's pretty rough. And I'm definitely not picky when I say that 100+ fps gameplay is OBJECTIVELY BETTER THAN 60 locked. Aiming is easier, it's more pleasant to look at, it feels more responsive; especially on mouse and keyboard. I'll still play for the story and the atmosphere but IF YOU DO NOT HAVE MY SAME RIG OR SIMILAR SPECS AND WANT THE GAME TO LOOK GOOD AND PLAY WELL, DO NOT BUY YET AND WAIT FOR MORE PATCHES.

keywords: story, last, also, character, gameplay, feel, instead, present, hype, find
text:
I mean, I love the game itself a lot, but unfortunately the experience wasn't great. It had my PC begging for mercy. It crashed a grand total of 6 or 7 times. Even though my graphics card isn't amazing,  my PC is still above the recommended system requirements in all categories and additionally I lowered the games' graphics a lot in hopes would run better, but i still had the same issue. Not to mention the FPS ranged from below average to staggeringly low, the shaders took at least an hour to load (when the game crashed/got updated I had to reload them!), and the environment textures were still sometimes buggy and weird. Very frustrating. It was definitely improved after the update but still, I've no clue why any testers would think "Hm yes, this works well enough to satisfy our players". A bad port of a great game.
 
The positives:
Cutscenes looked incredible. When they had loaded properly, the environments were very detailed and immersive - beautiful or disturbing depending on where you are. 
Looking at the remnants of people's homes and lives, piecing together their stories and reading about all of the premature deaths and desperate measures the people may have had to take to try and survive in the artifact notes was suitably haunting.
The initial outbreak/plane crash/you-know-what sequence is still as scary and devastating as ever... well, as is the rest of the game.
Excellent, complex cast of characters you can't help but empathise with and root for despite their flaws (most of them, anyway), and when the gameplay itself is uninterrupted by crashes it's very enjoyable. Audio is perfect, no complaints.

I'm unsure whether to say I recommend it or not because I do love all the story aspects of the game and I'm so pleased I finally got to play it, it's just disappointing it's in such a state.

If you have money and patience to spare, or NASA has cleared you to borrow one of their old computers then sure, buy it, but otherwise i'd recommend waiting until the issues get fixed because currently you will likely be disappointed and frustrated.

It has been 1 month since it released with lots of issues, but after multiple patches and GPU driver updates, I can definitively say that it is now

Please Wait...

Please Wait...

Please Wait...

Please Wait...

A really big disappointment on PC.

Despite the gameplay showing its age, the story is incredibly cinematic as it unfolds from gameplay to cutscenes. This version is also a rollercoaster ride of emotions, but not in the same way as the console version. The annoyances of the amount of loading encountered go from mildly inconvenient to frustrating which ultimately turns this masterpiece into an incredibly disheartening experience (but not because of the story). Sound crackling issues, cutscene audio desyncing and black screens (seemingly infinite loading without indicators?) are other remaining problems.

Hopefully this version gets properly fixed in the future, preferably before we really become The Last of Us (to experience this game).

Sadly, this game is not in a playable state as of now. (Yes, my rig is up to specs.) 
Between frequent crashes during startup, and further crashes during simple things, like adjusting the language or brightness, even before the shader compilation (which does not really take that long), it is not stable.

All in all, the experience is that of a beta-tester, but given the pricetag of 60 Euros I cannot recommend the game at this point. 

Anyone wondering whether to buy: Wait a few moths. They regularly update the game with large patches of up to 25 GBs. It will probably be in a playable state by then.

All the hidden items are just the same thing over and over, use a shiv to open a door... You can break some car windows, but don't bother, there is never anything inside. You basically just walk through the game repeating the same scenario- kill clickers, boost ellie onto a ledge so she can drop a ladder or open a door, kill bandits, swim a pallet over to ellie, kill more clickers.. if you take even a moment to explore the path, the game will start offering you hints.. the end.  Overall, enjoyed it enough, but didn't feel it was very creative and not challenging in a strategic sense. Felt like I should have been a paid tester with all the glitches and "shader building".  Why release a game if it isn't ready??   4/10
