text:
Updated review 17/07/23

Following a number of patches since my last review the game is in a much more playable state and I am seeing hardly any graphical glitches. FINALLY!!!!
Game stability and frame rate seems a lot better too but shader compilation still takes an age on my RTX2070. 

If you were holding off on buying the game because of all the issues then I would say that now is a good time to buy it.


====ORIGINAL REVIEW=====
Abysmal is the only word to describe this port.

Played this title on the PS3 and PS4 and absolutely loved it and was really looking forward to playing it again on the PC but dear god it is awful.

I cannot get a consistent frame rate at all.

Sometimes the graphics look good but then other times it seems that some rendering has broken and things like hair look like clay.

vSync seems to decide to turn itself off even though it is set to 'on' in the settings.

The list of issue goes on and this is after the latest patch which required another two hour shader recompilation.

All involved in this port should hang their heads in shame.

text:
So this game in its original form has been around for a while now. I remember when I was first introduced to it, thinking “this one seems right up my ally”. A post apocalyptic game in modern U.S settings? Sign me up! Alas, it was a PS exclusive. I’ve been part of the PC gaming master race for most of my life, and I’m not as young as I used to be. Last time I had a console, it was a PS2, back in the day. But the PC has always been my platform. Ever since the glory days of the CGI. The variety of games was second to none, and besides, aiming with a controller seemed to be an impossible feat. Not to talk about first person shooters. 

So, every couple of years, when I could rarely afford it, I bought a flashy new gaming PC. Those grand PS exclusives kept on coming out respectively, but good news - a decent chunk of them were starting to port to the PC as well! 
Some of these ports were really good. I enjoyed them. Games like God of War, Days Gone, even Horizon Zero Dawn, eventually. However, a lot of those releases - in the modern tradition of broken ports and games releases overall - were not. Basically, you paid a lot of money for a broken product.   

Then, finally, The Last of US came out to PC. Unfortunately, and not very surprisingly, It was also one big mess of a release. I read carefully the reviews describing various crashes and performance issues, and the oh very famous “wait for a patch” punchline. So I did. I’ve waited for it to be patched. I’m a veteran PC gamer, after all. I know the drill. Then, after a patch or two, I bought it. Knowing that there’s a considerable chance I might regret it. And I did. Hogwarts Legacy, The Last of Us, and now also Jedi: Survivor. What is the point of investing so much money in a lean mean gaming machine, if it won’t run any of these games. Poor ports and optimizations, be the reason as it may - enough is enough. 

So I bought a PS5. The console itself was cheaper than just my GPU, in my mean gaming machine. Aiming with a controller is still a pain, but the best part is, I know that now I can play all of these games without worrying about throwing money into the bin. Without purchasing another shady port, only to sit up all night in forums, fiddling with the settings and try to optimise that piece of garbage on my own. You don’t need a 4,000$ worth of rig, just to play Stardew Valley.

text:
Imagine buying a car and in addition to the first time you start it, every time a software update is available, you have to "warm up" the car by letting the motor idle for approximately one hour before being able to drive. Imagine on top of that, that without said software updates, your car runs like crap (or not at all). Further imagine that said software updates are available every other day. Sounds absurd? Sums up the experience pretty well..  
This is what the pinnacle of pc gaming looks like nowerdays. Whomever came up with this technical approach is either purposefully trolling the customers or a complete moron (and yes, i understand the technical aspects of what is going on, but this is a technical dead end). 
There are a lot of games that use this approach out there now, but TLOU has perfected this approach to the point where you will basically spend ALL of your logged time with the "game" precompiling shaders (of my 7h, i actually managed to play about 15min), in fact, the games title and description should be changed "The last of precompiling shaders" in order to not misleading potential buyers.

text:
At the moment, I cannot recommend the game due to technical issues. There are recurring display problems, particularly in relation to an annoyance where the characters' hair suddenly looks like it was imported from Minecraft. This seems to be related to the compiled shaders because it often works after recompilation, but only for 1-3 sessions before the error reappears.

Overall, it seems like a great game because when it runs smoothly without crashing, which happens quite often, it creates a great atmosphere, and the graphics are very attractive. However, I will wait to continue playing the game until the issues are fixed to avoid spoiling the experience. I will definitely revisit the game once it is resolved.

Therefore, I cannot recommend "The Last Of Us" in its current state due to the technical issues.

text:
As of April 25th I can confirm this game still has a lot of issues and its just not optimized at all.

My setup: RTX 3080ti, AMD Ryzen 7 5800x, 32 GB of RAM and playing at 1440p.

Even though I have not come across any crashes yet, the performance is absolutely terrible, framerate drops from 110fps to 40fps in the first sections of the game and then it struggles to even get past 60fps later on on High settings, I also tried playing on Ultra and High and the GPU and CPU usage remains the same (GPU at 100% and CPU at 90%), also the performance is so unstable on both that I can't even tell which settings run better.

Performance aside, Naughty Dog, Sony and everybody involved in this should be ashamed of themselves, not only is this a terrible attempt at a PC Port, but this game was advertised as a next-gen Remake "rebuilt from the ground up" and it also fails miserably at that, in comparison, on Ultra settings this game looks nowhere near as good as other next gen games, take Resident Evil 4 Remake for example, which looks stunning and runs smoothly at 165fps at almost max settings, hell, even Horizon Zero Dawn looks and runs way better on PC, but playing this Last of Us "Remake" feels exactly like playing a PS4 game, textures, lights, animations, shadows, reflections, everything looks so outdated that its just laughable. 

I hadn't played this game before so that's why I decided to give it a try, but if you already own this game then this is the kind of "remakes" that you should avoid, there's definitely nothing "next-gen" about this cash grab of a "remake".

text:
Edit:   After a good bit of time for Dev team to work on trying to fix this thing I thought I'd update my review.  
I wanted to like this thing.   After upgrading to a 40 series GPU I thought I'd give this thing one more try.  I only had 40 mins or so of play time, and most of that was shader compilation.   
Well anyhow, this game is in a better state than it was.   But not enough I'm afraid.  It is a very beautiful game, they have really done a great job with the visuals in this game.   And the gameplay, although it does feel a bit dated, it's not terrible.  Aside from the startup crashes, which still occur randomly for me at 50% of the time, other wise the game had been running ok.   In trying to shorten the shader pre-compliation times, they ended adding more stutter back into the game, and seemingly more instability.   After playing about 12 hours into this, enough time to get invested in the story, I was willing to look past the rough edges.   But after reaching a checkpoint in some watery tunnel, I am officially stuck, and can go no further.   As soon as I load into the game now, it starts me in an underwater cut scene, and as soon as I grab Ellie, it hard locks, every time.   I've tried moving back to previous state, etc..., and I cannot get past that point.   That was the breaking point for me.   I'm uninstalling this thing for the last time.   If this long after launch, they cannot fix the stability of this, well I'm just done.   My review still stands.   Stay far away from this train wreck.  For what it's worth here are my system specs.   Ryzen 7700X, Asrock B650M mobo, 32 GB DDR5-6000,  Samsung 980 Pro 1TB/PNY CS3140 2TB,  MSI Gaming X Trio 4070,  Deepcool 280mm AIO.  Original review starts below:

As soon as this loads up, the characters look like some kind of abortion of ugly graphics that don't render properly, long shader build times, what can I say that hasn't already been said.   If you own a 30 series Nvidia card, don't even bother with this.   Either Iron Galaxy is so incompetent that they can't fix this, or they aren't willing too.   Save your money, buy literally anything else.

text:
This is one of the worst PC ports I have ever played sadly. The game is not well optimised, even with low settings the game performs poorly. I am able to play other new games without these issues and my specs are in excess of the recommended requirements, yet running the game at high settings will max out the resources to an unacceptable level.

Also I don't understand why it needs to build shaders when first starting. I've never seen this on a normal PC game, only emulators. Why is this necessary on a modern PC game?

I did not enjoy the gameplay either. The gameplay is constantly interrupted by unskippable scripted events which take away control from the player, with occasional tedious quick time events. The first hour of the game is completely on-rails, with many forced walking segments and unskippable cutscenes. This makes repeat play throughs very long and boring.

The encounter sections are OK, however, often the game refuses to progress until all the enemies are killed, rather than give the player the choice to sneak or run past them.

The game is also very unbalanced on higher difficulties. Enemies may fail to drop ammo even if you DON'T HAVE ANY. The AI also cheats as they know your exact position without seeing where you went. Enemies will also randomly kill you when you punch/melee them even though you struck first.

I've also never managed to complete a full play through of the game without at least two crashes. I know other people who have experienced the same issue so it's not just me.

The story is OK I suppose, although if you're not invested in the story (I wasn't) then there's not really much for you here.

Good things to say, the checkpoints are fair for the most part. The speedrun timer is useful but you still have many unskippable cutscenes and scripted events which makes it an absolute slog to try and speedrun the game.

So why did I play it for over 100 hours? A friend wanted to race the game and told me the game was awesome. This turned out not to be the case. So I deliberately grinded the game to ensure that I would have a good chance of winning the race and taking vengeance for having to grind the game in the first place. I uninstalled it immediately after the race was over.

If you like the idea of this game and you're thinking of purchasing it, I would recommend getting Uncharted instead.

text:
Let me first start with this: I only post this review because The Last Of Us really is important to me and it makes me angry and sad that they somehow released this great game in this absolute horrendous state.
I played it first when it released on PS3, then I bought the remaster on PS4 and now I bought it on PC. With the state it is now, I cannot recommend it to anyone that wants to have smooth gameplay or a stable framerate. 

Usually I really want to have smooth gameplay but I forced myself to play the game and even had some fun. But every time there is an update or files are corrupted (which happened two times for me for no reason at all) you have to build shaders all over again, for almost an hour, if not even longer. 
There is almost constant stuttering and no matter on which settings or even resolution I tried playing, this game was just a hot pile of garbage performance wise. Extreme framedrops from 50fps to 30~ish out of nowhere, most of the time I had around 40-45 FPS when playing. 

Once they fix up the broken performance of this game, I will change my review to a positive one, but not in this state. Please Naughty Dog, don't partner up with Iron Galaxy anymore. They already brought a shitty PC port of Batman Arkham Knight and Uncharted to steam and I am pretty sure they don't give two cents about their clientele, as we can see by the aformentioned already bad ports on PC.

Gameplay and graphics arent all that. TLOU2 had better gameplay and graphics. I am not sure why prone, melee and dodge were not included in this game. Enemies are the same. TLOU2 had much better variety in enemy design. 

I would not recommend this game to anyone.

text:
I absolutely love The Last Of Us, I've played The Last Of Us Remaster on the PS4 and loved it, then I played The Last Of Us Part 2 and loved it despite its problem. When it was announced The Last Of Us Part 1 was coming to PC I got so exited, I then waited a few months and the day before it was released I bought and preloaded it. The next day when I got home from school I "unpacked" it and started playing. I then got stutter after stutter, to be frank a buggy fucking mess, but I pushed through, I beat the game and Left Behind. I then began a journey of 100%, the main story went extremely smooth and I ran into no issues when 100% it. Then Left Behind, I couldn't 100% without a crash, during the third chapter of Left Behind two stalkers are electrocuted, right after this my game freezes then crashes, I tried multiple things to fix this and had no luck, I had to give myself the achievement in order for it to be 100%. This bug is now fixed, but this still tarnished my view of this shitty port, I do not blame Naughty Dog for this but whoever they hired to port this masterpiece. So for Naughty Dog, whoever you hire to port your games, make sure they aren't known to port games in the shittiest way possible.

TLDR: Naughty Dog hired a shit port company which prevented me from 100% the game legitimately

Edit: I made the original review on April 23rd, and as of June 13th this game is still getting patched over 2 1/2 months after launch, and these patches are big, the newest one is 25 GBs, what a shit show

Forget it. Even with 4090 and 13700k, you can't get The Last of Us to run smoothly.

Keep waiting.

text:
The game is great...probably. The times I've been able to play it between crashes have been great but since it crashes frequently it's impossible to separate the quality of the game from the quality of the experience playing it, which has been a nightmare. I have tried every fix that has been suggested and nothing has helped. My system is better than the recommended setup and still apparently not good enough to run this game cleanly. To make matters worse Steam knows how bad the port is (they can read reviews same as everyone else) but still refuses to give me a refund because I've played the game for too many hours. Steam has a different definition of "playing" than i do. For example, I exceeded the number of played hours just in the time i spent waiting for shaders to build when I had to reinstall the game multiple times. Leaving the game running while i go and do my grocery shopping, coming back and still finding the shaders at 85% is not "playing" anything. It would be worth the wait if after all the time the game played smoothly, but it doesn't. I tried making my peace with the crashing but everyone has limits. A great game ruined by a trash port. Pre-ordering this game before the reviews were in was an expensive mistake I will never make with Steam again. It's too late for me; save yourselves!

Edit: Steam asked if I wanted to edit my review since I "played" the game for more hours. Ok, sure. After trying every single fix suggested online and several patches and an update from AMD specifically to handle this terrible port i will say it has upgraded from a complete trash fire to "playable" It's not great, it's still a memory hog and i had to move it to it's own SSD just to make the load times bearable (because even though the recommendation was 100GB  available it needed five times that just to load in less than a minute and not stutter at every checkpoint). So the game was bearable enough that I was able to finish it (logging in roughly three times as many hours as an average playthrough on a PS4). No I still don't recommend it, certainly not for the amount I paid for it. If down the road you see it on sale for $10-15, it's a good enough game to be worth the rough ride, but it was nowhere near ready to be released and even now is still not worth what they had the gall to charge.

🎀This is the worst PC porting, the point is that it's an exclusive, not just multiplatform game, and it should have been much better taken care of than it is; the porting work is absolutely pitiful on the technical side, and this is due to poor skills and the bad choice of wanting to entrust the conversion work to Iron Galaxy which is the worst in this field, instead of Nixxes.
If I have to make a comparison with titles that use much heavier engines, like Unreal Engine 5, I could take as an example Banisher or Lords of the Fallen which at maximum details achieve excellent performance and with excellent details; in The Last of Us it's not like that because this game absorbs an enormous amount of resources unnecessarily and has never been patched because the foundations are broken and irreparable, you can't fix something that is damaged at its core, because dev's wanted to save money on conversion.

🎀Imagine having to reach only 80 miles per hour with a Ferrari with the handbrake on; I don't think a Ferrari is necessary to reach such a low speed. But this game requires high-end hardware without any sense and it will be your hardware that has to compensate for the development mistakes.
Well done, you've reached the low 80 miles with your useless RTX4090 2000+ dollars card and you boast about it!? 
But you've been fooled/scammed twice!
The forum section regarding patches is closed to user comments, so you can't even expose what doesn't work or what should be corrected. Obviously, it's closed on purpose to avoid useless complaints; but it's not a good sign nor a good practice for marketing. Technical support for this game has long been abandoned.
https://steamcommunity.com/app/1888930/eventcomments/

The Last of US is not worth the full price at which it is sold and what has been said has nothing to do with the type of game or the storyline.

The best choice Sony has ever made is to entrust Nixxes (company purchased by Sony specifically for PC porting) with the conversion work for Horizon Forbidden West and for future PC porting, cutting off Iron Galaxy from everything and an excellent job has come out, Horizon looks like a native PC version, it doesn't look like a port and this should be an example.

text: Almost a month on from release and the game is still essentially unplayable. It has taken so long for controller compatibility to work and now that it finally does, using a controller seems to cause significant framerate drops no matter the graphical settings. When attempting to use keyboard and mouse instead, framerate recovers completely, but I have encountered the problem that the keyboard seems to have significant input lag (between 5-10s between pressing a key and the action happening on screen) for several minutes after finishing a cutscene. The last of us is an incredible game but this PC port is shockingly poor quality. I cannot recommend the game to anyone until its many issues are fixed.

text:
I played this game multiple times on Playstation and loved it.  Despite reading the predominately negative reviews I'm one of those schmucks that still willingly gave these clowns my money.  I figured if I fell in the seemingly 40% or so of people that can run this with little to no issues it was worth the gamble, and my PC more than meets the requirements.  

On launch shaders "only" took 45 minutes to load instead of the commonly cited 2 hours - the fact that I'm even chalking this up to a win is ridiculous.  Beginning of the prologue playing as Joel's daughter was totally playable, not perfect performance but thoroughly playable.  Heck, I'm in the 40% club!

Wrong.  As soon as we get to Joel carrying the daughter in a more graphically demanding environment I drop to about 2 fps.  Yeah.  2.  Even getting to the menu to quit (instead of alt+f4) is difficult, and I'm still running at 2 fps in the menu, the heck is that? 

It's been six days since the last patch - which focused on audio fixes (LOL).  I'm beginning to doubt there's any intention to fix this disaster.  It would almost be hilarious if it hadn't cost me $60.  Moral of the story: don't be me.  Don't buy.

text: It makes me sad to leave this review. I was so looking forward to playing this game, but with the virtually unplayable nature of this port, I am scared to launch the game. I don't want the experience of playing the game for the first time (seen a few play throughs and watched the HBO series several times) to be tarnished by the issues and take away from the story. I also want the developers to know, even if it does work fine for myself and a few others, a port as bad as it has been reported should not have been released in its current state. The fans deserve better since this is the first time non playstation players are accessing this game. It's been what? 10 years since the game first came out? I understand Part II and other projects have happened in the meantime, but this shouldn't have been what we are left with. I will be waiting until the game is finally at a state fair and up to the quality the players expect and that the developers will be proud of. It makes me sad to see the reputation go to waste.

text:
The game is unplayable and crashes constantly. 
I am very disappointed, as I was super excited to play and experience this game for the first time. The system requirements listed on Steam seem to be wrong, cause I should in theory have a computer that should be able to run this game. However, the game just crashes constantly. For the first 4-5 hours ish, the game ran ok (not perfectly), but after that, I couldn't play for more than 5-10 minutes at the time before it crashed. And this was on the lowest settings possible. 
I've tried to ask Steam for a refund twice now but they keep declining it since "it's been played for more than two hours." This is one of the worst pc remakes/releases in history and I wish Steam could take some accountability for that and offer refunds. It seems illegal in my opinion to release a game in such poor shape with terrible to little optimization. 

If a supercomputer is what is required to play this game, that should have been listed on the Steam site.

text:
Without a doubt, the game itself is a fantastic experience, and I enjoyed every minute of it. In spite of this, the PC port is a shame for Naughty Dog, Iron Galaxy, Mr. Druckmann, and anyone else who contributed to this port, and the main blame should rest with Sony who approved the release.

In this situation, a positive review of this game would be disappointing to other companies that strive to give the PC community what they really deserve with their optimized port.

>> The funny thing is that Sony actually accuses Microsoft that if they acquire Activision-Blizzard, the Call of Duty port on the PlayStation would be a worse version of the game. Apparently, they are using the same strategy with this PC port, as their most iconic and popular game, to indirectly tell players to buy a PlayStation if they do not want to deal with such a port!

text:
Looks amazing.  Plays awful.  I don't know about mouse and keyboard but controller feels like you're playing old school grand theft auto.  Reload and shoot are both trigger so there is what I can only assume is intentional latency there.  Not sure if it's to punish the player for using ammo to get them to conserve ammo or what but for a AAA game that takes 75+gb storage just to install it just Feels bad.  
If you're into story games that have less to do with playing and more to do with watching you may love this game.  But if not as far as I can tell you could dumb down the graphics to run on 10 year old hardware and your experience would be pretty much comparable.  It's a bloated installation for no other reason than it looks nice and I built a capable system to play games that make me feel like a bad ass not chose your own adventure 4k movies. Not sure if it's just a bad port or a remastered old game but considering it was designed to run on hardware not so different than mine I'm not sure.  Free game with my graphics card.  Not too upset.  But I'm three hours in and I'm prollly going to uninstall.

text:
I really wish I didn't have to post this as a negative review, but, here we are. It's no secret that this PC port was SERIOUSLY fucked over by something or the other. I'm not privy to all of the behind the scenes nonsense that may have screwed it over, but, I can sure talk about the results.

The game is BEATABLE - but performance hitches are heavy, almost to the point of a literal slideshow (I was checking my phone during hitches, talking to my friends over discord. This was with TLOU being the one big program I had running). Outside of those, the game runs at a muddy, but playable 30-50 FPS at most times, which checks out, since my PC falls below min specs.

The game plays shockingly well with KBM, and thanks to a recent update, you now no longer have to use more than the 1-4 keys to use the weapon cross, which is a personal saving grace IMHO. I've always liked cross-style favorites selections rather than hotbars because of this. If you've played it on playstation, it feels even better here with more precise control input, and the story is still great. Not the "greatest video game story ever," like some marketers would like to pretend, but it's a nice, refreshingly real feeling take on the wolf and cub story.

I wish I could recommend it, but right now, it's really just not there yet. I'll update this review if it changes. Naughty Dog and IG have been pushing out patches that have noticably boosted performance since launch, which leaves me hopeful.

text:
This game is big disappointment for me. I'm not talking about whether the game crashes or not, I'm not talking about the hardware requirements or how the game was ported to PC. I'm talking exclusively about the game itself.

It's probably because I had totally different expectations.
Audio-visually, the game is truly phenomenal.

However, I don't understand how people here can write that the gameplay is equally phenomenal. What is so great about a game that is strictly linear? The game is divided into segments, and the essence of each segment is "get from point A to point B, using a straight path", without any choice. Ok, to get to point B, you have to kill a certain amount of freaks and/or soldiers and possibly move a certain object to the appropriate place - to be able to climb, descend or jump over something.

Simply put, the concept of the game is too simple, linear, one-dimensional, moron-friendly and as such - the game is totally uninteresting to me, it doesn't pull me to play further because it's not challenging (I'm not talking about the difficulty).

So, when we are speaking about gameplay - just compare it with Dying Light 1 & 2, Days Gone or Resident Evil. It is probably visually ahead of the mentioned ones, but gameplay (from my personal point of view) is incomparably worse.

Who cares about the visual impression - any recommendation for the game.
But for those who care about gameplay - this game is not even worth $10

text:
Wait for more patches because there are too many issues to recommend this game.

EDIT:
So after several patches, the game was playable and I was able to finish it. I had 2 or 3 crashes during my playthrough but overall the gameplay was smooth and FPS were stable @2K ultra settings.

I had never played TLOU before the PC release. I bought it in preorder after seeing so many positive reviews saying that the game is a masterpiece and a 'must-play' title. I was pretty sure that I would enjoy it just like the others said.
The first 2-3 hours were indeed very good so I was excited. Unfortunately, those were the best moments for me because the game became repetitive pretty quickly. Maybe except for the graphics that I really liked, everything else was just okay/meh: story, gameplay, levels... There is no potential for the second playthrough because you don't make any choices that change the story.
After all the hype surrounding this game, I expected much more. I don't see any element done so brilliantly that would justify those 10/10s. The 'mixed' grade would be more adequate but since it is not here, I have to choose between yes/no and I go with thumbs down.

It's a hard game to recommend for now, but I feel like we're getting close. I'm not getting the 'please wait' loading screen that often anymore, so there does seem to be progress.

text:
I've played plenty of bad PC ports in my day.

I'm used forcing games to run at a limited framerate like:
-Evil Within 1
-Nier Replicant
-Resident Evil 5
-Dead Space (2008)

I'm also used to downloading fan patches to get games to properly function like Resident Evil 5, Tomb Raider 1-5, etc. 

But the thing is, once that's all said and done, I can reasonable run the game at a stable framerate with no crashing. The port for this game is just as terrible as people are saying. I'm honestly left speechless and Naughty Dog and Neil Druckmann seemingly released this port without ever testing if it ran well on a PC at all. My hardware is more powerful than a PS5 and even if I put the settings on low and render the game at 720p the game REFUSES to reach a framerate of 60FPS due to their mind-boggling lack of optimization when it comes to compressing and streaming textures on PC.

Now, normally, I will see games with reviews like these and experience little to none of these problems. However, I am experiencing ALL of the issues including random crashes at inconsistent points in the game. Good luck EVER doing a permadeath run in this game because Naughty Dog put less than the bare minimum porting this to PC and let Iron Galaxy take the fall despite the port being mostly in-house.

I purchased this game primarily as a joke to show my best friend how bad the port was and it shows.

I'd really like to finish the game, as I'm already so enveloped in the story, but this issue makes it impossible to enjoy it further. 

I would highly recommend this game to anyone, if it worked correctly. Unfortunately it does not. 

10/10 Story

0/10 functionality

I'd wait until its playable before purchasing.

text:
This is a phenomenal game, both from a story and gameplay perspective. If the port's ever stabilized, I'll get around to writing a full review and I'll definitely thumb this up.

However the current state of things is god-awful. I'm fortunate enough to have a very powerful PC, so when it runs, it runs fairly well. The issue here is that it lacks stability. The game crashes nearly once every two hours or so, and while that's annoying, the most debilitating part of these crashes is that the game will often force you to verify files afterwards. Once you've verified files, you've got to recompile shaders, which can take upwards of 45 minutes! And, to top it off, the cherry on top is that the game will often then crash WHILE COMPILING SHADERS, forcing you to begin the entire arduous process all over again. 

See image here: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2964269824

This is a completely broken port that shouldn't be purchased at the moment. Even after several patches it's still extremely difficult to keep the game running on my machine. I strongly recommend all players steer clear of this for several months to a year, as it should never have been released in this state in the first place.

🧾 Feel free to follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32979487-Greatjon-Umber/]my Curator page[/url] if you like my reviews.

Edit: Since folks have suggested in the comments that I only gave this a bad review because my PC is weak, I wanted to state for the record [url=https://i.imgur.com/0dEW0u1.png]I'm running this on a 3080 Ti.[/url] My machine is plenty strong enough to run this one, it's just an awful port.

text:
Once it's optimized and actually runs well, it will be one of the best games I've ever played.

This is my first time playing The Last of Us. I'm about 2/3 to 3/4 through and everything about this game is perfect.....except for the performance. As is apparently standard practice for game studios these days, the PC port receives little to no optimization and runs horrendously. I have an absolute beast of a PC (RTX 3080, 32-core 3.50 GHz Threadripper, 128 GB RAM) and the game runs at like 20 fps on Ultra graphics. The only way to play at a decent framerate is to lower the graphics to the point where it looks worse than the original release. However, the game is just so darn good I accepted the situation and played anyways. But now I've had to pause my playthrough because the most recent patch actually made the performance worse, to the point where it's absolutely unplayable. On the LOWEST graphics setting, it runs at less than 10 fps. 

I'm astounded at how little support this game is getting, considering how beloved the original is and the hype around the HBO show. I'm especially disappointed because I have LOVED the game so far. Storytelling and gameplay are beyond excellent. If Naughty Dog ever gets around to fixing the performance issues, this game will go from 2/10 to 11/10.

text:
The story line and the gameplay in and of themselves are absolutely terrific. But this PC port is *BEYOND* broken. If you set all of your graphics settings to their lowest possible level the game will play. But it will have random crashes. When that happens you need to verify the integrity of the game files. It will find one file that needs to be "revalidated" when that's finished and you boot up the game it needs to load shaders again, which can take anywhere from 15 mins to a few hours. 

There is NO word on when this may be fixed, and there are no helpful suggestions online on how to fix it to play in the meantime. So for the time being avoid this game on the PC like the plague, go play it on the playstation if you really want to play it.

On launch day, it took 2 hours just to build all shaders and still ran terrible. I played for 5 hours and thought the game overall was extremely mediocre, but I still wanted to at least put in an effort to complete the main campaign, so I dropped the game for about 2 weeks to wait for the potato textures and constant frame drops to be fixed up with the constant patches the game was getting. It's just terrible that about 3 hours of my play time went towards building shaders for a game that requires medium-to-low graphics to run anywhere close to smoothly on a RTX 2060. I know it isn't the most insane graphics card out there, but I've seen games look insanely clean and well optimized at 60+ fps with no drops, so I honestly don't think it's much of a hardware thing at this point.

The God of War port was a masterpiece, and I'd say the same for both Spider-Man ports.

I got gifted this game by a friend, and I still want a refund.

Other people should save their money and wait a few more months for it to get fixed, or at least go on sale.

text:
The performance is not the worst part about this game. This game just isn't really that good.

I mean as a movie I'm sure it would be amazing, but the moment to moment gameplay is fucking boring. Even some of the game mechanics just don't seem to work. For example, holding a button to move silently while crouched - or even just sitting still - for some reason still alerts enemies that supposedly only "see by hearing" even a modest distance away.

The game needs to communicate much more clearly what it wants you to do. Trial and error-ing my way through Dark Souls or Elden Ring is easy because the game communicates everything very clearly. This game is - frankly - fucking dogshit in this respect. It doesn't communicate what's necessary multiple times. There's a point where you need to dive underwater, but the game just doesn't prompt you to do so despite it being the first time this mechanic is introduced. I've seen people complain about the ladder/plank carry puzzles, but those were the most straightforward part of the game. At least those are puzzles that you, as the player, are supposed to solve.

I'll say it again: this game is fucking painful to play. I want to like it so much but I just don't. I'm so disappointed. You'd honestly be better off just watching a compilation of the cutscenes on Youtube because that's EASILY the only part of the game that actually makes you want to keep going.

I've never reviewed a game on Steam before, but this is such a frustratingly bad port that I want to warn people off buying it for now. It's such a shame because the game itself is clearly great, but this version is (as it currently stands) pretty painful.

I've now played this game for 36hrs according to Steam, but 22hrs according to my save file. So the difference (~14hrs) is the amount of time I've had to leave the game open installing patches and building shaders. This is just shameful. (The carbon footprint alone makes me wince). Do not buy - wait a few months until these issues are (hopefully) addressed!

text:
[strike]I’m fortunate to have refunded this game before I hit 2 hours of gameplay (though I’ve heard you could still get a refund for how much of a dumpster fire this game has been). 

Just don’t buy it. Don’t even wait for it to go on sale.

I spent almost 2 hours starting the game, clicking new game, and get to building shaders just for the game to crash randomly; whether the shaders were built 1% or (the best one) 98%.

I’ve played other PlayStation ports (Days Gone, Horizon Zero Dawn, God of War) and didn’t have any issues. I was hoping Naughty Dog LLC would be able to keep up with other publishers, but they can only produce a game that was poorly ported to PC (30 series NVIDIA GPUs specifically had a problem, what the actual f*ck? I was on this list, btw). Nonetheless, the rancid hot garbage this game doesn’t seem to be fixed after Sh*tty Dog LLC pushed out FIVE (5) patches since release and the date of this review. Are they trying to compete with other certain ‘big title’ games from other companies that pushed a game out too soon that ended up not being playable on old generation consoles? Seems like Sh*tty Dog LLC is in the running to win….(5 hot fixes/patches in 2 weeks compared to other company's 5 hot fixes/patches in 2.5 months).

Additionally, the other company managed to send an apology to gamers about the mess at launch. Sh*tty Dog LLC? Nothing. Not a word. Just pushing out hotfixes that….let me check….still didn’t seem to fix anything from recent reviews.

Don’t waste your money.

Not like PlayStation and Sh*tty Dog are going to lose money on releasing a game on PC that was originally on the PS3...back in 2013...and then again on PS5 in Sept 2022, they don’t care about PC players.[/strike]





Leaving my prior review up for accountability. Even though I am now able to play the game and have enjoyed it thus far. I 1) got the game for free when I purchased a new AMD GPU for a SFF PC I was making, and 2) upgraded my GPU to a 4090 [though I did play shortly with my 3080]. Another AAA was recently released *cough - space themed game* that was an utter dumpster fire due to the lack of play-ability on most (99%) PCs. I sadly, was a dumba** and preordered both of these games.

Companies need to stop selling trash games upon release that are not optimized. PC players need to stop preordering (fool me once...) until they know the game is in a playable state. Naughty Dogs and PlayStation need to get their sh*t together and take the time to make a game playable day 1 instead of pushing a game out too soon.

Yes, there will be more PS games coming to PC. Yes, I hope they are good ones (GoW, TLOU part II, etc.) but I [b]will not preorder these games under any notion[/b] until I know they are playable or are on a severe discount.

My experience so far:

2 hours playtime? 1 hour 50 minutes waiting for shaders to build. New patches make this process happen again. It never gets faster. Crashes often even just doing this.

Start playing, it runs pretty poorly for a 6700XT and a 5800X with 32GB DDR4 backing it. This is the ONLY Steam game I have ever played, even among the jankest of jank, that didn't AUTOMATICALLY MAKE SURE IT CAN FUCKING SAVE. WHAT? So yeah, I quit out, because obviously all further progress would be nill. Great. I get to walk through a slow intro again. 

So now, here I sit at 12% shaders being built, after a half hour of waiting, after fixing the file permissions, and dialing in the settings to actually be reasonable when the game gets going.

Whenever that is.

Yeah, don't get this port.

text:
TL;DR It's a beautiful game and runs great, IF you have high end hardware. I can't recommend it as is right now.

As much as I love this game, like many others I can't recommend it in its current state. It's great if you have high end hardware like me, but I can definitely see this being an issue for the average gamer.

Running this on a 4090, i7 12700K, 32GB DD5 RAM and NVMe, the game itself runs great. I'm over 100 FPS at almost all times with DLSS off and most things maxed (shadows I keep on Med/High). That being said, this game is definitely a CPU and RAM hog, not to mention the VRAM. I'm currently playing at 1440P, so that may or may not be the same case for you. There are a few micro stutters here and there when turning (could be a CPU bottleneck for me or could be the game), but it's nothing annoying or even immersion breaking.

The game looks beautiful and there is nothing better than playing it M+K, but if you are running with any kind of card under a 3000 series you may see some issues. I personally have not had any crashes whatsoever, but I did suffer the dreaded "Building Shaders" timesink. It took me about 15 - 20 minutes to get my shaders built, but I know there are folks who have had it much worse. The game is definitely poorly optimized. If they get this patched out, it will be great.

text:
I heard terrible things about the performance of this game so I waited a couple of weeks and a few patches before booting it up.  On launch it told me i was using a previous version of my graphics card driver and that i should update it and even listed a version number.  I checked Geforce Experience and the Nvidia website, bothof which told me i was on the most up to date driver.  A driver with a lower number than the game had told me i should use.  Great start!!  

Should have booted the game sooner it turns out, as i then had to sit through a 45 minute shader cache process.

Eventually started the game up and played through the prologue and was pretty impressed to be honest.  Haven't played the game since PS3 so was blown away by how good it looks now.

Until i got to 20 years later,  as soon as the cutscene had finished and it dropped me into the game in the alleyway, there was a graphical issue that made it impossible to see literally half of what was on screen as it was like i was looking through a grill and could only see parts of the game (in beautiful shades of grey) through this grill.

Immediately turned the game off as this turd still needs a lot of polishing before it becomes even a shiny turd.  At the moment it is just a regular old sloppy turd.

Don't waste your money for now. Maybe they will be able to get it in a half way acceptable state some day, but i don't think that day will be any time soon!

text:
I recently beat Resident Evil 4. Now, my PC isn't the best, but it's not bad either. I got a solid 60fps all the way through on Medium settings, and even managed to keep it around 60ish with high settings. It ran incredibly well, and looked great while doing it.

Which is just a window. I set the settings to as low as they will go, and the game looks [u]awful[/u] for it, and still runs like garbage. 32 FPS at its peak.

If your game looks worse AND performs worse than games releasing the same week, maybe your game just is worse.

text:
Wow, almost like they had to release this in Q3 or Q4 of 2023. But no, had to release in time to buy in the TV-show's hype.

Good job. 

My fellow consumer, this negative review shan't leave the graces of this steam store page just through patching here and there, 'nay. My fellow brother (Or sister we're all good in the hood) my complaints are directed towards the company itself and their business model oh yes.

1. This is a port, ladies and gentlemen. This is not a remake, nor a remaster. No. This is a port, with minor enhancements. Minor, enhancements, sire. A port takes way less effort, time, and resources. So, my fellow gentlemen of the digital realm, how was this port handled o' so terribly?

2. The Last of Us Part I is an extremely linear game. Yes, art teams and level designs knock it out of the park, but, in the end, it is a linear game. Now Batman Arkham Knight I understand, big AAA game, with a large world, and it is indeed a *multi-layered* world, with numerous side activities. Iron Galaxy's major mess with that is totally understandable.. But TLOU? Extremely linear, uni-dimensional, how could you mess up this badly?

3. People reading this with high end rigs: Do not purchase this now. If you see positive reviews as of this time stating that the game is playable, that is because these are probably users playing on 1080p or relatively close. Playing this game right now on 4k and above will absolutely gut your VRAM. It eats it for breakfast. 

4. This is a disservice to the fans that actually left positive reviews for your game during this time:

There are numerous people that actually endured the harsh bugs and crashes, immersion breaking errors, just to play a game they really enjoyed. You as developers releasing a game in a half-assed state, serving those die-hard fans who *truly* cherish your games is an absolute disservice, so don't go around spewing that "Oh sorry this isn't the Naughty Dog experience you're used to" nonsense because honestly that is both aggravating and highlights your sense of entitlement. 

Again, this is not a review that is negative for the "bugs" that will be patched out in a couple of months (Yeah surprise they'll need months to patch the bugs for PC builds of all ranges, surprise.) but it is one that is targeting the business model itself. This greed for the almighty dollar and blatant disregard to your fans time and resources is quite memes, and you had to do this to TLOU 1. This isn't even the Woke of Us Part II man.

text:
The Last of Us Part I made me review a game for the first time. To clarify, I haven't watched the TV show nor played the original Playstation game before.

On the one hand, the game is very addictive and fun. Story is interesting, gameplay is versatile, likable characters.

On the other hand, the game is very predictive, the majority of your enemies are humans and not zombies, and there are couple of instances where you should be able to pass certain sections undetected but the game does not allow you to. I pointlessly wasted time trying to stealth my way through.

The elephant in the room is obviously the performance and optimization. Playing on 1440p all low with a 12700K and a 7900XT results in a framerate of 100-130, sometimes dipping as low as 70. Needless to say this is completely unacceptable. 

The "building shaders" time takes between 45 to 50 minutes with the above-mentioned hardware and a Gen 4 NVMe while Resizeable-Bar is enabled. Loading a save/reloading a checkpoint can sometimes take up to 3 minutes. In addition, sometimes the game has to pause in the middle of the action to load up to 2 minutes. 

The game has clearly not been play-tested at all, and was released in an unacceptable condition. I highly recommend purchasing the game ONLY after all of its issues will have been fixed.

text:
To start, I 100% feel this game is worth playing / experiencing. That said, this port has some issues that still need addressing & it most certainly does *NOT* warrant a $60 asking price.

Positives: the graphical updates to this game are jaw-droppingly good (currently running everything on high). Everything from the rubble strewn about post-apocalyptic Pittsburgh to the water rippling & churning at the dam to the eerie cannibal lodge to the sunset-bathed town of Lincoln--everything just works & builds this very believable world. Also, slight tweaks to the bow-and-arrow mechanics are smart and very much appreciated. Some of the skins (like Ellie's "Game of Thrones" t-shirt and Joel's default pistol and shotgun) look great. And most importantly, the story remains untouched and just as gripping as it was when I first played it in 2013.

Negatives: I'll never, ever understand why developers ask $60 for a remake. I didn't think it was justified with all the Resident Evils nor Dead Space, so to charge that much for titles that are a decade-plus old? Be reasonable. Also, graphical glitches like characters getting soaking wet at random intervals or Joel sprouting sasquatch eyebrows might be just as hilarious as the naked T-pose on vehicles in Cyberpunk 2077, but it does get old after a while. My biggest issue in this regard is the water reflections looking whcky as hell at medium distances and appearing like Lego blocks are being reflected back to me. And just because some of these issues have gotten patched doesn't let the developers off the hook. I busted out laughing when one of the first screens greeting my newly installed game asked me to "help us build the best PlayStation experience." I mean, come on guys...that kind of proofing / auditing / game checking is kiddie stuff and just reeks of laziness. And while the game "only" crashed on me twice in 30 gameplay hours (currently on 2nd playthrough), they had occurred at some pretty godawful times which then required having to re-do massive stealth areas. Also, what's with games these days eclipsing 130+ GB? Seriously, they couldn't condense that code any better & require that much hard drive space? I get Call of Duty and some other titles are even larger, but that still doesn't excuse the fact that it's lazy programming that could've been done better. Devs should want to do better as this would make their game more readily accessible to a wider audience. God help the poor souls trying to run this thing on anything other than an SSD. There's probably more that I'm forgetting to list here, but I think I've made my point.

Bottom line: this is a very amazing game that I want to recommend to everyone. But it's *NOT* worth it at this price and *NOT* with all the myriad of technical issues presently plaguing it. I hope Naughty Dog stays committed to fixing this mess and doesn't chalk it up to PC player-elitism or some other b.s. reasoning. Because this is a worthwhile game & I'm glad it's finally released to the PC...just not in this broken state. Please be better & give the PC community a better experience.

Update September 2023:
Waited until a few weeks ago to try the game again. Things seemed to be fine. However, I just reached the part where you need to find car parts with Bill. I am unable to progress because the game freezes and then hard crashed within 30 seconds of me loading into the level. I cannot fathom how this game is still so broken this long after release.

---

My review is essentially an echo chamber at this point. The game itself is excellent. I have gotten solid performance for the 2 hours I spent actually playing it. The problem is that I needed to leave the game running in the background for 94 minutes the first time so I could compile shaders. So of my 4 hours I have recorded, only about 50% of that was spent actually playing the game.

The second time I loaded the game, it decided to compile shaders again. Between my work and family responsibilities, I only have a few hours per week to play games, so waiting 90+ minutes on EACH load to recompile shaders is absolutely asinine. Sony, Naughty Dog, Iron Galaxy, and all other personnel responsible for this port should be absolutely embarrassed.

If this game wasn’t gifted to me, I would refund it and wait a few months until the publisher and its development team can get their act together, because this game is basically shovelware in its current state.

text:
To recommend or not recommend... it feels like a catch 22 either way. I have owned the Last of Us on both PS3 and PS4 where I enjoyed multiple play throughs on each console. Now, eagerly awaiting the launch of this title on PC only to be met with a mediocre start to the game. Within the first 30 minutes of the game I had a GPU related crash to desktop. Normally this would be a problem but considering the state of most games upon launch this can be forgiven but not forgotten. Oddly, this game has moments of looking visually incredible but then other moments the game appears to be running at 720P, during these 720P moments the film grain effect makes it look like you took your PC monitor into the bathroom during a hot shower due to the pure blurriness. Disabling film grain leaves you with an image that appears as if disabling film grain just turned the slider up on color noise reduction. Meaning that the image looks blurry and smooth (not in a good way). Overall the games frame rate goes from okay to dog shit at the drop of a dime. To the games credit I am not running this on a super computer which is arguably the only way to get it to not be a stuttery mess but even that appears to still be a problem. What is most alarming is that required specs far exceed the console counterparts this game was originally released on. All be it on PS4 it ran at 30 frames, it didn't have nearly the same problems that my middle tier PC seems to have due to piss poor optimization. Again, as i previously alluded to, this just seems to be the state of gaming lately and i am hopeful additional optimization patches come out and correct the performance issues. For now I don't recommend but each patch seems to fix some overarching performance issues.

Edit: Upon playing the game more I have noticed numerous graphical glitches that are funny to see once and down right infuriating the second time you see it. The main killer one for me is a weird glitch that causes characters hair, including eyebrows, to render incorrectly causing all characters hair to look like their hair is made of trapezoids and their eyebrows to closely resemble Oscar the grouch.... funny once, completely unacceptable the next 18 times it happened over the course of my game play (including almost every cut scene). The hair issues are most commonly seen on Ellie while the eyebrows can be seen on Joel, where Joel's green flannel really illustrates the similarities to Oscar the grouch...

text:
I will add a caveat to this. I've played the game on console already - the gameplay, story and character development are all 10/10, absolute masterpieces, 100% worth your time and money.

But, when it comes to this port, right now it is not the optimal way to experience this game for the first time. For example, approximately 10 of the 14 hours I have spent playing were in fact just idling overnight letting the shaders compile. 

Once the initial shader compilation had finished I almost immediately ran into issues with the game just crashing to desktop before loading the prologue. After a few attempts, I was able to get ingame and progress to the first chapter, and get my first taste of the improved graphics and game engine - which are, in fairness, very impressive. I then updated my GPU driver to address a few reported issues, and following this had to wait another 5 hours for the shaders to recompile...

I would suggest waiting a few months for a couple of patches to drop to address some of the more critical issues. If you are desperate to play the game and do not want to wait this long (perhaps you've been watching the HBO show), and happen to own a recent PlayStation console, the experience on that platform will undoubtedly be better right now. Plus, you can find the first remaster that was released back in 2014 at a pretty steep discount compared to this.

text: Shader times aren't even my worry here, but yes they took 30 minutes.... The main issue is that the game caused Nvidia nvlddmkm error after about 10 minutes of gameplay where it essentially crashed and force rebooted my PC. I have a i9 12900K, 32GB of DDR5, and a 3080TI. Looking deeper at the log files on Windows 11, the reboot was due to the game causing lower level issues with nvidia drivers. This affected the hardware fan controller functions. The GPU was essentially overworked for no damn reason, and the drivers just shit the bed. Everything was up-to-date. 1 Soft crash back to windows, followed by a hardware level system restart was all I needed to blatantly say, "DO NOT BUY THIS". It's basically a $60 virus if it's causing hardware problems. (I know not everyone is having this issue, but fuck that... flat out).  I can run any game no problem, and this is the first and only crash I've ever had since I've owned this PC (2022 to date). I'm sure they'll fix things eventually, but having my PC restart makes me singlehandedly never want to boot it up again. I'm not playing the NVLDDMKM rabbit hole again, as that fault borderlines similar error codes that can lean towards a failing GPU.

text:
The CRASH of Us. 

AFTER patch 1.0.2.0.
Played time 12 Hours.

The Last of Us Part 1 on PC is a true disappointment. Hold off on purchasing this game until the issues are resolved. In addition to the previously mentioned problems, the game is virtually unplayable due to constant crashes. What's worse, the save system doesn't work properly, forcing players to repeatedly go through the same sections of the game.

I cannot describe my frustration with these issues. A game that should be an amazing experience is impossible to get through because the constant crashes and save system issues discourage playing. Save your money and your nerves until these problems are fixed.

I cannot recommend The Last of Us Part 1 on PC due to its numerous issues. As much as I love the game's story, the poorly optimized port severely hinders the experience.

1 - Bought the game.
2 - Downloaded over 70GB of data.
3 - Waited around 20 minutes or more for the shader process.
4 - Finally started a new game, only to face around 5 minutes of loading time.
5 - Game starts, watched the first cutscene, gameplay begins, performance seems smooth, and then... CRASH!
6 - Restarted the game, tried to continue, faced another 5 minutes of load time, cutscene ends, and CRASH!
7 - Restarted the game in safe mode, another 5 minutes of load time, skipped the cutscene, played for 10 seconds, and CRASH!
8 - Verified game files on Steam, restarted the game, faced another 20 minutes of shader processing, followed by another 5 minutes of load time, and yet another CRASH.

While I have been eagerly anticipating playing this game for years, the PC port is a huge letdown. Despite having a decent gaming setup, the game runs poorly and crashes consistently. It's hard to enjoy the game when it is plagued with such issues. The lack of replayability and corridor-style gameplay further diminishes the experience.

I wouldn't recommend purchasing this game on PC unless you have an extremely high-end setup or until the optimization issues are resolved. The Last of Us Part 1 on PC is broken. While the story is great, the constant crashes and texture bugs make it nearly unplayable. Save your money and time until the game is fixed.

My PC:
GPU: 3080 TI - 12 GB (67*C) everytime 100% used ingame.
CPU: Ryzen 9 3900x
RAM: 32GB 3600mhz
SSD: Samsung 980 PRO 2TB

Settings: all high in 2K resolution  (9GB VRAM used)
Nvidia: Newest drivers

text:
Disclaimer: With the current state of the port since release, this review will stay negative regardless of any whiteknighting surrounding this game. Until crashes, performance, and overall stability is corrected, this review will remain negative.

That being said, I feel very weird about the release of this title. I waited to play it for years and now that I have the totally redone version on TLoU pt 2's engine, I'm both elated yet disappointed. I don't know if I was expecting more or maybe I was spoiled by open world titles that encouraged dumb fun. Make no mistake, I am a huge fan of narrative corridor shooters, Bioshock and the Metro series being among my favorites, which makes it weird that I'm not totally floored by this game. For me, the entire appeal of this game is the story and while I did love it, it cannot uphold a game alone. Pt 1 is plagued by being a relic of it's time but also having the upgrades of the sequel, I desperately tried to find more reason to explore the game's world or refine my combat or stealth approaches but it's soooooo handicapped by the corridor-style gameplay, there's not much space there for you to experiment, it's either Option A vs Option B or just straight up Option A. Now, this game's been around for 10+ years so there's really not much to say as it's all pretty well known at this point. The game is good, don't get me wrong, it just features virtually no replayability to me and it's why I am awaiting Pt 2 to come to PC because while it does butcher the story of the first game, it nails the gameplay much better.

text:
Please see update/patch notes after initial review for current opinion and thank you for reading!

Bioshock and The Last of Us are my favorite games of all time so I was looking forward to writing a very positive review when this game released. I saw the hate that the game was getting because of all the technical issues and decided to wait a couple of weeks to see if the bugs were worked out. I had seen a patch helped some and was willing to give it a shot. 

This game looked better on PS3. I don't know how this is possible, but I clearly have a better system than that and it just looks bad. The performance is just not where it should be. Sony get Nexus to fix this and steer clear of whomever you used to port this game over!

EDIT: So I've played an additional 8 hours of game-play. This game doesn't crash on me like most have complained about. However, as I said before, the game is horribly optimized. I would suggest waiting until they have all the bugs fixed. There are far too many texture blurs. If you do decide to get the game....As people have said before, wait for the shaders to load on your first playthrough.

I don't have a state of the art system but I'm working with enough. For those that are curious I'm running a Legion 5 RTX 3060 6GB and Ryzen 7 CPU. The game will work, it's just not optimized properly and I don't understand how it was allowed to be released in this state. 

AFTER UPDATE, patch v1.0.3 4/15/23:
To think that the optimization couldn't get any worse....This patch has made the game almost unplayable in my opinion. Now the shaders are taking even longer than any previous patch and ANY OTHER game on the market EVER! Sony has really messed this up and they should give us our money back. After waiting an hour for the shaders to load, the game plays worse on my system than it did before. Will update should anything change, but this is unacceptable and I would NOT buy this game in the state it is in!

After patch v1.0.04, 4/28/23:
It looks like they finally fixed it. So after owning the game for almost a month now, they finally were able to fix it. This game is the best game of all time (my opinion), but released in the most poor quality possible. I am going to put a thumbs up on this game because it really is a great game. However, I don't support what the studio did by releasing this game in the state it was in. I'm sure it's still not where it should be. Lesson to everyone out there and even myself: DON'T PRE-ORDER GAMES because we the consumers are being taken advantage of by corporate gurus that just want our money. This game is a perfect example but if this isn't enough look at the newly released Jedi Survivor (I know not the same studio, but it's a perfect example of what corporations are doing: charging higher dollar for lower and lower quality). Again, thumbs up for the game but thumbs down for the way in which it was released. Thank you for taking the time to read my review.

UPDATE:
Well....I thought they fixed it, but once I reached the sniper portion (I don't want to spoil this game for anyone so I'm being vague) the game slows down to 6 fps. Not going to beat a dead horse. Just wanted to let you guys know that the game is just not optimized.

text: I would love to recommend this game, this and Part 2 are really incredible games and some of my favourites. But you can't get to all the good stuff because it's so broken. My specs are over the recommended and I run it at 720p and it still has stuttering. Stutters that don't even show on the fps counter. Nothing is being maxed out. I also get told when I launch I don't have the right driver when I'm pretty sure Nvidia knows better about what's the latest driver then the broken game does. It's vram requirement is absurdly high. Apparently a weaker card than mine according to them should run on high at 1440p, and to get to high on my card I need to go to 720p. I should be able to at least hit the equivalent settings to a ps5, especially with dlss. But apparently having textures that hold up to me even glancing at them takes a ton of vram. I get not being able to run at the max, but I wasn't expecting to. I expected to be able to use textures that didn't look like the ones from the ps3. The recommended environmental textures I got were worse than the ps3 ones and the dynamic textures didn't look much better. PC players had to wait nearly seven extra months for this. At the moment is barely runs, and for some people it doesn't. Every fix they have seems to be dancing around the bigger problems in favour of small ones. Even though some of the issues in the patch notes don't seem to be actually fixed anyway. I spend more time in the settings than playing it. The PS5 does not have over 40 gigabytes of combined ram in it. Why do I need that much to run at the same settings at 720p. I am certainly not preordering from Sony again. PC players shouldn't still be treated like second class customers that you throw a broken product to half a year later to scoop up some extra money. You keep sending out stuff like this and people will just not bother buying from you. Hell it doesn't encourage me to get a ps5 if your quality assurance didn't flag "barely runs" as a problem. If the game not starting for most people isn't a big enough issue to be flagged before release I don't know what is. At the rate the next big Sony release will probably smother me in my sleep, and they would still blame my drivers.

keywords: shader, wait, take, hour, time, update, load, patch, minute, still
text:
After the patches and hotfixes i finished the game. I have around 11 hours on my main save file and 40 minutes in Left Behind. Looking at my 24 hour game time currently maybe 5 hours of it was leaving it running on accident and the remaining time was on waiting for shaders. Every time there is a patch/hotfix or you verify game files it needs to build shaders again which took around an hour or so each time. The game started running "smoothly" (as in not as many random crashes) only a few days ago after the new drivers for rtx 3000 cards. Only issue i have right now is in Left Behind DLC where it keeps crashing in that one spot where Ellie has to turn on a generator which causes a few stalkers to get fried and then my entire pc freezes. Btw running on a Ryzen 5 5600X, 32gb RAM and RTX 3070 TI. 
The VRAM- Okay so the Vram in the menus is just complete cap. It says i am over the limit at 9.3 GB with everything on high/Ultra and DLSS on Balanced but task manager and the ingame vram counter that you can turn on say only 7.7 GB. 
The performance- Other than the glaring issue of it not being properly optimised the game does run around 60 fps sometimes 40 if in larger areas on high/ultra DLSS Balanced and 2k resolution with the only issue being that my cpu is 100% most of the time. But after all that said the game is great both story, combat and exploration but i dont think it is advisable to buy it yet.

text:
Terrible mess even after the new patch. 
Prompts to download a graphics driver version that Geforce Experience can't even download (you can find it on the web). 
Compiling Shaders again - i9 10900k, takes longer than an hour - more like 2.
When in game, CPU usage is at 100%, GPU usage at 5-15%, with a RTX 3080. Framerate is a terrible mess. Fluctuates between 20-60, with DLSS rendering <1000px width, with everything on medium, on a hardware that should outperform the console releases by a bunch.
Frequent crashes especially when loading cutscenes, or when starting the game.

Quality-wise the worst game launch I have ever personally experienced by an incredible margin. Launching this pile of shit at a price point of 70€ is customer abuse at best.

Of my listed 7 hours, I have spend close to 5 compiling shaders, because of various issues in game and driver updates.


Update July 2023: 
With the most recent update (1.1) it is finally playable, the framerates are more stable, and compiling shaders still takes way longer than almost any other game (15-25 minutes) but is more reasonable. It still doesn't run great, but will work fine with reasonable hardware, set aside the stutters and how incredibly CPU bound this is for no sensible reason. The negative comment still stands because this launch has been a big fuck you to players.

text:
This is the first time i have beaten this game, i tried back on the ps3 and just hated how the game controlled. 

This version of the game has a reputation, by seeing the mostly negative to mixed score this game has gotten you can probably guess that this is a horrible port and you'd be correct. HOWEVER after the most recent patch all the visual bugs seen on youtube are all gone at least for me, i have had 4 crashes in total all of which were early game and 60% of the time i was running the game at 80fps - 100fps with the lowest it got was 45. So why still leave a negative review? because i have; a 3070, 32 gigs of ram and a ryzen 9 5900, i know my machine is not what most people will have and even with my hardware this game struggled.  

the game itself is fantastic, the story is amazing and the game play (at least on keyboard and mouse) if so fun, the gun play has a weight to it i rarely feel in other games (even if it is just stealth gears of war), Each connecting melee hit from Joel has weight behind it that makes every hit have a deep impact.

This game is amazing, and i am glad that it has come to pc (i cannot wait to see what the mods for this game are gonna be like) but i cannot in good conscious recommend it in this state, i recommend waiting until it has more stability patches OR when it goes in a big sale.

without the bugs and glitches 9/10
With the bugs and glitches 5/10

text: This review is for those with a Intel A770 Graphics card. The game plays really well for the most part I played through with Ultra High graphics and it was smooth as can be with one exception, there are some scenes that are definitely not optimized and you can tell when they begin and end. As soon as a fight started and a series of sneaking and fighting was expected through the game it started to drop frames to below 20 FPS, I changed every setting I could and does not matter what it was on, it continued to be below 20 FPS. I tried everything from Ultra to lowest and anything between and it did not change a thing which tells me its either needing a driver update for the Intel A770 or the game is needing a patch. It was so hard to not get distracted by how bad the frame drop was that it really robbed the fun factor to experience of the game. But as soon as the 'scene' ended the Frames went completely back to normal like nothing happened and the game was a great experience until then. Only other complaint I have other then this is I was using an Xbox controller and It would not let me shoot the pistol until I changed to my mouse and shot once with it, went back to the xbox controller and it then allowed me to shoot going forward after that. Odd Bug. I have not played through a large portion of the game only about 2 hours worth so far (1 hour of play time so far is building the shaders twice because it was patched and had to build shaders again after the first patch). The game itself is fun and I would definitely give it a buy assuming the bugs are still being worked out, as of now if things stay the way it is I would not give it a buy.

text:
So you might consider this a bit of a hasty review but regardless I'm writing it anyway. 
The game is really not in a good place right now well not unless you have $5k plus to drop on a top end PC anyway which quite frankly for a 10 year old game should be overkill but alas only that kind of rig is going to make this game somewhat playable.

MY PC SPECS: 
Intel Core i7 11700k
ASUS ROG Maximus XIII Hero
16GB CORSAIR VENGEANCE PRO DDR4 
MSI VENTUS 3X GeForce RTX 3080 Ti 12 GB 
Samsung 970 EVO Plus 2 TB PCIe NVMe M.2
WD HDD 1TB 

These are my current specs not the best i'm sure but far from the worst, and I can run some of the newest games in full ultra settings at 1080/1440p with high frame rates no problem yet in this game I quite frequently drop below 60 like well below 60 especially during combat sequences. 
Not only that but it feels like it has motion blur turned on even though its off in the settings which I find quite jarring and its giving me a headache trying to play it. 
I've not been able to play the game much I am just past the point of 1st meeting Ellie I can't play it anymore due to the issues I noted. Its really not good when Sony's and Naughty Dogs flagship franchise is this bad on its PC debut. 

Another issue I had and I know many others have been in the same boat but 3.5 plus hours to compile shaders is just outrageous I have never known a game take so long to compile shaders before and speaking of knowing stuff I have also never known a game throughout my 30+ years of gaming for a game to require almost oll of my Vram, 11+GB out of 12GB of Vram just to play and my settings are not even maxed out like how can a 10 year old game require so much Vram. 
As much as I love this game and its premise I can't recommend anyone to purchase this right now I mean yeah I bought it but I bought it cheap off CD-KEYS makes no odds to me but I would advise people save their money and wait for more of the issues Sony knows about to be fixed.
