text:
Like Bleak Faith I went into this without bias. Not this or that. Thinking yes, or no. I actually took the game as is. Then after running for a bit, downloaded the "hot fix" for NVIDIA. 

Rig
Ryzen 7 5700x
3070 (8gb)
32gb RAM

Shade Time: > = 20 Min

Wow.. There is no denying this seems to be built like a house of cards waiting for a slight blow of the wind. From shadows to the characters hair. I took a screen shot of the hair, if you want to see. I am pretty sure it is the first shot I took. Looks like clay. 

To be fair, zero crash so far. But it is only an hour (well, 40 min) playtime. I have just under an hour left before a refund. I stopped and decided to download the "hot fix". Boot up aaaand it seems the shaders have apparently reset. So.. if I am lucky, I have forty minutes left. Already tired, I'll try again tomorrow. 

So far though? STAY AWAY. There has been I think three patches and this 30 series "hot fix" (a lot of the comments under the "fix" state it didn't help, well one person said it did...so.. there's that). But considering I do not care and I have time to refund, I downloaded this "fix" to see for myself if anything seemed better. I'll try tomorrow and update. I can say this though, your GPU should have at least 10gb. The 8gb under the RECOMMENDED is, at least for now, a straight up lie. 

Predictions For Tomorrow?

NOT A F**KING CHANCE.

UPDATE! 
So shaders finished.. again. In about the same time if slightly less at 15 minutes. The hot fix is 100% required. It actually did help. ZERO crashes for me thus far. Game graphics are very clean after hot fix. Still a stutter here and there but I actually mean here and there. During checkpoints / saving. Outside that, didn't notice. I felt something was off but I remembered a "fix" i found a while ago when PC gaming. If you're running higher frames, don't forget to crank up your sensitivity if using a controller. I moved it from 30 to 65. Which cleaned up this "off" feeling I had. I knew time was running out (still upset about the shader thing) and so the final test I could do. I shut the game down and booted again. Will there be a third time for shaders? FIND OUT NEXT TIME ON! Kidding. No. Not sure why it needed it twice. Maybe the hot fix, I do not know. But this time I loaded right in. Load times are > = 60 seconds. Something like that. Kind of long for what I am used to. 

Is this a be all end all? No. Look, the sharder thing is a massive issue. Taking up VALUABLE time the player can verify if this is good for the money. I was only able to pop the first firefly trophy (very beginning) and take down ONE enemy. The rest is story set up and you guessed it, shaders. 

So in the end, this is a tough one to call. I HATE modern companies spitting on consumers. Its as natural as laying off bottom rung and working your way up. So, I STILL have to say, stay away for now. Do I think they'll fix it? I do. Batman proved that and this IS TLOU. Sony won't let this go. I have to admit, I am still thinking of refunding for now. I do not have 2hrs, I have 117 min. I am low key worried of the next 15 hrs of play time for ANYTHING to crop up. 

However, after some patches and a hot fix for the GPU, and let's be honest, most do NOT come back for their reviews, I wanted to give y'all an updated look and see where it is now. Playing the guinea pig. It is a great game (played on PS4 years ago). It is actually the first game ever to get me to replay it. My ex and I would sit down a year (drought), and replay as she watched. It's a great drama with fun enough game play. 

Not to be mean, if Iron has this reputation, why would Sony hire, I do not know. I didn't even game during the Batman PC fiasco and even I heard of that. But here we are. Careful with this one. If you get it. Play it as I have. However, go for the hot fix first. This could save you valuable time in the long run. Give an updated review. 

UPDATE 2
Two crashes. One in photo mode (4/6/23). The other, while playing. Not sure whats happening but the error states something wrong with the files. So I am now verifying the integrity of the download. This is happening after the big 4/7/23 update. I tried going back in first and it won't even load my game without an issue. We will see if verifying fixes everything. I'll update once it is done. 

UPDATE 3
Verifying fixed it. Great session. Then today happened. Game looks like drivers need updating, but they don't. Back to verifying. This is a weird issue. However, resetting fixed it. Best way to describe is it made Joel look like a werewolf detective off of that TallTale game years ago. 

After Beating
Wait for sale. Although the game is much better, this optimization crap has to end. I don't even care for Part 2 if this is what we will expect (also the story goes to ish). I am thankful to have one of the greatest on PC, but to treat it this way? Seemed we appreciate it more than the ones who own it. Good game, bad port. Basically, same ish, different day. 

Update (4/13/23)
Updated drivers... Any driver version other than the one Iron Galaxy told you to use STILL causes massive issues (two weeks from release). I actually beat the game on the version the patch notes recommended (531.60, something like that). I was thinking it must be fixed by now. I started a NG+ and as soon as I saw Sarah's hair (looks like worms),  that's when I knew, I f**ked up. 

This is why the thumb is STILL down. 

UPDATE 4/14/23
Still not fixed after latest patch. Runs even worse. I joke you not. I am running the same settings as before, I instantly drop to 10/15 fps. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. 

Update 4/26/23
After patch, validating shaders (for the 6th time). I expect that now. Done within 15 minutes as usual. I loaded in and looked good. FPS was good too. Outside the shaders, it seems most issues are fixed. For the issues it had, get on sale. Gotta prove a point. 

Update 5/13/23
I am happy for another patch but tired of sharder's having to reset. Come on man! 

Hope this helps!

text:
When a 25 hour game becomes 40+ hours after i spend 10+ hours of my time fixing the companies bad design choices. 

But onto the review...

Decent game, story and gameplay wise, but it is buggy. However, the big issue for me, is that the graphics are too all over the place for it to be really good. DLSS and TAA share massive blows and sharpening in many areas is overdone and makes DLSS look great in some sences and bad in others. There is so much work that needs to be done for this game. Movement brings with it slight blur and texture smearing even with DLSS enabled (though its far less than TAA). Its plain as day that the flaws of taa are present here no matter what scaling option you choose. This port is clearly a lazy cash grab. Textures are too far apart quality wise for this to be flawless (a major telltale sign of console games). LOD Is terrible even at ULTRA because a lot of textures suck and this game really needs a good texture pack or at least better quality than what they give us. Trees and a lot of foilage are super low rez and that breaks immersion immediately when you see it compared to the sharper objects (hence why the base image is so blurry w/ taa). Sharpening filters are overdone for a reason. A default "built in" sharpener exists for TAA. And if you use DLSS, its active on top of the DLSS sharpening.  So DLSS looks oversharpened in many areas even if you crank DLSS sharpening down to 0, and all I got is eye pain from trying to focus on low detail objects that are oversharpened. Cranking the sharpening down is a must for DLSS, or disabling the default sharpening is what i would suggest if you're going to use DLSS in the first place (but this has to be done by modding the EXE file). Its not hard to understand why its easy to see these flaws as only PC gamers could because consolers have been fooled for so long due to how bad the hardware is and how little devs care to produce proper games even for them. One major reason why ill never own an XBOX. I dont want devs telling me what looks good. Otherwise no games will ever innovate as the markets will become too complacent.

Performance is bloody terrible for what little the scenes really have to offer. I have a 3090 and it runs mostly between 45 and upwards of 80+ fps. Totally nonsensical. Companies get so lazy these days with all aspects of designs.  They think sharpening filters is enough to make a good immersive game, so they skimp on the detail of objects and all you get are grainy images after you add sharpening to it. TAA OOTB is blurry as all hell (no change there) and requires lots of sharpening for it to be playable (hence why at default DLSS not only has sharpening in the game, but also has additional sharpening that sets itself to 35 everytime i enable it). This is the fault of consoles and the markets going to try and dupe people rather than try to fix the issue of having low res textures (gotta be able to charge you twice for the "enhanced edition").

Honestly, they deserve every ounce of criticism and negativity they are getting. I hope they learn from this, but the way these lazy cash grabs are going its probably more of the norm and i highly doubt anything will be done in the near future.

Not only do i recommend caution for anyone who might want to pick this up (especially if you're sensitive to blur and bad anti aliasing), but i probably, personally, wont even bother picking up the second part. DEEP SALE or at least a 6 month wait to see how much they care to fix any of this.

text:
2023-04-05: Buyer Beware!
-Game took 40 minutes to build shaders.
-Game performed poorly on my PC.
->Running this game at 1080p on default settings of high the following happened.
->It should be noted I turned off motion blur, camera shake, and the rest of the game play hindering settings contained on that list.
-->Despite having 100 fps on both the in game fps counter and Nvidia's performance overlay, panning the camera around was produced jutter.
-->Jagged edges and unfocusing when panning camera.
->Game settings set to default medium the following happened (still at 1080p).
-->Jutters still visible but less often.
-->Moved into a new area and dropped from 140fps to 40 for over 10 seconds.
-->Game crashed during the third fight.
-As a side note panning the mouse around feels 'heavy' or 'sludgy' as if my inputs are lagging behind.

My Specs:
CPU: Watercooled 11900k overclocked to 5300 mhz
GPU: EVGA 3080 FTW overclocked to 1955mhz
RAM: 32gb DDR4 @ 3400mhz
STORAGE: Two Samsung 970 EVO plus (operating system on one, all steam games on another)
Motherboard: MSI Z-590-A PRO
Mouse: Razer Deathadder v2 Pro
Keyboard: Corsair K70 RPG PRO
Headset: Beyerdynamic DT 990 Pro 250
Misc: GPU running on the game ready drivers released on 2023-03-23

There is absolutely no reason this game should be running this poorly on my rig. Especially at 1080p. Even after the patches the game crashed in the first 60 minutes of playing. 

Buyer Beware!

text:
What a disappointment from Naughty dog. I dont blame Iron Galaxies, You Hired them The blame rests with you. Some back ground on my history with TLOU, I bought it for the PS3 day one when it came out after being a huge fan of Naughty Dogs work. I bought a PS4 the day the remaster came out so me and my friend could play factions online we loved so much on day one. I bought TLOU part 2 day one and defended the game online as to me it was a masterpiece not as good as the first but all the same a fantastic game, I was disappointed there wasn't a factions mode as i love factions as much as I love the single player story, So when i hear part one was coming to PC i was overjoyed as i didn't need to buy a PS5 to enjoy the remake. I wish i had never bought this game. First off the game is a mess. One hour to load shaders to i assume help prevent shadier stutters SPOILER WARNING shadier stutters were still in the game and frequent, Resident evil 4 Remake did not have this issue. The game ran okay most of the time and looked pretty nice that's all i can say about this remake, Resident evil 4 looks just as nice and runs better. The game play is the  same as TLOU no change apart from a few new animations Resident evil 4 Remake completely overhauls its game play and revolutionises core aspects to create fantastic new experiences. TLOU crashed on me over 10 times and had a few glitches in 15 hours of game play, Resident evil didn't crash once in 72 hours of game play. TLOU has half the content on release, RE4R has all its content present and we are getting merceneys soon.

Final thougts on The last of us...Buy Resident Evil 4 Remake you will have more fun.

keywords: release, really, review, go, say, year, see, know, come, make
text:
My specs as some fyi
Intel AlderLake i-9 12900K
Nvidia RTX 3080 TI 12GB
64GB DDR5 RAM
2TB Gen 4 WD850 SSD

My Review
Coming from a background of playing both games on PlayStation I was incredibly excited about the game releasing for PC. Uncapped frame rates, improved graphic options, same epic story line, what wasn't to like?

Unfortunately as with many recent ports from console to PC so much has been lost to gain so little.

You don't need to look far to see the numerous issues with this release but from my perspective

Shader problem
Shaders building after install is crazy, either do it as part of the actual install before we run the game OR have a specific extension to the steam refund policy that the developers will cover claims against, mine took 25 minutes to install, crashed twice during it at the main menu at which point it reverted me back to 0% again, so it total approx 45 minutes stuck at the main menu before I could even play it

Optimisation 
Again you don't need to read very far in these reviews. I fail to understand how so many developers struggle to port a console game to a PC and bump into the same repeat issues each time, stuttering, crashing (Frequently) and frame rate drops are common. I'm not running an average rig, its well above the recommended specs and well within the ultra settings but you need 14GB of VRAM to run this game at max, it eliminates a massive portion of your potential audience getting to enjoy it how its meant to look. TLOU was already a very pretty game on consoles, so I abjectly refuse to believe it requires such a massive increase in graphics power for what you actually get, plainly put its simply not good enough and massively unoptimised.

Crashes
Frequent, frustrating, I experience at least one per hour of game play, sometimes more. Today over a 20 minute play-through I had three of them, each time setting you back to the last save or checkpoint. There is a game mode involving permadeath and no manual saves. Good luck trying to do that one until this is significantly improved!

Stability is non-existent. Its painful, because what little you do get to play looks stunning, the same amazing story but with superior graphics, I want to play it! But each crash just adds to the frustration and reset progress means you end up giving up. I can see the huge effort that went into making the game look so much better for PC players but its annoyingly locked behind crashes to desktop that become so off-putting that you give up. I had a spare hour today I'd have loved to dedicate to the game, in the end after those 3 CTDT I quit after 20 minutes, and probably won't be back until its undergone some major patching 

When it works its spectacular 
This is the major annoyance. TLOU isn't a bad game. Anyone who has played it on PlayStation already knows this. So the thought of those uncapped frames and graphics options should make this a done deal and a massive seller. And when you actually get into the game and can play it, it really does exceed expectations. Shadows, lighting, reflections and water effects all look a million times better than the console version. I spent an actual 5 minutes just playing with the light coming through a window to see how it reflected off the pools of water and walls, it looks that good, simply lost in my own little world admiring the efforts of the devs to make this the best version of the game.

But as mentioned, this immersion is broken far too frequently by stuttering and crashes to really have the opportunity to enjoy it.

Conclusion
I love the series. For me its a perfect example of where entertainment meets immersion meets fantastic storytelling to really get you to care about the characters. I wanted to love this version of the game, I want to play it.

But the lazy port they have made, the stability issues, the simply bad decisions they have made such as shaders and constant crashing, these all just leave a bitter taste in the mouth.

When you can get it to run and can spend longer than 5 minutes just in the moment of the game, its truly an amazing experience. But you just know that the next scene is going to not just be a test of your stealth skills to get past the next clicker, but also a test of whether the game will decide to keep running or fall over in a heap.

Because of that I cannot recommend it right now and the sour taste this has left means I'll wait for the next console port of a AAA title before going anywhere near it, its simply not worth the hassle or damage to your enjoyment of  a long loved series. 

Avoid

text:
The poor optimization makes it so that the game does't register button inputs during a lot of the fights. Are there more than three enemies running at you? Then prepare for your gun to just not fire no matter how many times you pull the trigger! Especially later in the game, this can make it nearly impossible to progress. It also means that the camera moves at inconsistent speeds, making aiming wildly difficult--suddenly the camera will start moving incredibly fast, and then go back to dragging, so you can't anticipate where the reticle will be. 

The poor optimization also makes loading screens incredibly long. I don't mean like a couple minute, either. I mean like 10-15 minutes in some areas. Even on the lowest visual settings offered, this game does not run well. If I didn't already know that this game ran well on console from watching playthroughs, I would assume the $70 price tag was a mistake. Too bad I can't return the game because just loading the shaders took more than the 2-hour return window.

Don't buy this port. It's garbage.

keywords: run, setting, pc, fps, performance, port, even, low, still, well
text:
This is strictly a "performance" review specifically for mid range hardware. The game itself IS fantastic if you can run it.

My rig is  an Intel 8700, rtx 2080 and 32 mb RAM. This is well within the official "recommended" requirements for 1080p 60hz at 'high' settings and the game auto default to high settings and native 1440p. The performance is drastically improved but I played thru the prologue and got about 40-45 fps. I also experimented with DLSS at 'quality' and 'performance' mode and saw a small buff to fps, but not too much. I tried 2160p and 'performance' mode DLSS and got about 30-45 fps. One scene that involved heavy rain during the night TANKED performance and couldn't get anything above 40 fps. Finally, I played thru about half of Bill's chapter with naive 1080p resolution and 'default' AA, whatever that means and got 55-60 stable FPS with a few drops to 50-51. I am not super sensitive to frame drop so this was more than playable for me personally but, I would still much rather have a stable 60 fps especially when I am told by the Dev that my computer can run this game 60fps. My 'benchmarking' was eyeballing the fps counter in the corner of the screen so it is nothing too serious but still, I'm pretty annoyed. 

Oddly, there are a number of visual bugs that definitely weren't present at launch. Joel's eye brows would get very bushy and would flicker. His hair and beard would also get very blocky and Ellie's hair would look like plastic. There was also broken floor textures that would look like matte black.

Unfortunately, I won't be finishing this play through because these just ruin this AMAZING game and my fun. I'll just play it on PS4. I still don't recommend this game on mid range hardware, at least until they fix the visual bugs.

text:
I cannot recommend The Last of Us Part 1, it is a technical, buggy, and unplayable disaster.

This has to be the worst port and launch I have ever seen for a high profile and much anticipated game, I originally played The Last of Us on PS3 during my freshmen year of college, it was an eye opening experience that to this day remains a highlight in my gaming career. I wanted to relive that experience on my RTX 3070 powered PC, a PC that can effortlessly run Marvel's Spider-Man, God of War, and both Uncharted games at 1080p Ultra Settings. But this game is so poorly crafted and optimized it retroactively makes the Arkham Knight debacle seem trivial. This game is fundamentally broken to the core, and it is unlikely that Sony or Naughty will be able to truly fix this mess. 

It pains me to say this as a long time fan, but do not buy this historical disaster of game. It isn't worth it.

text:
[h1] Do Not Buy This Game Right Now [/h1]
I have 7.5 hours in the game, and I checked videos from other people playing the game and I'm actually about 4-5 hours into the game. The reason for my hours being longer is because of the amount of crashes that I had which meant I was in the loading screen and main menu for about 2 hours of playtime. I had a total of 34 crashes in 7.5 hours of playtime according to steam. Unacceptable.

I am going to list the amount of crashes that I had and where I had them (No Spoilers Tho)
[b]In game: [/b]
25
[b]Cutscene:[/b]
2
[b]Loading screen:[/b]
2
[b]Main Menu:[/b]
2
[b]Before even getting to the main menu:[/b]
3 

I will say that under the horrible quality of the port that the game is genuinely great and that's why I kept [u]trying[/u] to play the game even with the stupid amount of crashes. There would be times where I wouldn't crash for about 30 mins - 1 hour and was really immersed in the game but then of course it would crash which would throw me out of the immersion then proceed to crash multiple more times quickly after. There was times when I couldn't get through an area due to crashes just not letting me. 

I will say that I haven't finished the game, but I can't see myself actually being able to finish the game with the state it's in. I would suggest not buying this game right now and maybe just wait a year or two until the game is HOPEFULLY patched enough to be stable. My personal plan is to play a year from now and play the game through, that is if it's fixed.

text:
Let me just start off by saying that The Last of Us is one of my most favorite games, so to see it releasing on PC was a dream come true. Goes to show that if something appears too good to be true, it probably is.

Seeing the system requirements before release had me worried, but I was hoping that I could run the game reasonably okay on my setup, and I'd like to think I had a decent rig, but unfortunately not.
RTX 3070
16 GB RAM
Ryzen 7 3700X
and I get horrendous stutters that make the game nearly unplayable, and that is with the game installed on an SSD with the shaders fully downloaded.

At the game's current state, I do not recommend. Save your PC from this torture, unless you want a portable nuke or something idk. Perhaps look back to this months down the line to see if they iron out the issues.

I find it funny that there are Steam Deck specific control schemes but runs like a powerpoint presentation. If you're curious, by the time you leave the quarantine zone, I averaged about 20-25 fps on lowest settings with FSR enabled, (And CryoUtilities).

'Tis a Shame, and I had high hopes coming from God of War running perfectly on PC.

text:
This game has been awful, and I think I hate it. A lot.
- First time loading the game… Your drivers are not up to date. Sure, fine. Updated the drivers. No big deal.

- Okay, drivers updated and in the game with no warnings. I got everything set up and tried to start the game. The excitement was palpable… Building Shaders for like 15 to 20 minutes!

-Alright, finally I can play this game that I’ve been looking forward to for so long. Nope. Crashes. Looking at logs reveals that it is my display driver.  

-I do a DDU on my display drivers. Get the latest drivers re-installed via a fresh download. Nope. Game crashes again; however, not before taking longer to crash in an effort to clearly trick me into believing that this game was finally going to load.

- I did a, “Verify integrity of games file.” All this did was trigger the game to build shaders again, and after rebuilding the shaders, it was kind enough to take a little longer before crashing.

I give up. I have an AMD Ryzen 5700X, 32GB of DDR4-3600, an RTX 3090, all on a relatively new install of Windows 11, and I’m loading the game from a 1TB 980 Pro, but I can’t play it.

I’m sure once I am, someday, able to play this game that I’ll like it.

Don’t buy it until it goes on a Steam sales and all of the bugs are worked out.

text:
This review is as of April 3rd,  2023. 

Gameplay itself is fair. While I do notice odd visual issues fairly often, they are usually in reflections, or in demanding scenes. During the prologue, my screen freaked out and I had thought my GPU failed. It was a rainbow stream of colors and I've never seen anything like it in any game ever. Genuinely had me scared for a long time. The story is unlike the show, however this game precedes the show by 10 years. Visually the game can look like borderlands, or even gta5 at times. I wouldn't consider this the remaster Sony advertised in the slightest. The performance of this game is absolutely horrendous. My Ryzen 5950X runs at 88C while by GPU runs at 64C, mind you this is high settings. However I have never had any other game, especially one from 10 years ago use all my GPU, and CPU, while creating waste heat the way this game does. I would refund the game if I'm being entirely honest. I watched for hours on twitch before deciding to purchase it as I hadn't encountered any of the issues that were there on launch day. However after the reviews and the way I'm not the only person who has these issues, is a little bit troubling for a game that is again, 10 years old. Honestly this port alone makes me wonder if this is why the PlayStation has such loud fans.

text:
Note before you continue read: I finished the game and dlc from start to finish on the deck on version 1.0.4, check edit 2 if you want to see my opinion on that matter, I'll maintain the original review and edit as a version 1.0.1 review of the game.

I played it only on steam deck so that is going to be the point of view of this review.

Some time ago neil druckmann actually mentioned that the deck would be consider on the port ( https://twitter.com/Neil_Druckmann/status/1601694903724953600?t=yc0YZG93IKw5sBgoiw-ieA&s=19 ) and well... The game is now released, let's see how it turns out...

Turns out ND actually took in consideration the deck or at least on the settings menu and the haptics (when you use the deck instead of another controller it adds a haptics configuration to the settings).

Now on optimization I'm going to say is garbage, I was targeting 40 fps, even 30 fps would be playable, I had everything in low and I tried with fsr and all, even with cryo utilities and it was running at 25 fps.

So, if you really want to feel the cinematic fps experience of the game the deck is your way to go.

I don't doubt that they are going to patch this mess but if neil druckmann says something even on a tweet he better keep the promise next time.

TL; DR: if you want to experience it on deck do not buy yet and wait for patches, it runs like dogshit.

Edit: it seems that update 1.0.4 makes the game more playable at 30fps with some drops, I've been quite enjoying the game but still needs more polish, when you enter into the big building on act 1 the performance still struggles to get to 30 fps so I still can't recommend to buy it yet but give it a try if you have it, is overall more stable than before on steam deck.

Edit 2: Finished the main game and left behind dlc campaign from start to finish on steam deck, I actually enjoyed the game on the deck but sometimes in buildings or heavy action scenes I still found fps drops that were between 20-29fps, I found rare graphic glitches and little artifacting in some places. The game still needs more optimization if it was promised to run on the deck but at least you can play the game from start to finish on the deck if you don't care about occasional frame drops on some parts of the game. Still wait for an update or at least buy it on sale at this state but I suggest you still wait for patches.

text:
Waited to install after a couple patches. Still not worth it. My build is an i7 8700K | RTX 3080 | 32GB RAM. On top of an almost 80 GB install size, the game took nearly 2 hours to compile shaders while at 100% CPU. Heated the room up exponentially. When the shader compilation finished, I started a game and the performance was pretty bad but I thought I'd stick through it since I played the original 10 years ago at 30FPS. CPU was still at 100% after the shader compilation and the fans were going crazy. 10 minutes into the opening scene, my game hitched and crashed right when i got into the truck. This is not the launch I expected out of a Naughty Dog game. Fix your game and care more about PC ports. Many people are switching over to PC and this is not the treatment we deserve. I'm sure I can speak for the majority of players that were excited for this PC port by saying it was beyond disappointing and a frustrating waste of time. 0/10 until they do something about this mess.

Edit: Upon updating my game with the v1.0.1.7 hotfix, I now have to reinstall shaders again. This will most likely take another 2 hours. What is Naughty Dog thinking? I am not going to wait another 2 hours for a hope that the game stops crashing. GET YOUR $H!T TOGETHER AND HIRE PEOPLE TO FIX YOUR MISTAKE.

Edit #2: So I try launching it after their 3rd "patch" - v.1.0.2.0. I was met with the infamous shader compilation for the 3rd time (I've been all caught up to date on my drivers) and I decide to go out and take a drive and get some shopping done. I get home about 30 minutes later and it crashed mid shader compile at 22% with a dialogue that said to verify the integrity of the game. I am now on the 4th shader compilation attempt. This is highway robbery, Naughty Dog. You owe your dedicated fans/playerbase an apology and compensation for this unplayable mess.

Edit #3: shaders...after...every.....single.....update.............

Optimize your games before thinking that making a single player game require a 30 minute download of shaders after every single update would be a good idea.

text:
The actual game itself is incredible, a masterclass in narrative storytelling within a third person shooter experience, and like many I was excited to finally get to play it on my preferred platform.

However, as it currently stands, I don't think this port is worth the price of admission right now. Bearing in mind, I've actually had a far more positive experience than most. In my few hours of game-time I have not experienced a single real glitch or bug and I haven't crashed a single time, nothing like that. Where the issues are for me is just the performance. The game doesn't stutter much for me, but the frames are very sluggish and the settings I choose don't make a lick of difference. My computer is definitely not top of the line, however it is far from bad and the specs they released prior to release would indicate I should still be able to run the game at a stable fps on decent settings, but this simply is not the case. On top of this, having to wait over an hour for shader's to load simply to play the game semi-smoothly is honestly not acceptable.

With some massive optimisation improvements, I could easily recommend it, but until then, stay far away

text:
UPDATE: Disabling DLSS seems to resolve the crashes and makes my game playable. I'm not changing my review to a recommend as yet, but if you are suffering lots of crashes, try without DLSS, it may help.

The game will be great when they fix it, but right now it seems to be a lottery as to whether your PC will be able to play it (and it's not down to specs).

My system (Laptop - Lenovo Legion 5 15ARH7H):
[list]
    [*]AMD Ryzen 7 6800H
    [*]32gb DDR5 RAM
    [*]RTX 3070 Ti 8gb
[/list]

Now I realise this is a laptop, but it's not ancient, and it has decent specs. The game is unplayable. I expect "ultra" to be out of the question due to VRAM usage, but both Medium and High settings are within the limits (according to the games own settings menu) - however with either preset, I get constant crashes. Only playable for 5 mins at a time before a total crash.

When the game works, the performance is acceptable (>60 fps 1080p).

There are also oddities, such as horrendous graphical glitches when you make settings changes and don't restart the game, even though there is no prompt to restart it.

finally, the 1+ hour shader compilation is ridiculous, but i can live with that since it's a one off.

Just be very careful if you choose to by this game on a system that  is on the lower end of the specs as that shader compile can eat into your 2 hour refund time.

I love the Last of Us games, I've played in the past, and i'm sure this can/will be great... eventually. If that is the case, i will update my review.

Until then, there's no way I can recommend the game right now and to be honest, it is a disgrace that the game has been released in this state. This isn't just some minor glitches that slipped through QA. There is absolutely no way in hell they didn't know how fundamentally broken this was, and released it anyway.

text:
This game, my god, I bought, downloaded, and installed this on the day it launched. I waited until the first patch because Sony has a track record of poor launches. The wait did me no good. I'll list the good, the annoying, the bad, and the system killing:
THE GOOD
1. Game looks fantastic. This is where most of their effort went, but then again, they did do the re-re-remaster for the PS 5, so how much credit does this team get? 
2. The sound is fantastic.
3. The writing is excellent for the little I will play of this game; more on that later. 
THE ANNOYING
1. Keyboard layout, I am sure you can take the time to remap the keyboard but come on, some actual thought should go into this; I know it is meant to be played with a controller, but this is the PC build people will use a keyboard and mouse. There is no excuse for having the pickup/action button be E and the put-down button be Backspace on the other side of the keyboard.
THE BAD
1. I could go on forever but will boil it down; Call it an hour of playtime. All but 15 minutes of that were the game-building shaders and a loaded scene to the tune of 30 minutes. 
2. Game crashed after all the shaders were built, load scenes loaded, and the military shot the daughters. After all that, the game crashed in the very first scene 20 years later. A hard crash also locked up the entire system; more on that later.  
3. It is a resource hog, this game taxes my system, and I am well over the recommended specs. I have an AMD 5800X3D, RTX 3080ti, the game is installed on a PCI 4.0 NVMe, and I have 64 GBs of DDR4 RAM for poos and giggles. That isn't a brag; that is to point out that my system should have no problem running this game, and yet it does. So unless you have a 40 series GPU, you should wait until they patch this game a few more times. 
THE POSSIBLE SYSTEM BREAKING
1. This game changes lighten profiles for some RGB software environments or at least did with my iCue ecosystem. That's good, but in my case, it also changed my fan curves; whose fault this is Corsair or the game can probably be debated, but I wanted to mention it because thermal throttling/crashing might be a few other people's issues. Not to say that it could damage hardware (it isn't likely, but possible) with your fans running lower and not keeping up with the obviously increased heat output. 
In closing, the game looks fantastic and will run amazingly shortly, but at the time I am writing this (4/2/23) is a different day. If you decide to buy it, you can disable the RGB function in the menu system, and I recommend it unless you are sure it isn't messing with your fan speeds/curves.

text:
This is a game that should have been an easy recommendation with flying colours. The Last of Us is probably one of the best games of the PS3/PS4 generation – heck, even the best of the last decade. However, this is a port that I can hardly recommend to anyone. I am fortunate enough to have a recently built current-gen system that can run it, but otherwise, good luck.

The sad thing is that it has all the bells and whistles that COULD make it a fantastic port: DLSS, ultrawide support, a plethora of graphics options, DualSense support, and more. We can blame Iron Galaxy all we want, but the foundation for another fantastic port by Sony is there. However, Sony and Naughty Dog clearly buckled under the pressure and the hype of the show, releasing this port in an awful and unplayable (for most) state.

I wish I could leave a "meh" review, because if you have a high-end system, you can run this masterpiece. But if not, avoid it until they fix it and it goes on sale. If the update coming this week and the next update slated for a later time actually fix anything, I'll update my review. But for now, avoid it.

text:
Watched opening cutscene, game crashed.

Restarted game, hit continue, the gameplay bit immediately after the first cutscene started, game crashed again after roughly 2-3 seconds.

Also, what in the world is being rendered here that would use up all 12gb of VRAM. I know it's not quite so simple, but honestly, there are games that look better than this and don't put much of a strain on a RTX 4070TI at all.

Nice going, guys, well done! I'd slow clap but I'm currently typing away.

 It's strange though - presumably this game was developed on PCs, so you'd think that, at some point during its months and months of development, someone at least accidentally had to have launched the game and noticed that there are some hitches. I know I'm not even close to being the only one who's had issues, so it's not like some obscure thing that could have been missed with even a modest amount of playtesting (if indeed any was even carried out). 

Or maybe every single person who worked on the development of this PC port for who knows how long was just super lucky with their combination of hardware and software/drivers and, entirely by coincidence, they didn't run into any issues and decided this is ready for launch. What are the odds?! The technical wizards at Iron Galaxy should play the lottery with that kind of luck!

text:
In the gaming industry, it's a sad fact that AAA developers commonly launch products in a broken state. However, the long-awaited PC port of The Last of Us is ESPECIALLY awful. I'd compare it to the disaster that was Cyberpunk, but at least that game wasn't literally unplayable at launch. 

It took four hours, over a dozen crashes, and nearly 100% of my entire CPU usage for the shaders to install, which is unacceptable to say the least. However, when I finally get to play the game, I wake up, I walk downstairs and wouldn't you know, the game crashes yet again, telling me to verify the integrity of the files. Not realising that this would lead to me sitting through the shader installation again, I did. After about 7 HOURS of similar problems, I finally got to play the game properly... well, that is when it wasn't crashing literally every 20 minutes. On medium graphics. 

It's not like it's even a hardware issue. While my PC isn't 100% top-of-the-line to today's standards, it's still decent, with it being able to run similar games on way higher graphics settings. Games like Uncharted, the other Naughty Dog game ported from the PS5 to the PC. So how did they fuck up the port this badly? Why can I barely run the remake of a PS4 remake of a PS3 game?

The only reason I didn't refund and persevered for as long as I did was because I knew that underneath it all, there was an amazing game waiting to be experienced... but even then I felt a bit let down. Don't get me wrong, this game is really good - definitely one of Sony's better titles. But I don't know if it was a combination of the technical difficulties eviscerating my hype, being spoiled over time, and a decade of people constantly hyping up the game to make it sound like it would cure cancer and bring about world peace with how good it supposedly is, but I wasn't really feeling it as much as I would've hoped.

Although somewhat overrated, this game is worth your time and money, and when the technical difficulties are fixed I'll change my review. But as it stands now, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. Don't give Sony your money for a fundamentally broken product. And fuck Iron Galaxy.

keywords: story, last, also, character, gameplay, feel, instead, present, hype, find
text:
My perspective on The Last of Us may be different to most: I’ve heard how great the game was over the last decade and have watched the show before I played the game myself. Therefore, I have a view that I am prepared to receive clown awards for; The Last of Us is an objectively good game – but one that I subjectively did not enjoy – and one that is most definitely overrated from the genre-defining masterpiece I had heard it to be. This review contains minor spoilers.

Story

When looking at the story directly, I simply can’t help but compare it to the HBO adaptation of which I preferred in every single way. TLOU’s game story feels less powerful and less emotional with little depth and development of characters and storylines, along with like-for-like scenes simply being done better in the show. The general plot is the same though, and it certainly is a good one with adequate pacing and time skips that hit harder as you can only assume the way a chapter concluded. The finale is a morale choice that is not black or white with Joel being a great example of flawed human character who must make an impossible decision. Voice acting is great along with character lip-syncing – which is important as a lot of scenes contain only dialogue as music felt very rare. Given the age of this game, I’m not going to go over exact parts, but generally the story is engaging and varied enough to be the sole reason you would play it. It is a good story. I don’t know if I could stretch it to be more than that.

Gameplay

Whilst I recognise Part 1 is a remaster of a remaster of a 2013 last last gen video game, gameplay wise it holds up. I loved the way your character moves in combat – especially when running through infected – rather than them getting near you and instantly attacking, their attacks felt fair, and it is possible to weave in and out of their paths in a way many games simply do not allow you to. The human enemies smartly flanked and called out their intentions to allies, with general combat difficulty and encounters appearing well crafted and balanced. Movement is generally dynamic, and the flexibility of crafting was well done, along with the upgrade system of your character stats or your weapons at a workbench through items collected in the game world. Having to watch every single weapon upgrade animation – some of which were literally just Joel rubbing the gun with a cloth – got quickly annoying though. I enjoyed scavenging for supplies, but the gameplay sandbox simply never demanded enough of me to use most of them – so I was almost always full on what I had crafted and how much I could store. Shooting was setting-accurate but frustrating to engage with, yet I got through it as it was simply the most efficient way of playing as stealth just wasn’t worth the effort due to the soft cover system being too finicky. The game had a fair balance between combat and puzzle / traversal sections, though I would have liked to see just something else to vary things up; there was no side content outside of collectibles for the sake of achievements.

Left Behind

The prequel chapter was something again that I played after watching the show’s version first, and once again I preferred the show. As something included with this edition, it was a good side story and did give provide further depth to Ellie’s past. Like the main game though, it just left me underwhelmed as it was a short and simple experience that didn’t offer anything different than what I had already played. The split between past and present honestly ruined a lot of the narrative strength this could have had, and I think it would have done better being one longer story set with Ellie and Riley exclusively – just like the show.

Graphics and Performance

The game looks good for one that is originally based off a PS3 title, and it holds up well even now in 2023. The variety of graphics settings were shocking – so much so that I just set a preset and was happy enough with that. At launch, right now, the game has been negatively reviewed due to the quality of Iron Galaxy’s port. I do not believe it is as bad as the Internet narrative has shown; we know that games are getting more VRAM intensive, and it’s clear that many people simply do not understand the right settings to use for their system. In my experience, outside of numerous crashes, the port ran well on high settings with the only real negative being occasional stutters (yes, I did wait for shaders to compile). There are obviously areas where this port can be improved, but so long as you are reasonable, it’s a perfectly playable experience.

Overall

My conclusion here is the same as what I said initially: The Last of Us is a good game, but not much more. It does everything well enough but did nothing great enough to truly be of note. To me, this title is massively overrated from what I had expected it to be; whilst others may enjoy it, I simply cannot recommend it. Maybe I will just fall into the minority group of people who prefers Part II…

text:
TL;DR: I am torn, because the game in and of itself is a refresh of a masterpiece, but its launch was absolutely horrendous on PC, and can't blame anyone who gives it a negative review. Let's get to it.
EDIT: I'm changing my review to negative until the performance issues get fixed. No amount of good story and gameplay should be held back by a horrible port.

I first played the remaster of the original on a borrowed PS4, so I knew this one was a good one beforehand. What I wasn't expecting was the myriad of problems the game had/has at launch.

From the beginning, I spent nearly the entire refund period just trying to last longer than a few seconds in the main menu while precompiling shaders without crashing the game. I would watch the performance tab on my PC to see RAM usage peaking at about 28GB before crashing, which is insane.

Nearly an hour later, I managed to launch the game, only to find abhorrent performance; almost impossible to reach 60fps even at 1080p on my 2080 Super, with horrible stutters and jittery camera movement. That same day I found a few possible fixes and tweaked the settings, which let me bump up the resolution to 1440p (w/DLSS) with possible crashes, or 1080p at nearly rock solid 60.... until it doesn't anymore. What I've found is that the game is heavily CPU limited, to the point where even a 12core 24thread CPU (Ryzen 3900x) gets capped to even 30FPS at times because of streaming data. I would understand if this happened because I'm running it on an old HDD, but I have it installed on a 3500mb/s NVME drive...

Outside of that, I didn't find any game breaking bugs as others have, so I don't have any comments regarding that situation.

So... what's left is the gameplay, graphics and the story.

Graphics are, as expected, superb. The engine rework is worth just based off the face animations alone, the rest is a huge cherry on top, with material rendering that makes every element in the scenery feel grounded, which is sadly still not easy to accomplish. Animations are reworked as well, based off Part 2 (which I hope lands sometime soon). This on top of excellent sound really do make sense in terms of just BEING, it basically revitalized the franchise so as to have a level of graphical consistency with Part 2.

Gameplay is excellent, if not a bit antiquated. You see, the gunplay is excellent, and the AI and level design allows for a very quick change of pace; slow and methodical, slow and stealthy, balls to the wall, or extreme aggression, and that makes combat REALLY fun. However, level design pretty much delineates just how combat is going to pan out to the point where I found myself saying out loud; there's a shootout incoming, and I know there will be at least 3 alternate paths. At the same time, the "puzzles" are nothing more than an annoyance, and wish they at least had varied them a bit more for this remaster. 

Story is ultimately what drove this one to excellence and what prompted the series IMO. The search for meaning of a broken, silent and lonely man with a girl who fears being alone and loves to talk takes for a great dynamic, which is expertly exploited all throughout the 20 or so hours it may take you to finish the game.

I will most likely play the DLC later on, but my review still stands. Were it not for the amount of issues it has/had at launch, this would have probably been an "overwhelmingly positive" reviewed game, but as it stands, I think it deserves the negative criticism.

text:
UPDATE: in the interests of being as fair as possible, I am now able to play the game without crashing after installing the latest patch and drivers. In light of having a few more hours under my belt, I wanted to update my original remarks.

None of the following points contain explicit spoilers, but I do mention character names and traits. You have been warned. :)

THE GOOD:
- The game is indeed gorgeous on the PC. The light shafts, the dust, the shadows...it's definitely immersive. Sound design is similarly great.

- The interplay between Joel and Ellie is interesting, especially during the quiet moments.

- Given the more-then-usual difficulty of the game, the checkpoint system is pretty fair, often depositing you very close to the point where you died (and you WILL die).

- There are a couple good twists (but also a couple horrible ones).

THE NOTE-SO-GOOD:
- CPU utilization still seems high, though not as high as before. Shader compilation after a driver update takes LONG time...up to fifteen minutes. The consequences of skipping that process are not clear.

- Joel is often a jerk, as are many of the people you encounter. I get that he's been through unimaginable troubles, but this is a game, after all. Traits I would understand and accept in a real human are sometimes annoying and grating in a game character.

- This isn't necessarily a universal point against the game, but please be sure you understand both the pace of this game and its core gameplay motif. This is a contemplative zombie shooter. If you don't like zombies, pass. If you like lots of continual action, pass.

THE HORRIBLE:
- I hated the ridiculous add-on Left Behind. Ellie and Riley's "story" is a story only in the strictest sense of the word. In reality, it was a transparent attempt to wring some pathos out of a friendship we already knew was doomed, with a touch of sociopolitical agendatainment thrown in, because that's what media creators do now. Hard pass on that garbage. I wish I'd just cut my losses, finished the main campaign, uninstalled, and never looked back.

BOTTOM LINE:
- The word "classic" occurred to me many times during my play through, but ironically...because so many people say this game is a classic but "saying it don't make it so." After finishing the main story and beginning the add-on campaign, I have to sadly assert that this game succeeds only at making me depressed and angry.

I will grudgingly admit (grudgingly because of all the technical frustrations I encountered and because of some of the poor writing) that I did enjoy the slower beats. It's actually fun to explore abandoned towns and similar areas, looking for scraps and upgrade fodder. Those quiet moments also allow the player to get to know the heroes better. The combat, however, is clunky and difficult, even at the easy settings. If you choose to fight often (instead of using stealth) you will also choose to die often. Supplies and ammunition are scarce, and some of the hidden stuff is TOO well hidden. I'm not sure this is a game I'll want to replay in order to scoop up anything I missed.

- I'm grateful to be able to play the game at all, from a technical perspective. Read that again. The game industry MUST enforce better accountability when games are released in the state this game was released. I bought a product that was almost instantly unplayable. Where is my remedy? Any acknowledgement would be appreciated: a coupon, a bit of free DLC, even an explicit apology. Instead, I shelled out a lot of money to...wait. Wait for an explanation; wait for a patch, never knowing a timeline or the actual cause of the problems. Very frustrating and non-customer-centric.

- If you loved the original, you'll probably want to play it again...just know that you may experience residual technical issues on the way to enjoying the gorgeous visuals. If you've never played this game, go in with the understanding that this isn't Call of Duty or anything like it, and you may feel deep disappointment and even betrayal at some of the story choices.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

This is an early review after about 90 minutes of playtime, after which the game crashed over and over and wouldn't allow me to progress. Technologically, this game is an absolute piece of malware garbage. The shader compilation took FOREVER...I'm not even sure it was finished by the time I started playing.

The CPU vs. GPU usage is completely out of whack...the game seems to depend on the CPU for an inordinate amount of rendering. And then, of course, there's the story and the characters, which I can sum up with two words: depressing and unlikable, respectively. And, mild spoiler, if you do end up liking a character, there's a pretty good chance he/she will die. Horrible waste of money; unbelievably over-hyped.

Plus, I'll also throw in the Covid comparison. This game is infinitely more upsetting after having lived through the last few years, when we all got a tiny taste of how unprepared society is for a global health crisis. This kind of bleak scenario is no longer pure fantasy. Some people really do devolve into horrible versions of themselves when faced with disaster.

Bottom line: if you remember this game from your PS4, you'll probably want to replay it. If you've never played it, run like the wind. There are SO many better new games out there, such as Dead Space and Forspoken. In my opinion, this isn't worth your time, either from a technical or storytelling standpoint.

text:
[NOTE: Play time is actually 7 hours as of the first update to this review.]

First, be warned - this is not the ORIGINAL Last of Us (Part 1), it is the remastered version, which in my opinion ruined the weapon and vitamin upgrade mechanics. The title should have listed it as the remastered version. Like I said, this is my personal opinion, which most players won't care about, but I thought why not mention it in case anyone else is picky about this too. 

Secondly, I too ran into shaders problem everyone else has. I chose the suggested solution to disconnect from the internet and it did go much faster (only took about 30 minutes total).

Lastly, and most importantly, are the games crashes. From the beginning to the part where Joel and Ellie meet Henry and Sam (where I stopped for the day) the game crashed over twenty five times, sometimes 3 times in quick succession. The good news is, I didn't lose much progress each time. The bad news is, how long it takes to reload each time. Hence I spent a day of reload after reload instead of actual game play. At least that is what it felt like. 

Very disappointing as it is now. Save your money until it's fixed.

UPDATE:
Installed all updates as of 4/9/23, including updating graphics driver as recommended for my Navidia Geoforce RTX 3080 computer.
Also, used another player's suggestions to turn off V sync and lock FPS at 70. 
     
Results were:
Shaders still took 30+ minutes to load even though I did as last time and had my internet turned off.
Load times are better, but still takes longer than it should.
A crash-free game for 4 hours, whereas before I would have crashed at least once an hour.
However, GPU still ran hard, though not as bad as before, so I did not play as long as I wanted, in order to protect my computer. 
There is now a weird look to graphics. It's hard to explain, but I can see texture of what's being displayed, mostly for larger areas of same color (like seeing the brush strokes of a painting). It was very noticeable at first, but I guess my eyes adjusted and I stopped seeing it as I continued to play.

So, while there is improvement, more needs to be done in my opinion. Older gaming computers will probably still have severe problems running this game.

So, my recommendation will remain negative.

Update 2:
32+ hours playtime now and nothing has changed regarding performance. Game continues to make my computer run so hard that after a few hours it crashes (always at a cut scene). I have completed the game and the DLC but the struggles to do so made this game a complete waste of my time and money. Another update is out of course, but these updates take so much of my computer memory, I'll probably uninstall the game and go back to replaying a favorite like Prey, Stardew Valley, Maid of Sker, or Resident Evil Village.

text:
The Last of Us has been one of my personal favorite games.
I love everything of it, the story, it's characters, the music, the atmosphere, the brutal hand to hand combat, and the overal atmosphere.

I am therefore sad to write this first, and quite negative experience.
And I am not a person who actually writes reviews.
This is one of the best games ever made, but the port of this game is a complete disaster.

I can see through the long shader buidling waiting time. It was annoying to wait like 45 minutes.
But, at least the game ran with a hick up here and there until it crashed when I took control over Joel in the opening scene.

Well, after each crash I can not restart the game anymore without rebooting my whole pc first.
Also here, rebooting my computer just takes a minute so, sure why not. Let's try again.

But now, if I even load into the game the fun part begins.
As soon as I press on continue, the game crashes to the desktop.
I have tried it 7 times now just to be sure, I was not missing something.

I think it is a very negative trend that so many companies release games with so much issues these days, but this is quite extreme in my opinion. I have not encountered many of the problems mentioned by others, simply because I was not able to get as far to run into them in the first place.

That is pretty sad.
Please stop releasing unfinished products for the full price.
This is not a ''oh a day one patch will fix those few issues''.

In it's current state, it is a damaged product and should not be sold for the full price.
Fix this game please, show care about your customers, respect the people who make you money, and give them the version of this game the people, and this masterpiece truly desserves.

People do not pay 70 bucks for Crashes or Memory leaks, unless ''Memory Leak'' is the title of a well optimized masterpiece.

text:
Well well well, what do we have here? The Last of Us Part 1 on PC, huh? More like The Last of Us Waiting for Shaders to Install Simulator.

I mean, seriously, what kind of sick joke is this? I thought I was downloading a game, not a freaking installation marathon. I had to wait for what felt like an eternity just for the shaders to install, and let me tell you, I've seen glaciers move faster than this.

But hey, let's say you have the patience of a saint and you manage to get through the installation process. What's waiting for you on the other side? Oh, just a little thing called constant crashing. Yeah, you heard me right. This game crashes more times than a drunk driver on New Year's Eve.

I don't know about you, but I didn't spend my hard-earned money to play a game that treats me like a crash test dummy. It's like the developers thought, "Hey, let's make a game that's as frustrating as it is emotional." Congratulations, guys, you succeeded.

In conclusion, if you're looking for a game that will test your patience and your computer's stability, then The Last of Us Part 1 on PC is the game for you. But if you're looking for a game that actually works, well, you're better off playing tic-tac-toe with a pencil and a piece of paper.

text:
Let me start by saying that I did not play the original game, and haven't watched the show yet. With that being said, I am completely intrigued by the story and the world building. The visuals are completely breath taking and keep me coming back for more.
A few hours into the story, I feel so overwhelmed with the game's atmosphere that I find myself actually terrified and shocked at times. I've found myself sitting on the edge of my seat at points, and I've grown to really care about the characters. Overall, I am completely enamored with this title and so thankful it finally made its way to PC. Unfortunately, that's where my praise ends.
This port is obviously based on a gem of a game, however, I am quite disappointed that my introduction to this franchise is mired by technical issues, including a seemingly never ending shader cache, poor optimization, and insane load times. Let me address each of these issues in more detail.

1. Shaders: I opened and closed this game around 30 times in an attempt to build the shader cache, let it sit over night with no progress, and eventually gave up. I've made it through an awful lot of the story at this point, all the while wondering if the visual experience (which can be truly breathtaking) has been altered or impaired by the lack of a complete shader cache. I frequently find myself blown away by the visuals in this title, but I am always wondering if it could have looked a bit better or if I could have gotten a few more frames.

2. Optimization: I like to think that with an R7 5800X, 32GB DDR5 RAM, RX 7900 XT, 1TB M.2 PCIe Gen 4 SSD, 12TB of HDD storage and a tiered caching software solution, I have a fairly high-end PC. In my humble opinion, I should have no issue getting a solid 90-120fps in a game like this. I DO NOT. This game is stored on my SSD to give it every opportunity to really shine, but it simply doesn't perform well. On Ultra settings, with AMD FSR 2.0 set to quality (I would prefer an FSR 2.1 or 2.2 implementation as 2.0 leaves something to be desired and causes trailing artifacts that detract from the otherwise gorgeous visuals, but I haven't found these options in any menu), this game barely keeps an average 60fps with the occasional dip into the high 40's. Obviously, this port needs a few more optimization passes!

3. Load Times: I cannot speak to the load times on the original title as I never played it. I do not own a PlayStation, but I understand they rely greatly on texture streaming. I can see an argument for hardware differences between the SSD in a PlayStation and a PC hard disk being to blame for the downright atrocious load times. However, I have the game stored on a Gen 4 M.2 SSD, and use tiered caching to vastly accelerate read speeds on my storage media. This is done by caching both 6TB HDD in a RAID array to a large chunk of my SSD (L2 Cache), and caching SSD data to 8GB of RAM (L1 Cache). Even with a cache hit rate around 90%, my load times from the main menu to the in-game world are measured in MINUTES, not seconds! After several minutes of staring at a loading screen, I wouldn't expect to have anymore issues, but between each "level" I still see "Please Wait" while the game attempts to load the next area/region. I say "attempt"; around half the time I see a loading screen, the loading process clearly times out and the loading screen never disappears, requiring me to close and re-open the application. For a story driven, and highly immersive game, this is gut wrenching. It reminds me of watching a crummy Netflix series and getting to the end of an episode only to be left with a cliffhanger, except with far more frustration.

All in all, The Last of Us Part 1 is fantastic game that was poorly ported and needs a lot of work. At this time, I can't recommend spending $60 USD on this title. Hopefully, the dev team continues to patch the game and get it across the finish line. If they do, and the performance issues are solved, I will gladly update this review. Until that time, you'd have a better experience watching a Let's Play on YT.

text:
[h1] The Lag of Us [/h1]

I genuinely don't understand how Naughty Dog and Sony even looked at dumpster fire of a PC port and thought to themselves "Ah, yes, it's perfect, boys its time to release!". My PC isn't really carrying the bleeding edge of technology when it comes to running games at a perfect 60-120 FPS every second a game is running, BUT my PC is just as capable as any other high-end set up when it comes running games that are graphically demanding like RDR2, CP2077, etc. 

Pardon my french but HOW do you fuck up a PC port this badly??? ND had like more than several months to get this ready for consumers, and yet they couldn't optimize this dogshit of a game before launch?? 
First of all, it should NEVER be taking this much of my VRAM to begin with in the first place. 
To play this at high graphics already made it push beyond my VRAM limits, actually insane. 
Luckily as of this recent patched version at the time of writing this, It's lil less laggy, and is kinda playable??
BUT still, after around 20-30 mins of playing, it already froze and crashed on my PC. 
Also, I had to wait 4-5 hours for this game to finish building Shaders so I had to keep the game running while I slept 
in order for it to be done with that. 
I honestly just don't get why it lags at like 25 FPS at HIGH graphics, when I can run RDR2 at like Ultra graphics with a near constant 60 FPS?

The game functions well graphically speaking as well as the game mechanics themselves, no issues with NPCs, crafting, UI, etc. It's a great game at heart, it's just REALLY REALLY unoptimized and badly performing. 

But hey, at least this current version of the game doesn't have Tess T-Posing in the fucking air compared to when it first released.

Honestly, if you want to buy this game, PLEASE I highly recommend that you DO NOT BUY THIS GAME until ND has fixed all the issues that should've existed in the first place. Wait like maybe 5 months? Maybe 5 more?? Who knows cuz at this point Naughty Dog's Support Team are scrambling like headless chickens to get all these issues fixed.

text:
Currently can't recommend until Naughty Dog fixes this bad port.
Played on Arch Linux and Fedora with these launch options:
[code]DXVK_NVAPI_DRIVER_VERSION=53179 %command%[/code]
Proton Experimental is recommended if you want to use DLSS.
Medium settings and FSR Quality.
[strike]Zero crashes so far, but the CPU usage (around 98%) just by decompressing assets is insane, resulting in bad stutter. Can be partially resolved on Linux by using different CPU scheduler like EEVDF, but you will be CPU limited anyway.[/strike] Fixed by v1.0.5 patch, only experienced one crash
[strike]VRAM usage is also bad, just changing textures to medium will eat my entire VRAM.[/strike] Fixed by v1.0.5 patch

[strike]EDIT: If you want to prevent this game hammering your CPU just by decompressing assets, then you can try faking your CPU topology on Proton with this command:
[code]WINE_CPU_TOPOLOGY=6:2,3,4,5,6,7 %command%[/code]
You can change it to any amount and specific threads you want. Everyone's CPU is different, so I can't say which threads are best for you.
This will of course lower your performance, but it's better to have CPU usage under 80% than 98% all time and have unusable system.[/strike] Insane CPU usage is fixed by v1.0.5 patch
[b][strike]EDIT (5/10/2023): v1.0.5 patch fixed most of the issues. It's still not perfect but it's finally playable. On the Steam Deck you need to increase swap (CryoUtilites can take care of it easily) to prevent crashes. I will rather still wait few weeks, but it's really close to recommend this game.[/strike][/b]
[b]EDIT (5/19/2024): Time flies really fast. They implemented FSR3 frame gen, which is kinda nice, but it was broken, now they fixed it, and also my saves got removed from Steam Cloud since last update.[/b]

keywords: run, setting, pc, fps, performance, port, even, low, still, well
text:
6 hours in and here's how its gone for me running a 10700 with an RTX 3060ti:

1st, the forkin' shaders took a solid hour to finish caching.  Absolutely no reason for it to be this bad. I appreciate letting them compile before starting the game, but an hour to get it done is absolutely ridiculous.

Once I got in game, I seem to be able to hold a solid 50fps if I set my max frames. Its not ideal, but its mostly smooth at that point.  Some random drops and hitched that seem to be coming from enemies being spawned into the game world.  Also get a bit of stutter when transitioning from brightly lit areas to dim, but nothing too bad.

My biggest gripe, besides a few CTD's, is the texture loading.  I have the game installed on a 7300MB/s SSD, and I see constant pop in or just low res assets being loaded with no high res textures in site.  This seems to affect items at random as replays of any particular section will have textures at their reduced quality in one run, with different items popping up with reduced textures in a replay of the section.  The most obvious example of this was when I came through a door, and the brick wall on one side of the door was full res, with the texture on the other side being very low res.  It was the same brick wall.  Just on opposite sides of a doorway. Waiting to see if they'll load seems to have no affect.

As other have pointed out, the VRAM usage is way higher than it should be for what we're seeing.  CPU usage is also way too high.  Expect to have both chugging along nearly maxed out at all times.  The bonus here is that it's cold outside where I am, and the extra heat my rig is throwing off is keeping my house nice and toasty.

You should definitely expect to be running with DLSS (or whatever equivalent you may be able to run) active from the outset.  Without it running I was having issues even hitting 30fps.  With, I can hold the aforementioned 50fps.

Bottom line: Iron Galaxy forked up another PC port.

text:
The underlying game is good but the PC port is very underwhelming. Not awful but way short of what I was expecting. I can forgive a twenty minute shader compile time if it eliminates stuttering; the problem is it doesn't. Not so much framerate but frametimes are all over the countryside. The game looks over-sharpened and has a hard contrast look even with the sharpening set to zero. There are numerous small bugs I've noticed despite not playing past the prologue which I've seen several times while trying to fix the issues with the game. I'm not going further until I decide whether to refund.  
There is no exclusive fullscreen and the game runs in a borderless window. Borderless windows are always a bit janky but while you can get away with it with RTS and strategy games, less so when you need smooth movement. Turning on motion blur does hide some of the frametime issues but it a poor substitute for a smooth framerate. I'm running 5950X and a 4090 so I'd suggest if you're on lesser hardware hold off until it's fixed.  
Horizon Zero Dawn launched in a worse state and eventually they fixed it and I'm hoping this will be a similar story. It's worth mentioning the game also comes with a slather of spyware that you can't turn off; only select less or more. As is, hard to recommend; a poor port to cash in the game's good reputation.
EDIT: I'm running a 5950X, 32GB ram and 4090. Hardly a potato.

text:
The game repeatedly crashes when trying to optimize shaders.  The shaders appear to be taking an hour(s?) to optimize.
My stable PC even bluescreen during shader optimization at one point.
Eventually it got past shader optimization.

Keyboard/mouse control rebinds have a variety of impactful issues.
The Weapon Cross(represented on a controller as the digital keypad), uses the keyboard's arrow keys, and you cannot move the weapon-cross keys elsewhere. The result: If you rebind your WASD movement to the arrow keys, you simultaneously start switching weapons as you move around the world.  Only 3rd-party keymapping programs can fix this.

Certain functions stop working at all when remapped to Numpad keys(Numlock on), like switching to your melee weapon on backpack, scanning for items, scanning for enemies.

Some of the multi-use buttons make sense on PS controller when there are a limited number of buttons, but on the PC, combining Reload/Quick Throw/Use or Weapon Swap/Listen does not make sense, and is awkward.  Fumbling around to find a key in a non-standard location is frustrating.  Another game that DOES do controller-versus-keyboard keybindings well is Call of Duty, seperating or combining functions for keyboard rebindings.

When the game does run, keybindings aside, it runs great.

I will update this review when the game is patched and can be launched and played decently.
