text:
[h1] The game is not optimal on PC yet so let's get that out of the way, luckily I recently played it on PS5, so here's my review of the game: [/h1]

First of all here's the positives, the game is a technological marvel in terms of graphical fidelity and sound design, Gustavo Santaolalla has done a phenomenal job with the OST, and the acting performances are stellar.
And that's about it.

[b] GAMEPLAY: [/b]
The overall game design is middling at best, and monotonous at worse, I don't mind slow paced games, many slow paced games are my favourite, but it's really boring in the sense that aside from combat encounters, the majority of the game is walking whilst mindlessly spamming the pickup button, moving a ladder or garbage cart, and to keep things fresh.....move a wooden plank when getting through a water level. It lacks the sophistication of traversal or puzzle solving in a game like Re4 or Re2 where each location is interconnected with one another forcing the player to create a mental map, where each item or tool you find is unique to one another and rewarding in terms of progression. As for the combat, it's serviceable, some quality of life improvements have been made to make it feel a tad bit more fun, but it's still void of any depth when it comes to human enemies, in regards to Clickers it tries to make things interesting(isn't rlly) by incentivizing you to crouch past slowly with the help of hearing button(making the monotony even worse), or use craft-able shivs, the bloaters are just clickers on drugs that shoot projectiles and that's about it, also worth noting that your first encounter with a bloater is a 1:1 ripoff the Dead Space 2 train segment where you're stuck hanging upside down, but without the build up that made that segment earned. It really doesn't help that the intro of the game takes 2 hours to start, ya know, being a game. The enemy encounters are placed so predictably, & there's no overall change to the layouts of encounters like something in DOOM for i.e, and there's very little level variety. Speaking of which, most of where you go next is not that different from where you were before, there's only one chapter in the game where there's a change of environment in a fresh way. I don't think I've read a single review that mentions this jarring flaw. And it's not that ND doesn't know these are factors of what make their games, heck an ex-ND employee literally mentioned the their games are focus tested to hell, if there's ever a segment that requires the player to use less than half a brain cell, they'll immediately simplify. I don't think that's inherently bad, but it's a problem when it's like this for the overwhelming majority of the game. Perhaps TloU would be a better game if the countless times you move from one building to another is at least cut short to focus on the combat, or if the buildings themselves were made to be engaging labyrinths. But hey maybe ppl like this. Oh and I must not forget, there's an inventory/skill upgrade system that's there to just exist I guess. There's 0 managing of survival items you find throughout the game, there's little decision making required in terms of the skill tree too, the weapon upgrades at least look cool I guess.

[b] STORY: [/b]
And so going back to that point where I mentioned that Dead Space 2 segment, this is a big problem with TLOU, it copies other pieces of media without understanding why certain things happen in other games & movies, and so I'm puzzled by the crazy extent of critical acclaim this game received as an "achievement in video game story telling", nothing regarding the narrative is reflected in the gameplay, and the gameplay itself is doing nothing special and isn't even executing it better than it's contemporaries even at the time of 2013. And in regards to the story, there's nothing stellar about it, as it's a blatant ripoff of Children of Men, with a bit of it mimicking Y The Last Man, but with the post apocalyptic backdrop of fungal zombies(so that it at least looks a bit different when it's borrowing TWD's plot points). Now there's nothing wrong with taking inspiration from several places, the issue I have is that nothing I'm experiencing here is unique, it's an amalgamation of the media it's remixing. A lot of things happen in the story because, well the writers want it to happen, rarely has anything happened organically in the story, and sometimes that can cause plot points to feel rather disjoint, for example in the intro where [spoiler] Joel reaches a check point, a soldier is ordered to gun him & Sarah down. Why? What's the point of the checkpoint if you're gonna shoot 2 helpless ppl? [/spoiler] Cuz calamity struck & humans bad 🗿? Seriously how cheap and derivative, I love it when films show more and tell less, but this fil- I mean game isn't even showing. You'll find numerous examples like this throughout the campaign. And what was depicted in that scene is kinda what bothers me, the game has not much else to say aside from the father daughter aspect that humans are just as worse as the zombies when calamity strikes, there's this misanthropic air throughout the entire story, which shows a clear miss-understanding of the story it's copying, in-fact I find it kind of disrespectful to Children of Men as that film's iconic long shot through [spoiler] the hospital building(which TloU also aimed to mimic) [/spoiler] was a scene intent to show that deep down inside humans are actually loving and selfless, and that they're not inherently hateful and violent, they're driven to be made that way via bad politics. Just recently the devastating earthquakes in Syria & Turkey for example, people dropped whatever they were doing and rushed to save as many of each other as possible, they were more loving towards one another than they were in their everyday normal lives. You won't see that in TloU, you'll see people eat each other apart, or make factions where everyone's a fascist. And yet Niel Druckmann claims that TloU is a study on the human condition and that it has something important to say. You can see how far up his own a** he has to be to say than, when 1. this is not how humans are, this is a POV presented in a psychology book by Le Bon in 1895 that every world leader during WW2 loved, Hitler, even Mussolini, the idea that humans are ready to erupt into anarchy whenever things go wrong, a concept that has been proven wrong multiple times throughout history.
2ndly, most of the game's story beats don't even come from a human place, they come from, well, other stories, like oh jee I bet nobody saw [spoiler] them cannibals [/spoiler] coming.

The some of the characters other than Joel & Ellie are often just literary devices to provide trauma fuel, rather than being actual people. And when it's not borrowing from other media, you get a contrived moral dilemma near the end that is too vague and unexplored to properly be called a dilemma and is an very dehumanising analogy for the 2011 freeing of an IDF soldier in exchange for some Palestinian. So basically Neil asked his dad what he thinks about the situation, his dad says this it's bad for their country, but he'd do it for his son, dawwh that's kinda touching isn't it, & what's gross about it is that it's very dehumanising in the sense that [spoiler] Joel saving a kid he's attached to at the cost of no cure for humanity, leaving zombies out & about, is akin to letting some Palestinians go home and be out and about [/spoiler]. On the surface it's a story about the love between a father & child (Just like The Road directed by John Hillcoat💀), but upon close inspection it's misanthropy disguised as a study on the human condition. Wrapped inside a game that shines due to it's polish rather than craftsmanship.



Thank you for reading as I've poured my heart into this review, for those that love TLOU, I'm glad it brought goodness to your lives.

text:
TLDR: Amazing game that got ported horribly. Unless you want to wait for loading times lasting 5+ minutes - wait for a few months after release and read reviews again if problems were fixed.

Let me just state that I love The Last of Us. I've bought it twice on PS4 and PS5, I played through 2nd part multiple times. It's the game that makes me sad that people who aren't into gaming won't be able to experience the same story and emotions that I did. It is one of those games that you get console for.
Now let's talk about execution of this port:
Pros:
- It looks good, very good. The character models, environment textures, the lighting - looks incredibly good. And this game supports widescreens!
- The performance is adequate. I'm running mid-level rig (ryzen 5600x, 32 GB RAM, RX 6800XT, 2k monitor), which is ~10% above the requirements for 2k resolution that was posted by developer. And 95% of the time I'm getting steady 60 fps. But there is a problem with loading time, read below...

Cons:
- Performance. I don't know how and why this happens, but even having game on M2 drive doesn't save it from loading time. It's so comically bad that I had to time it. I'm 80% done with the game at this point and I've spent: first 2 hours compiling shaders in main menu (because if I tried running the game before it was done - game would crash and imagine trying to refund this game afterwards, since your 2 hours of refund time ran out while you were staring at the main menu), during ~10 hours of gameplay I've stared at "Please wait" loading screen for 42 minutes. Sometimes I had to wait for 2 minutes for a game to load a 10 second cutscene and then I'll be facing same "Please wait" screen while the game was loading. What the hell is that?! To load up the game from main menu you also have to wait for around 5 minutes (had to wait less when running TLOU 2 on PS4 on HDD). My PS5 has less problems running the same game in 4k and you telling me a superior hardware can't do it? This is simply ridiculous.
- Bugs. I've played a lot of ND games, obviously most of them on PS4/5 and I've never encountered as many bugs as in this game. Don't get me wrong, it's not like it happens every 10 minutes, but when it happens - it breaks the game in a bad way. On multiple occasions: Ellie didn't jump on a float and Joel got stuck next to her. Had to reload the previous checkpoint. The workbench weren't usable even when the prompt to use it was showing, so I had to either ignore it or proceed to reload previous checkpoint;
- Controls. It got a little bit better with recent patches, but still feels weird. The mouse doesn't have a smooth motion, when you move it - it's as if you're not using a mouse, but rather you mouse emulates the gamepad stick. It moves in a ladder diagonally, almost pixel by pixel, which makes it look like your camera can't move in two directions simultaneously (either X or Y, gotta choose one). Some of the keyboard keys utilized are just weird, J to shake a flashlight? Very convenient, when I have at least 3 keys around WASD that aren't utilized.

text:
The whole spoiler text tells a story about a real life person and has nothing to do with the game's story so if you're interested, you can read it but if not then you can just read my review below the spoiler text (WARNING: for some of you the real life story can be more emotional than the whole game)

[spoiler]Let me tell you a story about a boy whose one of the major hobbies was video games as he was growing up
He would also spend time with his friends outside 
But as he would comeback home from friends or school he would either boot up his pc, his x360 or ps2 (that was all he owned and still owns it to this day)
One day in 2013 he finds out about a post apocalyptic game with an emotional driven story and as soon as he saw the gameplay he was blown away
He then started googling websites and see if he could download the game, he couldn't because it was only on consoles. He then went to online stores to see if he could order a physical copy of the game for his x360. He then found out that the game is only ported on ps3, something that he didn't owned and couldn't own because "your room is already filled with pc and two consoles, you really don't need a fourth platform" - said the parents. He eventually grew into his teens and desired the game more and more and started envy anyone who managed to already play it by now. He asked his parents if he could get a ps4 since it's more modern and has more modern games than a ps3 and a remastered version of the game but the parents still said no. Time passed by and that boy is now an adult, has a well paying job and a girlfriend, but the game he desired for almost a decade by now is nowhere to be found in his steam library (getting a console for one game is pretty stupid now that I own RTX 3050). One day around the fall of 2022 the guy who was once a boy, gets one of the best news of his life. The game he wanted to play since the childhood, is getting ANOTHER remaster and this time it is being ported to the pc. He patiently waited and waited, day by day with excitement. The day finally comes on March 28th 2023 (pretty much 10 years later by now lol). The guy install the game, unpacks the game and builds shaders which makes him wait another several hours. But after those few hours he gets to finally touch the game for the very first time in his life. And in the first 30 minutes of his gameplay, all of his smile, excitement and happiness gets shattered into pieces.[/spoiler]

I honestly don't even know where to start...
Guess I'll start from the very beginning
As soon as I went to options and saw that I have 4 VRAM and the game requires atleast 5 on lowest settings, I already had a feeling that the game is NOT gonna look great or even good before even starting it
In the first 30 minutes I saw: 
terrible looking character models
pixelated mirror reflections
few "please wait" texts popping up on my screen
even more terrible looking face models that were also missing a lot of detail
And I saw Tess literally having the time of her life by stroking up and down while T posing in front of me (that was the exact moment when I just didn't knew what to do anymore so I simply facepalmed)
Keep in mind that this was only 30 minutes
Later in the game I discovered "cyberpunk" areas (those who had this glitch will understand exactly what I mean)
Water that looks like oil 
Joel's thick, black eyebrows (surprisingly I didn't experienced black Joel like some people have)
And more "please wait" that extended way longer and forced me to just re-load my save file

The next day I continue this...torturous journey (yes I was really desperate to beat the story for the very first time in my life)

I say fuck it and decide to test out ultra graphics (keep in mind I have 4 VRAM). This is where I get a mini heart attack because the game immediately crashes and doesn't let me in because even the loading screen crashes (but I minimized my screen resolution to the lowest and managed to get back into the game)
More missing textures, more please wait and more "cyberpunk"
And also encountered several crashes 
Oh and almost every letter, whether it's in pause menu or main menu or notes that you read in the game or subtitles or pretty much any letters that appear in the game are missing and that was another problem that I had to overcome in the game because in some areas I would get lost and would need a hint but couldn't read it because 90% of the letters are missing so I am forced to pretty much restart my game
The game is basically more of a struggle and less of an enjoyment at this point
But I finally manage to reach an end of the game after many bugs, crashes and "please wait"s
Oh and you thought Left Behind was gonna get better right? well lemme tell you something, it was worse...

None of the issues I mentioned has to do with the story or it's characters. In fact some cutscenes would load up just fine and I would get to enjoy the emotional scenes without any bugs interfering. But it is a one big nasty interference of my enjoyment of the gameplay and in the end I ended up more disappointed than happy, because this was the game that I waited for 10 years (read the real life story with spoiler text to understand the context better)

Don't know when they will fix the game or even fix it or when will I own a PS5 because I really don't see a reason spending 600$~ just to play one game, but I know one thing that this whole experience was just sad...and my sadness has nothing to do with the story of the game...

text:
06-01-2023 - so many patches, and the game still isn't fixed.
The game was released March 28 FFS - Game uninstalled. Might check it several months from now.

Until then my review remains NEGATIVE.

----

Patch 1.0.4
NVIDIA driver update pack 531.68

Started the game over again for the X time, to see if it helped. Game wouldn't even start efter the patch. Veryfing files found an error.
Back to building shades from hell......

Rendering is better.
But after the patch, the game freezes every now and then for a few seconds. Then the xboxcontroller stutters, or stops responding.

Find it hillarious that I've supposedly played the game for 14 hours now, according to stats... LIES... I have spend time reinstallaling the game twice, adjusting settings, and waiting for the shade building. Not even once have I managed to get more than 45 minutes into the game, before I rage quit.

This release is a disgrace. 
The game should not be avaialble for purchase at all. We should all be offered a refund.


---------------
04-20-2023  Nvidia upgrade out so I thought I'd try again. Naive I know.
Couldn't even start the game. Un- and reinstalled. 
Then the same stuff obviously - 45 minutes worth of building shades and I lack words..... 


................................

Patch v1.0.3
NVIDIA driver update pack 531.61

And what's the change? Absolutely NOTHING - RIP to this game - once again building shades - force quit the game at 32%.

DO NOT buy the PC version, unless you have a monster PC gaming rig. 
Much better option, if you really want to play this game - buy the PS5 version.


.................

The patch v1.0.2.0 has helped a lot. 
Still not to the point were I can reccomend the game, but it's a start.

Combined with the NVIDIA 531.41 patch, there is now a visual difference. Still stuttering and odd rendering. Hair still pixelated. Slight blur if you make your NPC spin and turn fast.

Xbox controller now works.

Shade building after the patch started at 98% and it only took 5 minutes until I was able to start playing.
VRAM usage seems a little less heavy. CPU is still plenty busy, but not at 100% all the time.

Wating for the next patch. 

..................

Never in all my years of gaming have I played a fully released game that uses 100% CPU for over half an hour to build shades. 
I moved the game to a separate SSD to see if it made a difference. It did.... somewhat. Before the move, the shade building took almost 1 1/2 hours. At least now i "only" have to wait half an hour plus.

Game is supposed to have full controller support - it does not. 
My xbox controller that works fine playing other games, simply stops responding.

My character constantly gets stuck on inivisble objects, or simply stops walking all together. He can reluctantly be persuaded to run a litte faster than a turtle. And that only for ultra short bursts before he get's stuck again.

Getting my character to crouch, I have to spam my B button several times. Same with getting him to stop crouching.
Applying bandages only works half the time - and trying to fight the infected gets old fast.
Wierd rendering, stuttering and so much more. Having now tried to start the game 3 times, and NEVER even getting much further that a few mins into XX years later, I give up.

This is ridicolous.
I have never played a full release that performs so badly - even the worst ea game work better than this.

Can't even get a refund because I have "played more than 2 hours" - no I have not. I have waited for shade rendering, and have tweaked settings. As to actual gameplay 45 mins max.

text:
This negative review isn't a critique on the actual game itself but more the performance of the game in its launch state.
For context, I'm running this game at 1080p with the framerate capped at 60 on a mix of medium and high settings on a Ryzen 5 5800X3D and a 3060Ti. In most segments, my GPU is never at 99% usage. It's always fluctuating between 50% and 85% usage. As for my CPU, it's consistently above 50% on all cores which is problematic and I'm surprised that it hasn't crashed yet due to this. And oddly enough, In the few instances my GPU goes up to 99%, my framerate goes down to the low 50s on a system that should generally just function similarly to a PS5.
All of this to say that, despite this game's genuinely fantastic quality in the gameplay and visuals department, I do not  recommend going for the PC version right now (about 3 days after this game launched on PC) as it is just fundamentally broken on the performance end.

Building shaders at 0% again
Most likely Another 70 minute wait
Refund time will run out before I even start the game
Thank you naughty dog, you turned Last of us Part 1 into an Idle game.

(Edit) The developers/porters used a bugged release of the Oodle decompression library (2.9.6) which has confirmed memory leaking issues.

I moved a DLL file named (oo2core_9_win64.dll) From a Warframe install into the Last of us part 1's directory and the performance has increased quite significantly and the shaders were able to finish building in under 10 minutes compared to 76 minutes previously.

Not sure if this will work for everyone, people have reported that the DLL can cause audio issues or even more stuttering frame rate.

Hopefully this helps some people actually get in game let alone play the game they paid almost $100 for.

text:
First off, I would like to say that I thoroughly enjoy The Last of Us. I have watched a playthrough of this game 3 times before it came out on PC. I even decided to give the show a watch, while not as good as the game, I think it deserves it's own praise for what it tries to do. I was absolutely stoked when I heard that The Last of Us was getting a PC release. I would finally be able to play my favorite game that I never got the chance to play, or so I thought. So far, I have spent almost 4.5 hours building shaders, building more shaders, adjusting video settings, building more shaders, and crashing to destkop a total of 3 times in the first 30 minutes of the game: twice in the prologue and once right after. I have spent more time "getting the game ready" and dealing with it's issues than I have actually playing this game. 

I really want to give this game a good review. I REALLY do. I know Naughty Dog have put their heart and soul into the original, so it pains me so much to see it butchered like this for a PC port. I'm running a 3070 ti on a pretty beefy gaming PC, and I STRUGGLE to get a constant 60 frames consistently without stuttering and CTDs. I thought Cyberpunk had a bad rap for it's poor optimization, but let me tell you, I can run that game with ray tracing on high settings (albeit a bit framy), fairly consistently after its fixes in its current state. This game? Not a chance on even the basic medium settings.

I would give a lot to play this game (even now I'm currently debating upgrading my graphics card again just to get the extra vram that I need to make up for some of the issues), but I just can't justify anyone wanting to experience this game at a moderate level to buy it in its current state. I'm not sure if it's a driver integration issue, optimization, the porting team, or what, but I can tell you for certain, you won't enjoy the issues, and you are extremely lucky if you haven't encountered any yet.

Wait until the game gets fixed. As of now, Naughty Dog has released two patches for it in the first week of its release, and while I can't say if it fixed any of its original issues (as I haven't even had the chance to play it because I've been building shaders and working this entire week), they still exist. For the sake of the reputation of this game and new people wanting to experience it because of the show, I hope that the dev teams figure this out. This is still my favorite game, and I will still continue to try and play it, but I hope that it gets the love and care that it deserves and not this kind of treatment.

EDIT: After upgrading some hardware, it can be run without crashes. I believe the issue lies with how much VRAM the game consumes. With a large VRAM overhead buffer, the game seems much more stable and can be run without stutters or performance problems.

text:
Lazy remaster with a full price tag.

Lemme go into more details:

The inventory system is bad and finicky. For example, if you have a rifle in your hand and you quickly want to switch to a shotgun, because a clicker is running towards you. You have to press and hold the 1 button and scroll up to select the shotgun and then Joel will get it out of his backpack. But by then the clicker will be in your face and they can insta-kill you. And if you don't have any good melee weapons at hand it's game over.

This kind of weapon select system was good in the PS3 era when you had a controller which only had a few buttons but the PC version it should have been solved better. Like for example with a weapon scroll wheel like in GTA games.

Secondly, there's the cover system. When Joel takes cover behind cars, crates ..., he sometimes faces the wrong direction and you have to maneuver him around to make him turn to the right side which can be annoying due to the fact that your camera is facing more towards the direction in which Joel is looking. Sure you can press aim button and tab button to make him switch hands while aiming a gun but if let go of aim then he'll revert to his old position facing the wrong way. 


I played this game on my old PS3 and hoped that the PC version would have better mechanics, more suitable for PC gaming.

Lastly there are the performance issues that everyone is complaining about. I mean, open world games with better graphics run better than this, so what's the deal here? The game isn't even using raytraced shadows or reflections (you will notice that you sometimes can see your own reflection in mirrors but not on other shiny panels, like glass, water ...). So why does this game need so much system resources?

It is entirely due to the bad optimisation, not your GPUs or CPUs. And no, you should not have to overclock your hardware to run this game if you meet the minimum requirements.

text:
• CPU: Ryzen 9 5950x
• RAM: 32GB DDR4
• GPU: 4080 16GB
• 1440p

The Last of Us was one of my favourite games on the PS4 and I was excited to play the remake. For the first couple of the days this game worked well for me (for the most part) at 1440p with all settings maxed out at Ultra. I had major stuttering throughout the opening sequence and was nervous to play the rest of the game but everything settled down and played smoothly after that. I had a few minor graphical glitches but nothing more and had 0 crashes. In addition, the game looks beautiful with these settings but has a considerable drop in quality if you lower the textures.

After the first patch all of those graphical glitches seemed to have disappeared and the game continued to run smoothly. After the second patch the game became UNPLAYABLE. While everything was still smooth, the audio wasn't and was constantly crackling. None of the audio settings seemed to fix the issue, nor did restarts.

At Ultra settings, the game uses over 13GB of VRAM which is insane and is likely the cause of issues others are having. It seems you need high specs for this game and any GPU with less than 12GB of VRAM probably won't run well on Ultra settings. I have seen this game use 6GB of VRAM with graphics set to low.

In conclusion, I can't recommend this game, at least for PC. This is a masterpiece with an extremely shoddy PC port. As people continue to have issues, other things may break so it may be wise to wait until it's all fixed, if playing on PS5 isn't an option.

keywords: release, really, review, go, say, year, see, know, come, make
text:
It saddens me to have to not recommend such a beloved game. This isn't based on the story or characters or anything like that. This is based purely on how well this game runs.

According to Steam, I've played the game for "5 hours". I most certainly have not. Why? Because the load times are ridiculous, it runs about as well as Forest Gump before he figured out he didn't need the leg braces, AND I spent well over 2 hours downloading the shaders for the game just sitting in the menu. 

The first time I ever booted it up I was hoping the other reviews talking about how poorly it performs would not affect me. A mutual friend who also loves this game gifted it to me because he knew I couldn't afford to buy it myself currently. A real pal, thanks Phillips. While in the first loading screen to start the game, I sat for so long that I decided to bust out my blueprint writing homework and work on that while I waited. Eventually, for shits and giggles and for this review I knew I'd have to write, I thought "I should time this, it's already been a while". So I pulled out my phone and timed how long the first loading screen took me to even start the game. 4 minutes, 20 seconds, 5 milliseconds. THE longest loading screen I have ever sat through and no, I still didn't get to play the game at that time. The game promptly crashed. The second time? Loading screen was 1 minute 39 seconds. A lot better but still pretty long. I could forgive it if it meant I got to play one of my favorite games though, so I trudged on. Like the naive little bitch I am.

I like to think I'm capable of putting up with a lot. I don't have the fanciest PC that's ever run currently. It was a beast when I built it 7 years ago but of course now it's just a fine PC. Nothing to write home about but it's more than capable of getting the job done. However, I had such a horrible time playing through the intro that I stopped playing as soon as the game gave me control of modern-day Joel. So that was maybe 15 minutes of actual gameplay in? And that was no stealth, no combat, just walking and cutscenes. My average framerate was 28 FPS with frequent stutters and dips into the lower numbers. And yes, it got worse once the game picked up and more started happening on screen (ie. the car crash, explosions, infected running around town, etc). It got to the point where the dialogue no longer matched up with the animations, the game would freeze about every 10 seconds into cutscenes, and was extremely choppy. For lack of a better word. I wasn't expecting to be able to play the game on super ultra beautiful mode, I just wanted to enjoy one of my favorite games on the PC since I don't have a PS5 and now I'm left feeling as if I can't even do that. I hesitate to try it again, but I'm sure I'll try to play it again sometime this weekend. It just saddens me that this is the standard of gaming these days. I'm old enough to a remember a time when you could rush home from Gamestop, Hastings, Walmart, Target, whatever on the release date, plop the game in your desired console, maybe wait for an hour (depending on how far back we want to go..) for it to download and you played as much as you wanted without crippling issues till you got the red ring of death or the console sounded like a jet engine on a plane trying to take off. I miss those days.

Definitely do not buy this game and play it until it is fixed, if ever. Also, I too had to turn off the "film grain" option in the menus. It gave the game a weird look and it hurt my eyes. Just in case that helps you out as well.

text:
The Last of Us Part 1 has one of the most moving stories in video game history. I originally played it on the PS3 and it was a marvel of its time to end arguably one of the greatest generations for the consoles. That being said this PC port of the title doesn’t do the game justice. To put it bluntly, it runs terribly to the point of being unplayable. 

Now you will see reviews of people memeing and saying just get a better PC, but I have what is considered to be a high-end build with a Ryzen 9 7950X, 64GB of DDR5 6000Mhz Ram, a RTX 3080TI MSI Gameing X Trio, and all SSD storage. 

First loading in(after letting the shaders build and restarting), the game was utlizing over 12Gb of VRAM at 1440P Ultra. This wasn’t too much of a issue as I was getting roughly 80FPS with very small dips down to around 45FPS. For this style of game that was very playable and it lasted this way through the beginning prologuge. Then fast forward to meeting Tess, the game performance got dramatically worse when with larger dips. The dips occurred at scenes that didn’t matter though so I kept chugging along until just after the first introduction to the spore scene where it was unplayable. I dropped the settings, to try and conserve VRAM and get a more stable FPS when I experienced a hard crash. 

I have a RTX 4090, that I finally got around to ordering on the way mid April, but wanted to write this review for any interested in saying that this game is not playable at 1440P with a RTX 3080TI. Your milage, may vary if you force the resolution to 1080P with the same card.

That being said, I think this game when it was working looked beautiful, and I know it will be worthwhile to play once they fix at the very least the hard crashes. I am running the latest version of the NVIDIA drivers which at the time of this review is 531.41 so its also possible this may be a driver issue that hasn’t been reported yet..

From a optimization standpoint the game is actually well optimized for PC in the sense that it is making full use of the hardware, including benefiting from having a SSD, however its not translating well to ingame performance. I feel bad to say, but I would not recommend this game to anyone at the moment until, ether a combination of patches fix hard crashes, microstutters, etc. Alternatively, NVIDIA, comes out with another driver release to see if further optimizations for the game can occur. I will also just say that if your card has less than 8Gb of VRAM you should not buy this game.

I will update my review at a later point when my new GPU comes in but for now not recommended as well I can’t play the game.

text:
What a colossal disappointment. As I write this, The Last of Us is almost 10 years old. We waited a decade to be charged full price for a PC port that is literally unplayable.

On first launch, the initial config didn't display until the game was tabbed out and back into, and building the shaders took the better part of an hour while grinding everything else to a halt by pegging the CPU at 100%. Patch 1.0.1.5 addressed those problems, but even on an NVMe SSD, load times range from 2-5 minutes; it loaded faster on the PS3. While the opening cutscene looks stunning on Ultra, Vsync didn't work at all until forced on through NvCP, and the game runs no better and is just as likely to crash on Low. And when it crashes, it brings down the whole system, forcing a hard reset. Most of my "play time" was spent (re)building shaders and trying, with no success until Patch 1.0.1.6, different graphics options to reduce the constant crashing and omnipresent stuttering. Right now, it runs smoothly until it crashes, which it does with alarming and annoying regularity, and it still takes way too long to reload.

And this is just a few weeks after Sony whined to the courts about Microsoft/Activision leveraging platform exclusives or sabotaging competing platforms with buggy releases.

Edit: I did manage to eke out some extra gameplay by downgrading my graphics driver from the latest, which has a known issue of crashing TloU on 30xx series cards. It ran with some minor visual glitches but otherwise flawlessly for about 6 hours, after which point it just continued to crash over and over again.

Also, I just want to add that, as I wrote this review, Naughty Dog posted that the next patch is expected to be released on April 4. While Steam has been offering refunds, regardless of play time, Naughty Dog and Iron Galaxy let the game sit, broken and unplayable, over the first launch weekend.

1.0.1.7 resolved nothing, even with the Nvidia hotfix driver.

I'll be pirating The Last of Us Part II.

text:
Don't get me wrong, if I was reviewing the game for itself being just what it is this review would be extremely positive. However, this isn't a review of The Last of Us, this is a review of the PC port of The Last of Us. I have been waiting for nearly a decade (this game took way too long for Sony to port to PC) to play this game for myself as I never saw version exclusives as a reason for me to buy a console when I've been gaming on PC for over a decade. When I heard this game was receiving a PC port, I was ecstatic. I'd finally get to play one of the greatest games from the early teens. If only I knew what I know now: we'd be receiving a very shoddy port job courtesy of Iron Galaxy :). I don't want to cause anyone to stray away from this game (as it truly is one of the greatest, story-rich games of all time), but in the current state the game has been released in, I simply cannot recommend anyone buying it. If anything, wait for a sale or wait for the game to be released in a (hopefully) fixed state. Granted if you're really impatient, I hope you're okay with dealing with the game crashing every 30ish minutes or so. I still intend to play through and just suck it up and deal with the crashes, but this has been an eye opener that, even with ports unfortunately, it's best to wait and see how the quality of the port is prior to making a purchase. Again I reiterate, this review is only negative until they fix the crashing issues. 

TL;DR: An amazing, story-rich game unfortunately marred by constant crashes.

Update: I learned they've extended their refund policy for this game and have since refunded and gotten my money back. I will either use that money on the game at a later point in time after the crashing has been patched or (more likely) spend that money on Star Wars Jedi Survivor when that comes out at the end of the month. Whichever (probably the latter) comes first.

Update: over the last 2 patches the game got worse and worse. Loading times are now over 5-6 minutes, VRAM leaks are ridiculous and the game crashes often even before it loads!

The game played relatively ok while compiling shaders. Surprisingly after finishing compiling, performance didn't change at all, it still uses my i9 9900 100% not allowing my 5700XT to produce the frames. There is no stuttering, but it's CPU bound.

Artifacts are there left and right, like several scenes where out of the sudden everyone gets dripping wet for absolutely no reason, Tess having an extreme hair loss (only have her hair are there, she looks as if it's all white and you can see her skull through it), FSR has extreme ghosting and shimmering.

The worst of all is the ridiculous loading times. Over 5 minutes IF it loads. Many times it hangs and stops loading, others it just decides to quit. When dying there is nothing to do, the "spacebar" press that was available before somehow is not available anymore, so the game is just blocked there until it crashes.

I think it's a nice game, but they really have to fix all these issues. Hopefully they'll sort it out in a few patches time.

This is a broken port DO NOT BUY. The Refund of US
My rig: Ryzen 7 5800x, 3070 RTX and 32 GB of RAM.
Day 1 of TLOU - It works fine, until I launch OBS.
Day 2 of TLOU - It does not run no matter what I try, 720p low settings, 1440p high settings, all the same.
Barely 20 fps, 20 restarts later 60 fps 720p/1080p/1440p. As soon as you launch a game, you get graphics that are horrid as hell.
Day 3 of TLOU + Windows reinstall later, all new chipset drivers, gpu drivers etc. After building shaders still an absolute potato and still using 0% of cpu regardless of settings.
So for 2.8 hours I've enjoyed first 5 minutes of the last of us on pc, because it's completely and utterly unplayable.
Day 4 of TLOU - multiple playable launches with maximum potato quality looks.
Day 5 of TLOU - Instant crashes when booting up, game does not start at all.
Day 6 of TLOU - waiting for the big promised tuesday patch
TLoU - Day 7, yesterday was patch time... The big promised patch. They released a special Sauce drivers for RTX 30 series, that was supposed to fix the crashes.
Game runs now 2560x1080 60fps on medium settings and DLSS on.
And still crashes randomly for all the time. Time spent waiting in game for cache renders, and testing different settings. 4.2 hours. Have not even gotten out of the starting car drive section.
Still stutters weirdly even with all the updates. Updating as we get to a more playable state.
Day 8 - Big boy patch out. Fixed a lot, but I would recommend still not buying this, until they fix the performance. 
A lot of days later - Mixed baggage, the game either runs fine or randomly goes out of whack(graphics goes nuts or the game doesn't run at all), there is no consistency.
Basically, 2 weeks and 2 big patches later, still unplayable. I play 15 minutes after booting up the game at 60 fps and suddenly 15 fps.

text:
[h1] Sony took the fattest L [/h1]

This game took an hour+ to just build the shaders after crashing nearly 6 times during this while I did nothing but sit at the main menu and wait. I did not purchase the game as I played it through Family Share. If your friends own it, see if you can family share the game to try it out first. 

[b] This is an apocalyptic failure [/b]

Sony trusted one of the least like or respected companies to port us a masterpiece after seeing the hatred the community has against Iron Galaxy for previous works. First we suffered Days Gone rendering horribly, then HZD and its fps stutters and now MY MOST ANTICIPATED rerelease, and you spit in my f**kin' face? 

Sony (and Naughty Dog) you know we love your games, clearly. We keep giving you our money for your games, so why are you not taking the upmost care for the community patiently waiting for you to get your head out of your ass and release your IPs on Steam for PC. Yet you've done nothing but ruin it nearly every time. 

You blew it out of the water with the Marvels Spider-Man and MM. You and Nixxes did it, you were amazing. Now you've managed to ruin any hope for the future of your releases all because of Uncharted and The Last of Us. You keep letting this happen and you need to stop. 

All I am saying finally to this is if Bloodborne, the diamond in the rough that I am hoping to see SOON releases and suffers the way the past releases have been, I can maybe at least say for me and a decent majority of your supporters will never trust Sony as a valid hope for PC games. 

Take your time Sony (and Naughty Dog). Fire Iron Galaxy and never fu**ing work with them again. You guys literally have Nixxes. Its proved time and time again that it works better.

The Last of Us Part 1 is a highly anticipated game that recently released on PC, and as a fan of the original console version, I was excited to dive back into this post-apocalyptic world. However, since a recent update was released, the loading times have become unbearable and make the game unplayable at times. This is a huge disappointment, as it significantly impacts the overall experience of the game.

Aside from the technical issues, The Last of Us Part 1 is still an incredibly well-crafted game. The storyline, characters, and world-building are all expertly done and draw you in from the very beginning. The gameplay is smooth and satisfying, with a mix of stealth and action that keeps things interesting.

As for my PC system, I have an AMD Ryzen 9 with an Nvidia RTX 2080Ti and 32GB RAM, which should more than meet the game's recommended system requirements. Despite this, the loading times are still unacceptably long and detract from the overall experience of the game.

In conclusion, The Last of Us Part 1 is an excellent game that unfortunately suffers from technical issues that make it unplayable at times. I would highly recommend waiting for a fix to the loading time issue before purchasing, especially if you have a similar or lesser PC system to mine.

" BUILDING SHADES 1% " NOPE, NOT WAITING 16 HOURS AGAIN.

Due to Steam's totally fair refund policy, I'm already over the 2 hour timer (only 10 minutes of actually being in the game, the rest of the time was sitting in the main menu waiting for the shaders to build), and I pre-ordered the game during Christmas. I refuse to even attempt to play this game until I get consistent frame-rate, no stuttering, and all of the other issues in the game. I also refuse to wait another 16 hours for the shaders to build (that's not an exaggeration btw, you hear most people waiting eh, an hour, maybe 2.. text: Was so excited to see this game come to PC. I actually own it on PS4, but the overhauled graphics and such on a much more powerful system one would figure it would get better. The launch reviews were rough, and I thought I had made it through with a good install. I waited the 1 HOUR AND 15 MIN for the shader compilation processing. Everything was great, no graphical corruption, or any of the crashes I have seen about online and in other reviews. That is until about 3hrs in and I hit about 8 stuck spots in total. Every single time the NPCs would path into a choke point and I could not progress the story without restarting each of the segments. This last one, I cannot even work around it by rolling back to the check point. Elle popped into the path in front of me and is just standing there now. I would have to restart the entire section/chapter, which I was just about at the end of. The graphics overhaul looks amazing, the fluid simulations in the puddles (actually all water for that matter) look amazing. The Keyboard and mouse controls are actually quite intuitive. Which normally I would praise, but not when I can't play the game without speed running it always staying in-front of the NPCs, or constantly reloading back at checkpoints and having to re-play through them so I can stay in-front of the NPC's. I am over the time for a typical refund but this seems to be the trend for this game. I should have listened to the reviews. I have also recently refunded Days Gone for how horribly that was ported. I also ended up purchasing and returning a Sony branded gaming monitor because it was so poorly built, and has borderline false advertised features. I was very excited when Sony decided they better start stepping into the PC realm with their games/gaming centered brands. I exclusively buy Sony TVs, and was ready to expand that over into my PC life as well. I am done buying just about anything Sony at this point however. In the last two years I have seen their quality flat out tumble to nothing except the TVs, just so happens my Sony headphones just crapped out this week as well. I don't recommend really much of anything from them at this time, sadly, including this game.

text: However good you think your PC is, it's not good enough lol. I have a AMD Ryzen 5 5600X 6-Core Processor with a 3070 and 16gb of ram. Not the best but definitely above average and should be able to run this game perfectly fine on at least high settings. I bought this game after looking at the reviews so I knew I was gonna have a rough time but I at least thought the problems would start after I opened up the game, but to my surprise whenever I tried to open it said that windows 10 or higher is required (I have windows 11) after about an hour of trying to fix it I finally got the game to start. Got into the main menu and I made sure not to do anything before the shaders were done installing (to ensure my CPU wouldn't explode) which took as long as you think it took. Then I created a save and started playing and took a look at how my memory, CPU, and GPU was doing. CPU was consistently at 100 percent even though i waited for shaders to download like everyone said to do so this doesn't happen, of course it did anyways. To my surprise my 3070 was at 98 percent and my memory was at around 80 to 90 percent which is okay compared to the rest. Keep in mind I am on medium settings not even high. Then i switched it to low and it didn't change at all. At this point I didn't care and continued playing and surprisingly it ran well up until the 20 years later chapter and I had insane visual bugs, I can't even explain how bad it was so i restarted the game and nothing changed. For everyone looking at these reviews, it does not matter how good your specs are, this game is a joke and most of these reviews are going very lightly on the game. Even if you have the most insane modern pc with a 4090 you will still have insane bugs that makes it unplayable anyways, and that's if you get the game to even start. I thought cyberpunk 2077's launch would go down as the worst in gaming history (which is a incredible game now) but this is so much worse.

text:
***************                TLDR               ********
Your experience is going to vary from ''unplayable'' to a ''great time'' depending on the hardware you are using. If your computer is custom built your basically gambling if it will work or not, so I have to change my rating to Not Recommended.
**********************         TLDR        *********************

So far Ive been playing on my 2021 Razer blade 14 3060 on Low-Medium settings, DLSS on auto. When it was unlocked Frame Rate I was getting an unstable 100FPS and while it mostly felt smooth enough, the quality looked so downgraded so I locked it to 60 and it looks much better as DLSS isnt working so hard top achieve max FPS. Seems to help but from one area/ cut scene to another, things vary from "pretty **cking good" to "did this look better on PS3?" in regards to textures being so smoothed out and low level detail on both environment and characters. Overall playable though and mostly locked at 60FPS TBH. 
I LOVE playing TLOU with mouse and Keyboard! this is the way it should be played being able to flip the camera behind you  quickly while running away from runners, Im embarassingly bad at aiming with a controller so this is the best way to play for me. But still, I cant help but feel like the PS5 version is the definitive way to play this game with how badly optimized this port is. 
That being said, THIS IS PLAYSTATION and they're flagship IP, I  don't see them sitting idly by while people and critics rip it apart. They're more then likely going to throw resources at this to save face ASAP... And hopefully by your next playthrough it will be the best way to play TLOU P1... Im being very optimistic here, but mods and player fixes will definitely enhance the experience in th future. But the fact it was even released in this state baffles me so who knows what PS is thinking.
*** I Have had a very different experience with my desktop (2070 - 9700k - 32GB RAM) So the first time I loaded shaders it crashed and lost all progess. After the second attempt i got impatient and loaded the game with 17% shaders compiled, then crash to black screen until I reset my PC. so finally I got the shaders loaded it took almost 2 hours to finish this last time. I am able to play and havn't had any major bugs or crashes, but this is an issue, and if it didnt work It took so much time that I would have to dispute a refund as my 2 hour grace period is up.

text:
I don't write negative reviews or really any reviews in general, but this game is something special. I love The Last of Us to death, it is still one of the best stories I've ever had the privilege to play through. I've played the remaster 10 times and 9 of those on the hardest difficulty, so it's fair to say I love this game. 

With that said DO NOT BUY THIS RIGHT NOW. The game is poorly optimized and crashes consistently. Most machines that are over the recommended specs (mine included) can not play this game reliably. If you really want to buy this game (and don't own a PS5) then I would suggest waiting a few months to see if they ever got this thing fixed. If you do own a PS5, just buy it on there as, unless your machine was built this year with the most expensive parts money can buy, you won't be able to run it at the quality of the PS5 version anyway. 

I want to see this port fixed, I want the PC community to be able to play this game that is so dear to my heart, and I want to see what modders will end up adding to this game. But as it stands now, as much as I hate to say it, do not purchase this game right now, you will be disappointed.

text: To start, I love this franchise and have played The Last of Us on PS3 and PS4, and even though Steam says I've played for 5 hours, I've actually only played for 30 minutes maybe and hour at most. It's caused my computer to crash 3 separate times and reboot, and on Steam Deck it's even worse. I have a laptop with a 3070, and normally I can play most games even Cyberpunk at High with 60fps. This game gets maybe 30-40 at medium with DLSS set to Performance. On Steam Deck I get 20-30 at low with FSR2 set to ultra performance. The game is very poorly optimized and has a 1-2 hour wait for shaders to build before first play. I loved this game when it first came out on PS3 and when it was remastered on PS4 but on PC this version is virtually unplayable for long stretches. I want to play it because I know the story is worth it and I want to support Naughty Dog, but as of this moment I would not recommend picking it up. I'll update my review if this gets patched, but right now it's hard to recommend unless you have an extremely powerful computer. Othewise, you'll be lucky to get a solid 60fps.

text:
I was given this game for a review.  I cannot recommend this on all honesty and this is the first time in my life that I am going  to review this on a digital magazine as strongly negative and put me in front of the line against Sony itself but I need to be honest with my readers.  This is in no way production ready.

First, allow me to state my specs so you understand why I'm not recommending it:

Basic Specs:
- Core i9 13900K
- 128GB DDR4-3200
- RTX 3090 Ti Custom Water Cooler
- 1 x 2TB WD SN850 as boot drive
- 2 x Intel RAID0 - SN850x as gaming drive
- SoundblasterX G6
- LG C1 OLED TV

Now onto Refrigeration:
- Lian Li O11 Dynamic XL
- Top: Watercooler for CPU: Liquid Freezer II 360 with fan's replaced by 3 x Phanteks T30-120 running at 2000RPM max
- Side: 3 x Intake Noctua NF-A12x25 PWM
- Bottom:  30mm Corsair XR-7 360 Radiator + 3 x Phanteks T30-120 running at 2000RPM max
- Rear:  1 x Noctua NF-A12x25 PWM
- Extended Heatsinks for each M2 on the system.

Now onto performance:
- CPU at full load during this game:  66C celcius
- GPU at 4K + DLSS on Balanced averanging 90 FPS at ULTRA settings:  59C celcius
- 41C for the main M2 drive
- 44C for RAID0 drive1
- 45C for RAID0 drive2
- No overclock on the CPU
- No overclock on the GPU
- Average Cinebench performance for my CPU:  41250
- Average Read/Write speed for my Gaming RAID0 in CrystalDiskmark:  14420/12950

As you can see, my system runs beyond normal parameters, with extremely low temperatures taking into consideration the hardware at hand.

The first time Building Shaders took 10 minutes with all CPU's at 100% -> completely unacceptable.

First time playing the game, got 10 freezes and 3 crashes in just 1 hour of gameplay, could never go past the prologue.  After researching over the internet, it was found out that the libraries for: 

nvngx_dlss.dll
oo2core_9_win64.dll

Have issues. I've replaced both and the game magically stopped crashing.  I was able to start playing it, for real.  That is until yesterday when the crashes began once again.  

Reason:  a new patch got out and it took me some time to realize that the actual patch overwrote those files again so naturally the crash-fest started.   I've overwrote those files again and naturally, everything started working again.

Today the crashes began once again and sure enough, a new patch was out.

Conclusion:  Even with all this time they had on their hands, they managed to keep introducing crashes because their current libraries are bugged.  This may not crash for some, but for others like me.. this is totally unacceptable.

I'm running a high end PC with last Windows 11 22H2, rock solid with no overclocking and an extreme cooling solution for both CPU, GPU and M2 units.

Game still runs like garbage and they still refuse to replace the broken libraries.

Now, taking all of this aside and considering that I've managed to fix it by replacing the libraries (as most people did), the game moves like crap over the mouse.  I've tried every possible solution but mouse movement is like moving the mouse through sand,  it is almost unplayable unless you force your refresh rate to 60hz and enable vsync, which will totally kill inmersion for me as I specifically built this PC to be able to enjoy 120hz, which is also stated as an option on the main menu of this game.

They launched the game with broken libraries that send tons of PC's into oblivion taking hours to compile shaders when they could just fix that by replacing the broken library for : oo2core_9_win64.dll  which changed my building libraries from 10 minutes down to 1 and also removed all of the crashes but they didn't.  They didn't fixed the mouse movement on a game that they launched on PC where the most important attractive is to be able to move your character with the mouse for christ sake and on top of this.. they put the bar so high on the VRAM usage that most of the people without 24GB of VRAM are forced to lower the graphic quality.

I'm not engineer but jugding by the way this game uses the memory (both RAM and VRAM) I could swear they tried to replicate the PS5 memory behavior by replicating the storage on both RAM and VRAM like this is a shared RAM system, and I say this because every time the RAM memory usage goes up, so it does the VRAM.

Right now, when I have VRAM at 10GB I have the main executable using 10GB of RAM and when my VRAM goes up to 14GB, my main RAM usage also goes up to 14GB.  Pardon me for suspecting that they are actually dumping RAM into VRAM to simulate a PS5 but that is what it appears to be happening, which could explain the super slow load time, which is 5 minutes to load a map... WITH MY CURRENT STORAGE SPEED.

And with all this being said, I get constant stuttering, jitter in mouse movement, maps and sections that take minutes to load and the need to mess with local libraries for the game to run properly.

You cannot say my CPU is overheating
You cannot say my GPU is overheating
You cannot say my storage is overheating
You cannot say my CPU is insufcient
You cannot say my GPU is insuficient
You cannot say my storage is slow

So, what can I say then?.  I think the truth is pretty evident.

text: I wish I could recommend this, I genuinely do. It seems to play fairly smoothly, once the shaders are finished building, however that takes quite some time. While you can play the game while the shaders are building, the game doesn't recommend it. Here's where the big problem comes in, while sitting on the main menu waiting for these shaders to build, the CPU maxes out. Within minutes, cores 0-4 hit temperatures of 100 degrees Celsius. Simply waiting for this game to install can melt a CPU. I had to launch and quit in about three minute increments, but once done the game ran decently with some stuttering, though sustained CPU spikes were still occurring, albeit somewhat infrequently. Please be mindful of this because neither Steam, Naughty Dog, Iron Galaxy, or Sony are going to replace your laptop/processor. There have been two hotfixes released within the last two days, so there are signs that this game's state is being worked on, however it shouldn't have launched in this state.

text:
Postponed release date, no review copies for media, ... they knowingly released a broken game, totally overpriced anyway, turning early buyers into cheap beta testers, and ruined the experience for many people excited about playing it for the first time.   
I tried TLOU 1.0.1.5 and 1.0.1.6. Setup is RTX 3060 Ti (8GB VRAM + 16GB Shared, 531.41 driver), i7-10700F, 32 GB RAM, 720p. Compiled shaders before starting the game (45 minutes). Game continued to crash during the first minutes of the prolog. Not to mention shader or texture bugs. After reducing from default config to high, I could at least do the prolog, but the next crash was not far away. This is no fun. And the practice of releasing broken games deserves boycott.
---
Edit 4th April: Just installed the nvidia hotfix 531.58 and the 1.0.1.7 - the shader compilation starts all over again. So suggest to wait until the patch next Friday arrives, which hopefully reduces the compilation time significantly.
---
Edit 8th April: 1.0.2.0 and/or 531.58 seem to have done the trick. The shader compilation stukk took - once again - 50 minutes. But the game itself seems to run now much more stable and less resource hungry.
---
Edit 13th April: With the above patches and hotfixes, I have not experienced crashes anymore. The only bug that sometimes annoyed me was the broken scope, which many seem to experience from time to time. The game itself is one of the best story games - visuals, sound, story writing, characters, voice acting etc. is all top notch. I liked is as much as Telltales Walking Dead, Cyberpunk 2077, Red Dead Redemption 2, Half Life Alyx, Detroit Become Human and the likes. Definately a must play, if there was not that hefty price tag...

text:
So I will write this by emphasizing that the first TLOU is my favorite game of all time, I am NOT writing this bad review of the GAME ITSELF, only the PERFORMANCE of it, how it runs. In the regard of the game-play combined with the story this game is easily a 10/10 to me, especially since I have already played this games remastered version back in 2013 and beat it MULTIPLE times.

So when it comes to a remaster the main thing to discuss is how well the game looks and runs. Now I run a RTX 3080 Ti, AMD RYZEN 7 5700G with 32 GB of ram. My computer is considerably beefy, and for the life of me, I can NOT get this game to run smooth in almost any area of the game. It is choppy and terribly optimized. Overclocking helps a bit but it makes the game crash faster it seems. My modded Skyrim with 600 mods runs better than this.

There is no combination of NVIDIA Control Panel settings or in-game graphics settings I can use that makes the game run well while making it look well. I would have to half the resolution to make it at least 60 FPS and even then the game is choppy and stuttering. The game looks gorgeous whenever you stand still and take a screenshot, but the moment you start moving, it turns into a mess. 

Now as for crashes I have only experienced 2, which for a single player game is not good by any means, but this only seemed to happen whenever I overclock my GPU so I just steer away from doing such and I am fine, but by no means does this excuse the countless people who are complaining about up to 14 crashes which is just unbelievable. 

Now for the question... should you pay 70 dollars to buy a game that has been optimized as good as Cyberpunk? Not right now. Sadly, we have to do a similar routine of: Game release, game runs like shit, gets shit on for running like shit, then after 6-8 months the game is actually playable. Now, to be fair, they ARE releasing daily updates about this game. I don't know what they do, but they are actively fixing it I hope. 

TLDR: DO NOT BUT THIS GAME RIGHT NOW IT RUNS LIKE ASS, MAYBE COME BACK IN A FEW MONTHS.

text:
Last of Us Part I looks beautiful and game play is good, even the game is sort of tunnel run from the old days in this time of open world games but at this moment, this game is just unplayable for me personally because random crashes to the desktop. The release day they happened pretty much after 5 minutes of play time, now you may get to play an hour or two if you're lucky but they will come and then again it is back that 5-10 min time frame.

For Sony and Naughty Dog, this PC release seems to be money grabbing scheme in the wake of the TV-series hype, as the original game was released 10 years ago or so, remastered after that couple of times and re-released and you still dare to ask full price. But hey, that seems to be the way these days and like they say in my country, the one asking the price ain't the fool, the one paying the price is.

I wouldn't have bought this game myself but my nephew got it for me as a Christmas present 3 months ago and because of that I decided I want to experience Last of Us as it should be for the first time, so I didn't even watch the over hyped TV-show to not spoil the game experience for myself.

So far the silver lining in this is, that for some reason, my nephew got to play the game without crashes and his PC is less powerful than mine, partly made of parts of my old while I have the newer CPU, motherboard and better()?) GPU.

It seemed that the game run pretty much perfectly for next PC configuration: Intel i5-11600K, Asus TUF Z590 motherboard, 16 GB RAM, 256GB + 1TB M.2 SSD and Asus ROG Geforce RTX 3060Ti with 8GB VRAM.

For my configuration, result are the random crashes to the desktop with specs: Intel i5-13600K, Asus TUF Z790 motherboard, 32 GB RAM, 500GB + 2 TB M.2 SSD and Asus TUF Geforce 3080 with 10 GB VRAM.

Another difference is that my nephew is still using Windows 10 and I upgraded to Windows 11 sometime in November 2022, so who knows, maybe all of this partly Mickeysoft fault as well?

My advise to those thinking of buying this game, do not buy, not until it is in Steam Sale with more than 50% discount. I usually buy my games from Sales like that because last decade or so, the big game publishers have become more greedy and push their games to the public before they are finished and properly tested.

text:
The Last of my CPU

PC ports are always bad, but I've yet to have seen something as bad. I've a 3070 and an overclocked i7. Even then, I can't smoothly run the game, and somehow, the patch they released started giving me crashes left and right.

To those who still wish to play the game, you literally mod it. Downgrade from DX12 to DX11, replace the Oodle decompiler in your folder with a fixed version (nab it from any other game or google where to get it), use some DLL tweaks off of a modding page and maybe, maybe then - you can have a smooth experience.

In my case, before the unPatch, the game ran with so many micro-stutters I couldn't believe my FPS was 90. The mouse movement feels jittery and jagged, n' at parts - even on the lowest settings the game manages to look like a Roblox knock-off and still run with 30 FPS.

Until then? Don't touch it until you see a positive feedback from the playerbase. If you already bought it, welcome to the trenches. Don't let them off the hook for releasing the game in a state like this.

text:
I've been looking forward to this game for years since I never owned a Playstation. Bought the game the first week of release and tried to play it on the Steam Deck. Crashed within the first few minutes, trouble with the controller, really bad rendering.
So, I thought, I will try this on my PC and see if it runs better. Even with a 3090 and i9 13900k, this runs like garbage. My PC plays all the other AAA games just fine with very low temps, but this game destroys my CPU.
EDIT: I've been playing now for a few days and some of the issues have been resolved -- including the high CPU utilization and high temps. The game still does have some crashing issues every 15-20 minutes, but I'm hoping that they fix those soon. 
Other than that, the game is great. Good story and great graphics. I'm going to keep this as not recommended until they fix the remaining crash issues.

text:
I originally left a positve review, but after finishing the game I will be switching it to a negative review.

The game ran fine, I had no issues there. No crashes, and it seems after the newest patch the shaders build much faster. Game looks and run great!

But after finishing the game, I'm not sure it's worth $60. The story was pretty great, and I thoroughly enjoyed it throughout, although the game play just isn't fun.

I'm not sure if it's just meant to be played on a controller, but with mouse and keyboard the combat seems far too easy even on survivor, and never really had problems with ammo or supplies. The AI is probably pretty bad even for 2013 standards (although this is a remake) and it's a bit puzzling how it was both this simple when the original released, and how they probably didn't touch it in the remaster.

Enemies "flank" which is basically them leaving cover to walk up for a free headshot. Other enemies sit in place and will not move, making it easy to flank them in return. The stealth is a bit of a joke, where it seems the enemies will always move towards you, allowing for easy stealth/shiv kills. You can clear entire areas without firing a shot or moving from where you are. Just throw a bottle and stealth kill away.

The crafting/looking for resources is a bit of a chore. Doesn't feel like exploring is really that well rewarded in terms of interesting collectibles/lore. A few interesting stories here and there like that of the sewer base that is overrun, but nothing too crazy.

It's by no means a bad game, but a game that is probably a bit overrated due to it's good story. I think it would be fine to hold off on this until it's closer to $30, rather than pay the full $60 if you've been waiting all this time to finally play it like I have. I don't know if I'll ever replay this as the story was the only part pulling me through, and the actual gameplay part of the game isn't great.

Much better remakes/remasters are out there. Go play RE4, Deadspace, or Days Gone which are much better games imo.

text:
I was waiting months to play this. I really enjoy all of Naughty Dog's work, and the ports for Uncharted were *mostly* flawless. For reference, I play on a Ryzen 9, 3070, 32GB DDR4 3600.

Problems started during first boot up. The water effects glitched, creating oversized polygons on impact and lowering my fps to 5 or below. Restarted the game and that fixed it. 

I played for two more minutes, got to a cutscene, game crashed. I restarted the game and played for 5 more minutes. Got to another cutscene and the game crashed. I decided to stop there. 

In total play time of 30 minutes, the game crashed twice and had one critical glitch that required restart. This is absolutely unacceptable for release, and I can't even begin to comprehend how this would pass QA. This has to be the worst AAA release I've ever experienced first hand. I hope they do the right thing and fix these issues.

**UPDATE 04/01/23**
Was able to lay a few hours straight without a hitch after the last two hotfixes. Constant crashes started occuring again further down the storyline.

text:
I wanted so badly for the other reviews on this game to be wrong, but here's my experience:
Took forever to download.
Took forever to unpack.
Took forever to validate.
Took forever to compile shaders.
Crashed during the introductory gameplay sequence.

To be honest, I don't mind all of the time it took to download, unpack, validate, and compile. I'm a patient person and I won't give a game a thumbs down for that. But for a game to boast how fantastic it looks and then crash even when running the 'performance' settings, that's just sloppy. Graphics to me are a nicety but are way at the bottom of the list of priorities for a good game. If a studio cares more about great-looking graphics than about stability, they failed. I now have over an hour invested in this game and still haven't gotten through the intro. To be fair, I'm playing on the Steam Deck, but this is the first game I've tried to play on the Deck that I couldn't. I would have preferred the Remastered version's graphics with stable gameplay.

Final thoughts: I LOVE LOVE LOVE the PlayStation versions of this game so it hurts me on the inside to give the PC version a "thumbs down". I gotta be honest: unless your computer is a beast, you won't enjoy this experience. I'll change my response when the problems are resolved.

When I started the game today I quickly realized that loading the "shading" was going to take too damned long for comfort (more than two hours), and that set off alarm bells in my head. Too bad too, because I really wanted to give it a try. And it's the first time I've had to ask Steam for a refund. It seems to me that the company who made this game rushed to market with an unfinished product. I guess I'll have to wait a while and see if they can fix it. In the meantime, I'm too poor to buy a console just to play one game, and since my left hand is mostly paralyzed, I can't operate a hand control anyway.

Whoever's responsible for this should get their act together quick-smart.

I only have this game because I received it for free via an AMD promotion, otherwise I would never fork out this much money for something so badly made for PC. I'm not ashamed to say that I would have happily sailed the high seas instead.

text:
The Crash and Stutter simulator of Us, PC players.

Seems like playing with PS5 Dualsense is fine but oh how I'm so wrong.

The stuttering issue persists even if you're using PS5 controller but it's significantly much lesser than using the mouse and keyboard.

Shader compiling takes 30+ minutes but that's fine by me. I'd rather wait than having to play Stutter Protocol all over again. But even after shaders has been compiled, the game still manage to run like crap. The VRAM usage is inconsistent. Some scenes 11.5GB of VRAM some scenes just 9GB.

So if you would like to play this game now, USE THE PS5 CONTROLLER FOR THE CURRENTLY BEST EXPERIENCE, i guess. If you use M&K, you will be frustrated with the stuttering issues or better yet, WAIT FOR THE FIXES THAT TAKES ROUGHLY ONE MONTH (based on what they did with Uncarted).

At this point if Sony still hasn't fired the whole team in Iron Galaxy, I don't know what to say. Uncharted was once abyssmal and now this.

Edit Don't get me wrong, I LOVE THIS GAME. This game is one of the best game I've ever played on PS. The graphics are almost realistic and beautiful. The story is rich, the gameplay is very smooth and fun and the soundtracks are literally pieces of art. But this port this unacceptable.

Edit2: I was one of the lucky ones who don't have any crash issues. Now new patch just came out (1.03) and now I just can't launch the game (at all). The game just simply stuck at patching (100%). I had to uninstall the game and reinstall it and had to go over the shader building all over again. Then, the game just crashed like 5-6 times when I turn around at a very high speed. NICE GOOD JOB AT PATCHING! IRON GALAXY AND NAUGHTY DOG.

i7-11700K
RTX3080Ti
32GB DDR4 @3600Mhz
NVME.SSD

text:
f you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

text:
it's not like there's no reason everyone is giving a negative review. Lots of people have performance issues and also loading shaders for an hour before you even get a chance to play the game might instantly be a turnoff for the people who have never played this game before and don't know if it's a game for them or not. Plus people experiencing crashes or loading errors, yeah man people aren't happy with the state the game released in and they're not going to praise it even if it is a good game (which it is) mainly due to the fact PC gamers go the short end of the stick when it comes to experiencing tlou and what's even crazier is that if youve got a good enough rig you could just emulate the ps3 version or just straight up play the ps3 version without experiencing all the stutters, and crashes. It's an amazing game at the end of the day with engaging gameplay and a story you'd completely invest in but since this port is horrible think about how many people wont be able to actually enjoy this game for the first time, it's sad but reality. Personally I'm fine with capping my game at 30fps since i've always played this game on console. 

We can't be completely negative towards the game because it is of course the last of us. I do think it's great that they included the DLC idk if that's standard with the ps5 version but i think we should all be glad that we didn't pay 70 dollars for this port. The new coat of paint has me in awe at every moment it pops out, mainly in the lighting even at low settings it looks gorgeous. I can't say the same about the textures of course but that's due to the limitations of my hardware and im not gonna complain that I can't have high res textures. I don't think the graphics necessarily justify the 60 dollar price tag though.

Do i recommend the game? Yes, definitely Joel and Ellie have such an emotional journey together I've experienced it so many times since the game debuted on the PS3 and watched the TV adaptation which got me even more hyped for the game. Unless you've got a good rig or a good enough rig to play at 30fps at low if you're comfortable with that, i wouldn't recommend the game.
