text:
Originally I had the same problems everyone else had, but then I moved the game from my external hard-drive to my SSD and now all the stuttering and glitches have decreased heavily, and the load times are much shorter. The shaders took maybe 20 minutes to compile as well. This may have been partly due to the few hotfixes that came out, but redownloading the game to the local drive helped a bunch and I recommend the same if you have it on an external hard-drive like I did.

It's important to note as of now that the game still has some optimization issues. My setup is well past the recommended specs and I still can't run the game on full ultra graphics without exceeding the VRAM usage. So make sure that your VRAM isn't exceed past the limit as to avoid bugs and stuff.

Just to be safe, do not buy the game until there have been enough patches. The positive reviews do not invalidate the negative ones, you could still suffer from the same issues and probably will due to the sheer amount of people experiencing issues like crashing, stuttering, overclocking CPU, and much more.

text:
[h1] The Last of Our VRAM [/h1]

Sadly, I'd discourage folks from getting this right at launch (unless they have hardware that can handle the extreme VRAM requirements). Mind that the recommended settings seem to shoot a little under what you need to have a good time. Even running 1080p looks like it eats up your card's memory.

The egregiously long time it took to build shaders is inconvenient. The fact that this thing *devours* your VRAM is kind of strange, and seems to imply poor optimization. They got this to run on a PS5, but to have nice textures you need about 10 GB of VRAM at 1440p? Low-Med settings with the FSR cranked and still using ALL 8GB of my VRAM (and then some).

Hopefully it ends up running more smoothly for folks that are having more trouble than I am.
No crashes, but lots of stutter and the frame rate is all over. It seems like the initial delay was very much needed, and the game could have used a little longer in the oven.

Love the original game, and I'm excited to experience the story again, nonetheless!

We all know the story is good. We were never really worried about that. This port is pretty awful, on a technical level. 

Ryzen 3700x
RX 9700 XTX
32GB Ram
Installed on an NVME M.2.

Load times are awful but only randomly. One boot, the game will load fine. Come back a few hours later and it takes 10 minutes to load in. The shaders were installed in about an hour and I have not had a single crash. I have a hunch that AMD cards play better with this port and it is so poorly optimized, you need an over kill GPU and processor to run it decent at all. I am running the game at 50-80 FPS and the game is unreal, graphics wise. I have not seen a game as gorgeous, on PC, so far. 

My biggest issue, and I can forgive everything else, but the mouse movement in the game is horrible. Choppy and jarring. I will pan the camera with a controller, and its nice and smooth. Logically, I'm not sure how this game passed QA. Play if you must, but don't let a terrible port ruin this game for you. If its your first time, pass until its fixed. You have waited this long. Whats a bit longer?

text:
I'll admit that I wasn't running this game with the most up to date gpu despite it meeting the minimum requirements. However even with an outdated driver I can still run a lot of big games, including newer console ports, flawlessly. I expected this one to run smoothly especially since I just added more RAM to boost performance.

Truth is no matter how up to date your hardware is, this game just will not work. This is a terrible port of a good console game. The loading time is slow. The screen stutters just from browsing the menu and freezes constantly. And don't get me started on the shaders! Seriously it should not take 2+ hours just to build shaders. I've never had that issue even on the worst console ports. I never got around to playing the actual game because I didn't want to wait on the shaders. I downloaded the first patch, but all it really did was make the shaders load slightly faster (and by slightly I mean it started at 11% on startup and then lagged the same way it did before).

The Last of Us is a great game. One of the best. But the PC port is downright terrible. If you haven't bought this yet, then don't. Save up for a console and play this the way it was meant to be played. As for me, I think it's time to dust off my PS3...

I was reeeeaaaally excited for this game to finally come to PC, since I never owned a PS4 and probably never will, but now I'm just mad that i wasted 60€ on a game that barely f*ing works.

I always enjoyed it when my friend let me play on her console from time to time, but obviously I never had enough time to actually finish the game in one go. So when I heard that it was coming to PC, I instantly knew that I would buy it. However, now that I have it (and played like, 85% of the game), I absolutely regret buying it. It's not about the gameplay or the story, but just like everyone else already said; the optimization. Now, I don't have a High End PC or anything, but it's also not like my PC is total crap. It can usually run any game on high graphics at 60 FPS no problem. But with TLOU, I can barely get through a building without my game going below 20 FPS and freezing every two seconds. Occasionally I can't even shoot properly because the game is just so laggy, therefore I'm constantly wasting my materials and I sometimes have to play checkpoints 5 times over because it's just so unplayable. And yes, I already tried following some optimization guides, but it only helped so much. Now I'm in the last chapter of the game and I tried to set my graphic settings to medium because I'd rather be able to play the game than enjoy the graphics for once, but before I could even apply the changes, my game f*ing crashed. I was gonna finish the game tonight, but now I just want to refund it and never think about it again.

TLOU in itself is a lovely game with a great story and great gameplay, but I recommend anyone who thought about buying it now to wait a few months until it's on sale. Or even better; don't buy it at all and just watch a walkthrough or let's play on youtube for free. Don't waste your money on this until the devs finally get this game to work. You'll just be ripping your hair out over it.

text:
Lets not beat around the bush this is a shoddy port of the game on PC and the fact that they're £59.99 for the special edition is criminal, but it's still the last of us so it plays well and looks fantastic if you can push it.

PERFORMANCE 

The shaders took me nearly an hour to render and i suffered 9 crashes to desktop during that process, yes 9. I have had less crashes in my over 4,000 hrs of warframe than in just the setup phase for this game.

For those suffering from poor performance/stuttering in gameplay, let the shaders fully compile before starting the game, the compile times on anything are unforgivable but i personally haven't suffered from the stuttering issues or hitching that others have complained about.

When in game disable the chromatic aberration and the film grain, then enable DLSS or FSR in the games 'Display menu', this should gain you back some performance. After that the games graphics options are shockingly in depth and are more comparable to the Serious Sam 3 options for how many things there are to tweak so you have a fair bit of wiggle room to play with.

As a final note the load times are also abysmal, if you have the option install this game to and ssd/nvme drive, I can actually make a cup of tea in the time it takes to load this game.

Overall I got this for free with my graphics card so i can't complain to much but i don't recommend buying this until they fix it, this is the same studio that ported Arkham Knight to PC and they haven't learned a thing in the last 8 years and Sony still went with them anyway.

text:
I did not experience any crashes or stutters as I've updated my drivers. The game has been running smoothly, and I don't have a potato PC. However, having to wait for shaders to build every time I launch the game is insanity! And this process takes at least 30-40 minutes. And if you wonder - I do wait for shaders to complete before playing the game. Even after restarting my PC after shaders complete building, shaders start building all over again, every time I launch the game.

Also, the audio is too low and muffled when characters are speaking. Unless I turn up my headset to the maximum, I can't hear a thing. In a story-rich game like this, that is a major problem, too.

Not to mention that this game eats VRAM like it's nothing. Those of you hoping to play this on a GPU with less than 8GB, be prepared for a rough awakening - the game easily eats up to 12GB of VRAM on ultra settings. So, having a GPU with less than 8GB (or even 12GB) would make it tough for those who want to appreciate The Last of US Part I on PC.

A company like PlayStation, with such a big reputation, skimping on their top game and allowing it to release for PC in such a state is a mockery! Fanboys who leave disingenuous reviews and feedback, and are willing to overlook such bad issues are a big reason these billion-dollar companies slack so much.

This port is in a state that cannot be overlooked, and the negative reviews are justified!

Current state of the game is rough, Performance issues, crashes, an extremely long shader building time, it's a bit of a mess. Will update the review when the game is more playable. 

Iron Galaxy needs to be axed. They can't put out a worthwhile product to save their lives.

2nd Update: Fuck Iron Galaxy. It appears that LITERALLY nobody at IG ever thought testing the game was a good idea. They've put out shitty ports before, they will again and again until the company is dismantled and everyone there finds a job in another industry they're more suited for. Still have random crashes that are completely inexcusable for a full price game and a game with so much financial backing and prestige. 

*Update*: New patches are an improvement, but the game is still inexcusably poorly optimized. Game looks about on par with a late PS3, early PS4 game but even with a decade's worth of GPU improvements over the original hardware, the game runs like relative dog shit. This is precisely the age of game that should run on middling hardware extremely well and it runs like wet trash on a modern semi-beefy setup. 

I reiterate, Iron Galaxy fucking sucks.

*Updated again*: Still has major stability and performance issues even on a machine that doesn't have stability or performance issues with other games. Keep an eye on RPCS3, if you have the hardware to play this properly it's likely you can find other ways to play Last of Us on your PC without as many issues through unofficial channels.

running a 3070 with 128gig of ram on an i7 and it crashes constantly and on the recommended settings for my rig! My entire rig feels like its about to set light to itself with the insane heat its putting out and im fairly close to throwing a bucket of water over it. WHY?........

Because this game is so poorly optimised its a joke! There was no issue with days gone being ported and graphically intensive in ultra settings but this is just a hot mess! To add that proverbial nail to the coffin making it unplayable is the controller support witch is non existent, it works...... but you cant move five feet without the character stopping then starting again whilst using the analogue sticks.

Needless to say i was excited about a masterpiece that would outshine the amazing experience i had with days gone but this is utter garbage and i wouldn't recommend until its been patched what will probably be at least 200 times before summer is here.

Wait till its on offer before you take your chances but don't pay the £50 asking price for an old game that clearly hasn't been ported properly.

keywords: run, setting, pc, fps, performance, port, even, low, still, well
text:
Not a good port of the game at all. I've seen a lot of others here ranting about the vram usage, system ram usage, CPU usage, stutters, and crashes. I can thankfully say after 4.7 hours so far. I haven't had a single crash, running on 4k Ultra keeping 60+ fps with DLSS on Quality. The 100% CPU usage was entirely due to the game building shaders, and oddly had 100% CPU usage when downloading this game, which is bizarre to me as I've never had a game download on steam take my entire CPU. if you got less than 32gb of ram, honestly, forget this game. It may run on systems with 16gb ram, but when you're out of that. you'll be paging into the storage for virtual memory which can hurt your storage and rapidly decrease it's life span. I'm seeing 20gb ram usage while ingame, and seems like it's not much different on lower settings. Medium settings even 1080 hogging 8gb vram which is absurd for the actual texture quality you get at that setting. Ultra at 4k takes around 13gb. Biggest thing is, once shaders are built. experience is mostly pretty ok. Theres issues with the mouse stuttering when looking. But to be fair, with my system. it's easy to say I had a relatively decent time so far with the game. But that doesn't excuse the shape this game shipped in. sitting for an hour to build shaders, CPU being hammered while it happens, and even ingame afterwards, i'll have random spikes from 56-65% to 95% usage out of nowhere for several seconds. Given it's hardware usage, I'm shocked this even got verified for deck Considering the deck only has 16gb memory which is shared between GPU and CPU. They should never have given this to Iron Galaxy to port, given their reputation with the infamous Batman Arkham Knight port. But as it is at the time of posting, I wouldn't run this on a GPU with less than 12gb vram, and less than 32gb system memory if you even want a relatively alright experience. For now. Just wait til it's patched, if Iron Galaxy even cares to. It's absurd that this game hogs so much of my PC's resources to run at all.

Specs for anyone wondering about my performance:
Intel Core i7 10700k 5Ghz
32GB DDR4 3200mhz CL16
GeForce RTX 3090
And game is installed to my Samsung 980 1TB NVME SSD

text:
WARNING - I would advise against purchasing such a high priced game until its fixed. UNPLAYABLE. A £50 game shouldn't be this much hassle !!!!!

Constantly crashing as per everyone else's review. I do however have a possible workaround and also added issue that despite the workaround makes the game unplayable for arrow key players (not WASD players).

Firstly, the added issue that makes the game unplayable for arrow key players is that using the arrow keys keeps bringing up the Weapons Cross and this means swapping weapons every time you move. You cannot remap the Weapons Cross keys, very frustrating and a game crippler for arrow key players.

Now the good news (maybe). Long story short. I read a review that said let shaders fully load 100% and the game runs okay, but mine never did, they get to 20% and stopped.  I wondered why and according to Task Manager the CPU and GPU were running at 100% and 16GB memory maxed out also, the Shaders ran for a bit, increased a little and then crashed.  I had spare RAM and so put 8GB extra in making a total of 24GB and that worked!  The shaders loaded to 100%  and the game runs. Problem is for an arrow key player as above I cant play the game because of the keymapping problem.

Have logged a helpdesk request so fingers crossed for a patch.

Good luck..... a £50 game shouldn't be this much hassle !!!!!

text:
I did not realize I was purchasing a stress test for my CPU/GPU but this is what you get at the moment. In order to play decently you have to let the shaders compile, and this takes forever (I think I am 20 mins in and I am at 20%), and it looks like the compilation time doesn't change much even for super high-end specs. I played the first 15 minutes of the game until I got stuck at a splash screen saying "Loading, please wait" every 10 metres, probably because of missing compiled shaders, I don't know, but this is simply ridiculous, I mean not even Morrowind in 2002 had loading screens, and at this is no open-world game. On top of this the game eats up 7.5 GB of VRAM at medium texture details, plus 24GB of RAM, and this is frankly speaking unacceptable. No game I've ever played so far went beyond 16GB of RAM usage, including Cyberpunk at day one, and believe me that the graphics of that game is not comparable with this (open world game with way better graphics). This is simply put lazy and poor programming. As for me, I am going back to play Atomic Heart until the fix this. You should do the same. It's an awesome game which shows how a game should be released. I hope this ends up like Arkham Knight and that gets removed from the Steam Store, because at the moment this is just a scam.

In short, do not buy this until they optimize the game with patches.

I will change my review if this gets better.

text:
I pre-ordered The Last Of Us with the hopes of getting the zombie survival horror game that has been highly rated ever since launch. After days of waiting, The game finally unlocked and I load it. For context, I use a Steam Deck to play all of my games. I load up the game and wait for the shaders to compile. I set all the settings to the recommended and start.
 
The game really did not look too great, and I only got 30 FPS with 'frequent' stutters. When the intro got more intense, the performance dipped into the low teens and even crashed. 

The Last Of Us for PC is the only experience I have ever had with the series, and I am sorry to say it was a low. I refunded the game because of this, and I am not sure when I will have the chance to play it properly, on PlayStation or a higher end PC. 

In conclusion, I would not recommend this game in its current state, especially if you are using a medium to low-end PC. I hope that they fix all the issues later, because I have heard that the game itself is supposed to be really good.

text:
I pre-ordered the game but after I saw the horrible reviews, I didn't want to launch the game on Steam because there is a 2 hours time limit for refunds. I didn't want to waste that time on shader compilation screen so I downloaded the jack sparrow version to see if I can play it without issues. I installed the jack sparrow version on NVMe SSD and launched it. Shader compilation took approximately 30 minutes. First, I tried with ultra settings and DLSS on Quality. It uses almost 10GB VRAM on ultra settings even if you turn on the DLSS. My 2060 has 6GB VRAM but I tried the ultra settings anyways. 

I got 60-80 FPS in the beginning of the game but the first 15 minutes doesn't really put that much pressure on system. After the Sarah part ended, FPS dropped to 45-55 but when I switched to High settings with DLSS Quality, I could still get 50-60 FPS when I'm outside. I could get 60+ FPS when I'm in indoors. After I saw that I can play the game without issues, I deleted the jack sparrow version and launch the game on Steam. The Steam version's shader compilation completed after 15 minutes. I've installed both versions on the same SSD but Steam version's compilation didn't take that long. I've played the Sarah part again and I got 1 crash at the end of that car scene. I didn't get any other crashes for now. If I encounter other issues as I continue to play, I'll edit this comment.

By the way, I forgot to mention but the game uses minimum 80% of the CPU and 24GB of my 32GB RAM. I saw some benchmarks and it uses almost all of the RAM available if you have 16GB. CPU usage is also a joke. First time I see a game that uses at least 80-90% of the CPU.

My System Specs: 

CPU: Ryzen 5600
GPU: RTX 2060
RAM: 32GB 3200MHz (4x8GB)
SSD: WD SN570 NVMe 1TB

I agree that this port is poorly optimized. Especially the shader compilation and loading screens takes too much time but after you waited shader compilation, it is not unplayable imo. Maybe I'm a little lucky. 

Of course, if you are not that impatient for playing this game, you should wait until Naughty Dog release a performance patch. They said that they are aware of the problems (no sheet) and they will try to fix them (fingers crossed).

I won't change my review to "Recommended" until they fix these problems even though this is my favorite second video game ever. This game shouldn't have been released in this shape. Developers must stop releasing unfinished, unoptimized games. We saw so many examples of this in recent years. They also trust the upscale technology too much when developing a game. DLSS intend to be increase the current performance of the game, it is not an optimization tool.

*** UPDATE ***

I finished both main story and Left Behind DLC. FPS was not really a problem for me because I usually got 50-60 FPS on high settings. This is acceptable for me. But unfortunately, game still crashes. They released 2 small and 1 big update (around 15GB) but it didn't fix the crash problem. I found a temporary solution for this. When I play the game it crashes after 20-25 minutes but if I close Geforce Experience, I can play without any crashes. Some say Discord also cause this problem. So try to close Geforce Experience and Discord when you play the game. Maybe it is something related to apps with overlays, I don't really know but I can confirm that closing Geforce app helped me. Game also has weird graphics bugs. Sometimes characters' hairs, eyebrows and beards goes crazy. And sometimes, the ground become completely black. It usually requires to restart the game but it doesn't always help. Sometimes you just have to play that part with that bugs.

It is such a shame that we talk about technical issues instead of talking how good this game is. The game is a masterpiece but we can't even talk about that thanks to this sheety port. Well, almost everyone knows that The Last of Us is a great game, but still.

Completely recommended -IF YOU CAN PLAY IT WITHOUT ISSUES-. I still won't change the review to positive unless they fix the game.

I was incredibly excited for this game. It is still great. When you can get it to work it works wonderfully. So far I haven't seen any of the other issues other reviewers have noted . text:
I will preface this by saying that on my rig the game runs perfectly fine (RTX 4070TI, I7-13700K, Playing at 2K, 32 gigs of DDR5 6000mhz Ram) but that's no excuse for this bad of a PC port, and with that out of the way: 

Here's another underpaid and underworked PC port by our dearest friends at Iron Galaxy, known for their fantastic work on:
-Arkham Knight (removed from steam after launch for 3 months because of how bad the port was)
-Crash Bandicoot N Sane Trilogy (Constant option menu issues like the fps limiting itself with higher definition monitors, game flat refused to boot for certain people)
-Uncharted Thieves Legacy: (Mouse stuttering issues, same Shader loading problems as here)
-Rumbleverse (A Battle Royale that flopped on its face so hard they shut it down not even half a year after release)

All of this while Sony owns Nixxes, one of the most famously good PC porting studios on this side of the planet.

The Range of Issues in this one is so much more vast i'm fully expecting Steam to pull this off their store aswell at some point with these reviews.

Let's list a few: 
-Shader Installing takes about 4 hours, have fun refunding guys!
-Once Shaders are installed i'm about 200% sure you WILL crash upon pressing the play button (or just randomly whenever it feels like it)
-If you DON'T crash be prepared to be faced with game breaking issues such as essential NPC's getting stuck in terrain.
-If THAT doesn't happen either i'm sure you'll love all the 15 or so FPS the game will grace you with as it eats VRAM and CPU power like a morbidly obese person at a wedding
-Get past all of that and you MAY just get one of the MANY texture bugs the game still has up it's sleeve (Joel's face randomly turning entirely black for some reason, hair looking like it's made out of confetti, etc.)


Stay FAR and WIDE away from this shoddy attempted Sony Cheapout until it's worth actually spending the amount of money they expect you to pay for it by fixing the port up (if ever.)

Fast forward 10 years later and you can only imagine my excitement when I see that one of my favorite games from my childhood is being remastered for PC. I made the mistake of pre-ordering it, blinded by my nostalgia, and I paid the price in more ways than one.

The game is incredibly unoptimized, the shaders that the game heavily suggests you stay in the menu until they finish building take EASILY 30+ minutes of sitting there and waiting, the mouse/camera movement feels very rough, oh and did I mention that the game is not well optimized?

Naughty Dog had an incredible opportunity to get new PC players invested in the game that had never played it before, as well as players who had seen the hit TV show and wanted to visit the game that it originated from because they were either too young or had brushed it off when it initially released, and to say they blew it would be an understatement. Re-hiring the same studio that also did a trash porting job of the Uncharted Collection (Iron Galaxy) while not using a studio that you OWN that is known for doing a great job of porting games (Nixxes) is nothing short of a tragedy.

Do NOT even consider purchasing this game until the widely reported issues with it have been fixed. Get RE4 instead.

text:
I've never owned a Playstation, but have heard for years and years about how amazing, groundbreaking, wonderful, etc. That "The Last of Us" was. Unfortunately, I heavily disagree. 

First, the story, writing and characters are absolute bunk. It's as if the story was written by the most uninspired Daytime TV Drama writers they could find. Every character personality is completely two dimensional, every "twist" or "surprise" is able to be seen from miles away. Nobody seems to be written with any sort of intelligence or sense, and the "father/daughter" thing that is going on with Ellie and Joel is incredibly bland and trite as well. As in: it's not done well at all, and is written in a way that is purposely trying to tug at your fee-fees. Refer back to "uninspired daytime tv drama writers". 

If the "parent/child" dynamic is your thing, Telltale's 'The Walking Dead Season One" with Lee and Clementine,  and Detroit: Become Human with Hank and Connor (with Connor's Deviant / Pro Hank playthrough) do this dynamic way, way more successfully.

Gameplay-wise, the game is also incredibly middling. Generic, basic crafting system, and generic over-the-shoulder combat, fighting buggy / dumb AI. I would argue that if you want a generic third person story game / zombie shooter with crafting elements, then go play Days Gone.

For the hype, and especially for the price, I genuinely cannot see why this has received the praise it has. Maybe it was worth something when it originally released in 2013, but a decade later in 2023, it absolutely falls flat especially compared to what else is available.

text:
The Last of Us is one of my favorite games of all time. I absolutely love this game and the series. I pre-orded both TLOU2 and this the moment I could, and I planned on getting the Firefly Edition for the PS5 once I got one. 

But holy shit is this port so fucking disappointing, I've crashed three times just trying to build the shaders, and I ONLY HAVE 12 MINUTES OF PLAYTIME! It honestly infuriates me to see my favorite game be put out in such a pathetic state. This is unacceptable, especially after how great the ports for Dead Space and RE4R were. 

It boggles my mind that while Sony owns one of the most highly-rated developers for PC Ports, they choice to go with the team who made one of the most infamous PC ports of all time (Arkham Knight.)

And just like Arkham Knight, I'm sure this game will have a redemption story, and run beautifully soon. But I'm fucking sick of redemption stories in gaming. Why is nearly every Triple AAA product released in a near-unplayable state. These things should fucking work when they make it to retail. And I'm fine with a few bugs here and there, they're inevitable, making games is hard, and it's amazing most games get made. But when it's literally unplayable for most of the people who bought the game, it's fucking unacceptable, they should've delayed the game again. 

I'll probably keep my pre-order, just because I know this game will eventually be in a better state, and I do intend on playing it once it is, because like I said it is my favorite game of all time, but I would recommend people avoid buying this game for the time being, and if you already have, please get your money back. Steam offers full refunds if you have less than 2 hours of playtime. And if you're wanting to see if your PC can run it before refunding it, keep your eye on the clock because I've seen some people take nearly two hours just building their shaders.

text:
I'll start by saying I'm a veteran of the original game. I love it and was extremely excited to replay the game. Unfortunately, it has been unplayable across two different gaming machines.

One setup is a 7900XTX, 5600X, 16GB 4400 MHz RAM, and an NVMe high speed M.2 drive. On this machine I experienced 100% GPU AND CPU usage on the menu screen while shaders were being built. The shader build process took over an hour and a half for me. It kept freezing and crashing as well. Once this did finish, and I tried to start the game, the loading circle displayed for a couple of minutes before actually starting the game. There's significant load barriers, stuttering and crashing once in.

On another machine with a 6950 XT, 5600X, 16GB 3200MHz RAM, and NVMe M.2 drive the game hard crashes my machine. Once entering the menu screen the system freezes. It's a hard freeze where CTRL+ALT+DEL doesn't even work. Even holding down the power button on the front of my machine won't turn it off. I had to switch off the power supply to shut it down. I tried this twice with the same results. I literally cannot play it on this machine. I have all the latest drivers installed on my machine.

I know that once everything is patched, this will be an incredible game. It's an immersive experience that completely draws you in and will be worth your time. I just think that right now, at this point in time, it's not worth it. I would wait for them to patch everything so you can enjoy the game as it is meant to be played. Some people do report being able to play without too many issues, but it's really varied and essentially a dice roll. You may be able to play it, or you might experience a ton of issues. Unfortunately, as the loader build process can take most of your potential refund time period, you should exercise caution if you wish to try it out.

text:
[h1][b]My advice would be to wait until further patches have been done before purchasing[/b][/h1]  
It currently is not optimised at all especially for older GPUs. If you're like me and really just wanted to play the game you loved from console then [b]I would highly suggest letting the game render the shaders in the menu before launching[/b] as my FPS was so bad and pretty much unplayable until they had finished rendering.

The game seems to be severely GPU intensive and that is where I think most people are experiencing issues with bottle-necking I get anywhere from [b]40-70fps[/b] at 1440p on high settings using AMD FSR 2 on quality with the occasional stutter but not enough to annoy me, not experienced any crashes as of yet like others have but I think that really depends on your hardware.  If you're having troubles with low fps [b]try turning on AMD FSR 2 or NVIDIA DLSS[/b] for those with capable GPUs.

[b]My Specs[/b]

text:
Surprise surprise... the studio that makes awful ports made another shitty port *mild shock*. Why do they keep trusting Iron Galaxy i'll never know.
I may not have a high end pc but it should be good to run a remaster of an old game. For context i have a Ryzen 5 5600x, RTX 3070 and 32 GB 3200 MHZ RAM.

To begin the shader compilation takes like 40 min but whatever, then i have a 4k display but set dlss to performance (render at 1920x1080) and the textures on medium go over my 8 gb vram and low textures look awful (worse than the ps3 version), and since there's no fullscreen option you can't chose lower resolutions. So to play at 2560x1440 i had to set my desktop resolution to that and then use dlss (1280x720 render) to set textures to medium and even then the game performance dips all the time (from 90-95 to 40 fps). They even confirmed a memory leak among other issues.

So yeah, the last of us is one of my all-time favorite games. That doesn't mean i'll accept this poor excuse of a port. I don't care if it's day 1, games should release working fine, not after weeks of updates that fixes little to nothing. I didn't pay full price to be a beta tester.

keywords: release, really, review, go, say, year, see, know, come, make
text:
First, I have NEVER preordered a game until now. Usually I'm more than content to wait until the reviews come in, maybe a few YT videos of actual game play. But The Last of Us has always held a special place for me. And, after they announced the HBO series, I knew I wanted to play the PC version. 

I was a little disappointed when they delayed the launch but I figured that they wanted it to be done right. So I waited while enjoying the HBO series, and even waited to watch the season finale so I could go right into the game after that. I didn't download the game until I got home on launch day. So while I waited I read a few early reviews. And hey......that can't be right. Maybe all of these reviewers are just expecting too much from a 10 year old game!

So I finally get to launch the game. And I wait, and wait, and finally the start screen of the game. "No, I don't want to wait for shaders to load". I've played the game enough to know what comes next so I mostly looked for differences in quality of the cut scenes, or something at least to make it somewhat better than the PS versions. I really don't see much that's different. OK, on with the game play. Wait, what's the deal with the extended buffering going from cut scene to game play? Well maybe the game wasn't fully loaded into memory yet. Yet it happens again, and again,  and again, etc.

Well, the reason I like PC gaming is better control of shooting with the mouse. So Joel and Tess start their journey to find Robert and finally, finally, I get the chance after 40 minutes of game play (because of the constant buffering) to actually shoot. What a disappointment. Yeah sure, it does give you mouse control of your aim, but with the slow response I would have been better with the PS controller. 

And after the second gun battle, I shut the game down and requested a refund. Maybe I'll try again 6  months down the road if I find out they've improved the game play. But this is not just an issue of a few bugs. Trust the other Negative reviews.

text:
In order to play the game you have to wait for the 'shaders' to install. This entails sitting at the start menu for about 2.5 hours watching a % meter go from 1 to 100. you cannot walk away from the system or do something else while the shaders are installing because the computer frequently crashes during the process which prolongs the length of time for the install. My computer crashed 13 times while the shaders were going from 1% to 100%. I set aside three hours last night to play, i got to play for maybe 20 minutes.

Even after the shaders installed the game crashed three times while i was playing.

For reference: I have a GTX 1080 and 16 gigs of DDR4 and i played at the lowest settings.

One last thing to mention for context, this is one of my favorite games of all time, I was very excited for yesterday so this was particularly disappointing.

Day 2

Update, so second night of playing. i had to work late so i only got two hours of free time after dinner. I dedicated both hours to this game. The game crashed the night before during the cinematic when Joel met Ellie so thats where i started. It crashed three times before i was able to get through that cut scene.

It crashed a forth time when the fedra guys apprehended them just outside boston.

It crashed again, when they were sneaking around the lights. when it crashed this time, i could not reload the game, it kept crashing during the initial loading screen after hitting 'continue' off the main menu.

Day 3

Day 3 is the day i officially gave up. Had to work late again so i only got an hour in the evening to play. i could not get past the 'continue' button off the main menu. the system crashed 4 times. I tried to load into the save prior and on the second attempt i got in i played for five minutes, and the game crashed while i was playing.

Very sad.

Day 4

after a long hiatus and 3 updates i came back to this game. The updates were a significant improvement. the shaders had to be reinstalled which took over an hour and the game crashed once, which is a significant improvement from last time. i got to play several hours of the game and had a lot of fun. it often crashes during cinematics but it is somewhat playable. 

currently writing this review because it crashed and now i cant boot into the game, been trying for 30 minutes now.

its a good game, i played it on ps4, but on the computer really tough to play, you have to love the game to be able to stick with it.

text:
Thanks Steam refund policy.
The Last of Us Part 1 is a game about the zombie apocalypse, and if you need more than that you've been living under a rock for the past 10 years. This game made headlines in 2013 and more recently with its show release. Thankfully, Sony finally saw it fit to give us a PC port of the game, and my god what a damn shit show. Ryzen 5, 16 GB of ram, and a RTX 3060 and all I can get is a maximum of 58 FPS, which immediately drops to sub 40 and even sub 30 if you get in an environment that has any more than 3 npcs (including Ellie and Tess and any other friendly you may have following you!). 2 of the 4 hours of playtime were me sitting at the main menu waiting for shaders to download (twice, it wasn't a 1 and done thing), and messing with the settings to hopefully try and boost my performance a little bit. And I know my system isn't an issue because FFVII runs at 90 without a single hitch on the highest graphics I can get it to.
Learn from my and other's mistake. If you prepurchased and haven't played it yet, refund it now. If you're thinking about it, give it a few months to see what they do. How the hell do you delay by 6 months and still push out crap?

I even took this to the extreme and set internal deck rez to 400p then did FSR on top of that so the game was working with a rez of around 100x120p. Even at that extreme a solid 30 is not possible due to CPU utilization leaving no headroom for gpu to even ramp up to 400mhz. 

Worse than that all texture settings are locked off currently, and even when setting to high settings textures still seem very blurry at native rez so it seems they are adapting textures to render resolution not actual asset quality. Usually my go to for deck is low settings but high textures. That’s not possible here right now

This port is beyond broken currently, the cpu bottleneck, texture issues, and general lack of stability is unacceptable. I’ve never made a steam review but I feel compelled to highlight just how bad this is Currently.

text:
Never thought in my life I'd have to leave a negative review on one of my favorite franchises of all time. It breaks my heart but I cannot in good conscious recommend this game to anyone in the state it's currently in.

I have bought every iteration of The Last of Us since it's original release on PS3 all those years ago. That being said it's honestly embarrassing how terrible this port is.

You'll know almost instantly when you load up into the main menu and your frames are clocking at an average of about 20 - mid 30 fps. Never in my life have I experienced low frames in a main menu before even after shaders were compiled. Strange, but let's continue on.

There's absolutely no reason this game should be this taxing and demanding on your RAM, GPU, and CPU. it's asinine. I'm by no means running this game on a potato PC either my build is VERY much able to handle demanding games on high/ultra with little to no issues. But this? With everything on medium it's taking up 99% of my RAM and when I launch the game it sounds as if a jet engine just booted up inside my PC. 

I haven't experienced crashing, YET. (Let's hope I didn't jinx myself.) However I'm constantly teetering around 49 - 57 fps with some pretty frequent dips dropping down to the mid 30's. Again, on medium settings. Not to mention some textures are muddy and just God awful. I've walked passed signs on buildings that you couldn't even read due to how blurry they were. It was almost reminiscent of a PS2 title.

How on God's green earth Sony allowed this happen to one of their most famous IP's to ever release is on me. This one cuts deep. Especially caring as much as I do about this game. IF and I'm really praying here this is the case. But, IF this game does a complete turnaround for the better I will absolutely be updating this review as I feel everyone should experience this game the way it was intended to be played and not this shoddy broken mess that somehow made it passed quality control. All of you that waited years to play this and this is your first experience with the game, I'm sorry. I truly am. 

I absolutely do not recommend this game to anyone and Sony, fire Iron Galaxy. Please.

keywords: shader, wait, take, hour, time, update, load, patch, minute, still
text:
FINAL VERDICT: 
Buy it on sale and NOT for full price! 

Let Naughty Dog and Sony know that such a sh*tshow as this botched PC port will no longer be tolerated by us customers anymore, even if and when they finally perhaps completely fix it.
----------------------------------------
Original review: 

Even though Steam shows 2 hours of playing at the moment of first writing this review, I have not yet had a single minute of gameplay in this game, as it was still "compiling shaders" in the opening menus and I did not dare to start the campaign until this was finished. 
As I lost my patience after some time, I tried verifying the game integrity, which sadly then started the whole shader thing from scratch, hence I lost my motivation to wait any longer... 

My PC-specs at the time of the first review, in case anyone might want to know: 
Win 10 64-bit PC, 64 GB RAM AMD Ryzen Threadripper 1920X 12-Core Processor (12 Cores)
AMD Radeon RX 590 (VRAM 8192 MB GDDR5 2000 MHz)
And yes, all drivers up to date and the game runs on a SSD!

Seriously, Naughtydog, how could you f*ck this up so bad? 
The Uncharted games ran just fine at launch when I played them here on Steam, so why does not this?!?!

Also all other previous Sony exclusives (both Spiderman games, God of War, Horizon Zero Dawn, Days Gone) that I've played on Steam did not have any comparable issues like this at all!

I've played both TLOU games on the PS4, but was always hoping and very much looking forward to finally play them on PC, where I can actually aim properly with mouse & keyboard for a change! 

At this moment, this game cannot be recommended, until Sony gets their sh*t together and fixes this!

I will update this review when the fixing patches have happened... let's see when this will be!
-------------------

*edit 01: A first 35mb patch came, which somewhat elevated the shader loading issue (even though it still took over 20 minutes for finishing up after booting up the first time). 
In turn I've had 4 random freezes and 3 crashes during either cinematics or gameplay in the prologue and 1st chapter.... therefor I cannot change my recommendation yet!

*edit 2: Loading times are sometimes abysmal, up to 4 minutes when starting the game fresh and wanting to continue from the last safe!

*edit 3: Every now and then, especially during regular gameplay, just random freezes & crash. Framerate is also always stuck between 40 & rarely 60 FPS, tried lowering a lot of things still no satisfying result!
#TheCrashOfUs

*edit 4: The 2nd patch, another ~36mb, did not eliviate the freeze + crash issue (as soon as a scripted sequence was about to start). And the framerate dropped considerably at the first encounter with the runners + clicker scene in the Downtown skyscraper...

*edit 5: The 3rd patch (again ~38mb) did not fix the above mentioned issue with the crashes. The Framerate sadly did not really improve that much either, in fact it drops extremely when enemies come into an area. I suppose this will take quite some considerable time before this PC port is properly playable at all for most of us!
PS: And the shader compiling "fun" started again, going slow as always... [Took over an hour to complete! Wow, it's the same if not worse than before!] I hope it will not have to redo the shader thing again, otherwise this will get worse and worse I'm afraid. 
BUT, at this moment to my amazement, after having started the game in "safe mode" I did not have any crashes... yet. The resolution and performance are far from good, but it's at least currently playable. 
Plenty of graphical glitches, some hilarious, others rather embarassing.
I recommend to wait before buying this still!

*edit 6: A big 15GB patch dropped (Friday, 07.04.). 
While the shader thing was done in less than a minute for me (I know, imagine my surprise!) the fps performance is still almost always abysmal. 
Especially in encounters (when entering an arena area, no matter if stealth or combat) the fps performance drops into a stuttery mess, also quite often when going upstairs in a room (walking around on ground level mostly fine, but damn you if you get up some stairs or ladders!)
Even on lower settings this is going on! (The reflections in mirrors & water look horrible, and several textures are extremely mushy...)
This is still far from good!

*edit 7: After the recent patch (May 2023), the performance is still far from perfect (at least sometimes it runs more fluent on lower settings), but the crashes seem to be back. 
At least this time it took a lot longer before I got a crash to desktop. 
Definetely still recommend to wait for a sale!

*edit 8: June 2023, a 25Gb patch at least stopped the crashes, but the performance is still lackluster, and hardly/rarely/occassionally getting up to 60 FPS and more, even with lower settings (which results in lots of ugly textures and weird glitches every now and then in return). 
At least it is playable for now...
Definetely only buy this game on a sale. Naughty Dog and Sony have not earned the right to get full price purchases anymore with this terribly botched launch!

*final edit: 
Almost half a year later, I have upgraded to a new graphics card (Sapphire AMD Radeon RX 7800 XT with 16gb VRAM and GDDR6 2438 Mhz) and for the first time ever I had a fluent performance, beautiful graphics and framerate. 
Even though I could finally now play the game properly, it doesn't change the fact that this PC port has been terribly botched and if you truly want to buy this game, WAIT FOR A SALE!
NaughtyDog and Sony have to learn their lesson...

text:
Had to change my review after the 2 patches as they made the game stutter a lot, the shaders compile much longer now and the fps now drops very often. 

On a non-technical side, the save system is atrocious (a manual save does not actually save anything and instead keeps an auto-save available after it's overridden), which made me replay some parts because a collectible I picked before saving and quitting the game was not picked when I loaded the save later. 

At this point I suggest waiting until they stabilize the state the game is in before buying as apparently they can screw things with an update at any moment.

-----
Original review:

After playing through the prologue and the 1st mission I experienced no crashes, no fps drops (only one drop to 28 fps in the first 2 minutes of the prologue) and no visual artifacts or other technical problems. I had locked the fps to 60 since that's my very-old's monitor refresh rate (and I didn't want to waste energy needlessly) so I can't really tell how high it would go and how stable it would be, but unlocking it for a few minutes I reached 240 fps in full HD.

Controls are not perfect but fine (hard to look from corners for example), the enemy AI is meh (on highest difficulty) as they tend to stand in the spot that you threw a distraction indefinitely for example. There is also telemetry that you can lower but not disable, although my firewall intercepts every outgoing connection and it did not try to connect even once during my gameplay.

As for the game itself, I played it on the PS3 emulator years ago so the story is very good (unlike part 2 which sucks).

I play on linux with GE-proton 7.53

Got the game as a AMD GPU bundle (not a paid promotion).

text:
I must be the only person to not have any crashing issues, I'm having fun with it even if it's very badly optimized.
However I don't approve of games releasing in this state. It's been happening a lot in the recent years, from huge, popular games like Cyberpunk 2077 and Elden Ring, to smaller games set in specific franchises (Total War: Warhammer 3 and Darktide).
I'm worried about this trend of releasing games unfinished only to fix them on the fly later. It's not only working, but even spreading to most renowned developers, such as Naughty Dog.
That's why I cannot recommend this title as it is right now. Hell, I don't even recommend it at full price unless you're a huge fan or something. This much for a sloppy port of a one year old remaster of a ten year old game? You've got to be shitting me. I love that Sony is finally releasing Playstation games for PC (thanks to which I finally got to play both God of War and The Last of Us, and - like everyone else - am waiting for Bloodborne), but doing so for more than $60 is absurd to say the least.

text: *slow clap for Sony* Well guys and girls and everyone in-between, here we are. Sony's pièce de résistance is finally here, hidden away on the PS3, PS4, and PS5 for the last decade, now finally out on PC. And how has Sony treated one of their most critically acclaimed series, on the platform that should be able to play it in the smoothest way possible, and with the highest fidelity? Oh and the constant crashing. I've had about 7 crashes so far. Haven't had that so far for any games this year. Save your money, and make Sony think long and hard about how they treat their PC players, because they should be ashamed. I don't usually make reviews either on Steam, but this game has broken that trend, especially since I've been hoping for years that it would come to PC and to see it in this state now is honestly pretty devastating. text:
First things first here in the PC gaming world, running this game on:

- RTX 3080 Ti
- Ryzen 3800x
- 64 GB DDR4
- M2. SSD
- "2560x1440"

Such a shame. God d*mn. Just as the series finished its first run on HBO, and most likely hyped up and primed this release for great sales, somehow Naughty Dog and Iron Galaxy managed to ruin a great game with poor optimization and a plethora of technical issues. I just cannot fathom how on Earth this game was released in this state, and furthermore, I am even more baffled by the fact that they had the decency to do this if you take into consideration The Last of Us' cult status in gaming.

Never ever hire these guys to do anything related to your products, please. Their track record is horrendous. I truly believe in the game itself and the story and everything inside it is amazing, but I cannot recommend getting this technical disaster AT ALL. Will change this review IF they are ever able to fix this piece of disaster. 

Frames cannot keep constant, even if some areas work fine and look beautiful. Stuttering is very much present. Mouse worked like sh*t when I first booted the game. The requirements (especially regarding VRAM) are an absolute joke, even if I can run this game on ultra / high. The overall performance from this game is laughable.

This was that "one game" they should never, ever have released until it was absolutely ready and somehow in a working state. 

Never pre-ordering anything from ND again, cheers for this.

There has yet to be a game I bought that disappointed me so terribly than this port. I was counting the days until launch, and when it finally does? My computer cannot handle it. Mind you, I've yet to find something I can't play- at worst on lowest settings.

Terrible framerate from go, absolutely dreadful use of my CPU (to an extent no other game in my library has taken), and I'm looking at the graphics in their lowest settings- looking no better or maybe even WORSE than how they did when this game released nearly a decade prior. There is absolutely no reason I should be unable to play this game, and yet, I had to quit before I could even start. 

I'm left unsure if I should simply refund it, or wait for a possible patch. I'm saddened, I'm disappointed, but over all, I feel cheated out of a full $60, and I cannot and will not recommend this game until the issues are repaired and I can run this game at even *30* FPS. I'd take 30 over the stuttering mess I have now.

text:
This is my third time editing this review because I simply CANNOT fathom how badly they f****d this one up.

I pre-purchased the game about 2 weeks prior to its release, and downloaded it the day before. After it downloaded, it unpacked and installed. When I started the game, it took about ONE HOUR AND A HALF to build the shaders because it kept crashing.

When I was finally able to load the game, it looked great and I was starting to get excited and didn't mind the wait. When I get to use the first playable character something was amiss; the controls just felt funny. At first I thought it was due to the character waking up abruptly and had trouble walking, but still... I simply could not walk in a straight line. I staggered through to progress in the game until I was now playing with Joel and the same issue with the controls started again. I thought the issue was with my controller and tried using another and it was the same.

I then updated my AMD Adrenalin to version 23.3.2 because I thought this may be due to an outdated driver -- and when I open the game the shaders were in 0% again. I'm so f*****g PISSED. I spent quite a bit of money to get the Deluxe version and preloaded the game only to run into this. Although it shows that I've played 4.5 hours, I HAVEN'T BEEN ABLE TO PLAY THIS GAME. It's all gone to building the shaders.

After all of the wait, the characters won't move forward. You have to use the directional buttons to walk and it makes the game UNPLAYABLE. Truly dissapointed. They need to fix this.

16GB RAM

Cons:
- Long Shader Building time (~1,5h. Refund the game if you have a Lower Spec PC, as this could go past the maximum 2h of playtime and prevent you from doing so.)
- Sudden frame drops (Could be related to RAM usage spiking?)

- No fullscreen mode (only window and borderless window available)
- Looong loading times

Conclusion -  Dissapointed, but not surprised. Waiting for fixes!

text:
Asked for a refund. It's damaging to the image of companies like Sony and Nintendo, known for releasing polished products since launch day, to release half-baked ports with performance problems as severe as this. Excessively long shader compilation times, long loading screens, and high performance demands may not sound like complete dealbreakers at first, but it's BAFFLING to find out that not even THAT is enough to stop the game from running with insanely high CPU utilization, unstable frametimes, completely insane VRAM utilization for even Medium and Low settings, jagged mouse movements, and general stutters (all of that in an 8th gen i7, RTX 2080, 16GB of RAM, so for sure a PS5-like hardware).

This port is a complete diservice to the franchise and broken lauches like this will continue to happen as long as people keep pre-ordering them. I previously thought that some franchises were exceptions to the rule and that they'd never release an unfinished game to their consumers, but now I feel like a complete clown, because apparently even Naughty Dog and Rockstar can make the mistake of hiring unqualified studios to mak their PC ports.

text:
So, before we start off, I want to say that the game itself is amazing. It stands as one of my all time favorite games. From the graphics to the atmosphere, the world, the characters, and the story.

So why am I leaving a negative review? Well if you couldn't tell, like the rest of the reviews, this game has a major issue. 

Optimization. 

Lets start with my specs, I am currently running this on an Intel i9 13900K, an RTX 4090, and 64gb of Ram. The resolution set to 1440p on Ultra settings. This is more than enough.

For the most part, the game will run very smooth. But frames will drop drastically, with stutters every now and then. I like many others find this to be quite frustrating especially when it interrupts the flow of game play, and takes me out of the immersion.

That being said, this isn't a bash on the game itself a whole, as Naughty Dog and their team have created such a fantastic world to get lost in, this is only a bad review on the performance of the port. Predictable sure, but not excusable. I believe that those who have waited this long even after a delay deserve a better experience, especially those who are experiencing the game for the very first time. It also shouldn't require a nuclear reactor to run this game either.

As it stands, I plan to keep my review negative until optimization patches roll out and the performance of the game improves. I encourage others to do so as well.

text:
After playing for around three hours, where one was spent loading shaders (which wouldn't be a problem if it would run afterwards) and another one trying to tinker with the settings in order to get more than 30 FPS, I currently cannot recommend this game in good conscience. I'll inevitably have to wait for a patch to fix the performance because currently, the experience is rather unenjoyable.

I get on avg <30 FPS and sometimes it goes as low as 15 FPS which causes massive freeze frames and stutters and makes the game borderline unplayable. My PC is still within the recommended specs range and should be able to run the game on at least medium with a stable 60 FPS.

I do not have the crashing issue many others experience, but the port is still more than unstable and no matter which settings I changed it didn't get better. Even on the lowest settings, I got no frame improvements at all.

It's not surprising to me but still a shame that the port for TLOU released in such a state and I'm genuinely disappointed as I was looking forward to replaying the game again on PC.

Hope it gets patched soon and I'm more than happy to update my review then.
It's in an unacceptable state as of now.

text:
I was sceptical with buying this game due to the mostly negative reviews. I've been waiting to play this on PC for a while so I downloaded it anyway. Shaders took about 15 minutes to compile, wasn't too upset as I could just walk away and wait for them to compile. Once the game loaded, it lagged a little bit but not too bad in the intro. Once I got to [spoiler]the first shooting part with Tess[/spoiler] it froze but sorted itself out and was running fine afterwards. The occasional stutter here and there but nothing too game breaking. Hopefully these issues can be sorted out, if it's not my hardware.

Update: About 10 and a half hours into the game, was running fine-ish except from very big stutters towards the 8 hour mark, dropping me down to probably 1fps. At times it froze completely. I wouldn't recommend getting this game until the performance is fixed.

Limiting the FPS to 60 in Nvidia and in the game, as well as disabling chromatic aberration and film grain can help. Changing from full screen to windowed also helped with the performance, it's not a full fix but it's at least bearable now.

Another update:
It's running so smooth now, no lag spikes, no bugs, everything is perfect.

AMD Ryzen 9 3900XT
16GB
RTX 3060

Although I haven't encountered any crashing or graphical issues, most of my playtime was spent waiting for the shaders to build.

While the game is still playable for me, I don't recommend it for the average person, given the potential issues. Spending 59,99€ on it is essentially like playing Russian Roulette at the moment.

keywords: run, setting, pc, fps, performance, port, even, low, still, well
text:
Updates go back in time ---->>> Most recent to least. 

Hahaha - Updated driver and patch - 27/08/23 - Still runs like balls. I have all set to low - and performance DLSS. Weird I can run RDR2 on medium/high. Or almost any other game. Crap this company tricked me into buying a game that doesnt run. They stole my money. I will never break my longstanding promise to NEVER PRE-ORDER a game! I should have know. 

UPDATE 03/06/2023 - Still runs like balls for me. RTX3050... yes I understand what this is capable of. I have built custom builds (with full loops) for years and know the typical performance to expect from a gaming laptop. I run RDR2 mix med/high/ultra @1080p and get 60fps no sweat. At the same time I get this is an undervolted GPU (Laptop) and so cant expect wonders from every game. However.......

Standing in lane way with essentially all static objects and very little lighting streams or atmospheric, 0 NPC's should not mean running this game on full LOW settings and PERFORMANCE DLSS and be getting 30fps bouncing (low 25fps highs of 45pfs). 

My GPU max utilisation sits around 70% CPU 50% - meanwhile PC sounds like its going to melt (Temps getting towards 97'C). This is with latest drivers, reloaded shaders blah blah, all my other games run great - Horizon Zero Dawn runs smooth. 

Check out Digital Foundry's Youtube breakdown. Major problems with this port - not sure they will ever be full fixed - unless your lucky, or have a beefy GPU - im done with those days. Anyone justifying a $1000 GPU to run this is a sheep for the corp gaming mindset. Good luck. 

I'm done with this game. I actually broke my rule of never pre-ordering a game... I blame myself really. 

I literally threw away money with this - and the company knew it was a broken product. Imagine designing a fridge and selling it knowing it doesn't keep food cold... 

UPDATE: Waited  a few days and with two (small) patches I booted up again. 

Last time I didn't even get down the stairs, this time I got to the car with Tommy. At some point I imagine I will get to leave the house, this isn't a house simulator is it?..... Thanks - Wasted my money - Some of us have to work for it.

PREVIOUS POST: Game runs great, looks amazing right before it crashes. Nothing to do with hardware. Will update my review when patched. Going to wait till then to play. What a shame......

text:
Thumbs up for TLOU - Thumbs down for the port. I've already sunk some hours into it because it's my first ever playthrough.

Upon first launch - spinning dog tag loading screen for about 4-5 minutes.

In the main menu - shaders took about 1.5 hours to fully render. 

Loading into the game - another 4-5 minutes. 

In game - consistent frame drops and stuttering, "Please Wait" loading message appears rarely that pauses the game until it gets caught up. No crashes so far with almost 8 hours down. 

The game is not unplayable or unpleasant, though it does need patchwork to smooth out the gameplay considering this game has been out for nearly a decade.

text:
Of course The Last of Us is an iconic game, but this PC port is really horrible. I very recently built a new PC with the latest components, and powerful ones at that, but it still struggles a bit with this game.  
1. It took almost an hour just to load the shaders, which the game recommends you let it do before starting.
2. The loading times are terrible.
3. There is stuttering and frame drops.
4. The game occasionally crashes.
5. The game doesn't like to launch because it says my video card drivers are out of date, even tho they are the most up to date drivers. 
On the plus side, the game really does look and play well when it's running properly. I guess, until a bunch of issues are fixed, I just can't recommend TLOU on PC. Very unfortunate! I have been looking forward to this for a while now.
I never leave reviews, but I just had to with TLOU on PC.

text:
Amazing graphics, terrible port.

I was always a 360 lad growing up, so never had the opportunity to play this game. I've basically been waiting 10 years to play this, and even got a new rig this year as many games were coming out I wanted to play on good graphics. 

The game crashes every 10 minutes, and shaders taking ages to download? For those people who have worse specs, I wouldn't bother getting this for now. Chances are the shaders downloading will take the refund time limit, and even then you wouldn't be able to play due to crashes. 

This game so far is a prime example of how gaming has turned from a genuine art and hobby to pure profit making. I would have rathered the devs push this another 2 months to ensure it was ready to play upon release... Though how else would they rake in the profits without riding off of the TV show hype? Majorly disappointed. Hopefully devs release patches soon.

Final update, I want to switch this review to a positive. The game was amazing, the hotfixes, well they mostly worked. Just wish it hadn't taken away from the play through.

text:
I don't usually do this but I'm above recommended spec, I've updated my drivers, and I'm within my VRAM limits, yet this game still crashes. Thanks Iron Galaxy, thanks Naughty Dog. Thanks for nothing.

Edit: Performance is still bad, but at least I'm not crashing anymore. So, as for the actual game:

Story, characters, voice acting, environmental detail/storytelling, cinematography, all good to exceptional.

But the "gameplay"? Part walking sim, part dated cover shooter, part under-cooked stealth, part simplistic puzzle solving ("find the crate", "find the plank", "find the pallet", "find the ladder"), rounded out by crafting and character upgrade systems that seem entirely bolted on and bare bones. You're also going to be spending 60% of your playtime crouch walking and/or fruitlessly searching empty drawers and cupboards.

Wait for a sale, and absolutely wait until all the issues have been fixed. For me, the game has been a big let down, and that's not just down to the technical issues.

text:
===
The Last of Us is a story game. So let me tell you my story of it - or rather a PC port of it.

The Last of Drivers: I launch the game and it tells me my drivers are outdated - I need 22.40.43 ... err ... I'm using AMD 7900XT, what is that NVidia warning doing there?

The Last of Shaders: It took an hour to compile the shaders. Was checking how the game was utilizing my resources: all CPU cores/threads used, but drive speed was 10 mb/s ... on a 7000 mb/s capable M2! OK, they messed it up, but at least they allow to play the game while shaders are compiling in the background, right? Wrong: if you do that, the game crashes due to the same problem - IO disk speed bottleneck.

The Last of Loading: Shaders are finally compiled, I'm in the car with Joel and Tommy escaping the city and just when we reach the long queue of other cars ... loading screen! Very immersive. 

The Last of Controls: Finally proper gameplay, I'm in control of my character ... but the camera is totally broken! Same problem as in Uncharted : https://steamcommunity.com/app/1659420/discussions/0/5143704785452165725/ 
 and they never fixed it! I'm used with keyboard and mouse on PC. I played TLOU on PS4 with controller, same as I played RDR2. But on PC RDR2 is an enjoyment with KB&M - aiming is proper and it's incomparable (!!!) when you're in full control and not relying on that useless auto-targeting. TLOU on PC pushes haptic advertisement instead of making PC controls work properly. Camera stutters with the mouse to the point of inducing nausea.

The Last of Refunds: Will refund a game, though, I imagine that many people won't be able to because shader compilation and all the loading screen will take more that 2 hours for them to reach the actual playable section and realize it's in fact unplayable.

The Graphics of Us ... well, on 7900XT with 144Hz I'm running the game @90 to 100 FPS. All settings maxed out without using any kind of upscaling method ... that said, I was very puzzled when opening screeninfo.cfg game's configuration files  ... no wonder Naughty Dog is hesitant talking about their technology.

So what's The Result of Us? A broken game that is not set to use PC technology, with long loading times, mouse jitters and crashes (when you let shaders compiling in the background)

keywords: run, setting, pc, fps, performance, port, even, low, still, well
text:
If you are actually interested in buying the game, please read my comments before spending any money.  I wish there was a "Maybe/Depends" option rather than just a thumbs up or down. 

First the good: The game looks absolutely fantastic! The graphics are top notch, I am very impressed with it overall.  Game play is a lot of fun.  I have to say it again, the graphics are absolutely beautiful.  I run it at 4k 60fps, and there are some areas where it looks almost real. If I was basing my recommendation on game play only, I would absolutely recommend this game.

Now the bad: When you first launch the game, it will hit your CPU at 100% while it is building shaders.  On my 12900k with a 3090 and 64gigs of system ram, this took about 25 - 30 minutes give or take; during this entire time your cpu will be at 100%.  So make sure you have a good CPU cooler...

From others I've heard of who have lower hardware, it can take an hour or so to complete building the shaders, but again I only heard this, I cannot confirm.

It's clear this game needs a major patch.  It has serious optimization problems.  For example, in the game setup, it says that it is using 15 gigs of vram on my video card (my 3090 has 24gigs of vram).  How the hell does a game like this need 15 gigs of vram?  That seems very un-optimized.   Reminds of of Ark from a few years ago, that was another game that was very unoptimised and used way more resources than it really should have.

Another issue is that the game is unstable.  Roughly every 30 minutes of game play it will crash.

So while the game itself is a lot of fun, and I can recommend it based on that, if you are planning to buy this game and expecting to play it right now, odds are you will be very unhappy.

This reminds of a lot of the issues with Cyberpunk 2077 when it released a few years back.   The game had major issues at release, and the developer got a lot of flak, but luckily they came thru and released several large patches to fix stability and game play issues.  Lets hope that Last of Us Part 1 also gets some serious patches soon.

text:
Got this on launch because I loved the first season of the TV show and hey I have cancer I have limited games left to play at this point. 

I've been running the game quite well with both my configs once I compile shaders, keep expectations in check, run with settings adjusted from medium, and use upscaling: 

* Ryzen 7 5800X, RX 6600, 32GB
* Ryzen 7 5800HS, RTX 3060 Laptop (60+20W), 16GB 

The game is visually gorgeous even at low settings. The story is incredible. The acting is amazing. The animations are more lifelike than most AAA games that get built from the ground up today (COUGH ELDEN RING COUGH). The gameplay is excellent. Every detail in this game is lovingly crafted and re-done for the current generation. It has possibly the greatest settings menu I've seen in any PC game maybe except for Warzone/Warzone 2. The accessibility options are god-tier, and will allow pretty much anyone who wants to experience this game to play it. I have encountered ZERO shader stutter, a rarity nowadays.

This is an incredible way to experience The Last of Us. 

Don't get it. It's not ready yet. They did not allocate enough time or budget for QA. "Mostly Negative" is not a review bomb, it is a legitimate indictment of how this game is optimised and programmed., no matter how many people like me can run it well. 

The bugs are fixable, the performance can be optimised. But I would not recommend getting it in this state. 

And stop scapegoating Iron Galaxy. This is on Naughty Dog as the primary developer and Sony as the publisher.

Like with previous reviews of mine, (namely Boneworks) I will update my review once patches have gone into place to improve the state of this game.

text:
This is a steaming pile of shit.

I don't think I've ever written a review for a game, but this one is so bad that I just HAD to.
When I first opened it, my PC immediately became unusable.
I managed to opened Task Manager and saw that my CPU (i7 8700K) and RAM (16GB) were at 100%.
"Installing shaders" it said. This took so long that I let it run the whole night and went to sleep myself.
I have just woken up, shaders installed, memory and CPU usage way down. "Good, time to play" I said to myself.
Well I hadn't clicked play or the CPU and memory usage went all the way to 100% again.

Really? After 10 years, THIS is what you give us?
A 2013 game that can't even run on today's normal hardware?
A 4080ti REQUIRED TO PLAY ON RECOMMENDED SETTINGS?

This just looks to me like a quick cash grab because everyone let shader installation run which took way more than two hours.
I really hope you fix this garbage and give us our money's worth.

Update #2 I requested a refund....several times.  Each request was denied claiming that the  request did not qualify for a refund. Their claims; 1. "play time" exceeded 2 hours.  2; refund was not submitted within 14 days. There are exactly two problems with their claims.

1. My "play time" exceeded  two hours because the game took so long to load. The shadders that are required were taking so long I had to leave the  program running over night to allow sufficient  time for them to be applied. This accumulated the majority of the  11+ hours Steam claims I played the game.  

2. I did not submit a return claim within  14 days. This is the weirdest part since I pre-purchased the game over a month before it was release. This means that ANYBODY who  pre-purchases a game 14 days in advance in simply SOL (Shit out of luck). According to the Steam return policy. 

In the end I told them them I will not submit to their denial of my refund and I was completely justified in wanting a refund on a product they allowed to be released un-optimizes on their platform. 

If you are trying to obtain a refund for this game, DO NOT GIVE UP. There still may hope for you. It may take a while, but it is possible. 


Update: I left the game running all night to load the shaders because they were taking so long. I THEN WAS ABLE TO PLAY THE GAME. With immense stuttering and atrocious load times.I struggled to make it to the 
 Slums portion of the game, having to wait several times for the game to load. Sometimes five plus minutes. This is when the game began to crash. I tried several times to make it past to no avail. With the amount of time you have to wait simply to play the game, then all the issues you run into when actually playing, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. Absolutely terrible, I will be requesting a refund. text:
I'll preface this review by saying I've actually had an extremely smooth experience playing this game. I was able to beat the game without any crashes and few severe frame dips.

However, being one of the lucky few doesn't exonerate the myriad of problems that other users have seemed to have with this port. Poor ports are simply not an excuse in the modern landscape of gaming, especially so with groundbreaking games that have been gated behind single platform exclusivity for a decade. Naughty Dog's "acknowledgement" of the issue and promise of a fix is a clear bandage for a wound they saw coming miles away - don't be fooled into believing they didn't know the state of the port prior to release. They absolutely did, and were willing to sell the product as is.

Let me be clear - I LOVE TLoU, and have played every release of it thus far. It severely pains me to dissuade people from playing this wonderful game. The remake is stunning and really elevates the experience, but even under that hood the game as it was is an incredible journey that really pushed the boundaries of storytelling in the gaming format. By right, this port deserves more respect. Hopefully, Naughty Dog will fix this port and Iron Galaxy will get their shit together so I can change this review in the future. But for now, my heart goes out to PC gamers everywhere who have been severely wronged by the corporate greed machine.
