text:
Post-launch day review:

Sooo I've beaten the game now. I guess there was some sort of memory leak that they patched after day one, seemed to fix things a lot. Another problem people faced (myself included) was being a little impatient and not waiting for the game to "build shaders" prior to actually playing. This process seems to of taken some people 10 minutes, it took me just under 3 hours, and for some it took even longer.

Once this shader nonsense was over with, the game played much better. Load times were drastically decreased, and FPS stability was improved. I still feel however, that the game is poorly optimized. I'm running a GTX 1070 (8GB) which isn't insane by today's standards, and even on low settings I can not maintain a stable 30FPS (god forbid I try higher).

Ignoring my gripes about performance, the game itself is not bad. But I don't really see why it's revered as a masterpiece. That being said, there are so many unique good things the game has accomplished that other game's have not managed to grasp.

I'll keep it brief here. Atmospherically the game is perfection every step of the way. Graphics can be stunning on a high end computer. The stealth mechanics are pretty good, and the way the game forces you into different situations is great too. The game's mechanics itself leave more to be desired. This isn't call of duty, but gunplay can be a little frustrating (funny enough the game has a built in aim-bot under options somewhere). The gore in the game is on point, super entertaining. Blood splatters and bleeds out of people accurately, and bullets leave accurate exit wounds and chunks of flesh on the wall/ground. It's very satisfying to cut someone in half with a shotgun, or remove the jaw of some shit-talking enemy with a well placed shot; that alone is a feeling of satisfaction second to none. But this game is more focused on telling it's story as opposed to its gameplay.

That brings me to the story. I won't spoil anything obviously, but I just felt it did not live up to the hype my peers had put behind it. Was it bad? I wouldn't say that. Also despite steam suggesting I have 24 hours played, between waiting for shaders to build and other AFK time I only got about 16 hours of story at most. It's just not long enough.

Overall prognosis; buy it on sale. Better yet, buy it on sale on console.




Launch Day Review:

I have waited 10 years to be able to play this game, and in it's current state it will take me another 10 years to complete this game. Graphically the game can lovely, but even on low settings the constant fps dips are extremely frustrating.

It took me 3.5 hours to encounter my first Clicker, due to the extremely long load times of literally everything. This game is unplayable as is for me, and many other players. I have long since stopped purchasing new games, because I am often disappointed. For a remaster of a game of this prestige, it's very upsetting that the developers would put out such a shameful rerelease.

Do not buy. Not yet anyway.

keywords: story, last, also, character, gameplay, feel, instead, present, hype, find
text:
This review is based on very little play time, currently 2.1hours, but it's sufficient to have encountered numerous technical problems in the title. As such I will keep this spoiler free, but I would like to say as well, that this review and its conclusions will likely only be valid until the developer addresses the games technical problems.

PC Platform reviewed on:

Core i9 12900K
GeForce RTX 3080/3090
Samsung 980 PRO PCIe Gen 4 SSD
32GB DDR5 6,000 Mhz RAM

Graphical Uplift.

I will say that when it plays well it's very impressive and looks incredible, the resolution uplift over the original is stark to say the least. The graphical uplift is pretty incredible characters are crisp, and if you have the VRAM for it (greater than 10GB) the textures are beautifully crisp too. 

Technically speaking...

But the technical problems are incredible. Just incredible. For me they started immediately upon launch, The games executables resulted in an immediate Anti Virus detection that saw the games primary launch executable being quarantined. After I took the executable out of quarantine and created an exception  for it, the game called a DLL that resulted in another Anti-Virus detection. Another exception was created and the file was moved out of quarantine. 

After this the game started and spent approximately 45 minutes building it's shaders. I'm glad that titles like this do this once at the beginning, pre-compiled shaders are a great idea, they improve performance by eliminating real time Shader compilation during gameplay. That in turn eliminates stuttering and frame rate reductions when content needs to be streamed into the game engine for rendering, it can make a significant reduction in overhead.

At least, that's the idea. The reality is that the shaders are indeed compiled, but the game freezes, stutters and experiences significant frame rate drops during play regardless and there appears to be little logic to when and why this happens. It's so inconsistent that I can't believe that this has been through an optimisation pass.

As we play the situation becomes more pronounced. The frequency with which freeze's occur increases as does the stutter and hitching I'm thinking a potential  memory leak maybe? After a couple of hours of play I entered a building where we first encounter "Spores" and have to place masks on while exploring the building. I eventually reached a point where we arrive in what appears to be a basement laundry room, and another frame hitch/stutter event occurred. The game was frozen but I could hear the dialogue between the characters still playing. After a few moments the screen went blank and I was dropped to the desktop with a request to post an error report.

I filled in the error report, but the crash report utility integrated into the game, resulted in another Anti-Virus detection which saw the utility being quarantined and the report go nowhere. Sorry Iron Galaxy but your port is triggering Anti Virus alerts, you really need to check that out.

It is at that point I felt... this product needs more work and I gave up. 

Why didn't I add an exception to the games installation directory before I started? Because it shouldn't be necessary. Most modern PC's now run some form of Anti-Virus that is integrated into the OS. Some people use a purchased product that they trust instead (I said Trust, not McAfee). In my case I use an AVG Business licence that is fully up to date.  I imagine however, that if the product wasn't tested by the developer against AVG (one of the most popular AV products there is) then I doubt it was tested with others. Make sure you add exceptions to your Anti-Virus product to accommodate this title until the AV detection problems are dealt with.

100+ button controller players! (I mean your keyboard)

I have also encountered a UI design issue that is really quite annoying, basic user interface prompts. During play if you are close to an object you can interact with, the game will display the key you should press to interact with the object. So lets say it's 'E' you walk up to the object press 'E' and you could be reading a newspaper. But you don't use 'E' to stop interacting with the object, you use 'back.' Back? There is no 'Back' button on a keyboard, Do you mean the down arrow? Do you mean the button I have configured to walk backwards? Oh right, you mean backspace? Seriously? Why not use the button used to interact with the object in the first place? It's a minor gripe, but it's an annoying one. The user interface could be clearer and controls a little more consistent.

Technicalities

With respect to the system I ran this on, there is no question of the available processing, RAM and SSD transfer capability. The only component that lets the iniitial configuration down is the initially tested Nvidia GPU I used, which Nvidia gimped with an insufficient quantity of vRAM. Now I don't blame Naughty Dog/Iron Galaxy for that, I blame Nvidia for that, however it does highlight a fact, that the game itself definitely loves vast quantities of vRAM. So a 10Gb frame buffer is going to result in graphical fidelity compromises. Some of that may be down to the clear lack of optimisation, but the core problem here is still nVidia's own failure to deliver a sufficiently specced product during the 3080's launch.

Having said that I have tried the game on a 3090 with 24GB of vRAM and found, the same in game stutters and performance issues and the same crashes straight to desktop. So at least a significant percentage of the issues encountered are VERY DEFINITELY down to the optimisation and the stability of the title.

Conclusions

I have played The Last of Us on the PS3 and PS4 previously. And I am familiar with the content. I can say that the PC version is a faithful port of the game. And for that I am grateful. BUT I absolutely can't recommend a buy for this game just yet. 

Once again we're beta testing a product. Beta testing a product that is now 10 years old. There's no question about the content and quality of the story here. But the current implementation is lacking. I strongly advise customers to wait for a performance and optimisation patch. Iron Galaxy, who handled the port were also responsible for producing the Uncharted port for the PC too. They were very quick to respond and address problems related to that title.

Give it a little time, maybe in a month or two months time this game will be patched and ready, but today? It really isn't.

text:
Is this a joke? I'm on a 2022 Legion 5 Pro laptop with 3070Ti and a Ryzen-9 6900HX, 32GB of RAM and a 2TB SSD. It's a setup that just let me play Plague Tale: Requiem, a game similar in style and mechanics to TLOU 1 + 2 (but with even better graphics) at upwards of 100 FPS at all times on max settings. I was previously playing RDR2 with 4K textures which took about 6-7GB of VRAM. Cyberpunk 2077 on Ultra needs about 8GB of VRAM. This setup crushes anything I throw at it, and can do full raytracing on most games at 80+ FPS with only minor graphical setting compromises. Hogwarts Legacy runs like a dream.

I'm getting under 30 FPS on the MENU SCREEN. The game defaulted to medium/low settings and was at almost 8GB of VRAM usage off the bat. I can't select Fullscreen as there's no option. Shader cache is building and currently at 25% as of this writing... I pop open Task Manager to see what's going on, and my CPU usage is at 100 fucking percent! On the MENU! Who greenlit this garbage? Absolutely insulting to the PC gaming community, and I'll be refunding this and never giving these goblins my money again. My laptop is about to burn through its cooling pad and I haven't even started the damn game.

Literally unplayable, and unironically so. Couldn't have imagined a AAA port releasing like this in 2023...

EDIT: I, as always, let the shaders compile before trying to play. I did the Oodle 'fix' mentioned on Reddit and here. As soon as I tried to open the bedroom door, the game crashed. Alright.. I turn down settings a bit (which I should NOT have to do) and try again. FPS is slightly better this run, I make it to the stairs and boom - crash again, within 45 second of loading in. At this point I will just go for the refund and buy RE4 remake instead. I won't sit through 3 minute load screens just to crash within a minute because of shit optimization. I have a friend playing on a 4090 having the same issues, so it's clearly not about "upgrade your specs" or "fix your PC". Crazy how some people can't grasp that the game clearly has severe issues.

I know it's not uncommon to use this technique to free up system memory, but it's usually done when these parts of the map are out of sight completely, not partially obscured.  On top of that, there's many immersion breaking glitches still present, such as the hair appearing like it's strands of paper on a pinata or textures just failing to load outright and being an inky black void instead.  This game clearly wasn't ready for launch and it still isn't ready two months later.  Just pass on this and maybe it'll be passable in a year's time.  It should be going on sale regularly by then.

text:
Well...Another hit or miss PC port....

Before I expand on my experience with this game, I'll give up my gaming rig specs to hopefully give other players an idea if their machines are the problem or not(it isn't, it's awful optimisation..)

i9 12900KS
ROG Maximus Z690 Hero Motherboard
32GB Corsair Vengeance DDR5 5600 Memory
2 x 1TB SAMSUNG 980 PRO M.2, PCIe NVMe(OS on the main, games on the other)
12GB ASUS ROG STRIX GEFORCE RTX 3080 Ti
Windows 11
Sony Bravia 4k TV 53 Inch(I can get the model number if needed but I don't think the TV is the issue..lol)

This has been a weird mix of great performance with a solid frame rate and crashing every fifteen minutes with no rhyme or reason. I dived in with my optimist hat on trying a 4K DLSS Quality Ultra run and to be honest it was fairly solid with a smooth 60FPS initially. I didn't have any crashes in my first hour of playing but as soon as I hit the spot where the first lot of spores and combat kicked in, I knew that I was being over ambitious with my settings(on purpose with a string of hope). I really wanted to keep the Ultra settings going so I dropped down to 1440P DLSS Quality at Ultra.... To be honest it was running great and was super smooth and this lasted for a good ninety minutes and I was enjoying the game immensely. The last hour of my four hour playtime was a different story. I was still getting the smooth and nice game play as described earlier but I had eight crashes in the space of fifty minutes. I tried a few graphic downgrade options but to be honest that didn't fix anything so as of now I am not going to bother playing any further.

I am guessing that patches will come and hopefully we can play this game without the strife that a good few of us have at the moment. In the meantime, I personally will not buy another PlayStation Studio game on PC  unless it has been ported by Nixxes(I believe PlayStation bought this studio), they seem to be the studio that knows what they are doing. I hope they are the ones that will port Ghosts of Tsushima as that is what we all really want.

Thanks for your time anyway. I'll revisit this if it gets patched and the crashes are fixed and update it accordingly. 

Cheers,

Kalizto

keywords: run, setting, pc, fps, performance, port, even, low, still, well
text:
This is an absolute TRAVESTY of a PC port. Like don't get me wrong, I've gotten used to shoddy PC ports over the last while, but this is just purely unacceptable. ESPECIALLY when this is a game that is considered to be one of the best games of all time, and an absolute must play by anyone who has played and enjoyed it. I would rather boot up my PS4 and play the old version of this at 30fps, or of course play the new updated/remastered version on Ps5 even though it was more of a cash grab than a remaster in my opinion. But this is seriously, seriously, terrible. I run a 3060 and a 5700xt and even with trying all forms and options of DLSS and FSR 2, it was nearly impossible to even hit a steady framerate at upscaled resolution. I was so much looking forward to finally being able to play this gem of a game on PC, but instead what I got is probably the saddest excuse for a PC port in a long while, and that is REALLY saying something.
Makes it all the worse that most of Sony's ports have ranged from pretty great to basically perfect. Games like Spider-Man, God of War, Miles Morales, Horizon, Death Stranding, Days gone....ALL of them have had great ports that you can tell had a lot of care put into them, and you really felt like you were playing an upgraded experience. With this port, the ONLY thing that is upgraded is the graphics. But even if you bump them down to low, the performance is still terrible, and you could spend 3 minutes standing looking at a road sign just for it to not render in the letters.
I'm sure experiences will vary, and I'm sure that people out there with a 4070+ and a monster CPU can probably get this game to run at a smooth framerate. Maybe. But the fact that I have a rig that should theoretically push me through the next generation of gaming and puts out significantly more power than a next gen console, that can barely run a remaster of a decade old game, shows some serious problems with this game's optimization. 
I've comfortably pre ordered all of SIE's PC ports so far, but this was a great reminder that pre ordering is always the wrong idea, even if the publisher has a good track record.

text:
[h1] THIS PORT SUCKS, NOT THE LAST OF US! [/h1] 
 I'm very hurt that I have to leave a 'Not Recommended' review on this title. 
For One Thing, The Last of Us is GD [b]Masterpiece[/b] and if you have never had the chance to play it then go get if for PS5 or PS4. Clarifying that this 'Negative' Review is not about TLoU but rather THIS port. I'm also very willing to do an updated review if/when they fix these issues...and there are quite a few issues...
  I pre-ordered this game, and I also paid for the deluxe version because I love the original so much. I didn't even care about the extra gun skins, I just wanted to show my love and help support Naughty Dog because generally I love their games. Also a huge fan of UC and all their old school titles as well. So Yea...I feel very betrayed, I would have happily waited longer for a FINISHED GAME! I mean....Its not like I don't have other amazing games to play/ Stream. Oh and....damn almost wasn't able to stream the game either. So let's talk about my experience as of this review (day 1 launch)
  (OK about a day and half before actually) So my buddy and I who have been non-stop talking about this game do the pre-download and then notice....there are absolutely no reviews...Did they not give out review copies? It should have been a red flag, but I was too excited. To paint a full picture I even spent over $1500 to do a 4080 upgrade, new PSU and more RAM (not for this game specifically, but It was one i wanted to play), and have had an excellent experience with games on full graphics while streaming even! And then 3/28/23 rolls around and its not until 9AM central that it unlocks with, surprise! another update.
  So now we are caught up to the day one launch. I open the game and before I play, it tells me that I need to wait for the shaders to load...OK...fair....but an hour to load them? I then played through the Intro and wasn't able to break 70 frames....AND I WANT TO CLARIFY that I would have been OK with 60 frames if it was stable. However, that wasn't the case, several times it would drop in the 40's or hang in the 50's. My friend actually had 20's at this point. Once i cleared the Intro I closed the game for a bit and then went back to mess with graphics. And I had it running at about 70 for most of it. 
  I feel like, OK maybe people were exaggerating a bit on the reviews, but I still agree that it should have been better. That is...Until I decided to stream it, which I had already let everyone know last week I was going to do and even made promos for. I was showing everyone that the reviews were not looking hot but we were going to try to stream it, and that I had a lot of confidence in it because of my pre-run earlier.  So I clicked Launch Game live on stream and it seemed to work.
  The loading screen came on and I was talking about the shaders, but in this case they were loaded, so I went to start a new game and CRASH!!!! I tried 4 more times but it wouldn't open. I ended stream so I could restart the whole PC and when I came back Steam wouldn't open. I had an awesome viewer that helped me do a verification thing on it that allowed it to open, and we were then able to stream it but had to wait until the shaders (that have had to load 3 times now!) to install again. We played up until Joel, Ellie, and Tess make it out of the sewers and on to the city. 
  During the stream it was extremely rare that I got 70 frames, much less 60. The average was 43 and there were several sections that dipped to 20-30....and ugh....it gave me a headache. Yes I was irritated, but I mean i got an actual head ache trying to play. I missed a bunch of shots or had to check things out slowly to not miss anything. I was even playing on medium graphics. For comparison I have been streaming A Plague Tale: Innocence on my new GPU at Ultra Graphics (Beautiful Game BTW-Highly Recommend) and the stream looks crisp and I'm always at a stable 75 FPS and sometimes a bit more even with the hordes of rats on screen. 
   In Conclusion: The Last of US is a wonderful game that will make you laugh, cry, and FEEL for these characters like no other game has done before. If you have not experienced it you NEED to! That being said, go play it on a PS5, and if you don't have one, play it on PS4, and if you don't have one of those and PC is your only option and that's why you have been waiting, please save your money and wait until they fix this. I know a lot of people complaining about the price, and with the current issues...I don't blame them, BUT If this port was a True remaster something you could play/stream at 60+ FPS and have better graphics then when it first came out $60 or even $70 is well worth the price!

keywords: shader, wait, take, hour, time, update, load, patch, minute, still
text:
Sigh…I didn’t want to have to make this review, but the sad state this game is in has warranted it. They delayed the launch for an extra three weeks to “optimize it for a wider range of systems.” In the end, they optimized it for NO SYSTEMS. Neil Druckmann even promised Steam Deck compatibility and the game’s technical issues prevent it from even running good of Deck

The issues stem from several key issues: Shader compiling is way too long. Call of Duty does not take this long to compile shaders. At minimum you’re looking at 90 minutes to compile the shaders, don’t even bother trying to play the game unless the shaders are compiled otherwise it’ll be unplayable

Second issue: it happened again mouse aim is choppy. You’d think they’d learn from when Uncharted had that issue but apparently not.

Third issue, crashing. Even with an SSD there’s moments the game just stops working right

Fourth issue, lack of gyro aim and issues with Steam Input. I am a firm proponent of motion control aiming for gamepads. From playing Splatoon I know gyro aim is objectively better than sticks. With mouse aim broken I wanted to turn gyro aim on with my Dualsense. The game doesn't have gyro aim (which is still stupid the majority of Playstation games don't have this feature) so I gotta open Steam Input settings to turn gyro aim on. Here's the thing: By default, the game disables Steam Input whatsoever. If you have a Dualsense connected it will turn it off and you cannot access Steam controller settings at all, which is absolutely asinine. So I back out of the game to turn Steam Input on, to which the game gives me a popup saying that the Dualsense's settings of the adaptive triggers, haptic feedback, and touchbar and light bar settings, won't work at all if Steam Input is on. Naughty Dog...are you kidding me? SPIDERMAN REMASTERED HAS GYRO AIM AND STEAM INPUT SETTINGS AND THE DUALSENSE FUNCTIONS STILL WORK! 

And of course fifth issue as mentioned before: the game on Steam Deck will not run at all despite Naughty Dog promising it would, AND VALVE ADVERTISING THE GAME FOR DECK

Hold the hell off until it gets fixed, and spend your money somewhere else, like Resident Evil 4 Remake, a remake that adds new content and isn’t a mess like this is. This is an absolute embarrassment and a tarnishing of the good will Playstation PC built up, and also a black mark on Sony’s flagship game The Last of Us, the game that won and still does win numerous Game of the Year awards and made an incredible impact on the industry that is still felt today.

EDIT: After two patches shader building is a lot faster so that part is taken care of at least, for the most part. It's now at a point that I can play it. However, it is still not in a good place for you to buy it. There's still stuttering issues, mouse aim is still broken and doesn't work right, and there's still a lot of optimization to do. This is really heartbreaking that the game was launched in this state. This is Sony's biggest game, and they left it in such a sorry state, presumably to rush it out the gate after the hype of the HBO show.

text:
An absolutely phenomenal game ruined by an atrocious port.


PERFORMANCE ISSUES:

TLOU Part 1 has very bad performance and crashes pretty often. I crashed probably 13 or 14 times through my entire play through. Also absolutely insanely long load times. Compiling shaders takes an hour and I've had to do it 4 times now. First time startup, verify game files, new drivers, new drivers again. Loading into your save takes an insane amount of time too. I have the game installed on a m.2 SSD and it takes 50-60 seconds. Like something has to be broken.

My Hardware:
Ryzen 7 5800x
32gb 3200mhz
RTX 3060ti
M.2 SSD

The game ran at 60 frames at medium settings set to DLSS quality at 1440p. The performance is that bad. I was able to replace a .dll file in the game directory that made the frames jump to about 80 but it was still pretty bad and I should never have to do that. If you have a high end PC you might be able to just brute force your way through the performance issues, but if you have a low to mid range PC you're going to have some problems.



ACTUAL GAME REVIEW:

All that being said I pushed through and beat the game because it's genuinely that good. Fantastic story, incredibly immersive world, the best video game characters I've ever seen, great writing, fun combat, beautiful graphics. Like it's all just extremely well done.
I've always been a fan of dark, gritty, harsh, realistic stories. Doesn't matter if its a video game, movie, or TV show and this game fulfills that itch perfectly. Most games don't really hit me emotionally but I wont lie, some moments got me. The performances from the characters are that believable. That's even coming from someone that knows most of the major beats of the game. I knew how the game ended, I knew what would happen to certain characters, and it still got me.
I also underestimated the game play. I assumed the combat was just "shoot people" with occasional looting sections. I was wrong. The enemy AI is actually very good. When in combat you can lose line of sight with the enemy and flank around to other positions and the levels are made just for that. It's also super important because they don't give you a whole lot of ammo. Most weapons top out at 15-20 rounds. That means you have to utilize the molotovs, bombs, smoke bombs, and melee weapons at your disposal.

I'm seriously debating whether or not I want to make this review positive or negative, but I think I'm going to leave it negative because Sony needs to know that this level of port is not acceptable despite the game being fantastic. Once the game is in a good state I'll change my review to positive. Hyped to go watch the show now because I was waiting to play the game first.

text:
I've heard so much about this game and I was excited to play it for myself, but it is absolute trash. Whoever made this port doesn't know how to program, optimize or test. I cannot get a consistent frame rate, the game looks terrible and somehow eats up a ton of resources. I've played plenty of better looking games on higher quality settings and not experienced the pure frame dropping and low resolution.

Honestly, I would forgive all of that, because a game doesn't need to run amazingly to be a fun experience or tell a great story. What it does need however, is to give me control over my player character. Both analog sticks suffer from some kind of issue. The cardinal directions are basically useless and you won't move while pointing in those directions, weirdly diagonals seem to work more often, but it's not exactly a fun experience to wiggle between up+right/down+right to get your camera aimed (not at where you're going) but off to the side so you can run at a diagonal toward it.

I couldn't even get beyond the introduction sequence, I kept getting bitten by zombies while trying my best to finagle my way through with the bad camera controls and movement. I realized it's not going to be worth it to try to play this game, so I'll be refunding. It feels really lame that this game can't even get movement correct. I wanted to enjoy this and now I'm very disappointed.

text:
[h1]TL;DR: If your video card has 8GB or less of VRAM, do not buy this game until they decide to optimize it better.[/h1]
There's nothing in this game that justifies the use of that much VRAM. The only viable reason is that the game is unoptimized because they rushed the PC port release so it could coincide with season 1 of the show.

If you have better than an RTX 3070 you shouldn't have any problems playing this,
[hr][/hr]
AMD Ryzen 7 3700X 3.6GHz
RTX 3070 (8GB VRAM)

My system can run most games at 1440p / 144hz. My system can only run this on [b]1080p Medium-High[/b]. 8gb VRAM isn't enough for 1440p and is only barely enough for 1080p. I am still getting crash after crash.
[hr][/hr]
[b][u]Gripes[/u][/b]
You have to (re)build shaders every time your graphics card drivers has a new update. This shader building takes 30 minutes each time. [b]There has to be a better way to do this.[/b]

[b][u]Good things[/u][/b]
The new game+ modes and speed run modes are good additions that add lots of replay value. Weapon upgrades can be carried over into your next playthrough. There are a wide variety of graphical options and tweaks that I would be raving about if the VRAM optimization thing wasn't an issue.

I would love to recommend this game, and maybe I will one day. But right now, it's just a big hole in my wallet.

text:
The crash of us

extremely high CPU usage during gameplay

textures dont load

1st patch fixed nothing

2nd patch fixed nothing

3rd patch fixed nothing

4th patch fixed nothing.

As much as I like this game it’s a really bad port. The frame rate is very inconsistent due to the very high cpu usage and the way the game streams it’s assets. This leaves no room for the GPU to communicate with the CPU which results in very poor performance.

There’s also lag when using a controller which makes aiming and movements feel off and can become frustrating when you need to make small precision movements. I’ve also read there seems to be issues with mouse control as well.

I never preorder games but I felt this one was a safe option as naughty dog studio normally delivers high quality games. This was not one of them. I’ve learned my lesson to not break my own rule and always wait for reviews.

Unless they miraculously fix this game I would avoid buying it 

😔

text:
Are you tired of playing games that actually run smoothly on your computer? Do you miss the days of laggy, buggy gameplay that makes you want to throw your keyboard out the window? Look no further than The Last of Us PC port!

Experience the thrill of choppy framerates, stuttering cutscenes, and random crashes that will keep you on the edge of your seat (or angrily pounding your desk). And if you're lucky, you might even get to experience some bonus graphical glitches that will make your characters look like they're straight out of a Salvador Dali painting!

Sure, the gameplay and story are still top-notch, but who needs a smooth experience when you can have a heart attack-inducing one instead? So if you're looking for a game that will make you question your decision to ever invest in a high-end gaming rig, look no further than The Last of Us PC port. It's an experience you'll never forget (or maybe never finish because it keeps crashing).

tl;dr This game is basically Crysis 3 on the PS3.

text:
As of launch, this game is in HORRIFIC shape. You know you aren't doing well when I couldn't even make it past the FIRST CUT-SCENE without a crash. What exactly causes this game to crash in such a dramatic fashion, sometimes taking Steam or even my entire PC with it is beyond me. 

Additionally, it seems like this game is very poorly optimized, especially when it comes to VRAM usage. I'm not running any kind of 4090 rig, but something in me doubts that this game is just so graphically advanced that my RTX 3070 and i7-12700k can't even launch it at anything higher than medium settings. (I will admit, the game does look gorgeous, even at medium, or at least, the one room I can load without it crashing does,) 

This is basically unplayable right now, I'm not sure if I'm going to make another attempt or just wait. Hopefully we'll get a patch very quickly that at least makes the game playable, but say it does, how am I supposed to enjoy the game knowing it may not reach its definitive state for another 6 months? I almost NEVER buy a game like this at  launch, but I was eager enough to play this one that I was willing to shell out $60 for a game that released a decade ago. Shame on me for assuming that meant I'd be able to play it. Stay away from this one until the reviews get better.

text:
As someone who played the original once, the remaster twice and the second game twice I can atest to the fact that this game is a masterpiece in story-telling. While the story is far from unique it's not only well done but the world building, premise and sheer bleakness of the game is incredible. The update to the graphics, the combat all feel really solid. The problem here isn't the game; its'  Iron Galaxy. Notoriously one of the worst companies around to port a game yet Sony allowed them to port TLOU which in itself is downright stupid considering the slew of other teams that could've ported this properly. You might hit minimum system requirements, you might hit recommended or you might just have a god-tier rig but, as the community has pointed out, it doesn't matter.  Iron Galaxy absolutely screwed the community, Sony and Naughty Dog with this port that doesn't even feel like a 1/10.

The game itself is 10/10 but it's almost unplayable in it's current state. I've seen people levy hatred at the Devs. Levy your disdain at  Iron Galaxy. That's a company that genuinely needs to go out of business.

keywords: run, setting, pc, fps, performance, port, even, low, still, well
text: The Last of Us Part 1 PC port is a disaster. It is the single worst PC port I have ever played. The game is riddled with bugs, crashes, performance issues, and graphical glitches. It looks worse than the original PS3 version, which came out almost a decade ago. The PC features are minimal and poorly implemented. The game does not support AMD FSR 2.2 or Nvidia DLSS Super Resolution, despite being advertised as such. The game also does not support VSync or frame rate cap options, resulting in screen tearing and stuttering. The game is unplayable on anything but the most powerful PCs, and even then it struggles to maintain a stable framerate. The game also suffers from frequent crashes, corrupted saves, audio issues, and missing textures. The game is a slap in the face to PC gamers who have been waiting for years to play this acclaimed masterpiece. It is clear that Iron Galaxy, the studio responsible for the port, did not care about quality or optimization. They just wanted to cash in on the hype generated by the HBO show and the upcoming sequel. This port is an insult to Naughty Dog, Sony, and most importantly, the fans. Do not buy this game. It is not worth your time or money. You are better off playing it on PS5 or PS4, where it runs smoothly and looks beautiful. This PC port is a joke and a scam. It deserves all the negative reviews it is getting on Steam. Stay away from this garbage.

keywords: release, really, review, go, say, year, see, know, come, make
text:
I never leave reviews for games no matter how bad they are but this is embarrassing. For reference I am playing this with a i9-12900k, 3080 ti, 64gb of ddr5 ram, and it is downloaded on a 970evo NVME ssd. I have NEVER had a game run this bad no matter how dog shit the port is. Sony should have pulled this the moment they saw its performance I barely made it 5 min into the start of the game before giving up. Here are some of the issues I ran into during this short playtime:
[list]
[*] Upon opening the game I had to wait [b]45[/b]minutes for the shaders to download I understand this process isn't supposed to be that fast but there are game with much better graphics that take a quarter the time to do this
[*] Even after letting the shaders load the game still took about 2 minutes to load the first level then took another 2 when I skipped the first cutscene.
[*] The reason I skipped the first cutscene is because the character models were constantly shifting between what they were supposed to do and T posing/sliding this was true for all 4 cuscenes I tried to watch.
[*] On top of the last point when the characters were doing the right animations the sound was completely desynced along with the facial animation being almost completely wrong the entire time.
[*] The T posing/sliding issue wasn't only for cutscenes they also plagued any gameplay with NPCS
[*] I didn't make it to any combat but I have to believe that if these issues were even half as bad during those they would be unplayable. 
[/list] 
I have genuinely loved the last of us since it first released on PlayStation and I have happily bought nearly every version they have released but the fact that Sony allowed Iron Galaxy to butcher their golden child like this is beyond disappointing. This is not only the first ever review I have ever written for steam but also the first time I feel morally obligated to refund a Last Of Us release. [b]DO NOT BUY THIS IN ITS CURRENT STATE IRON GALAXY AND SONY HAVE ALOT OF WORK TO DO BEFORE THIS PORT IS WORTH ANY MONEY.[/b]

text:
It breaks my heart, but I have to write my first ever negative review on Steam, and I have to do it for The Last of Us, which is one of my favorite games of all time. I completed TLOU many times on PS3, PS4 and PS5 before.

Upon launching the PC version, I was greeted with an immediate crash. I updated all the drivers, restarted my computer and tried again.
When I reached the main menu, CPU usage immediately rose to 100% and stayed there as the shader building process started. I tried changing some settings and got booted out of the game again. Retried, and as soon as the shader compilation reached about 5%, Windows reported that it's totally out of memory and the game completely froze my computer to the point where I had to hard reset.
I tried launching it again, and the shader compilation got to 8% when my PC completely froze again.

So after nearly half an hour of waiting all I got was a few crashes and hard resets. Never had any sort of issues running other games, including RDR2 on the highest settings.

This is the worst PC port I've ever seen in my life so far. Do not buy this game on PC, not yet at least. Sorry, Sony/ND, but there is NO excuse for letting TLOU get the worst PC port in the history of video games.
If you have a spare PS3/4/5 lying around, I recommend trying the game there.

My rig is i9-10900K, 3080 Ti 12 GB, 16 GB 4000 MHz RAM.

text: When i was younger, video games used to be a bright ray of sunshine in my life. The excitement of a new adventure in a world I had read about in game informer, or followed closely on IGN could keep me vibrating with anticipation for months or years as i waited for its release date to creep ever closer.  As I and the video game market age together, even though I have lost the muscles, tight skin and thick hair of my youth, i still cant help but think Im holding up better than this industry's standards. Everything these days is a big steaming pile of trash. Nothing is complete. Its always pay now and wait a few months after launch for us to get this fixed and sorted. It feels like the pride in making something great has given way to timelines and cash grabs. Shame on Sony and the company they used to port this, one of the last actual masterwork games in recent memory. This marks the last time I let the nostalgia of my childhood excitement sway my wallet. Never again am I preordering something. And never again am i buying a game the day of launch.

text:
Last of Us needs no introduction. The characters are excellent, as is the storytelling and world design. I had this pre-ordered and pre-loaded before it was even released today. I was excited to finally revisit a game I once played on a friend's PS3 on my own PC after all these years.

I hope this gets fixed swiftly, and that the publishers of the disaster of a port adequately compensate those who they took money from but delivered a shoddy product. The Last of Us is excellent and deserves every bit of hype and praise that can be showered upon it, but this game as it stands right now is trash and unplayable.

text:
Pathetic.

I purchased this for 59.99€ as a pre-order on February 15th. I waited 1.5 months for this, until the end of March. 2 days ago, the Steam client allowed me to download the game files already. So I did. Yay!

Today, the day it was released, I logged on to Steam - and the game needed to decompress or something first, which took about 30 minutes or an hour or so of background work. Couldn't have done that 2 days ago and just let me play today. Nope. Had to be done the moment I wanted to play it.

So then after it's done expanding, I click the green PLAY button - and I get a warning dialog. My graphics driver is outdated. I need to have at least version 22.x installed. But I have graphics driver version 23.x installed. OK, so I click the warning away (every time I launch the game) and the game starts.

I configure a few things, end up in the main menu. Just about to start playing, when the game tells me it's better to wait until shader generation is done, otherwise the game will be slow. I notice a little message in the lower right corner of my screen, something like "Generating Shaders: 2%". 

I have an AMD Ryzen 7 5800X with 32 GB of RAM, all-out NVMe SSDs, and my Gigabyte AMD Radeon Vega64 Gaming OC Windforce 2X with 8G is no slouch either. If this graphics card can render Red Dead Redemption 2 in 4K at full details without any stuttering or frame rate issues on a slower CPU, then in this constellation there should be no problems rendering a game at 27" native 2560x1440p.

Fun fact: it took my machine 30 minutes (!) to generate 20% of the shaders. And this is the case EVERY TIME I start the game. In other words: the game expects me to launch the game 2.5 hours before I actually want to start playing, just so it can generate its shaders. Nuh-uh, not happening.

To put this 2.5 hour value into relation: it would take the game longer to generate its shaders ONCE, i.e. for ONE session, than Steam allow as the maximum playing time inside which it's possible to return the game.

The Steam discussions about this problem mention that Naughty Dog released the game with a buggy or faulty version of the Oodle de-/compression tool. Some people say it's version 2.9.6 that has a memory leak or something, and replacing it with version 2.9.5 works just fine. Only problem: the Oodle library can not be freely downloaded for "the likes of me", it's only available to the developers. 

A few links surfaced in the Discussions area, all to either Russian websites or otherwise shady "anyone can upload anything" hosting pages, that allegedly provide the non-buggy version 2.9.5 of the Oodle library. Others suggested installing games that also use Oodle (like Warframe or FIFA 23) and copying the Oodle DLL file over from that. Just that Warframe is free but a 30+ GB download, and FIFA 23 isn't free, and I'm not going to spend anymore time or money on fixing something that should not have been distributed like this anyway.

I will check back tomorrow, and then maybe again next Monday. If these (non isolated, very widely present) problems aren't fixed until then, I will make use of my right to return this flaming heap of sh-t. 

What a f-cking money grab. Imagine a 10 year old game not being able to perform on modern hardware. And then actually asking money for it. The nerve of these pr-cks!

Edit2: Even with the below "fix" the load times are still terrible. Which is not okay. For reference, my system is a high end system, along with having this installed on an M.2 Drive. The load times on this game is unacceptable. I have experienced load times in excess of 5+ minutes for a single level.

For those wanting to know my specs.

Ryzen 5950x
Radeon 7900xt

Edit: It appears at least for me, that the primary issue is a bad compression library that was bundled in with the game. I suspect this has already been discovered by the team who did this work and is working on a fix. In the meantime, you are welcome to try the following link.

Steps to replace, are to simply retrieve the file linked below, extract it, and place the DLL into the game install directory. For most folks that will be C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\The Last of Us Part I

Source Thread: https://steamcommunity.com/app/1888930/discussions/0/3818529563396381516/?ctp=3

Link to DLL: https://pixeldrain.com/u/hEtXRL1E

VirusTotal Run in 7z https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/617331c1cbc32dec701308158c45ac97ff7cb8a03ce65930c1eed6000bb1a47c

VirusTotal Run of extracted file: https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/019cafd2a2a955e4b12b34492162a9261053bef09c6cf3209a85b25a9952c613

Original Review
Like many others, I do not recommend this game as is right now. Between the shaders being built for over a half hour for me (and I consider myself one of the lucky ones). Even trying to load the game after the shaders being built was done. It took MINUTES to even load the first level. I actually gave up and turned it off, and it didn't even hit 1/4 of the level loaded. This is abysmally poor optimization and Sony and Iron Galaxy should be ashamed. I am a software engineer myself, and I would have been fired if I released a product in such a poor state.

Do yourself a favor, and wait for them to optimize this the way they should have before they released this for money.

keywords: run, setting, pc, fps, performance, port, even, low, still, well
text: Took 1 hour and 5 minutes to compile shaders on a 9700k OC'd to 4.5ghz. Sat at 100% CPU usage on all cores the whole time. When running high settings @1440p on a 2080ti I would get about 40-50fps for busier exterior scenes and sometimes up to 60fps in interior spaces. When lowered from high to medium exteriors were usually above 60 and interiors could be as high as the mid 80's. However, not all frames are created equal as by god the frame pacing was awful. At said 80fps it felt and looked closer to 30 or 40fps with constant microstutter. Had 1 scene drop to 9fps for about 5 seconds before correcting. When going from high to medium I also experienced a solid 45 seconds of extremely poor textures presumably from poor texture streaming. But it did correct itself and I haven't seen it again yet. Had I not ordered the Firefly Edition for the steelbook and comics, I would 100% be refunding this. This is absolutely unacceptable. text:
(updating the review as I've finished the game since)

Still the worst port I have EVER seen. Comically tragic. 
Despite playing it in 1080p, with everything on low and DLSS set to "performance" it ran like absolute garbage on a 12900k, DDR5 and a 3080. Crashed at least 2-3x per hour and had random frame drops causing MASSIVE stutters whenever it would spawn an enemy or whenever my character did a 90 degree turn. 
So, yeah. Fun. 
If you were wondering if the "hotfix" or dedicated TLOU nVidia drivers changed anything - they slightly reduced the frequency of crashes while making the game run even worse, somehow.

Skip it, if you already bought it but can get a refund - do it. Circle back in a few months, I really don't see this big of a dumpster fire being significantly improved anytime soon. Finishing the game in this state was an experience I wouldn't wish on anyone.

text:
I really wanted to like this. Never played it before, and I've been loving the PlayStation ports of recent years. Based on the detailed spec requirements that was published, I place somewhere between "Recommended" and "Performance" spec. So, I should have no problem running the game at 1440p with med settings. Not only could I not, but I couldn't even maintain 60 FPS with 1080p, DLSS set to Performance, and all graphics settings as low as they could go. An absolute joke. Spending my first hour and a half waiting for shaders, and load times in excess of a minute are just insulting when given this level of performance.

Edit: Saw a couple reviews mention that the FPS gets better after the prologue. While true, the increase is only marginal and there's a terrible stutter that's impossible to ignore. It also doesn't excuse that I have yet to play more than 10 minutes in a row without a crash, and many crashes happen on launch or at the start of cutscenes. I've relaunched the game to give it multiple chances, and I'm probably going to keep doing so because I really want it to be good. It just... isn't.

text:
Currently I do not recommend this game in the state it is in. I don't have the top of the line PC specs, and my game ran fine. It looks beautiful in fact. I've played this game on PS3, PS4 multiple times, and after watching the show I was excited to jump back in. I wanted to play the Part 1 upgrade, but couldn't justify the 69.99 price on PS5 when I already owned it. So this upgrade coming to PC was a better choice I thought. My issues came as follows. The shader building on the main menu. Yes I know it's something they have to install and with patience it finally finishes. My issue with it, was it had to do it 3 times! I've sunk 5 hours into this game, all of it being waiting for the shaders to build. And each time it got to 100% and finished. A bug maybe? Or just the state that it's in kept requiring it to build? 

My second issue comes with the audio. As I've mentioned I've played this before and I know there are quiet moments, but oh my gods I could barely hear a word spoken. I have a good set of headphones and I never NEVER have to turn my output to max in any game. This was the first. And it sucked because while I could now hear the dialog, all the sound effects were deafening so I'd bust my eardrums when a gunshot goes off or an explosion happened. 

I will change my review once things get updated and fixed. I love Last of Us and I have faith that they will fix it in the future. But in the state that it's in, it's a nightmare just trying to launch.

text:
Iron galaxy's newest port strikes again as being the most unoptimized, unpolished release of this year. It's a shame really since Sony/Naughty Dog decided to cooperate with Iron Galaxy rather than Nixxes to release TLOU Part I. I've been waiting for this game to release since i'm a huge fan of ND's storytelling and their characters, but all of the problems prevents me from enjoying the experience or even tried to feel the emotion the game tries to convey.

Rocking with i7-10700F, RTX 3060, and only 16GB of RAM, other games ran smoothly with this rig, especially the newest games like RE4, and MW2 with 90+ and 120+ fps respectively. For a game that is already 10 years old using the newest tech and graphical improvement, that is not an excuse for Iron Galaxy's laziness. 50-70 fps on High 1080p settings? I even had to use DLSS to improve the fps but its minimum to no avail. 

(It's a shame really, you really need an expensive rig to run TLOU Part I in this very state, it's not even a smooth experience even if you reached above 70+ fps since the mouse movement is so stiff.)

CPU usage is also terrible, I had to wait for almost 2 hours to finish preloading the shaders, because when I tried to play while the shaders still preloading, the perfomance were terrible and alot of hitching (same condition for HZD) but HZD were able to maintain good perfomance after shaders preload, though it's suffers from the same problems, that is the horrendous perfomance on launch day.

The game itself is a masterpiece on its own. With its story and their world building, My first 1 hour of playtime (considering the 2 hours of shaders preload, bs i know) is amazing, the characters are well voice/well-acted, the graphical technology, and the movement is as smooth as other ND's games. It is NOT RECOMMENDED to play this masterpiece since the bugs and the problems will ruin your time, they should be ashamed to ruin a first timer experience, like for those who hasn't played TLOU or watch the newest show on HBO at all.

Better to wait out until Iron Galaxy decided to patch all the problems. Shaders preload, terrible perfomance, popping textures, stuttering, and jittery mouse movements. I am really disappointed that Naughty Dog would let Iron Galaxy ruined their most beloved franchise.

text:
Please tell me how medium textures use 7GB of Vram...

Update: After a GPU upgrade, cache clear, unofficial fixes, I finally finished the game. It's true that the performance is abysmal. Now I already wasn't happy about it. After getting a 4070 Ti I still got frame dips due to the extreme CPU usage. 

Now when playing the game I was one of the few that didn't have the entire story spoiled. To simply put it, the game itself is phenomenal. This goes up along with Red Dead 2 as one of my favorite narrative game experiences ever. The chemistry the characters have and the movie-like nature of it all really does make it a unique experience.

As someone who hasn't played a Naughty Dog game before, I was a little concerned about their linearity. However I can 100% say that it was towards this games benefit. But I think this style of game isn't for me. Will I play this game again? Absolutely. If TLOU Part 2 comes to PC will I play that? Without a doubt. Will I buy another Naughty Dog game from a different series? Probably not. Unless there's another Naughty Dog game that comes close to this level of story telling, I think the main draw of TLOU and it's style of game is kind of gone. 


So TL;DR great game, bad port. If you have some beefy specs I'd give it a go as it'll most likely run well enough. Still completely unacceptable performance, but playable.

text:
When I found out that Naughty Dog had delayed the release of this game to further optimize it, I was happy because I'm honestly tired of buying a game and waiting weeks or months until it's somewhat playable. 

Unfortunately, I don't know what Naughty Dog did with the extra time, but they sure didn't optimize the game. 

Not only do you have to wait for an hour for the shaders to compile at the beginning, and it takes up an additional 30GB of disk space, but when you start the game, you realize there are FPS drops all over the place, and the game slows down even though it claims to run at 60 FPS.

I never played the remaster, I come from the PS3 era, and I honestly wasn't impressed by the new graphics, let alone think they're worth $60, so I found the purchase absurd. I'd rather buy Resident Evil 4, which did receive a thorough facelift and modernization, and get this game when it's 80% off.

In summary, poorly optimized, average graphics even when everything is set to ultra, and a lack of respect for all the fans of the series.

PS: I requested a refund, and you should do the same, so they understand the message.

I grabbed a controller, and it instantly went from stuttering to smooth as butter. Did this game SERIOUSLY get ported for PC... but use some half ass mouse emulation??? in 2023? You guys.. come on, that is something you could literally see on your end. Motion smoothing and V sync can only save you so much. Please give PROPER raw mouse input to the game, it's painful in it's current state. 

TLDR; the GAME itself is beautiful and phenominal.. the issues are what make me say just wait. They clearly are pulling the same BS every dev is doing which is releasing a public beta for us to test so they can iron out the issues later. Will the game be worth buying? Absolutely. But right now it's needing some fixes.

Refunded because I am SICK of developers getting away with thinking they can just keep releasing broken messes on release. I am not supporting this anymore, I'm done.

text:
Been waiting for this since it came out on console like 10 years ago, really excited to play and will be able to wait a little longer for things to be fixed, going to refund and buy it again later.

Update: Completely playable and I sit at around 100 fps on high settings on AMD's ASR or whatever, on 527.56 Nvidia drivers. But I'm still not going to recommend it yet because there are people who still can't play.

Update after finishing the game: This game is in the top 3 of best games I've ever played, what a beautiful and extremely engaging and fun game.

I'm going to just list and throw things at you instead of trying to put it together in a concise manner since I just finished the game and it's all fresh.

I vaguely knew the end of the game going into it (I did wait 10 years or so to play it after all), but the story is absolutely wonderful, it's enthralling and never once did I feel bored or like "Ugh I just wanna get this game over with.". Every time I felt like "Oh, the end of the game is coming up... darn..." the game ends up giving you another 2-3 hours, and that happens about 4 times (Ish, I don't remember exactly.) and it's absolutely awesome.

One of the only games to do stealth right and make it extremely immersive and fun. Going to replay on the hardest difficulty most likely so I can experience the stealth in an even harder way. (Dishonored 1 and Splinter Cell are the only others I can think of right now that do it well.)

Best visuals of any game I've ever played, it's amazing how much configuration there is in the graphics settings, and also the way they showcase each and every graphics setting is extremely different and vastly useful. It's something you would think would be commonplace in the gaming industry but absolutely isn't, I don't think I've ever played a game that was as indepth for graphics settings as The Last of Us is.

If you had to show a videogame to an alien civilization this would be one of the ones you chose, if not the first one you picked.

The combat is SO visceral, I wasn't super into using the melee weapons you find around, but the gunplay and the shiv combat is absolutely breathtaking and beautifully animated. It's extremely grotesque too but in a good way, the realism is amazing, I have heard rumors that Naughty Dog suggested and or encouraged their developers to look at real life gore to help with their work. Now I don't know if it's true but it's absolutely 100% easy to believe given how gore looks in the game. I normally am squeamish and tend to hate excessive gore in videogames but it's genuinely likeable and feels extremely on par.

There is so much polish in places where you wouldn't expect it, even just for a few seconds of gameplay, like Joel riding the horse and ducking his head, etc.

The dialogue system is really nice and refreshing.

Still feeling bad about Sarah during the credits, I don't think I have ever been so emotionally attached to a character that had so little time in the actual story. Her part of the game and story is so tragic and I feel so much empathy for it, it hurts a little now even writing this.

I absolutely love it and give it a 10/10, I would be recommending yes in a normal situation but given how bad the release was (I didn't get to play more than a few hours until a week or so after buying it, I tolerated about 70 freezes and maybe 5 ish crashes but then it became unplayable and it would freeze or crash faster than I could progress lol, or it just wouldn't boot to the main menu and would lock up at launch), but I want to stand in solidarity with other people that can't get it to run and help be a part of getting it fixed, even if it's a small contribution.

Even during the credits I was already wanting to play it again, I don't think I've ever felt that way about any other game I've ever played.

text:
[h1]They're Laughing at Us™ Part I[/h1]

This review is due to a catalogue of errors. From poor performance to corporate greed.

[list]
[*]Poor optimisation. Uses far more resources than a game with this many iterations should use. [i]Just download more VRAM[/i]
[*]Corporate greed. Overpriced port of a remake of a remastered remastered game that's not even 10 years old yet. Gives Bethesda a run for their money, but even Skyrim now has more content not less than it did on original release. 
[*]Shader builder. Can take up to 2 hours to build shaders necessary to play the game. AND YOU HAVE TO BE IN GAME TO DO SO. Running up that clock baby.
[*]Crashes. Not acceptable.
[*]Loading times. Loads like molasses.
[*]No Multiplayer. Contentious point since PS5 version doesn't have multiplayer either, but the multiplayer was fantastic and part of the reason the game maintained popularity. Its just a disappointment that content has been stripped away and they're still expecting full price.
[*]You can't buy a PC for the same price of a PS5 that will run this game.
[/list]

[h1]When you're lost in the stutter, look for a refund.[/h1]

[b][u]Refund window should be extended if you have to spend time in game getting the game ready to play.[/u][/b]

I want to enjoy this game, I was looking forward to it. I know the story is phenomenal, I know that the game play is fun, I know that the setting and the environments are top tier. I wouldn't have bought it if this game wasn't one of my favourite games. However it seems lately like too many releases now suffer horrible optimisation and shaders issues. It's frustrating.

If I could refund I would.

text:
Systems specs: RTX 4090, Ryzen 5900x, 32GB CL16 4000Mhz, Samsung 980 Pro SSD.

Looks amazing, has a super flexible options menu for PC and it's one of the best games of all time.  Though how on earth the Devs thought it was a good idea to release it in this state, I'll never know!?!  They must know there are issues... they can't not!

Personally, I don't mind the one off shader compilation time... but then, it was only about 25 mins for me on my rig (yes, I consider myself one of the lucky few).  I'd much rather have upfront compilation than a stuttering mess of a game. (even if this title does seem a bit extreme with regards to time to complete!).

Or at least, that's what I thought, but unfortunately, I still get a stuttering mess of game because it's just so badly CPU optimised.  One minute I'm all Ultra 4K, maxed at 120fps, my eyes bleeding from how good the upgrade is, loving revisiting this classic title.... next minute my CPU utilisation is up at 80-90% leaving my poor 4090 kicking it's heels at around 60% utilisation and my FPS plumet to around 54fps.  If I'm rocking a 5900x and seeing this kind of CPU behaviour, then I hate to think what's happening to others with lower spec'd rigs.  And yes, shader compilation had 100% completed....

Even running 1080p Low settings to brute force a fix, I still see's that the title is completely CPU choked at times... it's embarrassing.  How very very disappointing for the Devs, let alone us fans / gamers!  :(

I'd sit tight if you have yet to purchase... hopefully they'l be able to patch this mess and do justice to the players.  The potential is there for sure!

text:
[h1]An Absolute Joke of a Port[/h1]

Well looks like Sony is at it again with a REALLY Bad Attempt to Port one of their best games to the PC.
Meet The Lag of Us Part 1, a 2023 Remake of a PS3 Game that still can't compile shaders after 40 minutes, barely reaching 20%.

The game regularly interrupts gameplay with abrupt loading screens saying "Please Wait" despite being installed on an SSD on a Higher Spec Rig. This port has genuinely released in a Joke of a State and to be honest, it comes across as a really quick cash grab to cash in on the Popularity of the Show instead of a Heart-Filled Honest Port of one of Playstation's Best Titles.

I absolutely DO NOT Recommend this Game, If it ever gets patched, I hope it gets fixed.
Save your Money, Go Play Spiderman or God of War if you want GOOD PC Playstation Games...

2/10

TLOU1 finally out on Steam, I’m still happy for the great game. Why I’m saying “still”٩(｡•́‿•̀｡)۶  

The Last Of Us has always been one of my fav games, I've played it through five times on ps and also for two of my friends. I really love the game and I remember the whole storyline like where to go, what comes next etc. 

But then, Naughty Dog was just being too naughty when I waited ages just for a golf club. I loved Joel so much, he was my fav character. And I enjoyed every moment of seeing Joel and Ellie together, I loved their bond, their friendship and I even wished for them to come together as a couple (っ˘̩╭╮˘̩)っ

But it all ended with my tears shed for half an hour. For totally half an hour I just stared at my TV screen and couldn’t stop crying. It was the cruelest moment for me and also for many other players. I dun get why it has to end like this (・_・ヾ.

TLOU Part I is one of the best games ever, I can really recommend it to everyone. But I’m not gonna vote it with a thumbs up(•ิ_•ิ). And if u get emotional about game stories like I do, make sure u dun play TLOU Part II, coz then this game will no longer remain TLOU, it’d become The Golf Club: Prequel. And I've heard there’ll be a The Golf Club: Afterstory too. Let’s do some sports then again. 

Long live Joel.

text:
Edit 5/23:

Mouse stutter has been fixed and performance, textures, and shader compilation are somewhat improved. General performance still needs a lot of work, but things are slowly improving.

---

The game looks great and I'm glad it's finally on PC after all these years, but the port has some issues. Shader compilation sucks and takes quite a while, but it is a one-time thing and is important for performance. That said, performance is a bit on the low end. With my 3080ti and 5950x I can get 90 fps [i]most[/i] of the time at 3440x1440 on medium with DLSS on performance. I'm not going to complain too much since I'm not running a typical resolution, but you're going to need DLSS for pretty much any lower tier hardware or if aiming for higher than 60fps.

There is one major issue that guarantees a negative review from any PC player - major mouse stutter. It's crazy that this made it past even the earliest stages of QA, and is an issue that apparently [i]also[/i] plagues the uncharted 4 port. The only way to [i]potentially[/i] fix this is to change a bunch of mouse, monitor, and GPU settings to specifically work around this bug. And by doing so, you mess up the settings for everything else on your PC... which makes it a pretty poor solution. As you might expect, controllers don't experience this issue, so I'll be using a Dualsense until they release a patch.

Fortunately, the good news is [i]very[/i] good news. There are a TON of graphical options and settings to tweak the game to your liking. Native Utrawide support is very appreciated and the realtime cutscenes don't force black bars (unless you want them to!). I haven't experienced any crashes or microstutters on my desktop as of yet (though I do have a pretty beef PC). No Denuvo is good to see, and Steam Deck is supported at launch. Accessibility options are extensive and are always welcome for those who need them. 

Never thought I'd see the day PC gamers get to experience this game. We're just a few patches away from being able to recommend one of the best Playstation exclusives ever made.

Iron Galaxy ruins yet another beloved game. First it was Arkham Knight, then Uncharted 4 and now The Last of Us. All these guys do is half-ass PC ports. Uncharted 4 PC still has plenty of issues to this day that are unresolved.

- Crackling audio that was also and still is an issue in Uncharted 4

- Various performance issues that result in frame drops and poor fps

Such a disappointment.

text:
I really do not see any of the main issues most people are seeing here. I have a 3070 ti 8gb, i9-12900k and 32 gigs of ram. Not the godliest setup by any means but I can easily run the game at 1080p max settings with zero crashes. The CPU utilization is a bit nuts to be honest, but I truly did not receive any of the crashes or bugs that many are reporting. If anything, my performance is pretty good on this game considering I also have ray-tracing on. Overall, if you played the original and want to experience the Last of Us on PC then I do recommend buying the port.

EDIT: I stand corrected, hard. I wrote this review WHILE playing the game, and no joke 10 minutes after this review I crashed. Keep in mind I had played for 2 hours at this point, and this was my first crash. I was hoping it was a one-time thing, and unfortunately I have continued to crash at random points in the game. I am really hoping that for the sake of this franchise they don't ruin their reputation, with this frankly, terrible excuse for a game. After the crashes I started getting increasingly bad performance issues, I'm going to wait it out since I am past the return period, and just pray they do a Cyberpunk and fix most of the issues. I'm really hoping they do, but realistically, this will probably go down as just another terrible PS4 port.

text:
10 years ago, I invested hundreds of hours, meticulously searching for every comic book and artifact, every collectible, finding all the shiv doors and every optional conversation  -- I even replayed this game 7 times to achieve platinum on my PS3 because this game was just that good. 
I enjoyed every second of this game. It's still one of the greatest single player games I've ever played; even their multiplayer was the most fun I had since MW2 S&D.
As much as I loved it, I surely was not about to purchase this game again, especially not for $70 . . . but here I am.
I'd say it was to support Naughty Dog, but truthfully, I just wanted to relive a little bit of the nostalgia, since most every highly anticipated game in the last 10 years hasn't always lived up to their hypes. 
I knew this one would be good.

Just to emphasize: this review is NOT based off the game. It's strictly based off the fact that it is absolutely unplayable. At least for right now.
I know it's a huge issue, so I hope by the time some of you read this, it'll have been fixed so PC players can enjoy the beauty of this game, apart from the TV show.

Review:
I've updated my graphics card, validated the files, completed all the advised steps to ensure the game would run successfully, however nothing has worked. The only thing I think may fix the issue is waiting for my shaders to completely install, which is why I'm 10 minutes into the game with 93 minutes played, haha. 

Update, shaders didn't work; I ran the game outside of safe mode and it worked a bit longer.
Update 2: turned off vsync, lowered all my graphic settings to bare minimum, set to performance, enabled a few performance monitors like GPU usage and VRAM, so far so good!

So to sum it up: great game, terrible bug.


Side note: I hope they release a co-op DLC version of this, along with their original multiplayer as well.
Because I swear on my life, if they release a 3rd game . . .
And it's the re-remastering of the same ****ing game with just multiplayer/co-op added . . .
I will not be playing this story TWENTY-ONE more times. I don't care how good it is.

ND, Please fix your shit. 
I love you. 
But fix your shit.

text:
I was really looking forward to finally playing this game, only to notice this is absolutely unplayable on a RTX 2070 Super at 1440p. I tried 1080p, but even then it still lags on the lowest settings and it looks like absolute crap. Even when it shows 100 fps in small indoor sections, it's still jittery and has constant stutters. Absolute mess of a port.

EDIT - I had found a fix on reddit that made me able to decently play at 60+ fps at medium settings, only for the new patch (for increasing performance, haha) to bring that back down to a nice clean frigging 35-45 fps, no matter what I do. Thankfully I already played through it once, but man, this is just sad. Don't make the same mistake I did, and wait till this dumpster fire gets fixed. 

Game is great though when it runs, one of a kind. Amazing story.

I find this to be highly disappointing coming from a huge corporate company who has already has two successful titles to this big triple AAA game. The fact we wait so long just for you all to release a finished that doesn't run like a dog that has shit stuck on his ass. This is bogus, when we expect a finished game you all have a pre-order, pre-load knowing it runs like shit, when you can CLEARLY test the game yourselves. Gamers are tired of this bullshit, we aren't here for this sub par half ass releases. We just ask we get what we pay for. Hi-Fi Rush is a perfect example of a finished game, and by far ten times more effort than this ever received. A finished game with a $30 price tag not even $60 and it came out finished and blowing everyones expectations out of the water. NO ADVERTISEMENT, NO BULLSHIT, a finished game. 

It's about time it was said, I probably won't give a good review even when it is fixed, cause their is no excuse for a release like this in general. There wouldn't be a excuse in 2002 so why now. Just so you can "update" and fix it over time. This is a poor excuse. Don't even make it if you can't.

Do better Naughty Dog.

text:
I really like the last of us. It is one of my top fav games out there.
So getting this game on PC was like a dream, and now I have it....

... that's where the dissapointment comes in. If you want to buy this, after release, be sure to check your hardware!

Make sure you're not even close to the min specs and make sure you don't have any bottleneck configs in your systems.
Also be REALLY sure you want to keep this game! Why?

If you are like me, in between the min and rec specs of the game, you will get lagging, crashing, slow gameplay. 
Shaders need to be compiled which takes up between 30 to 2+ hours of time. Look at the discussion boards for this game.
According to steam I have been playing this game, "playing" = running, for 1,1 hours. Shaders have been compiled for 26%. 
During that compiling the game will get lags and give you messages like "Please wait...". 

I admit to have an older system, which still should work good enough according to the specs. But I noticed I have a bottleneck, which is my CPU. My GPU is hardly used while I am in a menu or waiting to be able to play for 5 minutes before I get the next "please wait" message.

So compiling the shaders will take up time that exceeds the refund period. If you're like me and want to keep the game anyway, you can go ahead. Otherwise I would advise not to buy or get a better system first. 
I play now on the lowest settings and this does nothing for the shaders, that is all CPU. 

I can not recommend this game based on the fact it is slow and needs a lot of time to do background tasks which make refund impossible if the game is not to your liking. 

Edit: 2,5 hour of gameplay, 37% shaders compiled.

text: The Last of Us Part 1 is a game that tries to be a movie, but fails at both. It is a boring, linear, and predictable story that forces you to play as a grumpy old man who has to escort a bratty teenage girl across a zombie-infested America. The gameplay is repetitive, the stealth is frustrating, and the combat is clunky. The graphics are decent, but the animations are stiff and the facial expressions are unnatural. The voice acting is overrated, the dialogue is cheesy, and the characters are unlikable. The game is full of clichés, plot holes, and moral dilemmas that are neither original nor meaningful. The game is not fun, it is not immersive, it is not emotional, it is not art. It is a waste of time and money. The Last of Us Part 1 is the last game you should ever play.

text:
I am editing this review to summarize my experience with the game. I initially wrote in anger this was the worst PC port I've ever seen. This is not really the case, but that does not mean the port is a good one either. 

I waited for almost 2.5 hours for the game to build shaders while crashing in the main menu every 5 or so mintutes - one of the most frustrating experiences I've had with a game. To clarify, if the game didn't crash every 5 mins while in the main menu, it would've taken half the time to build the shaders and actually start playing.

In general, my PC (even though fairly bad) is covering the minimum requirements and doesn't really have a lot of issues whatsoever running the game on mid to low settings. I never expected to play it on anything higher than that. 

The game actually runs decently. I expected a lot worse with my specs but mid preset + AMD FSR2 set on Quality is the most you can squeeze out of the game with this/similar hardware with it being playable and enjoyable. The only problems are the crashes on loading screens and the weird mouse movement (stutter-ish). Still, crashes at random times and at loading screens are pretty frustrating and for people with a lot higher specs than mine to be experiencing FPS drops and crashes is unacceptable. There is also a very annoying issue with audio crackling. Still would not recomment buying until it has been patched.

I am covering the minimum requirements but I am running a below average (for current gaming standarts) system:

GPU: Radeon RX 580 OC 8GB Dual Fan
CPU: AMD Ryzen 5 2600 6-Core 3.4GHz
RAM: 2x8GB 3200MHz

text:
I really wanted this to be good. And there are a lot of good things here, but the game is ruined by severe stuttering. Shouldn't be shader compilation stutter, so I'm guessing it has to do with asset streaming.

Pros:
- Beautiful game. Arguably one of the best looking games ATM. The original may be from 2013, but this remaster has pretty much redone the visuals from the ground up. Naughy Dog does lighting better than anyone else.
- Amazingly detailed graphics options menu, good job on that.
- Shader precompilation (it takes ages to complete, but it's good that they included it)
- Dual sense controller support (would be weird if it didn't have it, but still)

Cons:
- A lot of stutters. This is the big issue really. Standing in the same spot, in a small room, just rotating the camera will produce severe stutter, making the camera movement very unpleasant. It's not always a problem, but a lot of the time it's there, and really takes you out of the experience. I tried tweaking all of the settings, but it doesn't seem to make much difference.
- Very long load times. Haven't seen load times this bad for many years. Ever since SSDs became the norm, load times have pretty much become a non-issue. Not quite so here.
- Quite high CPU usage in many areas. May be related to the stutters.

If they can fix the stuttering, my review will immediately be changed to a Positive one.

RTX 3080
AMD Ryzen 9 5900X
32 GB RAM
2 TB SSD
